very good location from Shinjuku station. If you consider near Shinjuku station Hotel, Highly recommend this hotel. Very near from subway station and good quality and clean hotel. the bed is not that big size as other countries hotel. ( mine was double bed, look quite small.) except that other things was so great.

Very nice stay. The room was small but very nice. The bathroom (Oh those heated toilet seats) and shower area was great. The breakfast was adequate. We have had better but this one worked fine. The staff of the hotel and restaurant were fabulous and helpful. The location is great with numerous eating options, shopping and nearby metro. Don't let the "red light district" scare you.

Ok, the location is good but really too expensive and whatever you do, don't get the breakfast! Really expensive and not good at all. There is a mister donut around the corner which would have been cheaper and better for breakfast. The room was really small. But it was clean, very clean and had nice amenities like robes and slippers which were nice. I would not stay here again since it was really way too expensive.

We stayed here for our first trip to Japan, and found it was in a really good spot close to Shinjuku station. On the second day my partner was sick and not speaking any Japanese were struggling to find a pharmacy let alone ask for the right medicine. The staff at the reception desk spent a good 15 minutes writing out in Japanese what had happened and translated the medicine we were after and then pointed us in the direction of the pharmacy. It was such a great help and very appreciated and made it that much easier. The hotel room was clean and had generous bathrooms and the food at the Stella restaurant was also really good. Would recommend to anyone.

Shinjuku is definitely the place to stay! This hotel ticked all the boxes. Very clean and modern. Yes the rooms were small but functional. Good buffet breakfast with Japanese and Western choices. Helpful staff.

This hotel is situated in prime location of Tokyo where we can access to major department stores, Tokyo metro and JR easily by few minutes walk. Be careful when you browse around in the evening as the hotel is in red light disrtrict.

It' a good hotel. The room was clean but a bit small. The bathroom was really nice and complete of everything. Silent regardless being in the kabukicho center. The position was excellent, near metro, Starbucks and the station.I recommend this hotel.

The best location in Shinjuku, right in this incredible street with bars, restaurants and club. Staff is kind and efficient. Rooms are not large but confortable. The breakfast is not the best I have experienced, but choice is available. Great experience.

First of all I would like to write about the location. It is easily accessible and it is in the heart of Shinjuku. Shopping, Foods and entertainment centers are everywhere. There is a convenient store just next to the hotel. The hotel services was very good during our 5days 4 nights stay. Whenever you request things from the front desk. it will be sent to you in minutes. Very courteous, friendly, knowledgeable and can speak ENGLISH! We have two rooms and both are properly maintained. The only complaint that we had is the room was too small and the pillow is either too soft or too hard. Personally I will not suggest this hotel for family with young children as this is a Red Light District.

Hotel is about 10 mins walk from Shinjuku Station. Just need to exit via station's East Exit, or Lumine Est. As Citadines Central is within Shinjuku area, you don't have to worry about finding eateries nearby. There is a Lawson at L1 of Citadines, so it is convenient if you need a quick breakfast or late night snack. Rooms are relatively spacious for Tokyo's standard. There are sufficient space for 2 of us to chuck our few days worth of shopping bags aside, before we pack our luggage. Bottled water are provided daily, but we opt to boil water. Kettle provided is a little bit small though.Shopping places like Isetan, Bic Camera, Uniqlo and Muji are near to where we stay so we managed to squeeze abit of shopping before we return to the hotel for a good rest.

Very close to the Shinjuku train station & main tourist attractions. Really expensive for a very small room, however, we were in the heart of the city. Room was very modern. Beds were very comfortable. Enjoyed our stay.

Hotel is situated about 10-15mins away from either JRShinjuku or Metro Shinjuku-Sanchome Stations. It's located on the far right side within Kabukicho, which is not cluttered within the bar areas. You get privacy and peace from the bustling streets and nightclubs. A place I'd recommend if you want to experience what is it like to live within the red light district.

To be honest the room was not that great: very smallThe location though was brilliant!The staff fixed up a lot of issues I had with figuring out where to be picked up for day tours, I would not of had such a smooth trip without them. The level of service was outstanding

It was managed under the brand "Best Western" 3 years ago. After the handover to Citadines, I would say it offers better services. (1) I was asked for 30% of the room charge if I wanted to check out even one hour late. And now they seem more flexible if on the next day the occupancy rate is not that high. (2) Bottled water is provided every day but I experienced differently when BW managed it. The rooms have been well maintained. The bed and sofa are comfy and room big enough for you to open two pieces of luggage. You should have no complaint if you manage well your expectations on what a 3-star business hotel should offer.

The rooms were clean, well-designed and quite practical (good use of a relatively small space). Very comfortable beds. Fairly quiet for the size of the hotel and location (some outside noise from loud pedestrians at night, but nothing that caused me any issues). Check-in and check-out (stayed on two occasions) was efficient, and front desk staff were very helpful. Good location if you are looking to stay at the heart of Shinjuku, about 10 minutes walk from the station. No complaints, felt like good value and would stay again if we were looking to stay again in Shinjuku.
user_name:
Karim J
Dubai, United Arab Emirates

review_body: We really enjoyed our stay here. Two massive comfy beds, very well insulated walls (couldn't here any external noise even being just above golden gai). The room and the bathroom is huge, especially by Japanese hotel standards. The buffet breakfast every morning was great with so so many different choices, impossible not to be happy with the meal. The location was super convenient with an entrance to the train station about 4 min walk away, golden gai directly behind the hotel, and the robot restuarant 5 mins away.Wouldn't recommend staying here to families, you will see a couple of suited impossibly drunk business men stumbling around in the morning after spending all night in a bar. But that was more amusing then anything else.Don't be scared off by "red light district". This was the perfect spot, and as two females travelling alone we never had any concern at all.

Stayed for 6 nights, very near to train station exit B9 via Marounichi line. Front desk staff were all very helpful to our queries. Staff speak English hence communication is easy. Many good food around the vicinity. The restaurant on the second floor specialising in udon was great too. Lively night life in the vicinity, 5 to 8 minutes to Shinjuku. Many shopping department stores like isetan, takashimaya. A supermarket called 三番ストア, is nearby and you can buy Japanese products and necessity.

This hotel is in a perfect position for exploring Shinjuku & the rest of Tokyo. It was about 10 minutes walk from the station, but right next to the Golden Gai. Plenty of night life in all the areas around, but we did not hear any noise from this whilst in the hotel. We felt very safe in this area and did not see any trouble or problems. The room was quite small, but was very clean and the staff were very helpful. Be aware that many of the surrounding bars have a cover charge, so watch out when visiting. We did not realise this and ended up paying £33 for 3 beers one night because of this. There were plenty of bars that did not charge charge, so don't fall for the same as us and check the signs outside or ask if unsure. There are two shops below the hotel that sell food and drinks 24 hours a day if required. The hotel breakfast was also good and not a bad price with good variety. I would stay in this hotel again if I were to return to Shinjuku.

The hotel is situated in the heart of Shinjuku with many restaurants nearby. We were arriving from Thailand and had requested for early check in if room was available and they were able to offer it. The hotel is near to the subway and also it is very convenient to the bus station for Fujisan.

The hotel is unique due to its location in Shinjuku the wildest party area. The room was clean, Western style and adequate. The breakfast was more than expected with a limited number of both Western and Japanese items. The staff was very nice and helpful.The Sanjuku are has hundreds of small clubs featuring karaikoi, adult entertainment, and lots of alcohol. It not a place where one might casually stroll around at night unless you want to party, Why wind the area did appear to be safe for tourist.

The location is good, the hotel is good, there is a convenient store downstairs.During the stay house cleaning was done everyday. Consistently good.The location is a few blocks away from the main shinjuku station.
user_name:
allister y
Auckland Central, New Zealand

review_body: This hotel has everything you need - 5 minute walk from the East Exit of Shinjuku Station, close to restaurants and Lawsons Convenience store downstairs. Reception staff were extremely helpful and the buffet breakfast had a lot of variety. Rooms were typically small like all hotels in Tokyo but very functional and the added bonus of washing machines and dryers for guest use.

You can walk everywhere golden Gai, memory lane, Shinjuku station, downtown red light district etc Very small room as is most of central Tokyo but modern facilities, barely enough room for suitcasesHelpful staff plenty of great food and bars adjacent

Stayed at Citadines for 6 nights, two rooms (double bed and two singles) with 4 adults. The hotel is located on the border of Kabukicho, the red light district. Which i felt extremely safe and it was always very lively. Although our rooms faced the away from Kabukicho, we overlooked all the small bars scatted throughout.- The rooms were quite comfortable, with excellent bath and shower facilities. - TV had many quirky japanese tv shows and two english news channels. - The pillows were a little uncomfortable for myself as they are small Japanese styled bead pillows. - Although the hotel only had one elevator to get to the lobby and two to get to the rooms they could be a little slow.-Staff were extremely attentive and very helpful, especially via email prior to our arrival. - Locations was great and extremely close to all the shopping, clubs, bars and restaurants... no matter what direction was taken. Great stay and would recommend,

Love this hotel so much. Extremely close 5 mins walk to Isetan Department store, the rooms has lots of spaces, comparing to those tiny ones. The staff are friendly. Although it is in the so call red lights Kabukicho area, but its only about 50 steps away from the main street, which is acceptable.

It's a great hotel but not so much if you're a solo female traveller or with kids. The hotel is along a red light district and at night there is quite a bit of activity going on so gotta be careful when you're out after 10pm. Other than that, the location is great, near the train station and surrounded by so much shopping and food.

It was our first trip to Tokyo and with so many hotels and neighborhoods we decided on the Citadines Central in Shinjuku per the review and neighborhood recommendations from friends. We had a wonderful experience. The room was small, but we opted to save $ so they do have larger ones. For its size it was highly efficient, the bed was very comfortable and the bathroom was luxurious. The breakfast pleased both my daring self and my picky husband- A nice variety of foods to meet all tastes. The location is perfect. Easy walking distance to the Shinjuku station and you are located on a relatively quiet street in the heart of everything. Just behind the hotel is the "Golden Gai" which gives you a representation of what Tokyo looked like in the 60's. Great teeny tiny bars with eclectic signs & doors. Our check in was effortless, they have baggage storage and helped us to ship our bags ahead to our next destination so we didn't have to drag them on the trains. Best of all?? HONESTY~ We forgot to clear out the safe and to our horror left almost $300 USD in the safe along with a pair of glasses. We contacted them once we realized our mistake and they had every dollar and made arrangements for us to be reunited with our cash. You will not be disappointed, and all of the other guests seemed really pleased as well. I did not hear one complaint. We would definitely stay again!

Staff speaks good english and were very helpful in helping me make a reservation for a restaurant in Shibuya. Cleanliness is good because they change the linens everyday. It's just that the apartment interior needs more uplifting. Location is about 10-15 mins walk from the JR Shinjuku west exit. They also have the Lawson convenience store at Level 1 for you to get snacks etc. Overall good experience.

Had a problem booking on their website but this was resolved after I wrote in. The hotel even threw in free breakfast to convince us of their sincerity. Checkin was busy but smooth and rooms were clean and service good. Size and layout of room was efficient. It would be great if location was closer to subway. Luckily weather was good else cannot imagine how tiresome to lug luggage through crowded streets. On the other hand, it was easy to hail taxi from hotel ground floor.

This hotel is so conveniently located at the heart of Shinjuku. Just 5 minutes walk from JR East exit at Shinjuku, it's so near to everything... Takashimaya, nearby department stores and loads of restaurants. Also convenient that there's a 24 hour Lawson that's just downstairs. Room is pretty basic and very small especially if you have large suitcases, but very clean (as expected from Japanese standards). The location is the main selling point for me and overall if we come back to Tokyo, we most likely will stay here again due to the fantastic location allowing us to explore shops in ShinjukuThe only downside is the English competency skill of the receptionists, but overall this did not spoil our stay. Also, I seem to think that the advertisement on booking.com shows it has a gym but clearly it doesn't so was a bit unimpressed by that
user_name:
Christy Jesse L
London, United Kingdom

review_body: I'm truly awed by the wonderful professional services by Citadines' personnel. First, they helped me to source for reliable transport company to Lake Kawaguchiko and booked me transport to Narita Airport before my actual stay in hotel. Upon arrival at front desk on 6 June, the service personnel was serving me with smile and eagerness though I had several requests. Never did she show a sign of hurrying me but patiently making sure all my doubts were answered. She helped me to make 2 transport conformation in Tokyo (Forest Bus and Deevo) and even helped called me to call Okinawa to confirm my Day Tour packages which I was anxious about. Her excellent service attitude really put me at ease and made my stay in Tokyo such a delightful one. Of course, not missing out to mention that the accommodation was pleasant as the rooms are spacious and clean. Highly recommended stay.

The hotel is very convenient for shopping and visiting other scenic spots. The staff is nice and professional. The room is clean and neat. And there are convenient stores and restaurants nearby. The stay is a nice experience.

Bigger rooms than expected, given the location. Still not huge, however a decent enough size for a multiple night stay.Breakfast was always super busy, so its worth going at a time to avoid the peak hour rush.Only a short walk to the closest train and subway stations - 10 minutes if you are a slow walker.Be careful to get the right Citadines, a there are 2. Our taxi driver took us to the wrong one initially.

Whilst the location is about 10 - 15mins walk from the South exit from the Shinjuku station, the area is rather dubious. So, if you do not want to be solicited - almost on a daily basis - by pimps "selling" their "wares", then you might want to find some place else to stay at. However, that said, you can always simply choose to ignore them completely. The hotel is generally safe, easily accessible and the location is almost perfect - lots of eating places around! The service staff is most helpful and the rooms are decent (this is Tokyo after all!) and spacious enough. It is definitely a value-for-money.

So well located, just 5 mins from Shinjuku station. Would highly recommend. Lobby is on 3rd floor so you need to look carefully for the sign at street level. Located above a Lawson convenience store. The Mr Donut on the corner as you walk from Shinjuku station is a good land mark to find the street. Check out Lumine Est located in building above Shinjuku station (accessible via lifts) Many wonderful eateries and shops.

Hotel is really nice, but noise insulation is too poor regarding environment : location is noisy due to animations around in Shinjuku, with police, ambulance and so on... I was woken up twice every night by sirens and horns, very long and loud. And it has nothing to do with jetlag.

Our first visit to Tokyo/Japan and the hotel was very conveniently located close to station, shops and Golden Gai. Requested triple room & double room for our family of 5 and rooms were clean and roomy enough for all of us.Would stay again if we're in the area as we found the location was really convenient to the JR station and make use of the underground walkways as its so much faster & warmer than street level

Standard rooms are a good size, the location is great: central (within walking distance of several tube lines and the huge hub of Shinjuku station) but quiet. You don't really see the red light district aspect (a few guys doing security outside a couple of buildings in the evenings but you wouldn't blink if you didn't have more knowledge about the area and guess what's going on). Clean, comfortable, front staff is accommodating. Good value for money compared to others in the area. We didn't try the breakfast.

We found this a good location if you want to base yourself in Shinjuku. Room was big enough . Staff were helpful and friendly. Being the so called red light district ss still safe to walk around at night . Golden Gai right at your back door step . I would recommend this hotel.

love this hotel very much. this hotel is not luxurious hotel, but nice'n cozy. location of hotel is just right for anyone who wants to stay a night around Shinjuku area with a reasonable price. less than 10 minutes walk from JR line station, near "Kabuki cho" area. You will see a lot of bars and restaurants onthe way to hotel including "Golden Gai", famous area for night out.

We enjoyed our stay here. The staff were friendly and helpful. The room was small by European standards but large by Japanese standards. There was a Lawsons downstairs for food. No problems with being in the red light district.

We stayed here for the first leg of our trip in Tokyo, for six nights. We splurged a bit and got an "Executive" level room, and I think it was worth doing. We were on the 14th floor, and the room was spacious enough! It was definitely still tight, but that is just always going to be the case in Tokyo.We had two twin sized beds that were pushed together. There is a closet with a mini fridge (and two waters refreshed daily), and a small cabinet next to the bed housing a kettle with some coffee and tea options. The beds are quite firm, but softer than most Japanese hotel beds, and the duvets are quite soft. We had a small table with two chairs, and the chairs ended up housing our luggage, which were both carry-on sized bags. You might have a harder time with bigger bags.The bathroom was AMAZING. The shower room had a spacious tub with a window overlooking Kabukicho. The water pressure was fantastic. The hotel had two choices of shampoo, conditioner, and body wash. The toilet is, like many places in Japan, very comprehensive. I am back home now and long for that bathroom...The room is air conditioned, though the lowest setting is 20 degrees which is supposed to translate to 68 Fahrenheit, but it just isn't. It's much warmer. If you need a room to be pretty cold for a comfortable sleep, this might not do it for you. They only give you one key (which controls the electricity for the room) but the air conditioning does seem to stay on for the day when you leave, which is a nice change from other rooms we've had in Asia and Europe. It sucks to get back from a hike and still be sweating in your room for a while! The hotel location is great. It's right on the edge of Kabukicho, and while I think everywhere we went in Japan is super safe, if you're leery of Kabukicho but want to be near Shinjuku, I think this gives you the best of both worlds. It's much closer to the train station than the other Citadines, and there's a Maranouchi Line stop that is just one block away. Otherwise, it's about a 5 (7 with luggage) minute walk to the main station. As other reviewers have mentioned, Golden Gai is spitting distance away. We were able to do laundry on the 7th floor (soap is automatic in the washing machine, in case you need to do some laundry yourself!) and I was able to enjoy the massage chairs and free coffee vending on the 13th floor while I waited for my laundry. The 13th floor is only accessible to the "executive" floor levels via key card, which is obnoxious, but I guess that and the extra space in the room made it worth it. The front desk was very helpful in making reservations for us for lunch and dinner, and held onto our luggage for a couple of hours our last day there. If I were returning to Tokyo, I think I would absolutely stay here again!

Stayed for 4 nights whilst on holiday in Tokyo. Overall Value: Excellent!! Highly recommend this one if in TokyoRoom: extremely clean, comfortable and relatively large for a Tokyo hotel. Hotel may have been recently refurbished as it didn't have the dated feel. Bathroom: very small overall, shower tub. Shower had very good water pressure. Toiletries of a high quality (from Shiseido).Service: friendly and efficientLocation: very centrally located and walking distance from train station. Golden Gai next to hotel. Several department stores and Piss Alley a short walk away. Hotel is at / near the red light district but does not feel unsafe or seedy at all. However, a consideration if travelling with young children. Views: surrounding buildings or Golden GaiFacilities/ breakfast: decent free wifi. Breakfast included.

We stayed there for 4 nights and found it to be very good. Coming from a hotel in Osaka where we had quite a large room I must admit the room we had at Citadines was tiny.But having said that we couldn't fault the standards of cleanliness and customer service.If coming from Shinjuku station I would recommend catching a taxi to Citadines because if you are a first timer in Tokyo you may find it hard to find, but once you have spent a day or so in Tokyo it will all look easy for you. Take the East Exit coming out of Shinjuku station follow it all the way out and you will see the taxi rank on the right around the corner. Just beware there are stairs you will need to tackle with luggage on the way out. When we wanted to eat dinner in we would walk a short walk to the Isetan department store and head to the basement floor where you will have a choice of all sorts of delicious food to take it back with you and enjoy in your room. Don't forget to have some dessert from Mister Donut on the corner (can't miss it)Ang

Right in the thick of things, friendly and efficient. Yes it's tight, but then most things in Tokyo are. Close to the station and all that you'd need for the best bit of Tokyo. For two of us with handle luggage only, there was enough room but bulky luggage might make things very squeezy. Well kept and clean, tastefully decorated but would have loved to open a window.In the heart of bars and nightclubs and a few 'boys clubs' which makes it lively at street level but never with a sense of danger.

I stayed here before in October 2014, at that time it was known as a Best Western hotel. I decided to stay here for a 2nd time! We stayed the 14th floor (top floor) in a studio twin room. Apparently I booked this at Expedia, I just thought it would be a room with 2 beds nothing special. It had a separate seating area and a very large bathroom with separate toilet. The breakfast is included and there is free WIFI in the room! Close to Shinjuku station, just a 5 minute walk. They only serve breakfast and lunch at the hotel, but there are enough dinner options in the vicinity of the hotel. Friendly staff, clean rooms and nice decor.

The hotel is all about location. Very centrally located three blocks from the huge Shinjuku station. It is absolutely immaculate with sparkling clean bathrooms and floors. If you are looking to have more room...upgrade to the executive floor! We had a lovely room on the 14th floor. It was more than big enough for two people and had a wonderful bathroom. The hotel is on a block with a few massage parlors but we were not bothered at all. There is a very good pizzeria down the block and a Mister Donut on the corner. The department store Muji is across the street and it has a fantastic cafeteria if you are looking for reasonably priced food. It was very easy to find the hotel from the train station as well as from the Airport Bus. (Five long blocks)The breakfast was sufficient enough, but could have offered a greater selection of fresh fruit. The choices became a bit boring after a few days but there was always a variety of Japanese and Western style dishes. All in all, a great stay at an immaculate & centrally located hotel.

Like most hotel rooms in Japan, rooms are a bit small, but very well laid-out and practical. The only thing missing was a wardrobe and a space to store away luggage so they don't get in your way. Selection of English language television channels is very limited, so unless you wish to avail of the PPV (pay per view), there's not much to watch on TV (in English). The bed was comfortable, plus bath linen and amenities were of high quality.In terms of location, it's basically where Golden Gai meets Kabukicho, so it is in rather lively environs : a few touts hanging around later at night but they're not really a cause for concern (the African ones can be more aggressive/persistent). The bustling Shinjuku Station is just a few minutes walk away, so you can't get more central than that.Service was fair - not overly warm or friendly, but efficient enough (although I did report twice about a blown light-bulb in my room, but it wasn't replaced even until I checked-out 3 days later).The Reception is effectively 2 floors up from ground level - so there may be an initial struggle with luggage upon arrival and departure, since there is no bell service to assist.Overall, happy with the choice of hotel I made for my stay in Tokyo.

Recommended by friend who said Citadines is good for family. There are 2 Citadines in Tokyo, and I picked this newer one.The entrance was hard to find as you need to take the elevator up from the street level. Staff good, hotel clean and location is excellent but next to the part of Shinjuku that has all drinking, girlie bars, people handing out flyers for good deals on restaurants and bars. The street itself is really nice; but after 6pm, it seems to transform into a seedier kind of nightspot. You do not see kids here at all. Having said this, it's Japan - probably one of the safest places in the world. People abide by rules (there are no jaywalkers) and you do NOT need to worry about security.Location-wise, only 5 mins to the main shopping street with Isetan, Muji, etc... And also 5 mins. to the metro. Around 15 mins. to the business side of Shinjuku.Note: You pay upfront when you check in at the hotel.Our floor had a 'common' area with large conference table and chairs, 2 massage chairs, free coffee machine.

Stayed in Tokyo for 3 days. Was unable to book this hotel in our 1st leg of 2 days but definitely happy that we could book it on our last leg of our stay. Stayed in this hotel for 1 night. Our overall impression for this hotel was great experience. Room size is reasonable spacious for Asian. Room was clean. Receptionists were helpful and patience is answering to our enquiries. Location is central and walking distance to Shinjuku main station.

Citadines Shinjuku is a great place to stay if you want to be quite near to Shinjuku without having to experience its madness as soon as you step out your door. The reception staff are helpful and polite, and speak excellent English. The room itself is extremely functional with a fairly well-equipped kitchenette. when you leave the hotel, turn left and there's a 7-11 where you can stock up on the basics. At the 7-11 itself turn left again and walk down the little lane for a whole bunch of reasonably priced restaurant options. The hotel is a 10-minute walk to Shinjuku Gardens, which is well worth a visit. The main shopping area itself is about a 20+ minute or you can take the metro.

We had a marvelous experience at this hotel. We had written ahead requesting help making reservations, which they did perfectly. Our room was small but comfy and breakfast was delicious. It is so convenient to many lines on the Tokyo subway. Would definitely return. Thank you so much!
user_name:
Sarotchka
Croton on Hudson, New York

review_body: we stayed here for our honeymoon a couple of weeks ago. It was an excellent hotel in the heart of things, minutes walk from Shinjuku train station, multiple shops, bars, restaurants, malls and department stores, you can spend evenings pleasantly wandering around the immediate vicinity there are hundreds of shops open til late and some cinemas too. The breakfast buffet had everything you could need, croissants, toasts, jams, juices, eggs, bacon, curry, cereals, fruit, yogurt, noodles, vegetables enough to set you up for a days exploring Shinjuku. The room was cleaned daily, had tea and coffee/kettle, fridge, robes and slippers and downsatirs is a Lawsons mini market if you need anything else, came in majorly handy for buying fresh milk for our rooms tea and coffee and chocolate fixes. There are a couple of washers and driers on the 7th floor which I didn't think we'd use but made things so much easier and we didn't have to unpack a pile of dirty washing when we got home. The cost was 500 yen in total for wash and drier (about £3.40). The bathroom was great too with a fabulously deep bath and super powerful shower. Our room looked onto Golden Gai and we could see the Tokyo Skytree in the distance. The hotel is situated in Kabuchiko which technically is the red light district but to be honest it was all very discreet and not in-your-face so you wouldn't really know. There is a donut shop on the corner of the hotels street Mister Donut which was nice with fresh coffee if you fancied a change for breakfast, there's also a sit in or take out pizza place on the street too, if you're tired and just want to take something back to your room. I'd thoroughly recommend this hotel, the location was perfect, with everything you could need nearby, overlooks a shrine too.

This hotel is located in the heart of Shinjuku and mere steps away from the Golden Gai District. The rooms were good sized, the beds were comfy and they have a great bathroom. The staff was very helpful and extremely nice. However, what truly makes this a great hotel is its location. The Golden Gai couldn't be more than 40 feet from the hotel, which is awesome. Saves a lot of money on taxi or metro fares when you can walk back to your hotel after a few round at the Golden Gai. Being in the heart of Shinjuku is also nice, because there is a large number of shops and restaurants all within walking distance, so I would definitely recommend this hotel to anyone staying in Tokyo.

Convenient location - only 10 minutes walk from JR shinjuku station. Lawson convenient store is just located on the ground floor.Room was small but expected for Tokyo. Bathroom was almost as big as the room with a small bath tub - a nice bonus! Note that there is a Hotel Citadine shinjuku (serviced apartments) further away from the station - make sure the taxi driver takes you to the right hotel.Stayed in Deluxe double room in April 2016.

Just checked in and the room is clean and modern. Small super market on first floor and so many shopping and restaurants around, it's ideal place to stay in Tokyo. .....plan to visit the park and shopping tomorrow.....the front desk has good English speaking staffs who can help with choosing the restaurant or any information you would need.

Booking: We made a booking online two weeks before our visit. The booking process was smooth, the staff at the reservation desk could speak english so the entire check in process was a breeze.Travel: Citadines Central is approximately a 5 minute walk from Shinjuku Metro Station. It is extremely convenient to get there and the location is quite amazing considering the entire street is awake till the wee hours of the morning.Hotel: The Hotel was decent with plenty of dining and entertainment options around. The rooms are small, but quite spacious for Japan standards, comfortable nonetheless. All the floors had vending machines incase you need a midnight snack.The reception area had plenty of tourist books, maps, travel guides to help you move around in Japan. There is free wifi at the hotel. Everything about the hotel was just about comfortable.

The location is perfect. In the middle of everything. Restaurants everywhere, busy street and great people watching but quiet in your rooms. Decent sized rooms. Washing facilities which is great and free wifi. Will stay again when staying in Tokyo. Only 5-10min walk from subway depending on how busy foot traffic is. Convenience store below and good restaurant just under hotel.

Quick trip to Tokyo to see Eric Clapton and this hotel was recommended in Shinjuku to provide easy access to public transport, shopping and other places of interest (Harajuku, Yoyogi Park, iSetan, Ginza) - the hotel staff are great, the rooms are 'cozy' but very serviceable and sleep quality is great :) Hotel overall might be seen as a little 'tired' but overall, good value!

We've stayed here several times over multiple visits to Tokyo in the last decade, and this is a dependable place. It was formerly called the Best Western Astina Shinjuku, in case you're looking at old reviews or resources.A short walk to multiple transit options, tons of nearby shopping and food, and a stocked convenience store on the ground level too.The only negative: the area and main street feature a few touts after dinner trying to get you to come spend money in their bars - I recommend taking the garden path behind the hotel to dodge them (and it's a lovely little pathway anyway!)

We stayed at the Citadines in Shinjuku for 4 nights. We made sure we asked for a non smoking room on a high floor. The staff at the hotel were really friendly and helpful and spoke reasonable English. The room was on the small side but was very clean and the bed was comfortable. The bathroom was great and the shower had fantastic water pressure. The complimentary breakfast had lots of different options and was an added bonus. The location of the hotel is excellent, and once you have mastered the right exit from the station, it is a quick walk from the station. Would stay here again.

This hotel we had low expectations, in the red light district. But we loved it! Japan is so safe and is not seedy. Its like everyone just has their jobs and regardless its just another busy area. Location is great for food, culture, big neon lights and shopping. Shinjuku station is about an 8 min walk but at the end we noticed the subways very close by. Still walk there. Recommend a taxi going from Shinjuku station to the hotel as first time you can get lost. Returning just walk but be prepared for suitcases going down stairs. We didn't mind as it was only one level for the subway then fine. Food choices are plenty even for tourists not wanting to stray too much and entertainment around the corner. Room was smallish (18sq) but so comfortable. Bathroom clean and shower great. We got quite comfortable here. Highly recommended and price great!

The Citadines Central Shinjuku is right in the heart of Tokyo's Shinjuku district, one of the busiest and most exciting parts of the city. The Shinjuku train station is a short walk from the hotel, as is the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building. There are also countless bars, restaurants and all manner of other amusements right at your doorstep - including the famous Golden Gai bar area.The hotel itself was very nice, the staff all spoke good English and provided the highest level of service throughout the two week stay. The room for two was surprisingly spacious by Japanese standards although still a little on the small side, with comfy beds, a plasma TV and a window overlooking the busy streets below - A higher floor of the building might be preferable as the night life can get noisy.Breakfast was free every morning and served from 7:00-10:30am, with a buffet providing Japanese food and more Western options. Each floor has a vending machine providing all manner of drinks (some alcoholic) and there are laundry facilities on the 7th floor. The maids clean the rooms every day, we discovered during our day that hanging a "please clean our room" sign on the door ensured that our room was cleaned earlier than it would be otherwise - a useful thing to remember if you're expecting to be back in your hotel room by the late morning or the early afternoon.One thing to note about the hotel is its close proximity to the Kabukicho area of Shinjuku. We felt completely safe while walking through this area but it is a red light district and some of the seedier streets may not be suitable for families with children or women travelling alone or in small groups.One con is that the hotel is easy to miss if you're not looking for it, it is nestled in between some tall buildings without obvious signage. This isn't a problem if you travel to the hotel by taxi but if you're arriving on foot (via the train, for example), you could easily walk past without realising. An escalator and elevator lead to the lobby, which is unconventionally on the third floor of the building.

Friendly check-in; very helpful staff; room on the small side, but well equipped and clean; very good breakfast selection in a bright, airy restaurant area; very well situated for the hustle and bustle off Shinjuku, but still managed to be quiet in the room (we were on the 12th floor); easy access to JR Shinjuku and various subway lines. Thank you for a pleasant overnight stay.

This hotel is in a great location…near shopping, Golden Gai, and a lot of spots for eating and night life. The rooms were clean, and everything went smoothly with our stay. The rooms are small, and we were a little cramped in the what seemed like a pretty small bed, but the experience of the neighborhood was great! If I was going back to Tokyo, this is the neighborhood to be in!

On arrival we were not that impressed having to get our luggage up escalators and stepsThe elevator is not easily seen. The staff are very friendly and helpful and do speak English.We had 2 apartments which yes are small but big enough for 1 person. Would be very crowded for 2. Very clean and they have used the small space well. Rooms services daily. It is a 15min walk to Shenjuku station - Plenty street eating places - food was good Few "restaurants" around but mainly quick eatsFor elderly this is not a good location as need to do a lot of walking to get to station and surrounds. Breakfast is good. Caters for different nationalities. Only down side it is not on the pick up list for many tours. You have to get yourself to starting point and own way back . I think would be in their interest to arrange for this. These days it is an expectationBut otherwise a good experience.

Got the deluxe twin which was listed at 24sqm. Shocked when saw how cramped & oddly shaped room was. Thin walls & can hear baby crying next door, and family talking. Other guests left bags/prams outside room in corridor, can't blame them.Room abt 10min brisk walk from Shinjuku JR East Exit, best to take cab if luggages bulky as streets very busy and crowded. If need to walk to West Exit, where day trip buses and airport coaches are, it's a 16mins brisk walk. Red light district, this Kabukicho area, and bouncers will only solicit if you look their way, else generally safe (though noisy surroundings due to bustling trade surrounding hotel). Plenty of food & bars nearby, plus a big convenience store at level 1 of hotel building.Only saving grace was the excellent service from the front desk to the restaurant wait staff, most generally very polite, helpful + speak decent English. Breakfast choice was pretty decent though same throughout 4nights stay.Suggest you book the other Citadines Shinjuku, (with yellow & blue fascade), had kitchenette and bigger living space at 29sq metres, at my last stay in Nov'14. Much further from JR Shinjuku station (Shinjuku-san-chome station/Tokyo Metro line), but the room layout really makes a world of a difference, and you won't feel cramped and flustered.

Loved the location of the hotel. It is closed to all Shinjuku train stations. The room is small but that is the standard in Tokyo. Wifi worked perfectly and most staffs were helpful. The washroom is well equipped and it's roomy comparing to the room. There is a free vending machine on the 13th floor (need your card/fob to get there). Its hot beverages are really hot so use your ceramic cups in the room to carry those paper cups would be wise. The only thing I dislike was the escalators to the lobby. They switch them from going up and down in different hours so sometimes you have to take the elevator to get down. Still, it's not a biggie. Would definitely recommend this hotel to others and would come back when we visit Tokyo again.

This is a good hotel overall — I was not so happy with the cleanness of the hotel, specially by Japanese standards. The carpet in our room was really dirty and because the room is considerably small the dirtiness felt a little bit in your face — The breakfast was OK, however, I didn't find the options worth the money. The staff was very nice and professional, they kept our luggage for a few hours because we had a late night flight.

Great hotel stayed there for 8 nights which is a pretty long time if your hotel is horrible. Luckily ours was lovely enjoyed our stay breakfast was delicious would recommend. Stay in a larger room even if it's more expensive very close to everything!

This hotel is well located, about 10 minutes walk from Shijuku station. The rooms are small but clean and well appointed. The double bed was small for 2 people. A bit of noise from people partying on the street in the early hours, but that's Shinjuku.Nothing special about this hotel but a good base for sightseeing and close to the bright lights of Shinjuku.

We thoroughly enjoyed our stay at Citadines. The location was great, the staff were friendly and helpful, the breakfast was delicious and the rooms were comfortable and well furnished. I'll definitely be staying there again on my next visit.
user_name:
Gary M
Chapel Hill, North Carolina

review_body: If you like to enjoy the lively nightlife in one of the most dynamic area of Tokyo, this hotel is perfectly located for you. It's only 5 minutes walk from the Shinjuku station (take exit East, and head towards Kabukicho direction). Within walking distance, there are tons of restaurants, bars, nightlife activities. Room has a decent size and is spotlessly clean. 2 complementary bottles of water renewed every day is very much appreciated. Bathroom/toilets have all the needed amenities. The air conditioning and the heating work perfectly well : you can easily and precisely adjust to the temperature that you want. Free WIFI works well (good enough to watch youtube online for example)We had also the chance to use the self-service washing machine (300 Yens / load) and drying machine (100 Yens / 30 minutes which is definitely not enough : to fully dry your clothes, you might need to run the dryer machine for 2 hours). The staff speaks pretty good English and are very helpful. The price is also reasonable. All in all, the 5 points rating we gave to this hotel are justified by the fact that we were fully 100% satisfied, since it fulfilled all our expectations. We would surely consider staying here again if we have the chance to visit Tokyo in the future. We definitely recommend it.

Great comfortable stay in Tokyo. We stayed here in a comfortable room. We liked the location. I was worried about the location with some of the reviews saying it was in a red light district but we had no issues. There was some girlie style bars nearby but they are all over Tokyo so unavoidable. We were never pestered and I would have felt safe walking around this area on my own at night.Our room was an ok size. Big enough to manage our luggage. We loved the deep Japanese bath which was great for relaxing your legs after exploring all day. Breakfast was good with a wide selection to choose from. The service was excellent too. I would recommend that you have a portable wifi device delivered to the hotel to explore Tokyo. This made our trip as we could Google map everywhere we wanted to go.

The hotel is about 40 minutes taxi ride from Haneda International Airport. It is at the heart of the downtown Shinjuku where the night clubs are. It is surrounded by a lot of good restaurants 24 hours a day and not far from a train station. The room is smaller than any American hotel, but I believe that size is typical in Japan. But they kept rooms clean and smelling fresh. No need to worry about leaving your tooth brush bec they have them in the rooms. The staff are courteous and helpful.

Generally, a good hotel to stay in as it's greatly assessibility to eateries, shopping and train stations in Shinjuku. Thou required a minimum of 10mins walk to stations, its a good exercise after meal. The room size r quite reasonable and clean. The hotel services fits all our requests and we have a great day at your hotel. The doubt side is that as a Silver Accor member but we could not seem to get a complimentary upgrade of room and card points accumulation.

Odd area right next to the red light district. However helpful staff, beutifal rooms with comfy beds and a very nice bathroom. I would recommend this place...convenient location as well. Only a 5 minute walk to major shops and toursit locations.

My wife and I stayed 5 nights in this hotel. Upon arrival we were shocked at how pathetically small the room was. This is Tokyo and we were aware rooms might be small but this was prison cell like and (based on a similar experience in Hong Kong once before with a different hotel chain) we quickly decided that it would be really depressing to stay in that room. The staff were very accommodating at finding us a more suitable room and we looked at a few. Most were just too small to be comfortable and/or stank of cigarette smoke - they were nominally non-smoking rooms but clearly the policy isn't enforced. We ended up with one of the rooms on the executive floor, which was quite large and comfortable. There was some smell of smoke, but it was manageable and we were out of options. Despite not being impressed with the rooms, I was impressed by the attitude of the staff. They were trying very hard to help and although they had to charge us to upgrade, they did this at well below list rates (we had initially paid around £100 a night and had to pay another £30 per night, but it was well worth it).After that our stay was largely uneventful. Breakfast was good, although one morning we had to wait to get into the dining room since there aren't enough tables at real peak time. Wifi was good. Location is great - Shinjuku is a wonderful place to stay with real atmosphere. Maybe some would consider it a little rough around the edges but it's all incredibly tame compared to anywhere you'd apply that sort of description to in Europe or the US.Overall we were satisfied. It ended up costing more than we would expect in most parts of the world for the quality you get, but conversely I think it cost less than the equivalent might generally cost in Tokyo.

Whilst the rooms are not huge by Australian standards, they are quite suitable for two people to bed down. The beds and pillows are comfy, the bathroom well equipped with toiletries, robes and slippers provided. The front desk staff are very helpful and go out of their way to give good guidance on how to get from A to B. There's an authentic Japanese restaurant below the hotel and on the ground floor a mini-mart.

The hotel is located smack bang in the middle of Shinjuku and is close to the Shinjuku and Shinjuku-anyone subway stations. Take exit B9 and turn left, and cross the main road. It should be 50m down past Mister Donut corner store.Room was small as expected, but comfortable enough for a couple. There's a laundry on the 7th floor. We stayed in the 6th floor facing away from the main street.Shinjuku is a massive area so you'll enjoy the many variety of shops and eateries. Just make sure you have your GPS or map handy, as it can be very daunting to find your way around without either.Very good hotel and will be back.

Stayed here for three nights in Feb 2016. The location is right in the heart of the Kabukicho night-life area and perfect if you want to see the brightly lit-up streets at night. As others have reported it is a 10 minute walk from Shinjuku Station (south and south-east exits). I specified a non-smoking room. What I got was on the 11th floor. It was smallish, clean, quiet and comfortable. Toiletries, towels etc provided by hotel along with slippers. Internet access was OK, not particularly fast but OK for reading emails and such.There is buffet breakfast which catered for western tastes as well as serving traditional Japanese breakfast fare. There is a Lawson's convenience store located on the ground floor (the hotel reception is actually on the second floor).Would I stay there again - Yes.

Me and my wife stayed here during our first days of honeymoon. We needed a place where to sleep only so this hotel was great for us. Standard room (I'd say tiny) but essential for people who get up early to walk through the city and only come back for sleeping.

We spent 7 nights in the Citadines Central in Shinjuku. The hotel is a 7 minute walk from the East entrance of Shinjuku train/metro which makes it an ideal base for visiting other parts of the city, and perfect for the Narita Express airport train. The hotel itself was fairly easy to find- just look out for the Mr Donut sign at the top of the street. The staff were very approachable, and spoke good English. They had a few print-out maps when I asked about getting to certain locations in the city, and had tips about which metro lines/stations to use. Breakfast was good...a real mixture of options in a buffet style- from fruit/toast to pickled veg and beef curry! The room had a good sized bathroom, with a modern shower. Fully equipped with kettle, fridge, and TV. You can also borrow plug adapters from reception for a small charge. Our room overlooked the Golden Gai which consists of hundreds of 4-5 man bars...well worth a visit- but you wouldn't know without looking outside as the hotel is very quiet and relaxing. On a night there are a few 'touts' on the way to the hotel- but they're easily avoidable, and fine with a "no thankyou" response. Great hotel though, and a brilliant location.

I really enjoyed my stay here. The hotel itself is very clean, and centrally located to the bars and clubs. the room was tiny, but that is all over Tokyo. The Bathroom was big and had a walk in shower with a tub in there. The front desk is great, and I had no issues communicating. The subway is a little tricky here, as I got lost several times. But that is my fault. It is a 7 Minute walk, to there if you don't get lost.

I booked on line and was a little sceptical, but inside was lovely, my room was quite big, I had a perfect view of the town and street .. Beautiful big bathroom. Staff were lovely and very helpful, however they didn't seem to speak English but there were plenty of maps and brochures of what to do and see, perfect location if you want to be right in the middle of the night life . I definitely recommend to stay here.

Fair enough for the price, the location is perfect. Close to the downtown and all the main station. Breakfast and room clean and good, front desk are helpful and speak English well .. A little bit noisy at night  Had no trouble to reach it from the airport
user_name:
Reem M
Dubai, United Arab Emirates

review_body: We stayed here for 4-5 nights in mid-February and found the room very comfortable, service friendly and the hotel was in a good location.With the Golden Gai's less than 2 minutes walk, Robot Restaurant within 10 minutes and Shinjuku Station within 15 minutes we found this location affordable and centralized. Breakfast was average, but we found it difficult to find an affordable hotel in the area with breakfast.

Right is the heart of Kabukicho.Nightlife is just a street away.Shinjuku station is 10mins walk.Lot of eateries around.Shop at DonQi Ote which is at the junction 1 street away. You get everything there. Shinjuku connects to all parts of Tokyo.Worth staying here.Rooms are clean. There is a supplies store at the ground floor.Staff is helpful.

Stayed 3 nights in Premier Twin and Executive Double. At around 28sqm each, these rooms were roomier than what we've had at Daiwa Roynet and Richmond hotels. I quite like the layout of these rooms. Premier Twin had 2 twin beds (each 120cm) and less space for suitcases. Executive Double had a 140cm bed but we could lay out 2 suitcases and 1 duffle bag. Bathrooms in both rooms are very spacious and well designed. Room was a nice size and I love that there is enough lighting. Free wifi is fast.Staff was excellent. I made booking by calling on the phone since I really needed to have 2 rooms next to each other (travelling with 2 kids). Ms. Satomi spoke English very well and was so competent and helpful. I will say, all staff here spoke English well. Computer and printer in the lobby very useful.....I printed Disney tickets the night before we went to Disney. Free chocolate in the lobby welcome by the kids.Location quite handy. Very close to Isetan Department Store. Not super close to the Shinjuku station. But in the thick of things. That includes the red light district. You must decide if you are comfortable being very close to the red light district.Had a good stay here. Would definitely recommend if you don't mind being close to the red light district.

I also chose this hotel because of the reviews here on tripadvisor. Here is my review:The good:1. outstanding communication and help online - I had questions to ask them, especially on how to get to the hotel and the staff was very prompt, corteous, and gave very helpful answers to my queries2. Location - Near Shinjuki East, and if you want to buy some things, there is a Muji, a big BIC Camera, Don quijote, shoeps selling pre-owned luxury bags and watches, and a big Uniqlo nearby3. The room - yes it is small but it felt like a 4 star hotel that shrunk. There was a bathtub, quality bottled soap, shampoo and conditioner, complimentary bottled water replenished every day, TV with CNN and Discovery for English channels, and a safe4. Breakfast - we had to leave early twice, and you can exchange the coupon for 500 yen worth of items in Lawson right at the bottom of the hotel5. Staff - Very helpful, good English.others - good strong wifi, I was able to do laundry, and the vendo machines are helpful for a late night beer. A desktop computer with printer was available for guests. they provided an air refreshener spray in the closet, and a shoe horn and brushFor improvement - not much. I havent stayed in a 5 star hotel or any other hotel in Tokyo so I cant compare room sizes. But it was difficult to place big luggage. If I go back to Tokyo this would be a great place to stay.

First pro tip. If you get off the shinkansen and then local train at Shinjuku and your girlfriend finds the hotel on Google Maps, make sure she's searched for "Citadines Central Shinjuku" otherwise you'll have lugged both of your ski gear way further than actually required. There is another Citadines close-by which is not the "Central" Citadines. Anyway, once you're at the correct one you'll find it's in a super convenient part of town. Last year we stayed on the western side of the train station near the Government Building but we both much preferred this side of town. For me there were all of the Disk Union stores and for the partner there was tonnes of fashion stores. The other side is the electronics district. The street you find yourself on seems to be home to a lot of "massage" parlours. I'm not sure if that should be in inverted commas or not but it didn't seem very legit just judging by the photos. It was fine though, and I think the area is still fine for families as well. Of a night time there were club staff trying to coax people in but they were mostly targeting groups of guys and we were only spoken to once. As for the rooms themselves, they're miniature. We were on the twelfth floor. The first of the floors which needed a swipe card to access so I'm not sure if it's different below that as I think the top few floors were judged, "business floors". If you just had carry on it'd be fine but with a ski bag and another 120L bag it was tight as you'll see in the pics. Apart from that the room was really clean. The bed was comfortable and there were two different levels of hardness in the pillows. Nice touch. The bathroom was modern with a shower that had awesome pressure and heated up quickly. What a relief after the ski leg of the trip let me tell you! The shower is really oddly screened in at an angle from the bath. Instead of just having the shower head over the bath, it was weird. I wish we had that floorspace in the main part of the room! Anyway, that was the only complaint so we'd done well. Wifi was also available in room for free so that kept the pressure off the SIM data limits!We only ate at the buffet breakfast twice but it was great. I think it was around 1600 yen per person from memory. It was quite good especially on the mornings we couldn't be bothered finding something nearby. We'd definitely eat there again should we stay there again.Hotel staff were again excellent. All of their staff spoke a fair bit of English to be honest so that really helped. Directions, places to eat, it wasn't a problem at all with these guys and they went out of their way and even booked a popular restaurant for us over the phone.Would we stay here again? Definitely. This is the side of Shinjuku we enjoy the most and Citadines Central is right in the thick of it. A short walk to the train station and the majority of shops we're interested in looking through. It was very clean and the service was excellent. Absolutely no qualms giving this one the stamp of approval.

When we booked we were given very clear instruction to find the hotel. We were greeted by friendly and helpful reception staff. Our room was small and cosy. The bathroom was modern and clean.The breakfast buffet had a good selection of hot and cold dishes including fresh fruit, yoghurt, fish, potatoes, green veggies, eggs, salad, tofu, french toast, regular toast with jam and butter - everything you need to fuel up for a day of shopping.The hotel is situated between a great shopping location and the Tokyo red light district. If you are sensitive to that kind of thing then be aware when you venture out of the hotel looking for some dinner. It was safe but then we were out and back early.

First of all dis bread the nay Sayers who complain about the tiny rooms. You have to understand when you travel you are leaving your country behind. Japan like many other Asian countries utilities on the creativity of living in a small space with efficiency and need over excess space. Let's face it you don't need a huge hotel room. You sleep there and store your things there. That's the main function of any hotel, yes?The things I like about this hotel is it was very modern and had a sleek Scandinavian feel to it. The rooms are small for American standards but the beds are comfortable, the rooms are neat and tidy, the bathrooms we clean and the shower worked beautifully. The staff was so kind and helpful. They spoke English if you need that, and you can exchange money there too.Another thing I loved was the free breakfasts. They had a wonderful daily buffet which included eggs, cereal, toast, bacon, potatoes...but also, miso soup, beef curry and rice, pickled dishes, and a variety of other typical Japanese breakfast items. I would come again for the breakfast alone. It was a great way to start the day before heading out to walk through Tokyo.The staff a,so gave us a coupon deal to eat at the udon place door. Hotel guests get deals when they eat there. Take advantage of that. It is amazing!

Great location, but not great for light sleeper. You might hear loud announcement during the night. Adequate breakfast but with same choices everyday. The room was clean with decent size. Overall experience was good.

This hotel is in the middle of one of the the most notorious red-light districts in Tokyo, which while still safe, seems to have gotten seedier since my last visit. For instance, there were sometimes homeless people sleeping just near the outside elevator, and at night, be expected to be accosted on the street outside by touts trying to introduce you to a strip club or prostitute. The hotel itself is fine: very clean (cleaning staff is excellent). Front desk staff is just OK: not really helpful, could be a lot better. Despite what some other reviews have said the rooms are reasonable size for Japanese hotel (and in fact bigger than many others I've stayed in the same price range.) Since the last time I've stayed, they've added WiFi to the rooms and quality is good. The location (despite the drawbacks mentioned above) is very central, good for sightseeing, and within walking distance of some excellent department stores.Also, the restaurant downstairs (which the hotel euphemistically calls a 'sake bar') is actually a whale restaurant! (It's legal in Japan, though not without controversy, which is probably why it's literally underground here.) Just a word of warning in case you happen to wander down in search of a drink!

We first arrived to a smoking room, as we are non smokerd I requested they change us to another floor because of the smell, the stuff was really eficient and do that imidiately. Breakfast is perfect, it has a large variety of food, western and japanese. The room is small, but as it is everywere arround Tokio, the bathroom was new and bigger than we espected. Recomend

Good location in Shinjuku, within walking distance from the JR Station (<10 minutes) and the Highways Bus Terminal (15 - 20 minutes). A neighborhood is very lively, a lot of restaurants, bars and shops.A Studio Deluxe Double Room was tiny and it was crowded with a 140 cm wide bed, desk and sofa. There was hardly any room to move or for luggage. This should be sold as a single room, not double. The 13th floor was very quite and there was a vending machine available. Two coin operating washing machines and dryers located on the 7th floor.The reception staff were very friendly and spoke good English.

I saw that the hotel was rated highly and I booked a deluxe room.But upon check-in I found the rooms really tiny.The room has no space to open my suitcase, I had to put it on the bed to open it to get a change of clothes.The staff are friendly though. But the signage to the hotel is really bad.The location is the only reason why i would stay here, but for the price I think I will chose a different hotel next time.

Nice hotel towards the end of a busy shinjuku street. Area around the hotel is great for shopping, eating, etc. Hotel is easy to find. Once you're there, take the escalators to the third floor and you are greeted with a beautiful lobby. Hotel room was nicely sized for Japan standards. Clean. New. English speaking staff. Our room came with free breakfast coupons for the buffet at the Stella restaurant in the lobby. Breakfast was phenomenal - west meets east. Highly recommend.

Location is good. It is a walking distance from Isatan and other main attraction of Shinjuku but not that near the main train station. Room and bed is a bit small. Limited products in the bathroom, we might have to ask from downstairs. The price is not that cheap (6500 baht/night). They have fine selection of buffet breakfast, come with the room.

This was my 5th visit to Tokyo and I decided on the Citadines as I had previously stayed at their sister property also in Shinjuku and was impressed with the quality of that establishment.This hotel is in the middle of the red light district but that said this is Japan so it's hardly threatening and even at I night I didn't feel uncomfortable in any way. Check in was fast and efficient, the room very stylish and much larger than most Japanese hotels that I have stayed at. The decor appears to have been recently updated, the room had all the usual conveniences plus BBC and CNN which was great to catch up on the news after 2 weeks of all Japanese TV! Breakfast was combined Chinese/Western breakfast and it was fair to say this catered for most of the clientele in the hotel who were either Chinese or Australian from the ascents I heard. The hotel is a mere 3-4 minute walk to the main area of Shinjuku, with lots of bars, restaurants and even a Lawsons convenience store at the entrance to the hotel. The nearest subway station is Shinjuku San Chome which is a 7 minute walk, JR Shinjuku itself is 10 minutes, a cab from the station cost us ¥800. Given the location, price and experience at the Citadines, this hotel would be my first choice when I next return to Tokyo.

The price was great for this hotel, and the location was near public transportation, so I got all around the city with no problem. Price was some of the cheapest I could find in Tokyo. Lots of good ramen places in the area to eat at. The hotel is in the RLD, but it's not a bad neighborhood. The touts on the street were annoying since I was there alone, but if you're with your family/SO they won't bother you.

You would never expect this hotel to be as elegant and refined as it is based upon its location and lower price. It's tucked in the heart of red-light Shinjuku. My husband and I had just come from a capsule hotel the night before, then New Year's Eve, so we were grateful for a good nights sleep in such a clean and quiet hotel. The staff were very friendly and even gave us a late checkout for no additional charge. Breakfast was tasty with both western and Japanese options. The room was small but the bed was comfortable, and it was probably the largest room we had while in Japan. I would definitely recommend this hotel and will stay there on any future trips to Tokyo.

I stayed here 2 nights solo in December. The hotel is located in the red light district of Kabukicho. The rooms are very modern and super clean. The room is an average size for Tokyo, but no issue for 1-2 people. I liked the bathroom setup better than other hotels. The bed was comfy and I loved the pillows. I didn't have the breakfast so can't comment. It was great to explore Shinjuku from here, you are close to everything. The Shinjuku train station is about an 8 minute walk from here. You can hear a lot of noise from the street late at night as people are partying all night. Considering it's the red light district with a lot of noise, I wouldn't call it a family friendly hotel. It's prob better for couples or solo travelers. Wi-fi worked great. Overall, I enjoyed my stay and would stay here again.
user_name:
Ahmed R
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: This modern, well maintained hotel gets five stars from me because it offers an excellent location and great value. I was shocked at the price, in a good way!Golden Gai is literally right out the back of this hotel and it is in easy walking distance to Shinjuku and other metro stations, coffee shops, bars and fantastic shopping. It thus offers a great base from which to explore Tokyo, particularly for travellers who enjoy nightlife.Having said that, this is in a seedy part of town, which means families may want to steer clear. However, it is ideal for couples and singles. Crime is not a worry, but you will almost certainly be approached by touts and even pimps!

Stayed in the hotel with my husband in May 2015. The hotel is located in centre of the very vibrant Shinjuku. It is a very lively neighbourhood with active nightlife, restaurants and shops. It is very close to the "dodgy end" of the neighbourhood but feels very safe and quiet. The room and the hotel was very nice and the service was great. We felt we got way more than we expected. The room cleaning was impeccable, staff was very helpful and professional, breakfast buffet was great and it was very convenient to have a small store on the first floor of the hotel.

Stayed here during our honey moon. The location is perfect, it's close to Kabukicho, so you'll never have to worry about dining options. It's also about 6 mins walk to Shinjuku Sanchome station, and all the major shopping department stores e.g. Isetan, Marui (0101), Luminest etc. The customer service was excellent. Only downside was the room got really hot and stuffy when we stayed during winter and we couldn't change the temperature setting on the A/C. The bed was also a little bit springy and uncomfortable. However, would definitely stay here again because I just can't get over the convenience of the location.

This hotel is located just off a major street in Shinjuku. It is close to a lot of shopping and night life, but the actual JR Shinjuku station is about 10-15 minutes away on foot. That's probably the major downside of the hotel: it is deceptively far from the train station, and when we were headed here with heavy luggage we had to take a taxi from Shinjuku Station. The hotel was not expensive (we got a very reasonable price off Expedia). The hotel staff spoke good English and were very helpful: they arranged my taxi to Tokyo Station at the end of my stay and were able to sell me postage and mail my postcards. The hotel's free breakfast buffet was very high quality. My room, while small, was modern and clean and had a great view of the Shinjuku skyline.
user_name:
Bruce A
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Citadines is a reliable, friendly budget option in the centre of ones of the world's great cities. And this is totally in the centre. There isn't really anywhere nearby to escape the crazy - but that's Kabukicho. Rooms are clean, functional and comfortable. The breakfast is ok - but nothing special. There is a handy store in the building for snacks if you need it.The front desk staff are very helpful and smiley. It's located right on top of Golden Gai so dive right in and get started.Location next to main transport hub is VERY handy.

Tokyo. What an amazing experience. We were on a budget to be honest and this hotel had 4 stars on Expedia with great reviews. So we booked it. The room was tiny and it just had enough space for our suitcases. The shower was awesome - it was a wet room and we had no problems with the bathroom. The breakfast was unusual and not to our fancy - beef curry for example may be their thing but not to many of the guests. The location was good. I cannot fault that.If you are on a budget then it may just do the trick - but if you want luxury with great food then it may be best to avoid this.

The rooms where clean and comfortable, with good bathrooms, WIFI was also very goodI found the staff helpful.The location is excellent, close to great tourist spots and very good transport links, also plenty of places to eat in the area.The only thing I did not like (this is not the fault of the Hotel) was the touts trying to coerce you into the many strip club / brothels in the area.Apart from that I would recommend the Citadines Hotel for a Tokyo stay. one tip I would give is when you leave the hotel instead of going to the front of the Hotel use the lovely little lane at the rear, you will bypass the touts.

Citadines Central Shinjuku is situated in kabukichō district and is most suitable for people who love night scenes. Across main road is Shinjuku main shopping area, lots of eateries and stores. I was assigned to level 7 - The only non smoking floor in the building.Acceptable room space, compared to other hotels.Room is with bathtub, hairdryer and basic amenities.Everything is Clean.Helpful reception staff. They are very resourceful and willing to guide.Special mention to reception staff : Daisuke san. His excellent service made my stay memorable. My compliments to Citadines management.Only issue was with audible noise of doors opening and closing of other guest rooms at 7am. Went on for 2 hours. Fortunately it lasted only 2 days.I initially picked Citadines Shinjuku that's situated near the Gyoen National Garden and hospital. It is a quieter spot of Shinjuku area.Pick Citadines Central if you like vibrant nightspots, bars, shopping district within 5mins walk. And great area for photography.

Pros: - Within a 5-8 min walk from Shinjuku Station.- Restaurants galore- Nice amenities: hair dyer, toothbrushes, slippers, shaving cream, razors and nail clippers. :)- Friendly staff- Wonderful breakfast- Wi-fi is available Cons: - Hotel interior a bit on the smaller side, but that's expected when you visit Japan in most places. - Pillows are not too comfortable. - Shinjuku area is a definite hotspot for nightlife. If you're into that, you'll be fine. I didn't have a problem with Shinjuku, but the scenery isn't too great unless you like to stare at buildings squished together.

Great location close to transportation. We were not so fond of the Shinjuku area, but the hotel is definitely a great base for exploring the city.Wifi worked perfectly, there was a router in the room.Room was small, as always in Japan, but this was one of the more spacious rooms we had during our trip.Clean and quiet.Wonderful view of the city from the 12th floor. Breakfast was ok but nothing special.

I think it is overrated for being a 4 star hotel with such a small room and poor bathroom amenities. Only thing is the location is good as it is near to the Shinjuku station and eatery areas within 5 to 10 mins.

We chose this hotel base on all the great reviews and generally had the same experiences as other guests. Location- short walking distance to Shinjuku station for both the metro and JR lines. If you take the correct metro exit, the underground passage way will take you within 100m of the hotel! Very central to major shopping, night life, and restaurants, although we found ourselves dining/shopping in Omotesando, Shibuya and Ebisu.Service - Super friendly staff! We asked for a few restaurant reservations which they were able to secure. For one restaurant that didn't take reservations, the guest service agent looked up online Japanese reviews and advised us wait times as reported by others! Rooms - quiet and compact but larger and more comfortable than our Best Wetern hotel in Osaka. I must say the rooms are immaculately cleaned every day! The rooms also have the option for both heat and AC year round (some hotels only allow for heat in the winter which made it difficult to cool down after a long day of walking).

Stayed here for 9 nights for a wedding in tokyo. Was a short walk to shinjuku station which was great. Free in room wifi. Had a studio deluxe room which was small but had everything we needed. Only downside for us was the pillows were very hard. Otherwise a great place to stay with good access to all areas.

Stayed here for 3 nights during my trip to Tokyo. Very comfortable rooms, close to everything - restaurants, transport, nightlife, convenience stores. Only downside is having to walk past the African pests that hassle you every time you walk to or from the hotel at night to go into there bars. Very close to Golden Gai bar area which I enjoyed. Would recommend staying here again.

Great location right in the middle of Shinjuku district. Surrounded by many restaurants with a lively nightlife. Rooms are quite small, but that is expected in Japan. Very clean and comfortable Beddings with good wifi. Several breakfast options also available. Great toiletries are also provided.

I would have never found this hotel if it weren't for Tripadvisor's search engine. And I'm very happy to have found it.This hotel is located in the Kabukicho area near the Shinjuku Station. Many reviewers described this as the "Red Light District", suggesting that it may be seedy or unsafe. But neither adjectives would have been correct in describing this hotel.While the Kabukicho area indeed is the heart of the club scene with bright neon lights, big crowds, and non-stop traffic, this hotel is located on a side street off of a major boulevard. And as such, it's actually a relatively quiet street. In addition, if you ask for a high floor room, you cannot hear a thing. It's as quiet as any hotel room.I really like this hotel for its overall value: 1) Price is very reasonable, for under $300 per night for a Delux Double Room on the executive floor (13th) during the week before Christamas. 2) The room is very spacious for two, especially for Tokyo. It's well appointed, with lots of great design details that are simultaneously space saving and elegant. It feels like a room in any high end hotel. 3) An extra bonus is that there is an "executive common room" on this floor, with a large confernece table and desk areas for work. I actually held a phone conference there early in the morning, using it just like my own office. This extra room also allowed me to do some work at night or early in the morning without disturbing my family who was sleeping. 4) There are eateries below and surrounding the building. In addition, there is a Lawson's right at the ground floor. You can't ask for a more convenience set up than this!5) It's a straight shoot, 10-minute walk to the SE entrance of the Shinjuku StationThere are only 3 minor reasons for why I didn't give this hotel a 5-star.1) Slow internet: Data maybe ok.
