But forget about videos. Netflix or YouTube would not load2) Breakfast: The buffet breakfast is very basic. It has both Japanese and Western choices, but very limited. And the menu remains the same day after day. We stayed there for 5 nights, and basically had the same breakfast every day!3) Gym: No gym on site, nor affiliation with any gym for guest use. But overall, we're very happy with this hotel. We will definitely stay there again.

The hotel room is small however it was very clean and comfortable. The location is good, close to all kind of restaurants, shopping malls, pub etc. however not that close to a metro station. The people at the front desk were very helpful too, helped us to make various phone call for table booking and other enquiries. Breakfast were just fine, nothing fancy. Overall it's very good value and worth staying here.

This was our first stay in Japan and after reading the reviews of this hotel we were expecting a very small room but it was totally fine, I've stayed in smaller rooms in Europe and New York. The hotel was nice, very clean and the service was excellent. It's in a great location, walking distance to the train, lots of great food and shopping and even has a convenience store right next door. I was completely happy with this hotel choice.

This hotel is a great location for the area.Close to almost everything in shinjuku.All within walking distance to robot restaurant, samurai museum and the famous kabukicho nightlife.plenty of food options as well.The rooms are small but have everything you will need.there are only 2-3 English channels.but you can buy vod card in the vending areas.This card will allow you to watch movies.Over all a decent place to stay.

It's a clean and comfortable option, to come in the night to sleep and wake up in the morning, to continuing the trip. The breakfast it's very tasty and you have Japanese food and also American options if you don't feel like you want to try rice or soup early in the morning. You have convenience stores nearby and just walking less than 10 min you have the Shinjuku Station where you can catch a train for everywhere in Tokyo. If I go back to Japan, I don't hesitate to book this hotel.

Hotel is located in a great central location in Shinjuku. The breakfast buffet was very good and convenient. If was a pleasant surprise to find out our room rate came with free passes. The negative is that the room is very small, but that seems to be standard for Tokyo.

I've stayed at this hotel a number of times, even during the time that it was a Best Western but I had never gotten around to writing a review.This hotel fits my needs perfectly, as it is in the centre of Kabukicho in Shinjuku, which is a bustling area with lots of nightlife, and I also feel more comfortable staying here because it's closer to what I'm used to back home. Kabukicho is not your stereotypical area in Japan, there are more foreigners, the streets are littered (which you'd almost never find outside of this district), and there's quite a bit of touting going on despite it being recently illegal in Kabukicho. While these factors may dissuade some people from staying here, I actually prefer it because it's one of the few places where you don't have to adhere to strict Japanese norms because everyone is so free. I can also walk a little further and hang out in another area where all the traditional customs are imposed if I want the regular Japanese experience. I wouldn't necessarily recommend staying in Kabukicho if it's your first time in Japan - because it may give you a wrong impression of what the city is truly like, but after my 5th time in Tokyo, I feel most at home in this area. It's a little silly, but it's very fun. (Tip: Golden Gai is right behind the hotel, which is a really cool place to check out at night)In terms of the hotel itself, I did prefer it slightly more when it was a Best Western because I felt like the toiletries that were provided were a bit better, but overall the quality wasn't really affected by the change. The room is quite small, comfortable for one, but if I had two people carrying two large luggage cases, it would be a challenge to open them both up at the same time. However, the size of the room is something I'm fine comprising as long as the room is clean and affordable. I've stayed at the nearby Hilton before, which was more spacious but much further away from the Shinjuku city centre and much more expensive. I also prefer this Citadines to the other one in Shinjuku because the service I received was much better - I felt like the other Citadines was so overwhelmed with foreigners that the reception often seemed fed up with them.Thanks for a great stay again and I'm sure I'll see you soon.

This hotel is located in the red light district of Shinjuku, so you might sense the difference while walking down the street to the hotel. However, the location is quite good with 10 minutes to Shinjuku station. The staff of the hotel were very nice. We checked our luggage one day before check-in. When we check in, our luggage had already been in the room. The room is clean and we have a very good view from the window and the bathroom is great. We had a very pleasant shopping day around Shinjuku.

My partner and I stayed here for 8 nights in November 2015. Our travel agent accidentally booked my partner and I into this hotel instead of the other Citadines hotel in Shinjuku, so after getting a Taxi to the wrong hotel, then having to walk for 20 minutes and getting lost in Shinjuku, we were a little bit annoyed by the time we found the right hotel! However, it turned out to be a blessing in disguise. The location of this hotel was excellent, with only a few minute walk to the Shinjuku JR train station (it's not as hard to find as some reviews have made it out to be, just follow the signs! And then to get back to the hotel from the station, go to the east exit and follow the signs to Kabuki-cho). It is in what appears to be a red light district but at no point did we feel uncomfortable on the streets, even when leaving early morning and returning later at night.The rooms are clean but VERY small (which was to be expected in Tokyo). The beds are comfortable, but again are very small, and ours was pressed up against the wall (this isn't ideal for any taller westerners...). The pillows are also quite hard and uncomfortable. The bathrooms are a decent size and the showers were great. The staff are all very friendly and accommodating and speak good English. The buffet breakfast was average, there was a range of Japanese foods, and then a couple of Western options also.I would stay at this hotel again, but it would be mainly for the location.

This hotel was originally a concern for us because its located in a nondescript street with several shops offering certain night services.. But despite the location the hotel was pretty clean with comfortable, well-equipped rooms and friendly counter staff. Was pretty happy with the stay! Just make sure you don't return too late in case its not safe for families :( One problem for us was it wasn't as nearby to the JR Shinjuku station as we hoped. Spent 30 mins lost in a bustling underground which didn't exactly ease our welcome into this city. My advice: get above land. You aint getting anywhere figuring directions underground and not knowing whats connected to what. Get to ground level and a tip: look to the sky. There're several tall buildings around and the hotel has its logo on one of them, just look out for it and walk in that direction. After several days when you're familiar with the place you could then walk from the JR station.

Stayed here for a week while visiting Tokyo. The location was great, right in the heart of Shinjuku. The hotel was amiable; very clean and tidy. Did not spend much time here during the day as the room was quite small. The service was always friendly. They kindly obliged when we wished to make a booking for lunch.Should note that the hotel is situated next to a brothel, beware of the Nigerian touters who begin to appear after dark.Do not bother with the buffet breakfast as it is subpar.

I really liked our room. Very comfortable and not as small as the other reviews indicated. I didn't like the breakfast, but there is a great 711 right next door and they have a big selection of food. I just bought from there and cooked in my room.

For the price, this is a great option. Room was small but had everything you need. Everything was very clean.It's close to the subway (five mins walking) and there are lots of restaurants and bars within one or two minutes walk. There is also a 24 hour convenience store downstairs.Request a room on a higher floor, we had great views!Breakfast was great, lots of Japanese and western options.If staying here, remember to have your own information. There were no English language maps or brochures and reception were not able to provide much assistance.That said, would definitely stay here again!

1. I like that there's a Lawson's convenience store on the ground floor.2. I chose this hotel because this is one of the few Tokyo hotels that doesn't adopt the integrated toilet-and-vanity configuration. [It took a lot of researching to find the few hotels that don't adopt the integrated toilet-and-vanity configuration which I find distasteful. There are smaller hotel rooms all over the world, and they don't have to adopt the integrated toilet-and-vanity bathroom; my point being, thank you to all Tripadvisor reviewers who posted bathroom photos so that I could find these few hotels for my Japan trip.]

Its easy location are accessible only if you dont have to drag your luggage/stroller around to subway. Conveniently located in subways area, easy access in and out but without elevators or escalators going down or up. The rooms are a bit smaller than its portrayed image. Family Mart is just downstairs, the rooms are soundproof unlike other Japs hotel. The staffs are extremely helpful with assisiting us.

Finding this Citadine(s) coming out of Shinjuku Station turned out to be easier than expected (bear in mind Shinjuku is the busiest train/subway station...in the world!) as long as you keep on following the EAST EXIT signs from your very train platform onwards. The hotel is located at the core of the Red District of Shinjuku but is safer than safe (we're in Japan afterall!). We had requested an Executive Double Room Studio and ended up on the 13th floor with a nice view over the Shinjuku skyline (this is not the Cerulean though...). The room was advertised as being around 25 m/s but I HIGHLY doubt this is accurate, it felt way tinier than that and the bed is the smallest queen size bed I've ever seen in my life in terms of width (which for 190 euros / night in a TOP floor executive room was rather surprising I must say even by Tokyo standards). The bathroom was clean and functional with all the necessary amenities. The staff is extremely helpful and speaks decent English. The breakfsat (not included in our room rate but we tried it once) was extremely bland, so if you can avoid it, please do.

Stayed here for 3 nights recently as part of our 2 week honeymoon in Japan. It was the first hotel we stayed in, and we were pleased with the size of the room, the location of the hotel, and the selection at breakfast. The breakfast room itself is a little manic and busy of a morning, but there is a relatively good selection of Western breakfast items to balance out the more traditional items. The bedroom layout was fine - although the room was quite small, the hotel managed to make it feel spacious; and with the usual safe/fridge/amenities, it had everything you might need for a short stay. As mentioned by everyone, there is also a Lawson convenience store downstairs which was very handy. Staff were all very friendly and helpful, and are happy to store luggage if you either arrive early for check in, or want to explore a bit after checkout. For the price we paid, it seemed good value for the location we were in.

Firstly let me start by saying this hotel and its staff were very nice indeed. Then let me follow it up by saying that I didn't expect from the information I gathered that this was pretty much a Japanese Travelodge as far as room size (at least the one we had on the 4th floor). Don't get me wrong, it was very well decorated, with sporadic wifi and all the usual amenities in the bathroom, tea and coffee with kettle in room. We were just a little disappointed with the room size, the smallest double bed I've encountered in some while if I'm honest. But, it's a reasonable price and very clean, and you're right in the middle of a fairly lively area with plenty of bars and restaurants just moments away. Being a smoker, I had to pop down to the ground floor to have a quick smoke outside but that wasn't too much of a crisis, though I did come to realise that the hotel itself is positioned on a street where no one ever seems to sleep, no matter what time of day, night or morning (sometimes 3 or 4am) there was always crowds of people outside. Thankfully all of that outside noise did not filter up to the room we were in.

I stayed here April 2015 just as the hotel was being rebadged - business as usualUpon a second visit here Oct/Nov 2015 i was impressed with the same level of service and amenitiesthe bfst is small buffet mixed asian/western, its ok for a good start for the day. if you dont use bfst voucher that day you can use it to part pay for lunch at the hotelthe rooms are small , pay for an upgrade on the higher floorsadditional room amenities are available from receptionthe only criticism would be the wifi speed - on this occasion it ran slow

While I didn't love Shinjuku itself compared to other cities in Japan, if this is the city you want to stay in, this is the best hotel. Very reasonably priced, excellent central location and clean, spacious, modern rooms.We stayed in a double twin I think on the 13th floor, but the beds were pushed together so it felt like a king. The room was spotless, great size bathroom with a separate shower and tub, which I'd never seen but now I want one at home. Spacious room with a nice size closet and dresser. Lots of plugins to charge phones/devices. Friendly staff who helped us reserve our bus to the airport. Breakfast was just OK - buffet style.We especially liked the location - walking distance to Kabukicho - Japan's red light district, Robot Restaurant, Golden Gai and the train station - which is only 2 stops from Shibuya and Harajuku. We also really liked the price - very reasonable.My tip here: Try the restaurant on the second floor called Udon Dining Sururi - large menu and fun dining if you want to try something like shabu shabu. And maybe ask for a room on one of the executive floors (13 and up). I see several reviews regarding room size but was very pleased with ours and maybe that's because we were on one of the exec floors. Also, there are two Citadines in Shinjuku, make sure you write down or print out the correct address (in Japanese) to give the cab driver.

Surprisingly this hotel exceeded our expectations. We're 4 families composed of eight adults and thirteen children with ages ranging from 4years old to 18 years old. The seven rooms we occupied were pretty spacious and were kept tidy daily by the house keeping. Infact, two rooms were hardly used as the children can fit comfortably with the parents in their Triple Bedrooms and Twin Bedrooms. The hotel front desk personnels were very accomodating and they were also well versed with the different tourist destinations. They were very helpful in giving directions. The hotel is centrally located. It's just 10 to 15 minutes walk from the train station and the bus station. 5 to 10 minutes from Don Quijote (bargain store) and Isetan (Duty Free) and just a few steps away from great restaurants. Just below the hotel is a convenient store where you can find almost everything. Citadines Central Shinjuku Tokyo surely did give us a wonderful accomodation on our first trip to Tokyo Japan. We will definitely booked at this hotel again on our returm trip to Japan.

Great location if you don't mind the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku. Everything you want is around. Most importantly the hotel is spotlessly clean, very accommodating, great breakfasts and well appointed. The staff couldn't have been more helpful. I stayed in the Executive Twin which is like a small 2 room apartment. It had a refrigerator and 2 TVs (not that you'll use them). The bath was well appointed with washlet toilet and an excellent shower.The decor and facilities are up to date, modern and well kept. This is not a hotel that would fall into the "Luxury" class but if you want that check out the Park Hyatt and be prepared to be on an expense account. But for the money the Citadines is an excellent value.

Had a fast and hussle free early check in during our stay last weekend. Good breakfast especially in Tokyo where can be costly. Bottle drinks for health is important too nowadays of which the hotel feels a thumbup for us. Staffs are always very helpful from breakfast over to check in counter (who provides us good tips for trains and subway directions especially could be very confusing but they managed well) till their housekeeping. Highly recommeded as you will never gone wrong during your visits.

The down side first because there is a lot of good about this hotel The size of the room is cramped and had inadequate storage for us and I mean small however we didn't spend a lot of time in the room .There isn't a bar or anywhere else to sit either , but we knew that anyway . The breakfast is adequate , hot rice and meat , salad,fruit ,cereal,lovely bread for toast, fruit juice .If your staying more than 5 days it could get boring .Room service was ok ! Fresh bed and towels but often bins were not emptied cups not exchanged for clean ones .In room kettle , hairdryer air conditioning very good . Pillows well marvellous felt hard at first but really comfy as was the bed . Overall the cleanliness of the hotel was excellent.Ice machine on most levels and washing and drying facilities on floor 7 ,detergent included !Staff pleasant and helpful.Situation of hotel was very good 8 mins to station which was 15 by train to main Tokyo station , we had a JR rail pass so rarely travelled by metro . Even at peak times it wasn't as bad as I thought it would ,everyone is courteous anyway unlike London .Surrounded by cheap places to eat and 3 huge department stores which all have a whole floor dedicated to food .Inside the hotel was quiet we didn't hear any noise from outside .As a couple although in the red light district we didn't have a problem wandering round TIP of the week we got mobile wifi through NInja wifi saved us loads of time finding places and navigating the trains etc .I would stay here again

Walking distance to Jr station and shopping malls. There is also a Lawson beside it. Room is clean and bigger than expected. Please be care as there are two Citadines. I almost go to the other one which is further away. There was breakfast buffet and the spread was alright but I am impressed by the tea selection. Will stay here again if I am visiting Tokyo again.

Stayed here on holiday- Tiniest rooms yet- but then this is Tokyo- Coffee service was basic- bathrooms were functional- basic hotel with decent buffet café downstairs- You can't beat the location smack in the middle of Shinjuku action and yet rooms are quiet... So if you are on a budget and use the rooms only for sleep and bath then go for it!

Stayed here for two nights as a stop over to the UK. Very central (excellent location on top of Golden Gai), clean and tidy and friendly staff. Only downside is that it's quite small but was perfectly adequate for our needs. Definitely recommend!

We stayed 5 nights over the Halloween holidays at this hotel and we are looking forward to returning in the future. It wasn’t an exquisite experience but the location makes up for the compromises.After checking in, we were surprised to find that the adjoining room we requested for our children did not exist at all in the hotel—at least not in the configurations we had opted for. We were instead offered rooms across the hall from each other, and we took it. The staff spoke English very well and we sorted things out. Our room was very small but clean. Basically it was queen-sized bed (maybe smaller) with a little wiggle room to the mini desk / dresser combo. One corner of the bed was within 12 inches of the desk with1 sides of the bed and the headboard along adjacent walls. There was tiny little “couch” with two throw pillows. Add two suitcases into the room and it was very hard for the wife and I to move around the room without getting on each other’s nerves.The bed was a queen, although I suspect it was very undersized—just like the tiny pillows. I had to sleep on the side touching the wall, so a good night’s rest was eluded me most of our 5 nights.Our room had one window which could not be opened to freshen up the air in the room. The air-conditioning control is in Japanese, so we had to figure it out by trial and error. It can easily take more than one night to get the hang of but thanks to having two of them (kids’ room and ours) to experiment with, we figured it out in by the second or third night.The bathroom was very clean. The tub is extra deep with a shower head adjustable to a comfortable height for people over 6 feet in height. Like the room, the bathroom was very tight. The door doesn’t open to even 90 degrees and don’t even think about getting dressed in there. Definitely, a one person at a time kind of bathroom. I was seriously worried that door would swing open while I was shaving and made a conscious effort to keep a defensive elbow at the ready.The room safe is in the nightstand drawer and not bolted down to anything. A thief can simply take the whole safe, put it under a jacket and work on it when they get home. Definitely not good. That said, we never felt that any of our stuff would be at any risk.The TV had all of 3 English channels that I could find. CNN, an NHK English channel and Discovery.Breakfast was very tasty however, it’s the same thing every day, except for the alternating main proteins of either chicken nuggets (Kara Age, actually) or stir fry beef.The huge upside is the location that couldn’t be any better. The hotel is in the heart of Shinjuku, with restaurants, bars and shops seemingly all night. We were at one shop well past midnight. None of our ladies was ever harassed, despite warnings that the male crowd can get rowdy. Even very crowded places were comparatively quiet. The hotel is also a short walk to the train station that gets you everywhere in Tokyo. To sum up, we are definitely looking forward to staying here again. The cramped space and tiny pillows are a small price to pay be in the heart of probably the most vibrant city on the planet. Don’t worry about sleeping, you won’t want to anyway. But if you do crash, the place may be cramped but it sure is clean and queit.

The location is close to many shops (luxury brands, department stores, duty free and discount stores) and a variety of eating places. The metro and JR station are a few minutes walk away and very convenient. The breakfast buffet is good and has a lot of choices (except coffee was not good).The staff spoke english and were prepared with maps to the Tokyo motor show and a restaurant map.The room was tiny (compared to the usual Best Western rooms) and the carpet was not clean. The carpet was a bit smelly.We couldn't open the windows to air out the room. The bed is a queen size with small, flat pillows (so I asked for more pillows). There was hardly any place to walk once we opened our 2 full size luggages. Wifi was SO SLOW!In my booking request, I asked for adjoining rooms, which they replied that it was available, but upon check in, they said there were none in the entire property. They booked us on the same floor as our kids. This was not acceptable since they are minors, so after about 20 minutes they switched us to a lower floor.This is a three star, it is very convenient and good value for money. I would stay here again.

Stayed Oct 2015 for 8 nights. Spacious, clean, honestly non-smoking and only a short walk to everything. Close to subway M9 and the F line, excellent service, very clean and we appreciated the laundromat downstairs as in the middle of a longer vacation for us. Will stay there again for sure

My son and I spent a week in the Citadines. The desk staff was unfailingly courteous, kind and helpful. When we wanted to go to an Iron Chef restaurant for lunch, they arranged that efficiently, reserving for us and handling the communications. Two of the young women at the main desk had done internships at U.S. hotels. All spoke excellent English! The room itself was clean, big enough for the two of us, and the price was quite reasonable. It is also centrally located and close to a subway stop. We highly recommend the Citadines!
user_name:
marydN8876AZ
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: The Citadines is the rebranded Best Western and I stayed here for 3 nights a couple of weeks ago. The hotel is in a fantastic location less than a five minute walk to the Shinjuku station (East exit).The rooms are small by Western standards but I believe good for Tokyo, they are spotlessly clean and the staff are very pleasant and professional. This hotel doesn't wow - but is a great and affordable way to explore Tokyo for a few days.Breakfast options are good and the staff replenish items quickly when they are running low.

This was my second stay at this hotel and it still remains very good indeed. Rooms are of a good standard and for Tokyo are spacious. Hotel has all you'd need but if not everything is on your doorstep. Breakfast is a good selection and quality items are prepared freshly.Staff are all very professional and happy to serve your every need. Special recognition to Santosh who's honesty and professionalism are supreme. Hope to get back soon!

Everything in tokyo is small, even the cars, so don't expect a big room. But the hotel is very nice, the staff is friendly and speaks in english. The rooms are small but very clean and sufficient. The Hotel location is excelent, you have the shunjuku station 5 minutes walking, and metro stations nearby, also good stores like Bic Camera, UniqLo, Book Off and others. Also you can visit Golden Gai area to have some drinks it is a few steps fom the hotel, or take a good pizza dinner in an All 500Y restaurant.Few Yamanote Line stations to get to Shibuya or Ikebukuro. Also I walked from Harajuku to Shinjuku and it's very close (about 40 min) If your room includes breakfast you can expect something good, not marvelous but ok, with options between japanese style and occidental style.Very good option! I recommend a lot.

This is a comparatively small hotel in a perfect location, close to Shinjuku Station from which you travel all over Tokyo, but in a quiet side street. The room was equipped with everything I could have wanted, the bed was comfortable, and the staff were unfailingly friendly and efficient. The place had everything I wanted and at a comparatively low price. The breakfast buffet was not great, but I could find enough to eat to set me up for the day, and the convenience store on the ground floor supplied extras. I slept better in this place than in most upmarket hotels I've stayed in. Thoroughly recommended.

This was just an okay hotel. Information about the area and trips were poor - just a few leaflets on a table. Staff only spoke basic English. The room was shoe box sized and the twin beds filled it - no room to layout a suitcase. It was very clean however and the bathroom was good.we booked the hotel last March and it has been bought out by Citadines since, with no notification of name change - so we were looking for a Best Western Hotel, a bit confusing!

Product Ok - Friendly staffs. Stayed for 03 nights and my last night i had to move to a smoking room due to non-availability of non-smoking rooms. But as promised, they have freshen up the rooms so well, that i couldn't tell it's a smoking room. - Well Done.Location wise, right below's a Lawson. Walking distance to heart of Shinjuku and next to Kabukicho. Many F&B outlets nearby, Cinema, malls and JR Station. (10 mins at most via walking)Wifi was on and off. Could do better. But not the most worrying thing. Will recommend and come back again if the rate is good. No Pool, No Gym, But location wise pretty faultless.

I actually really enjoyed this hotel for the price. The workers are very friendly and willing to help with anything. The rooms themselves are small but as others have said, it's pretty normal for Tokyo. The bathrooms are pretty nice and they include shampoo, conditioner, body soap, toothbrushes, toothpaste and a decent hair dryer. The rooms were kept clean by housekeeping. They do include wash clothes which is something I was happy about. The rooms don't have irons, they do have a trouser press but I wish they had an iron. The breakfast I thought was surprisingly good. It was better than I thought it would be. Downstairs on the first floor, there is a convenient store that is open 24 hours. We didn't have any issues with the people outside at all. It's situated near a train station and a Starbucks is a 10 minute walk away. OH and they have a currency converter machine which is WAY cheaper than the airport. I'd highly suggest exchanging money via their machine than at the airport. A lot of places in Tokyo only accept cash so it was nice to have a safe in the room to store our passports and cards. They do have laundry on site if you have to do some laundry. WIFI wasn't that bad when we were there. We did rent a portable pocket WIFI for walking around Tokyo which I highly suggest doing.

The place is in good location to both JR and metro station.Room size is decent for Tokyo.Noise is not an issue as it's off the edge of the Soho type area.If I have to pick on something, it's the WiFi dropping off at night, or you can bring your own router and use the LAN cable connection provided.

Coming from Citadines Kyoto (and Somerset KL & Somerset Bencoolen Singapore in the past), we felt this Shinjuku branch was a letdown from the Ascott properties.Nice:* Check in/out was a breeze. Staff was helpful and efficient in handling guests.* Rooms are comfortable and well sound-proofed. Small sized but that's normal in Japan. * Location is good, an easy 10-minute walk with a 4yo kid to Shinjuku station. Lots of dining options around the station.* There's a convenience store downstairs and a nearby pharmacy. Poor:* The studio deluxe twin room is old and slightly musty though housekeeping did their best to ensure cleanliness. There was a portable aircon inside that we used from time to time to cool down the room. * Wifi was pretty bad. We resorted to using our own portable wifi the whole time. * Prepare for some long waits at the laundry machines. It must be terrible for the adjacent room/s to hear the machines going on and on until midnight. The hotel should increase the number of machines and choose a better location.Outside the hotel's jurisdiction, my husband was a victim of drink spiking on our first night. The next morning, he had sms and calls from the bank confirming $2000+ card charges & withdrawal! He was totally blank on which pub it was and what actually happened. Strong advice: bring cash if you'll try out the nearby pubs, leave all your cards in the room safe.

Small room but clean.WIFI doesn't work well. Location is good closed to Shinjuku station but please understand it's in Kabukicho area, meaning plenty of bars for people searching "love". Breakfast is good, not really expansive. Last comment: may be a bit expansive, surely due to location!

Check inn was quick and easy and the room was nice and new with modern facilities. The room was reasonably clean, some surfaces were quite dusty and I did find hair in the shower. They do have washing machines and dryers which is always helpful when travelling with a family. Whilst not the most central location we were quite happy with the position and happy to take the short walks to everything. The only thing I was annoyed at was the fact that the hotel charged our credit card in USD and not YEN which was at a higher cost to us. The staff were always helpful with any questions we had and friendly.

What should be an excellent location is somewhat marred by recent changes to the Kabukicho area. With the new Gracery Hotel in the center of the area, the "seedier" elements have been pushed to the sides. Unfortunately, that's exactly where the Citadines is. At night you will be propositioned every 10 feet from Yasukuni Dori until you get to the front door of the hotel. This is, of course, not the fault of the hotel, but it's something to keep in mind. On the actual hotel end of things, The public areas are lovely, the staff were very helpful, and the room itself was clean and pretty great overall, minus a few things.1. the pillows were very uncomfortable (we were able to ask for softer pillows which were quickly provided and exceptional, like i said, very good staff!)2. the internet connection (not just the wifi) was extremely poor and spotty. I found this to be highly unusual for Tokyo.3. the curtains were not at all adequate for keeping the light out. This was particularly frustrating given we were staying in a sunrise-facing room at a time of year where the sun was coming up shortly after 4am. Note that i did inform the hotel about these issues and they, to their credit got back to me and let me know that they were planning to upgrade the drapes in all rooms but had not done so yet. Citadines has only taken over this hotel reasonably recently, so take that into account that this and other improvements might be on the way.
user_name:
John P
New York City, New York

review_body: We had a really great stay in the Citadines.We arrived on the train from Narita to Shinjuku and the hotel was easy to find and centrally located. It's a max 10 minute walk from the main Shinjuku station (depending on which exit you take of course).The staff were really helpful, the hotel was modern and clean. I was expecting our hotel room to be the size of a box but I was pleasantly surprised. Bathroom was a good size and modern.The breakfast was interesting (beef curry anyone?) but there was a good variety.If I go back to Tokyo I'd definitely stay here again and recommend to friends.

The staff was very helpful. The rooms were a bit small but so are all the hotels in Tokyo. Close to the subway and 10 min walk from shinjuku station. A nice hub for all the tourist hot spots of the city and also for near by places

I spent two weeks at Citadines Central Shinjuku as my home base. There's a lot of positives that make this place deserve a higher rating than the three stars I gave but a couple things could be improved.Let's start with the positive. The check-in and front desk employees are extremely nice. The rooms are clean and quiet. Two bottles of water are provided each day as long as the bottles are being used. The shower and bathroom are in good condition. The location is about 8 minutes to Shinjuku station which is the main hub in Tokyo. The Food: The breakfast included was decent. Each day at the breakfast buffet there is different juices available, salad, toast and other types of bread, eggs, either beef or fried chicken nuggets, Japanese miso and curry, rice, and fruit. FYI, the coffee was terrible at breakfast. The negatives are that the free wifi they provide barely works. It's so frustrating that I would go to Lawson's store next door to use the free wifi. The staff wasn't always totally knowledgeable about everything but that is understandable I guess. My wife didn't like the bed but I thought it was fine. But overall for the price and its location, Citadines is a good choice. If they could only fix the wifi I would give them 4.5 stars.

Hotel is set in a good location which is within walking distance of main shopping area with big international stores (approx 5 mins) and also within short walking distance of local metro stations (approx 5 mins). Hotel lobby is nice and modern with a friendly atmosphere. Hotel receptionists were very friendly when checking us in, and with general inquiries were always happy to help and with a smile.Room was modern and clean, although very small. Was not enough room to store suitcases, so for 2 people in a small room it can be a bit cramped. However, this is standard in Tokyo, plus we didn't spend a lot of time there anyway! Pillows like all hotels in Japan were rock solid and not what I liked. However, I improvised and slept on the sofa cushion which was fine!Plenty of local bars immediately opposite the hotel which is lovely to see. Also a large temple which is lovely.There is a family mart at the bottom floor of the hotel which is really handy for all your essentials such as water etc. Breakfast at the hotel was nice. Selection of continental cereal, toast etc as well as some Asian themed curry etc. Overall the stay at this hotel was nice, and I would stay here again.

The hotel is in a very good location, 5 minutes walk to Shinjuku station and close to many shops, restaurants etc. The reception staff are very pleasant and helpful.The bathroom was fine, good shower but the bath tub was quite small.The main issue I have with the hotel is the room. The bed was very small and was also pushed up against the wall to allow room for a large desk and chaise lounge which to be honest wasn't needed. The bed being up against the wall gave the room a very cramped feeling and I really feel the rooms could be remodelled with the bed in the centre of the room to allow access from all sides.Also the bedding was extermely thick which when in September when its very warm means for a very sticky nights sleep.Also the wifi wasn't very good at all, kept cutting in and out. Usually a call to reception sorted this out but there was a period towards the end of our week's stay where it wasn't working in the whole hotel for a long period of time.Overall I probably would stay here again, but mostly for the location.

This hotel is located right next to an area lined with little bars. Perfect for meeting new people. Brian Bar was US friendly with plenty of people who spoke English. 24 hour mini mart right downstairs for drinks and snacks. Lobby has a money exchange machine to quickly convert USD and Euro to yen. Staff was very accommodating. Room was perfect sized. Heated mirror and deep soaking tub, not to mention the super cool Japanese toilets.

the room is very small i cant really walk with my 2 luggage but i think its normal for all hotels in japanhowever the interior is good and it looks clean the bathroom is small but not too small compared to room size overall im ok with it amenities are ok as well but not as good as thee hotel in bangkok where they offer aromatic spa grade amenities the location is good u can walk to anywhere not too far

In the heart of Kabuki-cho. Interesting nightlife! However, first experience not great as I got into Shinjuku at rush hour and it was raining very heavily. Not an empty taxi in sight. Rolling a heavy bag to find the hotel in the squall was not for the faint of heart. But once I was there, staff were exceedingly kind. Had my room ready in spite of the early hour. All facilities and amenities very well thought out in spite of (or because of) the small space. Counter staff spoke excellent English and were most helpful with tips and directions. They seemed to have thought through every question a visitor might ask.As many have said, shopping and dining options aplenty in the vicinity. Would definitely consider this place again if I am travelling light.

Very well located, within walking distance from Shinjuku station (we always exit at B9 from the train station) and in the middle of shops and restaurants.Rooms are small but not even the smallest in Tokyo. Bathroom has a full size bath whereas the other hotels we looked at in the same price range had half sized baths. Concierge was very helpful, you can rent a plug converter at the concierge for free though you need to leave a JPY1000 deposit that is fully returnable.

We arrived at Sinjuku Station at about 8pm from the airport with direction printed off from their web site. It was pouring rain so we jumped into a taxis and handed him the Japanese direction.He couldnt work it out and we ended up dropped off at another Citadines about 10 minutes from ours. The manger of Hotel kindly went out in rain and flagged down another taxis for us.We made it there at last. Handy Seven 11 near by and we got our water, wine and snacks. Great breakfast ,tiny rooms but very clean. My advise take as little as you can as there isnt much room to get to your suitcase. We had 3 night there then onto Kyoto.

Hotel was on the happening side of Shinjuku (where you want to be), a short walk to Shinjuku stations. The hotel is at the start of the red light district however we always felt 100% safe and it wasn't sleazy at all. Golden Gai is around the corner and there are so many places to eat/shop/karaoke. Room was on the small side but this is typical for Japanese hotels. Our continental breakfast was complimentary however the range is not fantastic.Overall we felt that the hotel represented excellent value for money and the location was fantastic if you want to stay where the action is.

This hotel is in a great location.Close to the station.Best Western Citadines near Mr DonutThere is another Citadines further upBreakfast is very good.There are some Carabean guys just outside- seem to be Spruking for the English pubthey hassle you - just ignore them - don't talk to themalso I had 50000 yen go missing from our roomI had the flu so let my guard down we didn't know we had a safe in the room at firstthe staff investigated but no luckmystery ?This goes for Japan in generalbe careful of thieves !!!An old Japanese gentleman told us !Lovely people most of them but some of them worried meI think some of them are potentially dangerousSo be friendly but don't believe your "bff's"Still all things considered I enjoyed my stay at this hotel

I loved staying at this hotel, it's in a good position, about 10 minutes walk to the JR Shinjuku station. You can walk out at anytime and there is something going on, so many places to eat nearby. Great shower pressure, very comfortable bed, decent sized room, very good soundproofing and very clean. Helpful front desk staff. The breakfast buffet was the best, the staff at the buffet were so hospitable and always ready to greet you with a smile in the morning. I would deffinately stay here again.

About a 10 min walk to the JR Shinjuku station. At night there were a lot of scammers on the streets outside but we just ignored them. There is a convenience store on the first floor of the building which we frequented during our 4-night stay. Our stay included breakfast and it was pretty good. We were worried about noise at night, but it ended up being quiet (our room was on the 7th floor)

The hotel was perfect. The staff were very friendly and helpful whenever we had questions. The room was clean and comfortable, and housekeeping always cleaned it every day.The location of the hotel was ideal in Shinjuku, made it easy to walk around/catch train to wherever we needed to go to. The shopping and nightlife in Shinjuku is fantastic so it was so easy to get to places within walking disctance from our hotel.The buffet breakfast was great, with many options available.We were really happy with our stay here and would stay here again.

Located in the heart of Shinjuku, the hotel is pretty convenient, the subway are a couple of minute walks away but the walk is always enjoyable. Me and girlfriend were a little worried at first since the hotel is located right in Tokyo's red light district Kabukicho, however, it is extremely safe and no worries is needed, we had a little culture shock around the area but thats it. The hotel staff are very polite and professional, they know English and they recommended me places to go during my stay. Rooms are clean but a little small (average for Japanese culture), there is also an automated USD-YEN currency changer so that would prove to be really convenient. The breakfast buffet is dissapointing though so don't bother to try that. But the food around is amazing! (Well technically most restaurants in Japan tastes amazing). I'd recommend a small corner ramen shop called Nagi ramen around the area, one of the best ramen I've ever had.

The location of this hotel is amazing, close to the railway station, close to all entertainment and night life district is so convenient. Yes, the rooms are a little small by Australian standards but they were clean, well stocked and the beds (although against the wall) were comfortable. The included breakfast buffet was quiet acceptable (I've never had a good HOT buffet even in any five star property anyway as Buffet's are Buffet's) The staff were friendly and it has a convenience store right under the Hotel. Anyway, a hotel room is for sleeping in and having a shower and apart from that we did not spend any time in our room, we were too busy enjoying the Shinjuku District and Tokyo!

This is a good hotel that provides a great value for its location and quality. On my trip to Japan, I stayed there for the beginning and the end of the trip. There are a lot of choices of hotels in Tokyo in all price ranges. Citadines Central Shinjuku definitely falls into the mid value but high quality class.Finding anything in Tokyo is nearly always an ordeal. While Citadines Central Shinjuku is only 10 minutes away from JR Shinjuku Station, it is down a smaller street and isn't visible from outside the station. The website is fairly good in describing how to get to the hotel. For me, I found the easiest way was to just go to the East exit from Shinjuku Station, look for the BIC electronic store and start walking down the street. Cross the first street and you should see ABC Mart on your right. Keep walking in a straight line away from BIC until you get to the next big street. You should see a Burger King and a 7-Eleven across the right. Turn right until you get to the first crosswalk. You should see a Mr. Donut across from you. Cross the street and continue walking. You should see the hotel on your right. Once you know where the hotel is, you will find lots of different ways to get to and from the hotel every day.The hotel lobby is on the 3rd floor and there is an elevator to the side. The lobby is smallish but large enough to have a restaurant on the side. Check-in for me was very fast and smooth. They had a stack of face towels, wash clothes, shavers, etc at the check-in counter that you can take. The room itself was about the expected size for a room in Tokyo. We had 3 luggage that we ended up stacking on top of each other so that we can have some room to walk around. Everything looked new and clean. Every room has a electric kettle and all of the amenities. In addition, they provided 2 complimentary bottles of water every day. That was certainly a pleasant touch. Internet is also complimentary but I think it was probably the worst of all the hotels I stayed in on this trip. It frequently stop working during the evening. I think they just had too many guests using it and not enough bandwidth.We had breakfast at the hotel as it was part of our package. It is a nice little spread but gets old after a day or two since they don't really change the variety. The food was good but you can find better just outside the hotel. I also did laundry at the hotel. They had 2 washers and dryers. Washers were 300 Yen but includes the detergent while dryers were 100 Yen for 30 minutes. If you are washing heavy items like jeans, you will probably need more than 30 minutes from those dryers.The staff at the hotel was friendly and helpful. They even recognize me when I returned for the second stay. One service that they include is luggage storage. My trip included a 7 day trip down to the southern part of Japan. They were happy to hold on to my unneeded luggage until I returned at no extra charge. That was also very helpful as luggage storage can be quite expensive in Tokyo.Overall, I really enjoyed staying at the Citadines Central Shinjuku and would recommend it for most people unless you need solid internet. I think that the area is busy and can get really crowded but the hotel itself is unaffected. There must be a million things to do in Shinjuku and you can't go wrong using Citadines Central Shinjuku as your base!

There are 2 citadenes hotels in Shinjuku one is called citadenes Shinjuku and the other Citadels central Shinjuku.We went to the wrong one after getting lost in a typhoon for over an hour only to discover we were in the wrong one.This hotel caters to overseas guests very well as we couldn't see many Japanese staying.The rooms were compact, but hey this is Tokyo.The room was spotless and the shower was great.The staff speak good English and the breakfasts are good value for money.Our room didn't have the advertised kitchenette,but that was okay as we didn't need it.I would recommend this hotel as a good place to stay.

Booked a room on the brand site, no confirmation email was received afterward and I had to go through 3 round of email to ensure the room is secured....Anyhow, when I went to counter to check in, the room is there but the rate is higher due to some miscommunicaton between the centralised and property team. Had to stand in the reception for 30 mins, showed them all the email communications, and wait till they sorted out internally.......Anyhow, it's quite a good location, many restaurants and shops nearby, the room is in decent size but i would very much recommend to do the booking through other booking websites to avoid all the fuss.....

The superb location was very convenient for this unfamiliar traveler to Tokyo.All you need is within walking distance. The one negative that I have is the size of the rooms. Our room was so small that the bed was hard up against the wall on one side. Overlooking the space issue and you have a reasonably priced, clean hotel.

Near shinjuku central station and metro system which is about 5-10 min walk. Room was spacious compared to other hotels in Tokyo. Although located in 三丁目 which is famous for night clubs, the hotel is very quiet and safety is never an issue even if traveled alone. Breakfast was good but not much change during my 4 days of hotel-stay. The hotel provides half price sale from time to time. Wait till then and you will have a wonderful stay in Tokyo.

The Citidines concept is great for when you need extra room for a third person. Sometime it is hard to find hotels that accept three people in other countries. The room is small, but not tiny compared to other major cities. Having the sofa bed out as a bed of course eats up space. The bathroom is tiny, with a Japanese soaking tub with shower. The tub is not as long as a western tub, but taller for soaking. There is a Toto toilet with a bidet washlet function, which is very common throughout Tokyo. The sink is outside the bathroom, with hardly any counter space. But there is a medicine cabinet. The room only has one tiny trash can, and one medium trash can. We would bag up food containers and put them outside our door. The kitchen is tiny, but functional with a sink, a small counter, a microwave and utensils and plates. Storage space is reasonable except for luggage. Seating space is limited with the sofa bed setup as a bed. Rooms facing the main street do get some road noise. We had a non-smoking room with no hint of cigarette smell. The main bed is comfortable; the box spring is directly on the floor, so the bed height is short. The location is east of Shinjuku station, in a relatively quiet section of town. Compared to areas near Shinjuku station, the area is a haven. If you wanted more activity, Shinjuku station is a short metro ride away, or a long walk. So if you want a restful and peaceful place to stay, the Citidines Shinjuku is highly recommended.The metro is a short walk from the hotel. The street to the metro is a alley like street with limited vehicle traffic with a steady stream of people walking by. Compared to the Shinjuku station area, it was much more peaceful. There are lots of places to eat along the route. We did not have a bad meal during our stay. There is a 7-11 on the corner of the hotel with a decent selection of prepared food. The ATM also works with U.S. ATM cards. At the 7-11, make a left down the street to the metro. Near the end is a Family Mart store with a better selection of prepared food. The prepared food is much better than in U.S. convenience stores. Across the street from the hotel to the left is a bento box store. There is a buffet style selection of food, you select what you want and put it into take out plastic containers. You pay by the weight. The food quality of course is better than the convenience store. The location of this Citidines is great because it is near a small metro station. From this station you can get to anywhere. Shinjuku station and Shibuya station are massive and takes time to navigate through them. I would avoid them just because they are such a headache to get through; there are just massive amounts of people going in all directions. They are also not well air conditioned because of the energy crisis in Japan. The Shinjuku gyoemmae station by contrast is tiny and not that crowded with people getting on during the times we used it. It is also not that hot. In the morning there is a wall of people coming out of the station, but few people going in it. In the gyoemmae station, it is short walk to either platform. In the big metro/train stations, it is a major hike to find your platform. We took a taxi to Tokyo station for the Shinkansen, The staff went outside to hail a taxi for us, and told the driver where we wanted to go. We took a taxi to a avoid lugged our luggage through Shinjuku station and then to Tokyo station. The taxi was 2,800 yen, and it is worth it to avoid dragging our luggage up and down stairs. Tokyo train stations are not designed for ease of mobility. Highly recommended.

At first, this hotel didn't look much from the outside because its entrance didn't give it justice. But our opinion did change the moment we got our rooms. They were clean, spacious and had what we needed. The view was great, the beds were very comfortable and the bathroom was equipped with all the necessities that we could ever wanted. The location was a plus. This hotel is near the subway station, which was only a few minutes walk. There were also many restaurants around and shopping. Customer service was amazing. Each morning, we would come with our questions and various destinations inquiries to which the staff delivered the precise answers and helpful tips to how to navigate our way throughout the city. When we requested to change the room for our kids so we could be on the same floor, it was done right away. Breakfast was good. There was an enough variety that could satisfy any hunger. I am not a big eater, so this was not an issue for me and neither was for my family. And honestly, how much could a person eat? All and all, this hotel was super clean, super friendly and super safe. I would recommend this hotel to family, friends and to travellers around the globe.

This hotel is quiet new, looks like it's undergone some renovations or new management. Interior decor looks new and very clean, carpet immaculate too. We traveled with our 11 month old who had a hard time adjusting to the humidity in July. This hotel is 60km from Narita airport or 17km from haneda airport. I suggest you travel light in Japan to avoid taxi cost which is not cheap. Unfortunately for us arriving late, train was not an option with a infant and extra baggage, fortunately we arrived at Haneda airport and cab ride was roughly $70AUD.The buffet breakfast didn't have a wide range of food and for the 4 days there, it was the same menu day in day out. There is only one restaurant in the hotel and it's not open for dinner. It's about 10 min walk to Shinjuku Central where all the shoppings at. Short stroll to subways also. I wouldn't recommend this hotel to young families, the room we had is the size of a shoe box. Bath tub wasn't even full length. But plus side, it's super clean!

I had stayed in Citadines Central Shinjuku before, when it was still Best Western Astina. The rates are just a bit more expensive than other Japanese hotels I had stayed in, but I can say that their rooms are more spacious -- which is already saying a lot, given the usual size of Japanese hotel rooms! The bed and pillows are comfortable.The location is great. It is in the heart of Shinjuku, a few minutes walk from the various Shinjuku metro stations, with lots of dining and shopping options nearby.But what I like most is their customer service. Some noted restaurants require reservations on the first day of the month before, so their phone lines are usually busy then. I had emailed the hotel to do the reservations for me. They had been persistent enough to keep calling the restaurants for several days. They were able to get me a reservation in only one famous restaurant, but I truly appreciate the effort even in just trying to contact the others. It saved me time, effort, and cost of long-distance calls. In person, the front desk staff are very friendly and helpful.

First time in Japan so not used to the small rooms.Clean comfortable and well serviced Reception staff very helpful.The area is abundant with places to eat. Plenty of people around . Felt quite safe walking around.Went to Robot theatre bar .3 minutes walk from hotel what an amazing show.whoever designed the show must have been on some really good stuff!

We have stayed here twice: 2012 and 2014.Rooms in Tokyo are small in general, yet at this hotel they are always clean, fully featured, have a wonderful bathroom, couch and TV. The beds are really comfy.I needed a favour from one of the front desk staff and spoke to Takatsuka-san. I have limited Japanese and he very kindly telephoned a specialist car rental place for me. This extra level of service really marks out this hotel for me, and I won't consider staying anywhere else whenever I stay in Shinjuku.There is a Lawson in the base of the hotel (you have to go outside to get to it) so its very convenient for a late night / early morning snack or drink.

Recently had 6 nights in this hotel and could not find fault with it. The location is very convenient to Shinjuku station, only about a 10 minute walk, but if you have luggage I would suggest you take a taxi, which is quite reasonably priced.(Have a card with the address in Japanese to show your cab driver, as it is impossible to explain an address in English). The room we had was on the 14th floor, quite spacious for a Japanese hotel, an enormous bed, very quiet and the best and largest bathroom I have ever found in a hotel. From check in to check out, despite some language difficulties the staff were a delight. It is worth having breakfast in the hotel as there appeared to be nothing in the area where you could get breakfast, other than something packaged from a conveniences store (although these could be very tasty, you never knew what you were eating). There was a guest laundry on the 7th floor which as a traveller I found very useful and it was reasonably priced.

My boyfriend and I stayed here when we took a trip to Tokyo. The hotel is very clean and compared to other hotels in the area, this one was very spacious. Full-sized bed with a small couch. The bathroom was very modern and the price overall was good.The best part was the breakfast that was included in your stay. It was great to start your day off with a good meal. Typical as most hotel breakfast buffets in Japan, there is a mix of Japanese food and Western food, so even if you are picky (like my boyfriend), you will surely find something you like! :D

This property is located right in Kabukicho with easy access to everything along with a family mart downstairs. We stayed here when it was still Best Western and the staff were very helpful. The rooms are a little small but that's Tokyo! If your looking for a very centra property this is highly recommended!!

Brilliant cheap - good value. Extreme central, nice, clean and relaxed. The rooms are not big, but that's standard in Tokyo. It's in the middle of everything in Downtown Shinjuku. The best location in Tokyo

We stayed here while travelling through Japan in March of this year (2015) , when it was still under the Best Western name (I'm sure it cannot have changed to much since then!) we found it to be very reasonably priced, excellent rooms even though small as is the norm in Tokyo, made use of the space very well. Water pressure in shower fantastic and beds very firm and comfortable. Breakfast was very good, both Asian and western choices. Staff were efficient and helpful (as are most people in Japan generally) The best part of it was the location, relatively easy to find from the station and so close (Japan is difficult to navigate on the best of days, make sure you have locations on your smart phone maps!) So vibrant and full of life all around the hotel, whilst still being quiet. The Golden Gai right behind is an incredible place to wander through at night, have a drink in the many little bars that offer to tourists and find a place to do some Karaoke with the locals great fun! We loved The Champion Bar, be prepared to battle it out with some of the best in Japan though!

We stayed 6 nights in this hotel. Rooms were relatively small but they were sufficient, quiet, clean, and comfortable. They have triple rooms which is kind of hard to find in this area. Although it is in a "red light" district with couple of entertainment facilities nearby, the hotel is safe. Nobody bothered us when we (and tons of other people) walked by every day. It had coin laundry facility for 300 yen per wash and they even provided detergent. Breakfast was adequate but kind of boring after a few days. Since our rooms did not include breakfast we tried out different breakfasts in the area. According to the hotel website and Google map it is within 8 minutes walk from the Shinjuku station. However we were lost the first day (and the second... fourth day) and took us longer than 8 minutes to get to the hotel. The second to fourth day we were kind of lost inside the Shinjuku station and got out from wrong exits....

A 3 stars hotel (with +) in the quarter Shinjuku that is very central. Near to train station and subway. In the evening the quarter change to a "nightlife quarter" but it's not disturbing. We had our room on the road side. You have a freezer in the room, hairdryer and of course, Japanese toilette! The breakfast it's not so exciting, close to early in the morning (10:00) and not so many places (you have to wait sometimes). It's really the same things every day and not so many chose. Boring that is no bar so you can take a glass of cold drinks when you come home from sightseeing.Behind the hotel you find the Shinjuku Golden Gai, a little quarter with "minibars) some of them can take only be 5-6 people). We loved to visit the bar Bardot!!

Great location in Shinjuku. 10 minute walk from the station. Small room but everything you need with a fantastic bathroom. Popular with Aussie and European travellers. Hotel was busy and had a nice vibe. Breakfast was good although could not get used to fried chicken for breakfast,Would stay again at the drop of a hat!

In 2013, we looked online for very cheap accommodation in Tokyo. My wife and I had no idea where to look in Tokyo. After doing online search, we stumbled across Best Western Shinjuku which is now called Citadines Central Shinjuku Tokyo. It was reasonably priced for the 3 nights we booked. We found a package that included free Breafast. On arrival, we checked in around 10pm. We were greeted by very friendly staff. Communication was great.We stayed in the Studio Double room. A very nice room. That room in particular is not that big and that was expected when we saw reviews for it. Free Wifi was also accessible from our room. Its a perfect location for shopping. Not far from clothing stores such as H&M and Top Shop. If you're looking to get a break from the busy streets of Shinjuku checkout Hanazono Shrine which is a 2min walk behind Citadines.Shinjuku Station is not far. Once you know your way around you'll know the short cuts to get to the Station. It took us about 8mins to walk to the East side of Shinjuku Station. Btw, for any first timers, if you do take the train from Narita Airport to Shinjuku Station, make sure you exit out the east side. It will be over whelming when you arrive at Shinjuku Station, just make sure you look for the yellow signs as they will direct you to your exit.So because we enjoyed our stay we went back to Japan in 2014 and stayed at the same accommodation in Shinjuku. We're heading back this year and we will be staying there again.

I liked this hotel and its location although as has been said, the location will be a live it or hate it I guess as it is very central to the action.I didn't find it a problem although I didn't really go out in the evenings.Big bonus was the washing machines located on the 7th floor. They are coin operated and I managed to wash and dry everything I wanted during my stay.The staff in front desk were exceptional. Really helpful and nothing too much trouble. They sorted out a trip to Mount Fuji for me and also tickets to the Robot Restaurant at which I had a great time.Breakfast was vast and delicious

Good Hotel , excellent location downtown Tokyo Shinjuku district in Tokyo about 8 minutes walking from Shinjuku station (one of the biggest in Tokyo) and convenient for moving around in Tokyo.Shinjuku is a spot for shopping at relatively reasonable prices in Tokyo it's also a nightlife spot for amateurs. Rooms are clean well maintained and well equipped. Staff are friendly & professional.
user_name:
Hatem A
Dubai, United Arab Emirates

review_body: After arriving from a long flight from the US, we headed into Tokyo for one night, before heading out to other parts of Japan. We arrived via airport shuttle after dark. The entrance to the hotel is upstairs. Reception and check in were quick and easy. Our room was larger that we expected and had all the amenities we could have wanted. The next day it was a bit of a walk to the nearest subway with our luggage.The area was full of shops, restaurants, and nightlife, so there was plenty to do.

I stayed here with my wife for five days and the overall result is good. It's the only hotel I've been in Japan so far and the room does seem small, but I kind of expected it by the reviews. The bed is around 140 and two average persons can sleep on it. The western breakfast is not great and the paistries seem industrial. I can't compare the Japanese breakfast with other hotels, but I liked it. Also, the WiFi works well and its very very clean.

We stayed at Citadines Central Shinjuku for three nights at the start of our trip and two nights at the end. The hotel is located about ten minutes walk from Shinjuku station and close to lots of shops. There is a convenience store downstairs. We had breakfast on the first three mornings. It was good with a combination of western and Japanese breakfast items. Our room had a bar fridge, a kettle, tea and coffee and was quiet despite the busy location. The main reason I would not give five stars is that the room was fairly small with the double bed pushed against the wall on the left side making the bed difficult to get out of. We booked here again at the end of our trip mainly because it was in a very convenient location and was of a reliable standard.

The location could not be better. Just a quick walk to the train station where you can easily access the entire city. Good restaurant options nearby as well. The rooms itself are a bit small and basic, but expected for Tokyo. Would definitely stay again!

We stayed at this hotel for our first two nights in Japan. We took the airport limousine to Shinjuku station and then took a cab to the hotel. (Be careful, we went to the wrong hotel at first, there is another Citadines in Shinjuku. Be sure to have the address for Citadines Central). We probably could have walked but had too much luggage and Tokyo can be like a maze. The hotel is in a busy and interesting part of Tokyo with plenty to do, see, and eat. Although this part of town is known for its nightlife, the hotel room was quiet. It is close to Shinjuku station (from which you can get just about anywhere). The hotel staff were friendly and spoke English well. I would definitely stay at this hotel again.

3 nights in standard room.Positives: Location...The rooms are small but clean and comfortable. For the price you pay I feel its great value for money. But once you find it you'll appreciate the fact that its surrounded by restaurants and shopping areas.Negatives: Ironically....Location...either you love it or you hate it. Initially the hotel is pretty hard to find, especially if your dragging heavy luggage from Shinjuku station. This area isn't quite the place to bring your kids out for a evening walk and I'll leave it at that. Overall: Not so great for families. great value for money and you'll be spoilt for choice on restaurants and shopping areas.

The staff are very friendly and helpful. It's in a really vibrant area that comes to life from about 6pm, there's plenty of bars and restaurants. It's also close to shinjuku station which makes it really easy to get to surrounding areas. Our room was to the rear of the property over looking golden gai and the temple.The room was a decent size but there was limited storage. Buffet breakfast was different as you could have fried chicken, chips and beef curry as well as the usual fare!!

The reception is reached from a street level lift, opposite the convenience store Dawsons.We arrived too early to check in, but the hotel stored our luggage whilst we explored.We stayed in a Double Studio, which was clean and the bed was comfortable. Room was small, but with more sensible use of storage space would have seemed much bigger. No wardrobe or drawers, just a small open rail, with few hangers. We were like children with the multi-functional, heated toilet seat!We didn't eat in the hotel apart from the included breakfast, which was fine - a fair selection of Japanese and Western dishes.Location is perfect for the sites of Shinjuku and Kabukicho and for Shinjuku Station.It's an easy JR trip to/from Haneda airport as per the directions on the hotel’s web pages. Other reviewers have mentioned that it is in the red light district, which it is, but we didn't feel unsafe or uncomfortable in the slightest. Whole area is full of bars and restaurants and don't miss the alleyway bars of Golden Gai, which is directly behind the hotel (not all charge a cover). 'Seiryu' restaurant a few doors away was excellent.

Close to shops, food, nightlife and only a 10 minute walk to Shinjuku JR station. Nice clean room. Very foreigner friendly hotel. Buffet breakfast included wasn't bad. Friendly and helpful staff. Good value for what you pay for. Would definitely stay again.

We picked this hotel before it changed brands, but we found it to be as excellent as all the other reviews suggest. The service from reservation to check out was outstanding. We got help finding places in Tokyo and further abroad. One of the desk clerks helpfully translated directions to a zoo and park we were planning to visit in Osaka later in our trip! We chose a room on the executive floor for a little more space and we're glad we did. Our room was well-appointed with a nice bath, lots of amenities, and room for a little sofa. We used the laundry facilities on the 7th floor, which were a good value at 300 yen for a wash and 100 yen for a drying cycle. There are lots of nearby restaurants and several helpful convenience stores in the same block. The breakfast included large buffet of both western and Japanese foods, which we enjoyed each day. Some reviews note that this hotel is in the "red-light district" but the neighborhood is perfectly fine and felt very safe. It's a short walking distance to Shinjuku Station to go anywhere in the Tokyo area.
user_name:
cmdevlin64
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: We loved our stay here. The staff are so polite at check in and at breakfast. We asked for a room with views and got it. The rooms are small, but not tiny. There is a Lawson store on he ground floor and a 7 11 2 doors down. My partner's only whinge was that the breakfast was the same every day. Yes it is buffet, but after 5 times one does wish something new would appear, like pancakes or bacon. The hotel is based in Kabukicho which is the red light district. Other reviewers say they were harassed etc. We were not. We did see the black men waiting to offer a pamphlet to all walks of life, perhaps I had the look of "Don't even bother". You will feel safe anywhere at anytime in Tokyo. Stick to the main streets to enjoy the fashions and lights at night. Use common sense and you'll be right. Hotel wifi was quick!

Great hotel and in a really good area. Very close to shopping and rail lines. Very clean apartment and staff were tremendous. They even tried to talk English to help me out…very rare in Tokyo. The place is situated in front of the bar district, if you like that sort of thing. Near to temples and great restaurants. The food for breakfast was to die for. Asian and western food is catered for. I travel a lot and this was actually on of the best places I have stay in. I will go back there every time I stay in Tokyo. People were fun and interesting and made my stay very pleasant.

We booked a standard twin room and were given a room on the 14th floor with a great view. Yes, it was a bit small for European standards, but it wasn't that much of a bother, as we were out during the day. Bathroom was a nice surprise - large, fully equipped, with a big window next to the bathtub (as it happens with most hotels, windows could not be opened, which is a pitty, as we had a great terrace). Breakfast was fairly reasonable (continental and asian), but choices were a bit limited for our taste (i.e. no cheese at all) and the menu was the same each day. Coffee was poor - but there are a few Starbucks in the area, so you can skip it at the hotel. The staff is really nice and polite and really make you feel welcomed.The hotel is at a 10 min walk from Shinjuku station and there are some Tokyo Metro entrances closer. There are plenty of places to eat around and even a small shop at ground floor (it is called Lawson - it's pretty much like a 7 eleven), where you can buy water, drinks, food and so on. Also, you have plenty of up-market shops at a walking distance, both local and from other world-fampus brands.Despite its proximity to Golden Gai, it is ok to walk around in the evenings; most likely, when they see you are a foreigner, they won't even bother you trying to lure you at the shows. Mind, however, men standing in front of bars who try to convince you to go in for drinks - we were told by a local this is a form of scam and we should decline politely.

The location is fantastic, close to all kind of facilities. Many restaurants and shopping nearby the hotel.The standard twin room is quite small, can't even have space for 2 big suitcases. However, the room is clean, and fairly comfy.We like the buffet breakfast with both western and Japanese style. Our family enjoyed it every morning. Laundry machine is located at 7th floor, guests need to pay JPY300 for 30 minutes, JPY200 for drying. No detergent is needed.The lobby is located at 3rd floor. Check in and check out was smooth and fast. The staff are helpful and friendly. They can provide very clear and accurate information on the direction and which subway line or train to take. Lawson just located at the ground floor, very convenient!One thing to take note is the hotel is located at the red light district - Kabuchiko. Every night you will get to see some local guys or African guys standing outside the bars, but they are not pushy or rude. So we didn't really bother it.

We stayed at the hotel's twin room for 4 nights in late May. It is in the heart of Kabuki-cho and a stone's throw from Golden Gai entertainment district. The room is very spacious as is the toilet. Staff were helpful and accommodating. The reception is on the third floor and is accessible by either escalator or the elevator. Overall a wonderful stay.

We stayed in a standard room for 5 nights as part of a trip to China and Japan. I agree with most of the reviews, in that the check in staff spoke good English and the room was small but made good use of space. The wifi signal was good quality, and the bathroom was well equipped. We didn’t have breakfast included in our rate, but it was easy enough to go to the nearby 7-11 or Lawson for breakfast. The location, an easy walk from Shinjuku station was convenient as a base to explore Tokyo, and the Kabukicho location was relatively quiet during the day, but busy every evening. The area is full of touts trying to get you into their clubs, but they’ll leave you alone if you tell them you’re not interested. There’s also plenty of hostess bars and adult entertainment venues, but round the corner from the hotel is the Golden Gai, which has many tourist friendly bars. On the same street as the hotel is a branch of the British themed “Hub Pub” chain.My only negative points were the pillows, which were uncomfortable as they were a single small pillow with a large beanbag like pillow underneath. We also found the curtains let in too much light to make it easy to sleep. I’d probably stay somewhere else if I were to return to Tokyo, but Citidines is a good value choice if you want to stay in Shinjuku.

stayed for 6 nights during our Japan vacation. The rooms are smallish but adequate.Everything is very clean and well maintained. The buffet breakfast is good with a choice of Oriental and European dishes.The location is perfect for the Shinjuku area with an entry to the train/subway "labyrinth" just a few minutes away.

Stayed here for 5 nights. We traveled straight from the airport to the hotel, which was very easy to get to using Japan's rail network. When we first arrived to the hotel, the reception staff were friendly and helpful. Having arrived a couple of hours too early to check in, we had to leave our luggage at the hotel and chose to walk to Gyoen Gardens to relax a little after a long flight.When it was time to check it, we were greeted by different staff at reception. Unfortunately, this particular gentleman that checked us in, was not was as welcoming as the first staff members we had met. He was sour faced and seemed to dislike his job. He forgot to offer us some of the hotel amenities (tooth brushes etc..) until a colleague reminded him. I didn't think too much of it, and assumed he was just having a bad day. But we encountered this same gentleman a few more times during our stay, and his attitude was always the same.We stayed on the 12th floor and had a decent view. The overall decor was nice and modern.
