The room was quite small and had a slight musty smell. Luckily the windows in the room could be opened, so that helped. You will struggle for space if you have large suitcases. The bathroom was a very good size with a good shower and decent bath.The breakfast food was never a joy to eat, but it did the job.The location of the hotel was really good. Very close to Shinjuku Station, and variety of restaurants, bars and shops. It is located within Tokyo's red-light district, and the road which the hotel is located on can have a bit of a seedy vibe at night time, but it was never an issue, and we always felt safe walking around the area at night.Ultimately, I wouldn't choose to stay here again, but I would happily recommend it to a friend who might be visiting Tokyo for the first time.

This is Citadines, so you do expect the IHGs to deliver. Room and bed are kind of small but at least it's clean. Stayed for 5 nights. Was kind of difficult to spot when we drove there. Very busy street. Very convenient with Lawson downstairs and 7-11 just 2 stores away. Reception is at level 3, do take note. A great base to explore Shinjuku station.Not the safest neighbourhood at night, you do get pub-goers approaching you. Just 2 streets across you see many well dressed (and even good looking) guys in suit, selling their "products" to guys. On weekends, you see ladies soliciting on street. Solo travellers just got to be more mindful.There are many F&B options around but most allow smoking so be sure to ask.

Hotel is centrally located near Shinjuku train station and not hard to find. Only complaint is that there are annoying touts for hostess bars on street outside hotel who won't stop pestering you. Rooms are larger than you'd expect for a Japanese single room. Of course toilet is state of the art Japanese toilet. Price was reasonable Breakfast is ok with lots of Japanese and western food

Hotel had all the basics and was very clean w large shower area with own doors. The beds were ok, hated the pillows w rice in them. Location was amazing and highly recommended. We were close to everything we wanted and or public transit was easily accessible. Staff was very friendly and helpful and spoke English. We witnessed a rough earthquake while there and hotel held up and staff managed people well. Highly recommend bars right behind hotel which no one tells you about,

This Hotel is very conveniently located only about 10 minutes walk form the Shinjuku train station, breakfast included in the room rates, I actually I checked various hotels in the Shinjuku area and the Citadines was the only one that included breakfast with the room rate, with a wide verity of Western foods as well as Japanese traditional breakfast items like rice porridge, miso sup, Natto beans and curry etc. The staff was very helpful and friendly a and well spoken English.The rooms are very clean and updated, great signal with the WiFi in the rooms as well as in the lobby, the bath room was very modern and renovated.I was very pleasantly surprise that we were only about 500 ft from the Golden Gai area, the very historic old Tokyo alleys where they have more than 500 bars, I only seen a report with Anthony Bourdain and been there was a great experience.I would highly recommend this hotel to any traveler coming to Tokyo.

Stayed two times during our stay in may the first time is when we arrived in tokyo and the second time is our last 3 days in japan.The hotel is located close to everywhere you just need to walk 10 minutes to I setan department store and 15 minutes to takashimaya times square.it is also easy to find a food for breakfast (7 eleven family mart,lawson)so you don't need to have breakfast in the hotel.the hotel also closed to shinjuku central station aproximattelly 1000 yen.they also have washing machine for 200 yen and drying machine for additional 100 yen that is very useful if you have a long trip.the only negative thing is they can not provide us a twin bed but the sofa can be changed into a bed should you don't want to sleep in the same bed.the price is also reasonable overall this hotel is recommended.

This is a decent quality place with a great central location (if you don't mind being in the red light district. Small room and bed but secure and neat. Staff were great (as we found everywhere in Japan) and if you are travelling on a budget wouldn't hesitate to recommend this place.

We've stayed in this hotel twice during our visit to Japan on April. Our first visit, hotel was a part of Best Western and after we have returned, it was changed to Citadines. Hotel's location is great, room size is decent (when I say decent - it is still small like other Japanese hotels however it is acceptable). Breakfast is sufficient and has a good choice. Especially during our 2nd visit, staff was much better and attentive. on our last day, we were leaving before 5am and hotel offered us a money off voucher for the supermarket downstairs as they couldn't offer breakfast at that time. I must say it was a nice gesture from the hotel. overall great location, clean hotel, good service and would stay there again.

Let me address the elephant in the corner – yes, this hotel is in the red light district. However, it really is quite safe and the touts will leave you alone. Certainly, there was nothing that made me feel unsafe at all.It is great value for money, in a good location – if you just need a place to sleep each night, then this place is in a very good location and is very good value for money. The breakfast is particularly good, see if you can get it bundled in the price.Yes, the room is a bit small, but so are all rooms in Tokyo. The shower and bathroom was particularly good, having appeared to have recently been renovated. The bed and pillows when nothing to write home about.

Lovely hotel in a great location - very close to many train stations, lots of great food and shopping nearby. The room we had wasn't huge, but it was big enough with a comfortable bed and nice bathroom. The staff were very friendly and helpful. The breakfast was good - not the best I've had, but a good range of options, and we certainly didn't walk away hungry!

Look no further!by far the best hotel in Shinjuku if you are doing your rounds in Tokyo.With Golden Gai at the back,Kabukicho in 'front' & with Gojira looming over..there's no better stay!A big plus & accolades goes to SATOMI & hotel staffs as they will go all their way to help you with almost anything!keep it up Citadines!Mazlina & Hafiz from Malaysia!

The Citadines is round the corner from Shinjuku Goen station, a stone's throw from Shinjuku, but away from the hustle and bustle. A nice breakfast is available at a reasonable price for those who prefer it. Rooms are reasonable size and have everything you would need

The comments from others on the small, noisy street-facing rooms are presumably true, but these problems can be avoided if one takes a larger, non-smoking executive room, all of which are located on the upper two floors. It’s not all that much more and well worth it if you like space and quiet. Our only complaint about the room were the pillows (the soft one is the size of a large postage stamp and the larger ones feel like they are filled with bean bag material). Breakfast was fine and the lack of an evening restaurant is no problem as there is a decent udon restaurant on the second floor of the building (the hotel begins on the third) and numerous others nearby. The short walk to Shinjuku station is very convenient. The area is of course dicey, but the touts aren’t all that bothersome and the streets are packed so there is no sense of it not being safe. Good value choice for Tokyo.

The room is quite simple, with oven and microwave. Comfortable bed, nice bathroom and free wifi.10 min walkig from subway (Shinjukugyoenmae) near to the Sukiya Restaurant and Seven Eleven market, I recommend !

Little worried by mixed reviews and change from Best Western but all fears allayed at Reception. Welcomed warmly, had a perfect Executive room which catered for our needs. The location was excellent as the Shinjuku station was a mere 5-8 minutes walk away so we used our JR Rail Pass to great effect. We stayed 3 nights and had the breakfast buffet included. It was great value serving Western and Japanese food. I believe in a good breakfast to start the day and that's exactly what we got. We weren't out very late but never felt threatened outside the hotel - it is quite different in the evening compared to the day but we always felt safe!The staff were always pleasant and helpful anything we requested we got be it toiletries or advice!Would definitely return and pay the extra for an executive room.

We chose this hotel for our last night in Japan for its proximity to Shinjuku Station and a few nearby attractions (New York Bar, Government Building, Ace's in the Golden Gai). It's in the red light district but we never felt unsafe. The hotel is great - clean, functional rooms, great service and the best western hotel breakfast we've had. If you're a party of 2 and staying longer than one night I recommend paying for a larger room. Also bring eye masks and ear plugs - it gets bright very early and this lively area comes with the occasional siren during the night.

Very comfortable size for a Tokyo hotel. Service:The staffs were nice and the check in process was smooth. We asked for some plates and cutleries for our cake and they were delivered within minutes! No tipping required cos it's Japan so that was nice.We stayed in room 414. Bathroom:We believe given the change of name from Best Western, renovation took place not long ago. The bathroom was fantastic, very clean with soft colours on the walls to give you that modern cosy feel. Make sure you grab your wash towel and amenities during check in. The water pressure was excellent 10/10. The shampoo smelled lovely and the toilet had warm seats which was another + for this room.Streets and surrounding:Some odd juvenile on the streets where the hotel is situated during day and night. Given it's on the third floor once you pass them everything is fine. It's Japan anyway, not need to worry about safety too much.

Our room was a little small, but it was very clean and modern. The buffet breakfast in their restaurant was excellent and included everything you could wish for; including eggs, sausage, french toast, fruit, cereal, juices, etc. The staff at the desk were always numerous, friendly and helpful.The hotel is situated in one of Tokyo's lively pleasure districts close to the huge Shinjuku Railway station, which we were told was the busiest in the world. We used the train to go to downtown Tokyo and arrived in less than 15 minutes. However it is easy to get lost in the train station, so the hotel provides maps of the station and the neighborhood that are very useful.The area around the hotel was bustling with people at most times of the day but was even more so in the evenings. We always felt safe and enjoyed looking at the gaudy neon signs everywhere. It was also easy to find great restaurants in the vicinity.

The hotel I tried to get wasn't available for the dates I wanted so I booked this place. I am SO happy I did. My wife and I were very happy with the location. It is in the heart of Shinjuku, there is so much going on and so many things to do. Plus, it is a 10 minute walk to the major Shinjuku station and about an 8 minute walk to a smaller station which will get you on the convenient Marunouchi line (getting you anywhere you want). The staff was great. When I first booked, all they had was smoking rooms. I asked the front desk very nicely if he could please find me a non-smoking room and he found one. I was so relieved and happy. The staff is incredibly knowledgeable about the area and have several maps to help you. Also, they have all kinds of power adapters if you forgot one. I will be honest and say this is sort of in the red light district - however if you aren't looking for that type of thing, you can just walk by the places and not really know about it. The free wifi is very reliable and as fast as you need.My wife and I were thrilled that this place was right behind the Golden Gai area -- alleyways of cool, unique, tiny, special bars. It was so fun to explore at night (still safe). It is also right by the Hanazono Shrine which is beautiful to walk to at night.The breakfast was fine. A "western" breakfast although Westerners may find the food just slightly different than we are used to. We got the breakfast included which for us, was very convenient. Go a little early and do your day planning at the table, it fills up quickly. The room we got was a Standard Semi-Double Room and it had more room than other hotels we had visited in Japan. Other hotels had room for only bags and here you could spread out a bit. Still smaller than usual, but pretty good for Japan.

Been staying in this hotel for the last 4 trips and it is still the best hotel for long term stay. Although the room is not as big as other hotel around Asia but it is so well designed that you do not really its "smallness" at all. Love the way they place the queen size bed and a small little sofa bed that you can sit to have a simple breakfast before your go out to explore the city. The bathroom is well designed and the best is that they placed the face basin and a cabinet out of the bathroom so if you are couple then you can use both at the same time. A small little kitchen is placed right after the entrance and it let you cook a simple meal and drinks.Try to book early as it gets sold out pretty fast during peak season. Will I stay again! Yes definitely!

If you are into shopping and nightlife, this hotel is for you. Lots of convenience stores, bars, restaurants, shopping arcades nearby. The room is a bit spacious for japanese standard. Clean rooms and friendly staff. Breakfast is good. Overall, we had a great stay. Will definitely stay here again.

We spent five nights at this hotel, the room we booked was a standard double but the trap here is that since the rooms are small, one side of the bed is hard up against the wall. This, combined with the "snugness" of the room, and the fact we were to spend 5 nights there persuaded us to request a room with two singles. In fact if your budget can stand it pay the extra and take one of the apartments on the 14th floor, plenty of room, great open views and most of all, you can open the windows. Additionally it is very quiet at night. Breakfast is adequate, staff friendly & helpful speaking English, and it's a short walk to Shinjuku station. Convenience stores nearby  All in all a good place to stay.

This is a rebranded Best Western hotel right in the middle of everything you need in Shinjuku. Breakfast included which a bargain if you are staying two or more to a room, nothing overly fancy but makes a good start to the day.Rooms are very small, but it is Tokyo, so no complaints there.We needed a clean, functional hotel for one night close to Shinjuku station and this fitted our needs 100 percent.Plenty of great places to eat and drink within a few minutes walk, and the walks can be very interesting in this part of Tokyo!!!!!!

We booked this hotel when it was still the Best Western Astina Shinjuku. We were notified prior to travelling that this was changing to Citadines.the hotel was not as hard to find as most people said. we exited the main Shinjuku station at the east exit and used the guide, provided by the website, to reach the hotel. if you get lost there are numerous street maps which helpful place where you are in relation to roads around you. whats even better is many of the maps list the old Best Western so you have a point of reference.We arrived at 11am and were not able to check in until 2pm. The very helpful receptionist took our bags, secure them, and gave us a token. the staff spoke very good english and even provided us with maps for the local area, information on how to get back to the airport and helpful info with regards to the metro and public transport.on checking into the room we found it very comfortable, clean and nicer than we expected. Many people said the rooms were small which is to be expected in Tokyo, however after just coming off a cruise ship, we found the size of the room to be more than sufficient. The bathroom facilities and amenities were excellent and we were provided with clean towels every day.The hotel staff in general were very helpful and accommodating. The area its self it somewhat active at night and we often found ourselves being accosted by gentlemen offering to take us to local drinking and ‘entertainment' establishments. However you can fend them off very easily. there is a convenience store at the base of the hotel which is very handy for water or snacks.This was an excellent location to explore the city and we would stay again without hesitation.The one piece of feedback we would offer is that, upon arriving at the hotel, you take a lift to the 3rd floor, which is where reception is located. You can then easily use other lifts adjacent to access all other floors. We know that other Citadines facilities require key card access the other floors. I hope that this hotel implements similar security as anyone could walk in off the street and find them selfs wandering the 9th floor. With that said you still need key cards to access the rooms.

This is a very snug fitting hotel, in a place that is very crowded for real estate. It is cleverly put together, though for an extended stay, the room would be just a touch too snug for a couple of Australians and their luggage.However, the hotel offers all that a traveller could want, including laundry facilities on the 7th floor, and it is smack bang in the middle of Shinjuku, and right next to the Golden Gai area both of which just go off like a frog in a sock, especially on a Friday night. The hotel entrance is on the third floor, so dont go looking for an entrance lobby at ground level. The area that the hotel is in abounds with fantastic eateries, and some amazing bars, all that are within a quick stagger of your roomThe breakfast was good, the staff very helpful, and to wander around Shinjuku and go from full on Tokyo hustle to the quiet and peace of a temple is just fantastic.

This apartment was perfect a model of Japanese style and clever design. It had everything that you needed for an extended stay, including a laundry. The local area had a wine shop, supermarket and a range of nice restaurants. The staff were lovely and extremely helpful. The only downside was the very basic breakfast. As we only stayed three nights it was easier to eat the breakfast than invest in too much grocery shopping. For a longer stay I would certainly use the local supermarket. The hotel stored two big suitcases for us until we returned two weeks later. This certainly made our tour of Japan much easier! You might need someone to explain the three remote controls necessary to make the TV work!!!!

We have just stayed 5 nights at this hotel, having previously stayed at Citadines Shinjuku Apartments. The rooms are totally different. Rooms at this new Citadines property are very very small and hotel rooms, not apartments. Passing each other in the room is difficult. The bed is only a double size. I expected the room to be small but not this small. It is however for its size well appointed. The bathroom in comparison is roomy with a bath taking up far too much space in my opinion unecessarily. The location in the Kabukicho area is good. Close to the Shinjuku station, even closer if you can master the Subnade system. Theres plenty of convenience stores and an over abundance of restaurants and clubs, if thats to your liking. Yes there is quite a lot of street noise in this area through the night and plenty of police cars coming and goingA big negative is the terrible wireless connection, if think this would preclude me from staying again as we had difficulty staying in contact for business and it was very frustrating.With poor internet connection even researching train/restaurants/ maps or anything we wanted to do in Tokyo was difficult.A big plus, theres a coffee machine on the 13th floor in the conference room and its free. Great iced coffee too

For the reasonable price, I would definately recommend this hotel. The location is great; a five minute walk from Shinjuku station and right in the centre of a busy area with so many restaurants, bars and things to do close by.The room was somewhat smaller than what I am used to, however, i think by comparison, this is pretty standard for Tokyo - it's probably even one of the larger ones you would find. Rooms are modern and extremely clean with good amenities.The were so lovely with good English language skils and happy to help with any assistance you may need.Breakfast was not great. Nor was it bad. Just very average. But that is my only negative point, and even then I am being somewhat on the fussy side.Overall I would highly recommend this hotel!!!!

this was a very good stay in a moderately (for Tokyo) priced hotel. I kinda wish I could add a half star to the rating because it's a little better than average but just shy of outstanding. I did a lot of research on TripAdvisor before selecting this hotel and it perfectly matched my expectations.The staff is very accommodating, offering free umbrellas when we went out, knowledgeable about the area, making nice restaurant recommendations and arranging taxis. The rooms were very clean but (of course) small by western standards. the breakfast buffet was very nice. the Shinjuku area is so lively. we loved the location of this hotel because it really felt like it was in the center of all there is to see in Shinjuku. I'd definitely return.

The Best Western is your budget to mid range hotel where it's at a great location. At first we had trouble finding the place, however after getting our bearings right it was fine and very close to shinjuku station and surrounded by many public transport options as well as shopping complexes and restaurants. The rooms are adequate size, the staff friendly and check in and out easy but don't expect any frills and bells and whistles. Breakfast was included although personally I found there was not a huge range and the only thing I would be eating would just be the fruits (just personal preference). I wouldn't be going if it wasn't included in our room package and paying the extra. We ended up skipping breakfast at the hotel after the first day. Overall still a good stay and good rooms given the location and price.

Hotel has been rebranded as Citadines.Paid $AU130+ per night and received free buffet breakfast and free wifi. Excellent value; particularly for this location.Room was central Tokyo small. Bed was double and probably due for replacement. Bathroom was excellent. Five minute stroll from Shinjuku station East exit or two minutes from Exit B13 or 15 from the underground (look for Subnade Est in the station as a guide).Entry to hotel is on third floor above a Lawson's.Location is noisy and interesting but I made sure I had my wife with me when I went out at night. We were never hassled and felt no threat at aniy time.At the price, would jump at the opportunity to stay again.

We are visiting Tokyo and we are very pleased to have chosen this hotel. Staff are friendly and helpful.A lovely healthy buffet during breakfast is a highlight.The room is comfortable, wifi is reliable and the bed is just right. Overall the 5 days with great eating, shopping and sight seeing having the base hotel here was a good choice.

We completely regretted booking this hotel purely because of its location. It's bang right in the middle of the red district area and you have the dodgiest looking guys literally outside the hotel doors trying to get people (only locals) to come to their strip bar or brothel. We felt unsafe the whole time we were in this area and we only found out from our Japanese friends afterwards that this area is the most dangerous and unfriendliest area in Tokyo, possibly out of Japan. I just don't recommend staying in Shinjuku at all, unless you love the nightlife of bars and being in the red district area. The actual hotel was great and staff were so helpful and friendly, and speak relatively good English, so its such a pity that they're situated in the most horrible place. Room was the tiniest we stayed out of all the Japanese hotels though, which was disappointing considering how much we paid. Their breakfast food is really average so we actually ended up going out for the rest of our stay. We stayed for 4 unfortunate nights.

This hotel is very centrally located in the action at Shinjuku. Very easy to get to everything and good selection of dining nearby. Room was small (as expected in Tokyo) but very good. Breakfast is good and very helpful service. Would stay here again.

I stayed with Best Western for 6 nights in March 2015. The room is not too small and enough for 2 persons with luggages. It is within 5 minutes walking distant to Shinjuku East Entrance train station and 5 minutes to Uniqlo and Isetan Shopping Mall. However, it will be about 20 minutes walk from Shinjuku West Exit if you're taking the Airport Limo Bus so make sure you request a map from the hotel to guide you. There's no escalator within the train station so with luggages, you will need to walk a big round to from West Exit to reach the hotel.

The hotel is situated near a subway exit however it is rather far away from the Shinjuku JR station where the Narita express runs through. So it was hard work trying to navigate through traffic and crowds with two big suitcases but if you like to travel light then you wont have any problems. Their rooms are relatively standard Tokyo hotel room sizes and it was clean and neat. Their breakfast consists of a variety of Western and Japanese options as well as fruits and cereal (have to try their yoghurt with jam or honey, it's delicious). There are a great choice of restaurants near the hotel and there are a few host clubs downstairs as well. So overall it was an enjoyable stay and the staff were very nice and polite.

Stayed here for 4 nights at the start of our holiday in Japan. It is clean,friendly , modern, well equipped, good sized rooms and provides a good breakfast with plenty of choice. It's just a short walk from the enormous Shinjuku station but once you know your exit and have a map of the station it is fairly easy to find to find your way around. It is in a good location near to shops, restaurants and the quirky bars of Golden Gai. There is a very nice reasonably priced Yakiniku restaurant a couple of minutes away called Blackhole and they have an English menu.

Good location, helpful staff nice stay. You get what you pay for! Nice clean and superbly located close to the metro and one the most enormous stations one can come across. Remember to take many printouts of the hotel location from the metro station available on their website and also address in Japanese so that you can ask around in case you are lost. Remember most maps in Tokyo are in Japanese so be prepared. Recommend this hotel

We found this hotel to be good value. Rooms are a decent size considering Tokyo is known for small hotel rooms. The bathroom was also big enough with a good shower/bath and great toiletries provided. Breakfast was ok with a big enough selection, however not much fresh fruit - which seems to be common in Japan. Our only issue was that we were put in a smoking room - as non smokers the stench was terrible as soon as you got out of the lift on the floor. Unfortunately the hotel was fully booked so we were unable to change rooms. However the hotel went out of their way to help us by providing an air purifier immediately and allowing us to open the window. The location of the hotel is great, with Shinjuku station close by and lots of restaurants and bars in the area. There is no bar at the hotel though. They do provide washing machines and dryers which are very cheap to use. We enjoyed our stay here and would recommend it to anyone visiting Tokyo.

I was at the BW Shinjuku this past May, I found it to be a very clean hotel, great sized rooms for the price, & breakfast offered plenty of fair, Western/Eastern elements. Avoid being out later on in the evening, it is near a "seedy" section of town after dark. Much like any big city, avoid hecklers on the street and life is good. No reason to feel threatened, just wasn't my cup-o-tea. I found this to be an excellent jumping off point to explore Tokyo, being a very quick walk (7 min) to Shinjuku station. The hotel staff was extremely helpful as I am a novice when it comes to Japanese. I would certainly stay here again.

We stayed for a week at this hotel and it was very well located. 5 mins walk to Shinjuku station. Right next to Golden Gai. Lots of restaurants nearby. Staff were all friendly. Rooms are tiny but it's Tokyo and we were barely in the room anyway since there is so much to do in Tokyo. Well priced considering location. Breakfast wasn't great though.

We stayed here for 12 nights for our first trip to Tokyo in March of 2015. The only thing we ever had trouble with, was when we arrived in from the airport and we couldn't figure out how to get from Shinjuku station to the hotel (mind you it was dark and raining).Pros: Free good breakfast, Free WiFi (sometimes it is a little slow), only 5-10 minute walk to Shinjuku station, friendly cleaning staff & front desk, comfortable beds, fantastic amenities and the price was fantastic.Cons: None. We enjoyed everything about this trip and the stay at the hotel!

Pros:- location near to Shinjuku (ard 10-15mins walk depending on which line you are taking)- lots of restaurants and bars around the area with a Lawson convenience store on the 1st floor of the hotel building itself. - helpful English speaking staff- Bathroom is quite big for tokyo standard and comes with complete toiletries including makeup remover, face lotion etc. for the ladiesCons:- Very small room and we had difficulty walking in the room after opening two standard large size luggages. - The area further down from the hotel are all the hostess bars, pubs etc. However, we did not feel unsafe walking in that area or to/fro the hotel to the main Shinjuku train station area.

We stayed ay BWSA last year when in Tokyo, the location is handy, the hotel is clean, the rooms are small (as to be expected in Tokyo) but functional. Short walk to Shuinjuku station (we found Shinjuku-Sanchome just as easy to get to and easier to navigate as Shinjuku station is so big and it’s easy to get lost). Plenty of eating, shopping and entertainment options close by. Don’t think I’d want to stay anywhere else in Tokyo.

It is not easy to locate hotels in the busy Shinjuku area, this one is convenient to be just opposite the ward office, above Lawson convenience store, and only a few minutes walk from shinjuku station. I booked a single room for three nights, I am not sure whether I received an upgrade or not, but I did find the room slightly bigger than the normal business hotel rooms for single, it has pleasant decor with clean and comfy beddings. The buffet breakfast has a reasonably good selection and varied a little in main entries on different days. I find the hotel quite a good choice if one wants to stay near to Shinjuku station and be readily envelop in the hustle of the place.

Okay so the hotel is really nice. As you would expect from Japan, everything is kept super clean and staff are super friendly. I thought it was a great price for our stay of 12 nights and breakfast included. The room was small of course because it's Tokyo but you don't go to Japan to spend the time in your hotel room. The bed was really uncomfortable and the pillows were horrible but we were so tired every night that we fell straight to sleep anyway. Location was great, short walk to the metro and train stations. I heard people say otherwise but we felt 100% safe walking around the area at any time of day or night.

1st time that I stayed at Best Western Shinjuku Astina Hotel Tokyo is in August 2009 and I thought if I have opportunity to visit Tokyo again I will stay at this hotel at least 1 night. Because it is very convenience, very easy to go to many place by sunbway, JR or bus and located in the heart of shopping area. After check-out from Lungwood Hotel Nippori, we came to stay at Best Western Shinjuku Astina Hotel 1 night before go to OsakaJust 5-6 minute walk from Shinjuku Station (I took Shinjuku 3cho-me Sta. B9 exit)Service still good, room is clean, staffs are very helpful, breakfast still good & have more variety choices than 1st year that they opened.Hotel is near everything, Lawson convenient just locate at the ground floor, plenty restaurants, shopping mall near hotel (Isaton, Lumine, Muji, Uniqlo, Keio Plaza,Don Quijote)

Stayed here for 1 week. Rooms were very clean, although tiny, even for Japan. Breakfast was ok. Service was alway excellent. The hotel is a 5 minute walk to the train station which made travel easy. There's a convenience store on the ground floor as well as numerous eateries and shopping centres close by. It sits on the edge of the red light district, although you never feel unsafe.

My first time coming to Tokyo, Japan with my wife for my honeymoon.Trust me as a hotellier, Best Western Shinjuku is value for money.In terms of location is only 10 minutes away from Shinjuku Station ( easy access to Ginza, Shibuya, Harajuku, Asakusa, Roppongi, meeting point to Gotemba & Mt. Fuji ) . In Shinjuku itself theres a lot of entertainment & Shopping center as well. Plus there is Shinjuku Gyoen Park where Sakura blossom.In terms of Service and Quality Hotel, the staff is friendly and helpfull. The rooms size is suitable for 2 persons ( who needs a spacious room over then 30 SQM if spending most of the time is outside of the rooms ). The Cleanliness of the hotel and public area is top-notch.Overall, I definitely will recommend Best Western to my familly and colleagues when they are planning to go Tokyo and definitely I will come and stay there again if go to Tokyo again.Keep up the good work Best Western Shinjuku Team.Regards,Aldy&Della

We enjoyed a couple of nights here on our way to Hakuba. As expected the rooms are small but for a place to put your head after a long day exploring tokyo this is perfect. Showers were great the beds were super comfy and the buffet breakfast also hit the spot. The convenience store at the bottom of the lift also came in extremely handy.

I booked this hotel because it was relatively cheap and all the reviews said the location was excellent. The hotel itself is very clean and smart. The room was very much on the small side but it was sufficient and we didn't plan to spend that much time in the room anyway. The location is excellent and shinjinku is definitely a great location in Tokyo. I had read the hotel was in the red light district and worried but my husband and I joked that we didn't in fact notice this for the first few days. It is fair to say that only on one day towards the end of our stay I was walking behind my husband and a man approached him and asked if he would like help getting hooked up but when my husband said he was with his wife the man apologised profusely and left. A few streets down is the real red light district, but again we perhaps naively didn't at first realise this. My husband described it as the pink techno light district!The breakfast in the hotel is good as well - it provides a hot breakfast which is nice but some dishes are perhaps a bit random for an English person (it includes a beef curry) but they do also do scrambled egg, omelette and sausage as well though don't expect a full English. They also have cereal and croissants. There is plenty to eat. There are loads of good restaurants around the hotel and just a few steps down the road is a British pub that does brilliant drinks and has a great atmosphere in the evening. We went in there most nights. There is also a shop right underneath the hotel which is brilliant and I highly recommend it - it's 24 hours and it sells drinks and also hot food as well as cosmetics and umbrellas! Getting to shinjinku station and getting your bearings can be difficult for the first few days. I recommend leaving a 'building breadcrumb', I.e. Trying to remember buildings as landmarks. It is difficult to spot or see road signs, and in fact I can't remember actually seeing one at all. Mister donut is at the end of the road for the hotel and we always used this to find it. Also the east exit from Shinjinku station is the best to get to the hotel. Again, the hotel provides lots of maps in English showing you walking routes and station exits and the staff - who speak good English - are exceptionally helpful. I highly recommend using the subway to get around and buying a suica (their oyster equivalent) card. The suica can also be used in Kyoto subway and you pay 2000 yen for it with 500 yen refund when you return the card (1500 yen credit) - so don't throw it away! Shinjinku has a number of subway and JR lines going through it but the signposts are also in English. Also the stations now have a letter for the line and then a number for each station - this helps you to decipher which direction you need to go in. We used the subway quite easily.I really do recommend this hotel if you're staying in Tokyo both for location and price. Shinjinku is a great area, and this hotel will allow you to discover it. There are other hotels on the western side which are by the government buildings, but that area is quiet at night and when we visited, it felt a bit far away from the action of East Shinjinku. The last thing is we took a taxi to Tokyo station when we left which cost 3000 yen (about £15). This might seem steep but we couldn't face pulling our suitcases through Shinjinku station which is very busy.

This property was fantastic. It was the second stop on our Japan adventure and we felt right at home. It's in a perfect location, with everything one could possibly need in walking distance, red light district and Izakaya included. The room was spacious enough given how notoriously small Tokyo hotel rooms are. It was clean, comfortable and all we needed, and the bathroom facilities exceeded my expectations. It was very hot inside the room as it was winter and the heating was pumping too high with the a/c doing very little to cool to room down (my only gripe). The breakfast is substantial and contains everything one needs to start their day. Reception staff were approachable and helpful when needed. It's also handy having the lawson store directly below.The directions on the hotel website are very vague, so here are the ones I used when I was there... When you exit the station (east exit) you will see the mizuho bank to your right (across the road), so walk down the alley way to the left of that landmark and head to the next main street, which is Kabukicho. Cross the pedestrian crossing and turn right down Kabukicho. Walk one or two blocks (depending on what alley you turned down), and on the corner a few blocks up you'll see mister donut on the left hand side... this is your street. Turn left and the hotel will be located above a lawson store on the 3rd floor some 300m down. I hope this helps. It's really that simple, and you'll find it no problem the second time. Trust me. I am very happy with this property and will stay here again when I get the opportunity to be in Tokyo once more. We were on the 5th floor with not much of a view so request a higher floor for the potential of a better view. Enjoy!

Stayed for 1 week in Shinjuku, Tokyo. Hotel was a great location, easy to get around on foot and close to subways. The room was small as expected but was clean and comfortable, the bed was very small for 2 tall people though! I asked the hotel staff where their favourite restaurants were in the area, and in a flash they produced the 'best western list'. I was disappointed as they couldn't tell us their personal recommendations as locals instead we headed off on foot ourselves. The hotel lacked personality - perhaps what you'd expect from such a large hotel chain.

No complaints about this hotel. The location is perfect for a first trip to Tokyo. In the 'red light' district, but it's very tame and feels extremely safe. Not like Australian/European 'red light' areas at all. Close to transport, a great area to walk around. Lots of shopping/eating options. Rooms are small, but very sufficient and amenities are fantastic. Bathrooms are spotless. Breakfast is good with both Japanese and western options. Staff are professional. Quiet and secure. Would stay again.

Love this hotel, I came from nirata airport, where I took the train directly to Shinjuku station, where the hotel was a 7 min walk away. The area surrounding the hotel have great places to eat or drink, great shopping and the red light district is very closed by, but I didn't have any problems. There a supermarket just under the hotel, and a 7/11 close by. Great breakfast buffet in the morning, all in all a great value for your money, I would definitely come back next time.

My husband and I stayed at the Best Western Astina Shinjuku in January for four nights at the beginning of our trip. I wanted a central location and access to the JR line. What we ended up getting was so much more then that. The room was small but that is standard for Japan. We were a 8 minute walk to the JR Shinjuku Station. While the hotel is in the "red light district" it was so tame and I never felt unsafe. The breakfast included in our room rate was great. Lots of options. American style and Japanese style food. Additionally, they had a great selection of teas. So nice since it was really cold outside. There is a Lawsons downstairs so if you need any convenience items or drinks you just have to go right outside. Golden Gai is right behind the hotel so if you want to stay out late one night you don't have to walk very far to get back to the hotel. Robot Restaurant is also really close by and a must see if you are in town. Before arriving I emailed the front desk and they were able to make reservations for us at Sushi Kanesaka (Michelin Rated). It really was a highlight. I would highly recommend this hotel and would definitely stay again.
user_name:
Jessica J
South Orange, New Jersey

review_body: One night stay only, smallish rooms but hey it's Tokyo.Good value, clean room with full amenities, convenient location close to action Around Shinjuku but Also not too noisy, decent breakfast bar, wifi was free but very patchy, but overall satisfied good value for money.

Great place to stay. Close to heaps of tokyo attractions. Easy walk to shinjuku station. Felt safe walking around at night. Would easily recommend to anyone want to stay in tokyo.Good service, good breakfast. No complaints at all.

All the basics are solid - clean, very small room, hot water, toiletries, good location among lots of shopping and dining. No lobby area. Well, it's only US$180 via Expedia, nor the Okura. Walked to the high fashion brands couple blocks away.

My partner and I stayed as a couple here in Oct 14. This was our first hotel in japan and i was expecting the room to be small and tiny as everyone usually mentions that this is how japanese hotels are. To my surprise the room was bigger then i expected.. There was a double bed, a couch, a desk and still enough room to open two suitcases. Bathroom is clean and quite spacious as well. Staff are friendly and cater to your needs. Breakfast was included in the room rate and was fine. They didnt change up the menu a lot but it catered for japanese and westerners. Location is fantastic! In the golden gai, family mart next door and lots of restaurants and night life around. Everything else is in Shinjuku is walking distance with Shinjuku station approximately 5-10 mins walk. I found this hotel to be value for money with great location. I would definitely stay here again.

A nice hotel with good facilities. Breakfast had a good range and the rooms were comfortable. A nice price and a good location with lots to do around the hotel. Close to a large station with lots of travel options. I hope the free WIFI continues when it changes hands.

BW Elites use your perks while you can. This BW was quite generous - my basic room was upgraded to executive room (the largest layouts in this hotel) and free breakfast. Great views and enough space for 2 arm chairs and an oval table. The "executive" lounge though was a joke - it looks more like a meeting room with a free vending machine hidden in a corner.The staff here were snarky to non-elites tho. I was extended an early check in at 10am while my friend had to wait for his room to be ready by noon. Do not expect any other perks tho - no gym, no pool, no spa. You will get a 500yen gift voucher (good for souvenirs or future stay) for every day (up to 2) you indicate your rooms not to require cleaning. Many here have already mentioned the great location at the border of the Kabukicho ganglands. The Golden Gai bars are right behind the hotel - check out Nagi for 24/7 sardines ramen and the yakitori bar at the corner for some late night skewers.

Stayed for 5 nights this January. Room was small, made smaller by the inclusion of a chaise longue, not sure why. However it was clean and comfortable, with a great bathroom. Breakfast was good, more suited to japanese tastes but with enough for everyone.Hotel is in a good position, within easy walk of Shinjuku station.We would stay there again.

Everyone told me that Tokyo was difficult to navigate and the subway was complex. It is really not that hard, even if you are jet lagged. Just keep looking for the signs (they are in English as well as Japanese but sometimes can be tricky to spot).I chose this hotel as its just a few minutes walk from Shinjuku railway station which is served by the Narita Express from the airport. The hotel website has a handy map you can download from its website that gives you directions. It is REALLY easy. Took just a few minutes even pulling a trolley case.The hotel staff were excellent. Check-in was fast and efficient and they had noted my advance request for an early check-in and had the room ready over 2hrs before their normal time. That was really good as I was super tired and just needed to rest.Rooms are small by European standards but average for Japan. If there are two of you I think you'd have to be pretty organised with your luggage and quite neat in order to avoid it feeling cramped. Clean and modern though. They offer you an 'opt out' from daily cleaning as a way of saving the planet... if you agree to it and don't have your room serviced for two days they will give you 500JPY gift voucher. It is not as easy as it sounds so check the conditions!Location is great, Shinjuku Golden Gai literally behind the hotel, easy walking to shops and subways and the breakfasts are pretty good too, plenty and a nice variety. Often my breakfast lasted me until mid-afternoon when I had a 'coffee and cake' break meaning two proper meals a day and a snack... so I save a little bit on expensive meals out.There is a 24hr convenience store downstairs if you need extra snacks, beer or pretty much anything at any time. They speak a few words of English too which was helpful. There is a 7 Eleven a bit further down the street with an ATM/cash machine that works with non-Japanese cards (many only work with Japanese cards), so that was really useful.There is free wifi in the room BUT oh lord... it is slow!! No matter what the time of day or night it is really painfully slow, or inconsistent, which meant that often my searches timed out and Skype/Facetime was impossible. It made it tricky to check maps, local sightseeing info etc. Sort this out and it would have 5* rating from me!

This hotel proved a remarkable deal for us when we wanted to try a new neighborhood on a visit to Tokyo. We took a very affordable suite, the Executive Twin, for just over $220 a night (probably made possible because of an off season and with a favorable exchange rate). The room had a great view, large comfortable beds, a good living area, lots of storage space, and excellent sound proofing. The room contains a small refrigerator and all the other regular conveniences.The hotel’s official map, available on their site, was effective for getting us there easily. Breakfast, maybe not luxurious, was able and filling, housed in a bright space overlooking the street. We also fared well upon arrival at Udon Dining outside of the hotel, on the 2nd floor of the same building complex.

The reviews here are already pretty thorough, but here's my brief take. The hotel was in a great location- so close to Shinjuku Station and tons of bars, restaurants and shopping. There are a lot of hostess clubs around the hotel, but I felt quite safe even late at night. There is a Lawson right downstairs and a Seven-Eleven about 2 doors up the street. We stayed here for 9 nights with breakfast included. The buffet breakfast got a bit boring since they only change up one or two dishes, but it's decent enough. The room we had was on the 11th floor, with a nice view (on the Golden Gai side) and I didn't find it to be particularly small, I thought it was a good size for two of us, however, I'm used to New York apts, so it's subjective. The bathroom was nice with a tub and semi-separate shower. I was glad they had a small laundry facility, I used it twice during the stay, FYI the detergent is dispensed in the wash automatically. The hotel was clean and the staff were friendly and helpful. I know this Best Western was bought out by Citadines, so not sure what will change, but I would definitely stay here again.
user_name:
Jenyc_native
New York City, New York

review_body: As many have pointed out, this hotel is well located to explore Tokyo. Make sure you know how to get to the hotel before arriving at Shinjuku station. This area can be pretty daunting to navigate first time around. It is a 5 minute walk once you know where you're going.The hotel rooms are small but, as I understand, average for Tokyo, and typically Japanese clean. Don't do breakfast in the hotel, not good. Rather go out and find something better for less $$. This is the only reason for a 4 rather than 5 rating.Yes, the hotel is in the red light district, but if you weren't told that, you wouldn't know. We felt very safe, even at night. The immediate area buzzes 24/7 and has a multitude of restaurants and bars, not to mention other weird and wonderful attractions. Make sure to visit the warren of alleyways behind the hotel that is the Golden Gai. Fascinating! The Lawson's convenience store under the hotel is very useful.Staff were very friendly and helpful. One tip - If you're catching the bullet train out of Tokyo to Kyoto/Osaka etc, give yourself more time than you think necessary to get to Tokyo Station (possibly go to Shinagawa rather, the bullet train stops here).If you don't mind walking, I would suggest a walk from Shinjuku to Shibuya via Yoyogi park in Harajuku. Another cool and free attraction was the view from the Metro Government building in West Shinjuku. On a clear day you can see Mt Fuji.

We stayed for 2 weeks in the summer and absolutely enjoyed our stay. We had no complaints, the hotel was very clean and located conveniently near the JR Shinjuku station. The staff was very helpful and understood english very well. The rooms are larger than the average hotel room you can get in Tokyo. We stayed on the 11th floor where we had access to the executive lounge on the 13th floor, it was nice to enjoy free hot drinks and views that were different from our hotel room. one great perk of staying here was that all toiletries were provided and restocked daily, it was something less that we had to worry about while traveling. The morning buffet was delicious, offering both wester and Japanese style breakfast. I would definitely recommend this hotel to everyone. Families shouldn't worry about the location of the hotel either, it is safe and no one bothers you!

This is my second stay at BW and i am very sad to hear that they have been sold to Citadines. I hope their service quality and offering remains.Firstly, the location of this hotel is amazing: it is walking distance to Shinjuku JR station as well as the subway lines. Secondly, if you get a twin room, the bathroom contains a large bath tub: you don't have to go to an onset. Thirdly, they put out a complimentary brekkie which is generous.How to get there?Your hotel is one of the first rises on the street heading into Kabuki-cho with Mr Donut as your landmark. If you are coming from Shinjuku station, it is pretty easy to get lost manoeuvring/walking to the hotel. So, print a map, hop on a cab and it will cost you Y1000 to get you from Shinjuku station to the hotel. Very short ride but will save sanity and marriages. Once you have oriented yourself, you will realise how close everything is but so easy to get lost. The best exit for BW is the Shinjuku East station exit. If you get lost on the tunnels of subway: come out immediately. Staying underground makes it more disorienting.Tip 2: get a high floor so you get to see all the twinkle lights.Tip 3: the executive lounge is where you can sit and read the paper/ipad in peace. There is a machine which dispenses extremely sweet coffee and tea.Tip 4: make your own tea and coffee before heading to lounge.Tip 5: the hotel produces their own Shinjuku local map and a train map. Take a couple. I have saved a lot of lost people using these maps. No other hotels produce such a comprehensive map.Tip 6: if you are non-Japanese, you will not get hustled by the local pimps (did i say pimps? yes but they are respectful of you). You will, however, get hustled by black hustlers who are aggressive and rude. Think hustlers at the base of Eiffel Tower and you will get my drift. The local hustlers get into conflict from time to time with these foreign hustlers. So, what to do? Head down and don't make eye contact.Lawson is your local 24 hour supermarket. At the escalators of the hotel, if you turn right and walk down the street and take the first left, there is a supermarket which stocks gazillions brands of whiskey, sake,wine and cheese. This fave "tuck" shop of mine is about 10 mins away. There is no duty so stock up as much as you want. This brings me to Tip 5: bring bubble wrap so you can go home with exquisite sake tucked into your luggage.Tip 6: You have run out of money. Where do you go for currency exchange? Head towards Shinjuku JR station. There is a cake place called Ducky Duck. Ducky Duck is opposite Citibank. You can change your money there but the rates are awful.When you see Ducky Duck, walk to wards ABC Mart and you will see a decorative rock in the middle of the road. Take a right and you will see Mizuho Bank and SMBC bank. Both have better currency exchange,Tip 7: There are these crazy Matsumoto drug stores which are always always full. If you bring your passport, you will get 8% off.Tip 8: Uniqlo in Tokyo is very different from all the shops globally, They sell everything..i mean everything. Again bring passport to get tax free.Even though BW is in the middle of a red light district, as a woman, i never felt hassled and always felt safe. Of course, be vigilant. The hotel is quiet too. And if you want extra privacy, there is a ladies floor only.
user_name:
Yappas
Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: We spent 4 nights at the hotel in late November as the last stop for our trip. Took us a while to find the exit from Shinjuku station. Easier if taking B9 exit from underground walkway.Hotel check-in is a breeze and they provide child amenity kit. We stayed in a Executive Twin A room and there are 2 semi-double bed pushed together. Great for family use though walking space is tight. Room is clean and fairly new. Bathroom is great with a nice big tub. There is a router in the room cupboard so wi-fi is good. To access executive rooms, guests need to tap their key card in the lift to go up to their level. There is a executive lounge (looks like a meeting room) on level 13 with free vending machine drinks/coffee/tea. There are 2 dryers and 2 washers in the hotel.Our room comes with free buffet breakfast and spread is quite ok. Surrounding area of the hotel gets a bit "interesting" around nightfall so better to head back early if you are travelling with kids.Overall, we enjoyed our stay and will consider staying again if we visit Tokyo.

This is the best place of my 10 day trip in Japan. It's comfortable, modern, clean, bright. Staff were helpful, hotel is convenient to Shinjuku Station (nearly all trains stop here). It was easy to find during the day as most landmarks can be easily spotted and the hotel logo can be seen from the main intersection. At night, I would suggest you have good GPS loaded as it's not as easy to find.

This hotel is in a fantastic location right in the heart of Shinjuku, close to the station and for those so inclined, next door to the Golden Gai. The staff are incredibly helpful even setting up a couple of dinners for me, weeks in advance with prompt replies via email. The superior room (on the 13th floor) was a decent size, very good bathroom and shower but the bed was on the very firm side and the pillows extremely firm (a couple of cheap feather pillows from a local dept store helped). Unfortunately most of the room and TV controls are in Japanese which is complicated to work out, you can also get some residual noise from the street below. For a tourist like me who doesn't spend a lot of time sitting in a room but gets out and about, this is a great hotel for you.

I initially had a hard time finding my way to the hotel from the bus stop I got off from, but I lucked-out and ran into an extremely helpful local that walked me to the hotel that didn't even appear to be a hotel from the outside. However, once I checked into the room, I was impressed by how immaculate and contemporary the room was! While not the largest of rooms, it's still bigger than your average Tokyo hotel room, and it was very accommodating to say the least. The staff were helpful and responsive when I kept pestering them with emails about my laptop accessories that I had absentmindedly left in the room after checkout, no English barriers whatsoever. The included breakfast buffet was meh, nothing special to write home about, and I could have sworn their scrambled eggs had enough oil in them to power ten vehicles, but you could easily reach for other breakfast proteins. The only knock on the hotel (and this isn't even the hotel's fault) is that it's situated in a slightly seedier neighborhood. Every night, I had these Cameroonian guys approach me, pretending to by my friend and wanting to introduce me to ladies at a club. But hey, I learned that they don't bother you much if you sprint by them, so they kept me in shape during my vacation.

We stayed for 5 nights during our family vacation in Japan. We chose this property for the convenience locale. It is a short walk east of the Shinjuku Station. There are a lot of shops & restaurant along the way. There is a Lawson convenience store on the ground floor of the hotel building. The 7/11 is a couple doors away!The rooms are small but adequately equipped. The price is reasonable when compare to others in the same area.One big drawback is that the hotel is in Shinjuku's red light area. There are many night clubs and karaokes near the hotel. We could hear people screaming from the streets in our room on the 12th Floor at 4am in the morning!It is not exactly a family vacation spot. Luckily, all my children are grown adults.

I had a very pleasant stay at the Astina hotel. Very attentive and helpful staff. Just off Yasukuni dori( street), a hop to Isetan(flag ship store),JR Shinjuku station and many other tourist spots. The room is large, compared to the other hotels I have stayed in Japan. All in all a very good place.Advice to any one who wants to save some money commuting to Narita. Take the Yamanote line to Nippori and catch the Keisei limited express( platform 2) to Narita. The total travel time is approximately 2 hours. Try to avoid rush hours if you have too much luggage. The fare works out to less than 1000 Yen. If you have too much luggage you could use the luggage delivery service to and from your hotel ( around 500 Yen per piece), there will be a 1 day delay in getting your bags. So if you are going to the airport, do it the day before.Cheers!

This hotel was barely identifiable to the untrained eye. As you can see from the pictures the words "Best Western" hardly appear on the building (there was a small sign upon closer inspection). Once we found it, we found it to be very accommodating and centrally located. Our room was small but was adequate and clean. There was plenty of shopping and restaurants located nearby and the neighborhood felt generally safe. Would stay again. A bargain for such a high demand area.

I enjoyed my stay at the Best Western Shinjuku Astina Hotel. It is conveniently located, relatively close to the Shinjuku Train Station, and is an easy walk from the station Just be sure you have GPS or a detailed map available, as there are many narrow streets in this area and finding the hotel for the first time may be confusing. There are lots of restaurants nearby and plenty of choices for night life. The staff was exceptionally friendly and helpful. The room was nicely appointed and I loved the Toto toilet with the heated seat. The room was immaculate and the bed was comfortable. The breakfast which was included in the price of my room had great choices each morning. You could even skip lunch as there is so much to eat on the breakfast buffet. I would definitely stay here again!

Smack in the middle of shinjuku, this the best hotel for you to explore Tokyo. This is our third time staying at Best Western and it will always be our favorite hotel in Tokyo. We always stay in executive floors for more privacy and bigger rooms.

We used to stay at the Hotel in Shinjuku where the airport limousine stop for the convenience. This time we booked the package deal(air+hotel) led us to pick Astina! It turned out to be a great surprise!! First of all, location is great : it is very close to restaurants, shops, Department stores... . On top of that, the staff were very friendly & helpful, the breakfast was very good, curry beef, stir fried beef, teriyaki chicken nugget, loved them all! Of course the room is clean , spacious & comfortable!! We will definitely stay here next time we go back to Tokyo!!

Best western offers clean modern facilities in the heart of shinjuku's red light district. It is also conveniently located right next to golden gai. Its easily accessible from the east end exit of shinjuku station. There is also a 24 hours convenient store located directly downstairs. Breakfast selection is good and staff are fridndly.

The room is small (I heard most of hotel rooms in Japan are fairly small so no complaint here). The hotel is comfortable and reasonably priced. The heated toilet seat is awesome!!!The breakfast is very good. I can eat the miso soup, beef teriyaki, and chicken karage all day everyday :D there is a mini market next door where you can get water or basic amenities. They also have a money exchange machine in the lobby (the rate is not bad).Overall, my boyfriend and I enjoyed our 5 days stay at this hotel and would recommend to visitors to Tokyo.

The hotel is located centrally for shopping, eating and transportation by rail. Stayed 3 nights, excellent breakfast, clean rooms and very spacious for Japan standards. Exploring the walkway in the back of the hotel leads you to many back streets, restaurants and bars. On the main streets, many nearby banks,major shopping and restaurants.

We stayed there for two nights. Our flight from Chicago to Tokyo got delayed by 24 hours and local staff were very sympathetic and understanding (upgraded us as a result of our miserable experience with United Airlines!) Very good service at front desk. Excellent breakfast. Clean rooms. Spacious by Japanese standards and beautiful modern bathroom. Perfect location for those wanting easy access to subway and exciting Shinjuku. Only real critique is that it is difficult to find when you first arrive in Tokyo and do not speak Japanese! Would definitely recommend to visitors to Tokyo.

I stayed there 4 nights at this place and it was pretty good!! Free wifi, good selection of breakfast, convenient location, many restaurants, many department stores nearby and 8 min walk to Shinjuku Station. It's in heard of Kabukicho, so on the weekend and at night it was loud!! Many young people hanging around the escalator which leads to lobby. Other than noise factor everything was great. This room had huge bathroom and comfortable bed.

I think I may not be completely fair in my review as I stayed at the Sunroute Plaza Shinjuku (which was just excellent in terms of location and everything else) for 4 nights at the start of my trip and stayed at the Best Western Astina for 1 night at the end. I paid the same rate for both. The location of Best Western is close to the East exit of Shinjuku but is still a good 7-10 minute walk. There are no lifts to the ground level at the East exit so you will need to carry your bags up the flight of stairs. The area is at Kabukicho and as much as it was safe, I would not want to stay here as a alone female. Probably not the best place for children too. We stayed on a Friday night and it was very noisy. I am very sensitive to the noise and you can hear the noise in the rooms too. We were on the 9th floor. The hotel itself was clean and the staff very friendly and warm. The breakfast was a good spread but got very crowded and people had to wait for tables. Do try the Korean pancake stall that is located just a few metres from the hotel. Cheap and so good. There are many restaurants around so dining options are plenty. If you don't mind the area, this could be a good option. Directions which I got from somewhere online:1. From Shinjuku station take a Central East or East exit to Kabukicho.2. From outside JR Station look for big MIZUHO billboard sign at the top of building on your left and ABC Mart on your right.If you take the right exit, Mizuho sign cannot be missed.3. Walk straight in the valley from there until you see Family Mart on your left and little crepes stand name Marion on your right (the end of this valley) and immediately turn right.4. From there walk to the first traffic light and at the crossing look for Mister Donut accross the road. Walk in the street and Best Western Shinjuku Astina will be on your right side.

I cannot say enough good things about my stay here, but suffice to say it was the perfect hotel for a week's (7) stay in Tokyo. Located within walking distance of the train station, restaurants, shops and nightlife, but just far enough that it wasn't noisy. Hotel staff were very helpful and pleasant, we had the buffet breakfast everyday as part of the hotel package and it was good, catered for all cultures and lots of options for breakfast.Wifi was free and so was the TV. Rooms were large, comfortable and clean, service was great. Definitely recommend!

Stayed here with my partner for 2 nights. Rooms are fairly big, very clean and quite handy. They provide lots of amenities such as slippers, robes, bathroom needs (hair ties, earbuds, face towels etc). Gotta love the heated toilet seats!The hotel room was great, comfy beds and spacious enough for 2 large suitcases plus a little cabin bag. Free wifi is a plus also.Only down side was the TV had to be paid for per night... 1000 YEN I think. Which is not bad if staying for long period but not worth it if staying for 2-3 nights.The hotel was quite close to Shinjuku station, however locating it was not easy. Shinjuku station is HUGE and quite stressing if being lost with a rush of people going from different directions. Best to ask the Information desk to get to B9 exit. TIP - Buy the Suica card from any green Suica machine with a penguin, much easier than single tickets.Only reason rated this 4 stars was because in reality it is quite pricey. I got $100 off from booking it with an agent at the time, otherwise it would be close to $400 AUD. Ask for WiFI password at the front desk.

Average hotel in good location, bang in the middle of red light district, 5 mins from Shinjuku station. 100's of shops bars and restaurants a stones throw away. My room was very small and very expensive, not sure how other reviewers got large cheap rooms?? Also not sure how one reviewer didn't notice this was in red light district, didn't you go out after 8pm or look at the name of the bars in the building opposite!!??? I would stay here again however as the location was great for a weekend in Tokyo.

Visited tokyo for a quick 2 to 3 night business visit with 2 other colleagues. Choose Best Western Shinjoko for near the center of Tokyo and some site seeing. For the price we paid I can highly recommend to stay there as the rooms are decent and clean. Right down stairs there is plenty to eat and drink. Staff are friendly. So if you are on a budget in Japan you can't go much wrong in choosing this hotel.

The rooms are fairly large by Tokyo standards (they even have a closet and drawers). The location is right in the middle of the entertainment/red light district, but what impressed me most was the helpfulness of the staff. We were in with the flu one night and our video on demand wasn't working. Instead of just making a note of it, the front desk man came up to the room and fixed it for us. They also arranged for our luggage to be sent to the airport, avoiding crowded trains with 3 weeks worth of bags. The breakfast is worth getting.

This is a very comfortable, reasonably priced, hotel, located at a fantastic location with in close proximity of one of the major stations in Tokyo. Please dont worry about the red light district location of the hotel, for 3 reasons: 1- The red light district is a lot more toned-down that those of European cities. Dont think "Amsterdam"; its not like that. 2- The district is further down from the hotel. You wont have to go through the area on teh way to the station... if you want to go to the area, its a 3 minute walk though! 3- The lcoation actually gives this hotel a bit of a character. Its a lively area with lots of bars and etc. Its basically like Soho in London, but the Japanese version! Also, the touts dont bother foreign tourists anyway!The breakfast is very good. Its not traditional, but it caters for all tastes and is more than adequate. There are LOTS of restaurants around the hotel. There isself-service laundry facilities on the 7th floor. There is also a supermarket on the ground floor if you need anything, and a restaurant on the 1st floor that serves good ramen!All in all, this hotel is fantastic (and the staff speak English and are very friendly!). If you are travelling as adults, like us, I would not hesitate to recommend this place.

We really, really, enjoyed our stay here. After leaving another hotel because it was dirty and disgusting, we truly enjoyed our stay here. The rooms are clean, comfortable, and beautiful. The bathroom are really nice, with beautiful decor. The continental breakfast was really good, with a wide selection of food. The staff are all courteous, friendly and speak great english. The only down side of the hotel is that it is in the "red light district", with lots of men standing on the street trying to get men to go into the bars where women host men. Being a couple we thought that simply saying "no" to the services would suffice - but they're pretty persistent. Lots near by - restaurants, malls, shops, and the subway is about a 10 minute walk (to Shinjuku station).Once again, if you need the comfort of North American, there are lots of fast food joints around. The the local food is amazing!

Great for new visitors to Tokyo and especially young people.Excellent location near big department stores such as Isetan. JR rail and other subway trains nearby. Link to Narita airport close as well.All of the above are walking distance.The area is a bit "rough" with nightlife girl-bars and clubs, but it can be passed quickly.Hotel is one of the best Best Westerns in Asia. Price is reasonable, rooms are fine (small but this is Tokyo!) and bathrooms large and very nice, with large rain shower.Definitely would recommend this!

Great location so close to the station this allows you to get around Tokyo very easily and the staff were so helpful and friendly. Rooms smallish but to be expected in Tokyo. Very clean and surprisingly quiet also. We stayed on the 11th floor facing the main street and didn't have any major issue with noise. Free Wifi was great and the breakfast was good again with excellent service. Would definitely stay again and recommend it. Airport Limousine was an excellent service also.

I really enjoyed staying at the Best Western Shinjuku. The staff was very friendly and helpful with both directions and helping us arrange the takyubin (luggage forwarding) to our next destination. The room itself was small, but probably above average by Japanese standards. We found it to be quite comfortable and clean. Many toiletries were provided as well. Our room was on the 6th floor and faced the front of the hotel, but we didn't have any issues with noise. The Free WiFi access worked well for us too. The breakfast was included and had a good selection of western and Japanese foods. The best part was the location - it was only a 5-10 minute walk from Shinjuku station. It is located on the edge of the Kabuki-cho (red light district) and behind the hotel is Golden Gai - an area with very small bars which was an experience in itself. For my wife and I, we never felt unsafe in this area and actually really enjoyed this location. Downstairs was a Lawson and a 7-11 was a few stores over (for those whose cards only work at 7-11 ATMs). Large department stores, and stores like Muji and Uniqlo were only a few minutes walk away.

Loved this location. Perfect to go to the Robot Restaurant. Great for walking and late night bars. The golden Gai is right behind this hotel. These little shack like 4 seater bars are great to see. The hotel itself was clean and staff was friendly and helpful. I would def stay again. Hotel is ideal for young people because of location. Just be careful at night if alone. Japan is pretty safe overall but this area is very close to red light district so just a little extra vigilance would be good.

I always stay at the Best Western when I travel to Tokyo. It is conveniently located, around 5-10 minute walk from Shinjuku Station. It's also less than 5 minutes from the Shinjuku Sanchome underground exit E1, near the Hanazono Shrine.The easiest way to find it when you land at Shinjuku Station is to take the South East Exit (near "Gap"), walk across the street and down the road with "Green Peas" to your left. At the traffic lights, keep going 'straight' (it's a little dog-leg zig across the road) - there will be a Kinokuniya to the right and a Suit Factory to your left. At the next lights, cross diagonally towards Mister Donut. Pop down the paved alley (pedestrian traffic only) and when you see a convenience store concourse area on your left, this is where you catch the lift to the third floor for reception. It's tricky to find the first time, but very convenient once you know the way.The hotel is on the very edge of Kabuki-cho, convenient if you want to visit the 'red-light' district, and on the edge enough if you'd rather avoid it. During the day, you are no more than a 5-10 minute walk from tonnes of great shopping such as Isetan, Marui Department stores and Muji, Kinokuniya and more.The hotel itself has a really welcoming atmosphere, especially for a business hotel. The staff always go above and beyond, even calling the City Office to help me organise my wedding! Nothing is too much trouble for them, from storing luggage, to helping with travel plans, to dealing with my multiple bookings for 9 people on various visits over 1 month (November 2014). Even though the Japanese are known for their service, the staff here exceed expectations with their genuine and kind manner.The rooms are small, but comfortable. Housekeeping is excellent, the rooms are always fresh and clean, with complimentary bottled water supplied each day, along with nice cosmetics, shower supplies and other toiletries. We love the new oil cleanser packs! The bed is comfortable, with a double-sided pillow so that you can choose between 'Western' style or a more textured Japanese style pillow. The bathroom is excellent, not a pre-fab room, but an actual, real, tiled bathroom.Breakfast was included with our room, with a great selection of fresh items for both Western and Japanese tastes. Even though November is extremely busy in Tokyo, we never had to wait for the buffet. I love the Best Western and would not hesitate staying here every time I'm in Tokyo. My only regret is that it was booked out for my last few nights and I had to stay elsewhere.

BAD POINTS:1) Lots of pimps under and near the hotel property. Best to access the hotel using the back lane.2) WiFi is super slow3) Machine-like services and they insist on 2pm check-in although room is available. Can't really feel the services as we were hardly feel the existence of the hotel staff.4) Poor breakfast. But well, it comes with the rate. GOOD POINTS:1) Easy access to Shinjuku station entrance2) Happening neighborhood 3) Good room service 4) Can keep the luggage after you check out

Hotel was easy to find, just look for mister donut. Room was clean and the staff friendly, they made reservations for us at restaurants and a tour. Hotel is in middle of Shinjuku so it's great for going out. Shinjuku is an interesting neighborhood so be prepared.

The hotel and the room itself is ok. It's the neighborhood that disturbs me. The area seems quiet at day time with Muji big store in the front of the alley, but at night time you would find black guys hanging in front of restaurant with Japanese cute girls poster...and also Japanese guys calling in customers. Such a weird ,red light-like district.. so I didn't like it that much. Oh, and the wait for breakfast buffet is long.. so I passed.

We arrived late at night and the Hotel is actually on the third floor so would be easily missed. After going up the escalator we realised there was a lift to the right of the entrance but did not find that till later. Very helpful staff, very nice place and in a good location even though it is supposed to be the Red Light district. Would not have known if I had not read it here. Located just off the main street of Shinjuku but would not have known from the little noise we heard.Breakfast was a feast, staff friendly and the room was excellent. Would definitely stay here again.
