room is quite small but very very clean. i asked that our room be cleaned everyday and everything were changed each time, even the cot cover. everything i needed were provided in the kit, body scrub, even facial wash, moisturiser, cleansing oil, pony tails, hair brush, cotton pad etc. i just love it that they have a complete set of what i needed. breakfast is delicious everyday. staff are super friendly and very accommodating. above all, their location is the best! i will surely stay in this hotel when i come back to tokyo. this is the first time i travelled that i became so attached with the place and felt sad that i was leaving. i love best western shinjuku astina tokyo ;)

Stayed in Nihombashi which was way too quiet at night so relocated to the Best Western Astina for the rest of my stay in Tokyo. First impressions of the Astina were not so good, reception area was cluttered with cheap Halloween tat which made the place look awful, then corridors and room had a terrible stale smell (I think it is from the carpets), tiny room with locked windows. Asked for another room, same stale smell. Thankfully the rooms have airfreshners. No foreign t.v. channels. Breakfast was good although they had no vegetarian dishes at lunch.The hotel is in a fantastic location, on the edge of Kabukicho. If the area is too overwhelming then you can walk to Yasukuni Dori or through Golden Gai where you wont be approached by touts. We got approached by touts every night but just laughed them off. Kabukicho is really tame compared to other red lights in other countries, was wonderful to see alternative Japan like drag queens on the street and staggering salary men trying to find their way home. I found Shinjuku Sanchome metro station to be alot nearer and user friendly than walking all the way to Shinjuku Station, there is a subway exit beside Hanazono Shrine, a couple of minutes walk from the hotel. I heard the Post Office has a good exchange rate but the nearby Post Office on Meiji Dori does not have currency exchange, best place I found was UFG Bank near Shinjuku Sanchome Station with total commisions etc of 3.7% .

We chose to stay here, primarily based on the good reviews on Tripadvisor -- and we were not disappointed with the room (having adjusted our expectations, from reading the comments by other reviewers on the room size). Certainly, good value for the price paid considering the modern bathroom (separate shower and bath tub, heated toilet bowl), free wifi (good connection throughout our stay), inclusive of buffet breakfast (good simple spread), and proximity to Shinjuku shopping area. The Golden Gai area (right behind the hotel) is worth a walkabout -- would recommend trying the ramen at Nagi (a tiny hole-in-the-wall first-floor ramen shack in one of the Golden Gai alleys, that's opened till late). Laundry facility at level 7 of the hotel was a plus point (no need to purchase washing powder as it gets dispensed once you put in the right amount of change into coin slot; and there's a dryer as well).The walk to Shinjuku station was a lot further than expected. Found the multiple exits confusing. With hindsight, would have chosen to stay in the Shibuya area instead (which has a nicer vibe).

We stayed there three nights. It was difficult to find a hotel, which offered a good price while situated close to the JR Shinjuku station. Finally we were settled in this Best Western Hotel.Location: I expected it to be quite close to the JR station but it turned out to be not. You have to walk for 10 minutes from the hotel to the station. If you have to take local trains of other lines, it may take you more time to find the platform. But consider its room rate, it was fair enough. It is also located in the Kabukicho area, where you can enjoy nightlife in Tokyo. If you are fancy of pubs and bars, this hotel will be a good choice for you.There is a convenient store downstairs. And you don't have to worry about finding a restaurant as it is one of the most lively areas in Tokyo at night. But the bad point is, the streets around are packed with people, especially when it is a Friday night. People enjoy themselves with drinks and some may just yell on streets. It's kind of annoying. Room: We stayed in a standard double room. The lobby is on the 3/F and our room is on the 4th. I am impressed with how the room insulated sound from outside. Despite the nightlife downstairs, we barely heard noises in the room. We slept well during our stay. Size of the room was just right - not big but not too small. It was also clean and well maintained. Staff: some can speak English and they provide up-to-standard services.

This hotel is in a very good location en Shinjuku, their personnel is extremely helpful and friendly, the breakfast is pretty good too, and the honesty of their personnel is in the top, I just forget one of my Smartphones but the manager was just waiting for us to come back in order to pick our luggages up and then return the phone to me

Our family stayed here for five nights. The location is close to Shinjuku Station and shops and restaurants. The only downside to this hotel is that it is in the red light district. However, there is a 'walking' street at the back of the hotel so you can avoid the main street. There is also a convenience store downstairs.The hotel is very clean and beds are comfortable. The staff was friendly and always ready to assist you. We would certainly stay here again for our next trip to Tokyo.

I wasn't expecting much from this hotel, so I got what i expected - mediocrity. I guess the price is OK considering the location, but really, the architects could have applied a bot more flare - well, any flare at all would have been good

I book at best western in june for our family trip this dec, but i decided to check this hotel last week as an advance party for my family and i didn't regret one bit. The hotel has a good location, a mere 5-10 min walk and you are in bicqlo, isetan, marui area where shops and restaurants are aplenty. All the staff are very helpful and polite, especially Aya, Satomi and Yuya. I have been bothering them prior to my trip and they have diligently replied to my email. Just look for the mister donut in the corner and walk straight on the same side, you'll be at the hotel in no time. This hotel is not a grandiose one like park hyatt but definitely it serve its purpose of being one.

Great place to stay.... Apparently this is the red light district of Tokyo...really???? It's wonderfully busy. We picked a tour up from the Hyatt Regency and it was in a dead area....no atmosphere....but plenty of homeless ppl living under a bridge...anyway..back to the great little Best Western Astina....I would definitely stay here again...breakfast was great...staff friendly (everyone is in Japan!!!)... We are staying another 2 nights when we get back to Tokyo in a few days....but not staying here...I wish we were...One thing to note....we didn't know there was a lift to the right of the escalators wen we arrived late the first night...so dragged our tired selves up the escalator...and up the last maybe 10 steps into the reception area...just remember there is a lift to the right.... LOVEABLE this place

A lot of travelers have mentioned the great things about this hotel - the location right in the heart of Shinjuku, the very good breakfast buffet (both Western and Japanese offerings), the 24-hour convenience store downstairs. One thing I would add regarding the location: even though it's only 10 minutes from Shinjuku Station, it is NOT an easy walk when you've traveled for 30 hours and are carrying your luggage. We only travel with one carry-on roller each, and dragging them through the packed streets of Shinjuku at night turned out to be a very bad idea. Get a cab from the station when you arrive.The rooms are very clean and well-designed, but small enough that one side of the bed was flat against the wall and there was only one side table. Even for tall folks though, the bed was pretty comfortable. At least there's no footboard, so my 6'7" husband could let his legs dangle off the end. The bathroom was actually a nice size, considering the size of the room, and the tub was deep enough that I could use it comfortably (I'm 5'10"). The hotel provides two bottles of water (free) daily, which I always appreciate, and there's an electric kettle in the room with tea and coffee bags (although my mom, who had a single room across the hall, did not have a coffee setup in her room). Ask the front desk for restaurant recommendations. They gave us a very good map with several different types of restaurants within walking distance marked in English. One soba place in particular, Daian, was really special (see my separate review of it if you're interested). The udon restaurant downstairs is also very good, especially on the first night when you're travel-weary and hungry.One very special touch: we happened to stay here for Culture Day (Nov. 3), which is a national holiday honoring the traditional Japanese culture and promoting the love of freedom and peace. When we returned to our rooms after an amazing day at Senso-ji Temple, we found two origami cranes which the staff had made and left as a gift. One is now sitting in my office and the other is in my husband's. What a lovely gesture. I highly recommend this hotel - the only reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 was the size of the room, which started to close in on us after 3 nights.

Great location for the Shinjuku nightlife and shopping. You are literally right next to the Golden Gai area. Rooms are compact but not too small and it was a good value for money stay. Walking distance to Shinjuku station.

This was our first trip to Japan and was recommended to stay in Shinjuku and I am so glad we came across this fantastic hotel. We stayed here for 5 nights in October and will be back to stay here again. We were given a room on the 11th floor which is non smoking (thank god)! Rooms were average size for Japan so knew to expect a small room but we didn't feel that the room was too small for us. The bathrooms are modern and an excellent size with walk in shower and the beds were very comfy! Breakfast was excellent with a mixture of western and asian cuisine. Breakfast area was a bit small so at peak times you could be waiting a while. Location of the hotel was excellent, felt like were amongst everything. Restaurants, bars, shopping! We were walking distance to the subway & metro which was super easy to find! I will definitely be back to stay at this hotel and will recommend all my friends and family to stay here as well!

This was my first hotel experience in Japan, having just arrived in Tokyo, and Shinjuku is a marvellous area to stay in - it feels like you are in the middle of all the action and there is so much to see and do!! When I heard I was staying at a Best Western I thought - "Ok, Best Western, it'll be clean and comfortable, nothing exciting" - this place is awesome!! It is well located in Shinjuku, an easy 10 minute walk from the station. The reception area is warm and peaceful and the staff are very pleasant and welcoming. They charge you your bill for your stay when you check in, so you only have to worry about any thing extra you buy at the hotel. Breakfast was included in our room rate , and we were given the credit in the form of vouchers which you present to the staff at breakfast time, The rooms are immaculate and comfortable! You can sort of hear the noise outside but not enough to keep you awake all night, and the blinds do very well at keeping the room nice and dark for a good peaceful sleep. The bathroom was a good size, complete with a combined shower and bath, and the shower had great pressure and temperature!! I also loved how the hotel provided almost every toiletry you could possibly need - complimentary - even though there us a 24 hour convenience store in the same building :-P The breakfast buffet was wonderful, offering a wide array of cuisine - western style breakfast: cereals, fruit, yoghurt, toast, croissants, eggs, sausages etc -- and also the more traditional offerings in a Japanese breakfast. It was very high quality fresh food!! The hotel is really well located -- with a 24 hour Lawson convenience store right downstairs if you need anything, and the whole area of Shinjuku is buzzing with great restaurants and shops!! I won't stay anywhere else in Tokyo, I know where I will have it good!!

The great: Everything is in walking distance and so much to take in. The parks are amazing, plentiful and close. It is very close to the Shinjuku station to catch a train to where every you need to go.The good: The only memories I have of a Best Western was staying at motels during car trips as a kid. But the reviews were great and decided to take a chance. It was worth the savings over the Hilton and Hyatt which were only a few blocks away. The rooms were very small but comfortable. Service was great and we had free breakfast every morning which was a plus. If you don't have that as part of your hotel stay, just wonder down the street to Dunkin Donuts for a quick cup of coffee and donuts :o) The bad: Ask for a high floor. There is a lot of street noise from midnight to 3pm. Also, the staff didn't have very good insight for western visitors. We asked for dining recommendations and we received very little input. We ventured to the Hyatt to talk with their concierge. We got great tips where to eat and were told to always venture into the basements of the large office buildings. It was an amazing tip. Each building has several shops and dining options. The food was very reasonably priced, authentic and they always had "happy hour" specials. Do not dine at the Hyatt or Hilton. We looked at the prices and a burger was $50 USD! The ugly: I knew this place was too good to be true. During the day, it appears to be part of the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. But after 10 pm, the street transforms to a redlight district. They have many "gentlemen's" clubs where many drag men were soliciting for patrons to join them in the club.

Location of the hotel is excellent, based about 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku station, which is an excellent station for metro and also connects directly to the airport. There are also loads of restaurants and shops all close by.The hotel itself felt very modern and clean, the room was very small but this is not unusual in Tokyo. The bathroom was actually well spaced and all fittings were very modern.Breakfast buffet was ok considering it was included in the cost of the room. We did not try any of the other restaurants. I would recommend getting a taxi from the station though, Shinjuku is very hectic even though the distance is short and easy to navigate once you know the way. You need to exit out the east exit and there is a taxi rank just there.

- located at the center of the most bustling area of Japan, Tokyo Shinjuku Kabukicho.- approximately 10 minute walk from JR Shinjuku station, world's busiest transport hub. A bit of a walk from the JR station but it was an interesting walk.- great breakfast buffet.- right by a convenient store.- coin laundry machine.

My first stay in Japan/Tokyo. Was not sure which area to pick, but Shinjuku is a good choice. Hotel is near the station and close to shops and dinning. Room/bathroom are clean and a reasonable size. Good service and nice breakfast buffet!

We had a superb and wonderful 6N/7D stay at the Best Western Shinjuku Astina Hotel Tokyo. Love its easy access to almost everything that a traveler would need...Shinjuku train station, a huge variety of restaurants and shopping malls such as Isetan,Takashimaya,Muji to name a few and many more. Though it's location is just minutes away from the heart of the red light district, we felt very safe and no unpleasant experience at all. I traveled with my husband and our two teenage boys.Room - was kind of small by our standard but because we are in Tokyo, the size is acceptable. Toilet was neat and clean. Free two bottled water are provided and replenished everyday and so as the basic personal hygiene kit.Staff - can speak English, courteous, helpful and so accommodating. Our request for a higher floor was granted and my sincerest thank you to Aya, Satomi, all the front office and Stella staff and of course the housekeeping for always making our room clean and tidy to rest after a long day of exploring Tokyo. My son deeply appreciates the welcome chocolate with birthday greeting card and so as the birthday cake for bringing it up to his room was such the sweetest gesture. You guys rock!Stella has a widespread of hearty breakfast to kick start the day. Can't complain about the food choices for they have what we usually eat in the morning:coffee, tea, bread, milk, cereals, rice, egg, fresh fruits, yogurt, vegetable salad and many more.On our first day, we had walk from the hotel to the National Gyoen Garden. The garden is huge and so beautiful. You'll need at least a day to see everything in there.The Fee is 200 JPY. Hanazono Jinja Shrine is about 3 minutes walk from the hotel. The following day we took a cab from the hotel to Kagurazaka and paid 1,350 JPY where we had our lunch. Kagurazaka is a good place to relax and enjoy good food. It has traditional Japanese small shops with plenty of restaurants tucked away along the side streets. We had the best lunch and bought good quality of different types of tea and a teapot to go along. I wish we have stayed the whole day.Overall, we had a marvelous Tokyo holiday, enjoyed our day trip to Hakone, an interesting star wars ride in Tokyo Disneyland, gastronomic feast in Kagurazaka and saw the magnificent Tokyo Sky Tree and was able to do some shopping on the side along the way.Best Western Shinjuku Astina Hotel Tokyo will always be our number one hotel choice whenever we are in Tokyo!

Our experience staying at Best Western Astina Shinjuku Tokyo is delightful althoigh there was some hiccup on our firat night. On 3am fire alarm was ringing and inside the room there is a speaker but they only said in Japanese and when we call the reception of course the line is busy. Then eventually they picked up the phone and explaining there is some error with the alarm. Nothing dangerous. They did put an apologetic letter in our room. I just wish tgey speak english on the speaker so we dont panic. Overall staying at this hotel was not bad at all. Location pretty near shinjuku st. Room is a wee bit small but most of hotel in Japan is very small so i have no complain. Good points are: breakfast taste great0 compare other hotel qe stayed in Japan. And bathroom is big (again, compare to other hotels in Japan)

Very Good HotelClean & Comfort BedHotel breakfast buffet is Nice(but almost everydays the same things)Hotel canteen's staff are very friendly and welcome usCan see alot of restaurant for a short walk around 5-10mins

highly recommended, the hotel is 100m from the center of Shinkjuku, in the middle of everything - food, karaoke, shopping, fun. Very smart because of the small supermarket on the ground floor, should you need water or other quick foods. Washing machine available for guests small rooms but in the very typical Tokyo-style (by the way, bigger compared to other hotels we experienced). Excellent bathroom, wide shower, good supplies of room kimonos and beauty stuff. Price fair enough, huge breakfast included (buth Japanese style... Means beef and chicken at 8 am!!).

Love the service and location, even if it is located near the red light area, we felt very safe at night. It is a short walk from the east exit of the Shinjuku train station. We could walk to the pickup location to our day trips booked on Viator and using the train was an easy way to see the city too. Our room was on the 12th floor (#1203) right off the elevator and facing the street, yet still quiet. Its small but clean and had all that we needed, for a four night stay (9/23-9/27). The staff was great, as most of them spoked English and was very helpful. Breakfast was excellent, with a nice choice of selection. Right next door is a great restaurant and if you like shopping there is a lot of stores too. I hope to return some day and stay here again.

Excellent location – the hotel is a mere 2 minute walk to Shinjuku Sanchome Station (metro), 10 minute walk to Shinjuku Station (JR). Golden Gai is just behind the hotel, literally a 1 minute walk. There’s a huge variety of restaurants and shops close by. There are some hustlers outside, but they are more polite than most waitresses in Australia. The rooms are small by western standards but you’re not going to Japan to stay inside a hotel. Services and amenities are perfect.

Centrally located in Shinjuku, very helpful staff and good standard of the room which was absolutely fine size-wise (economy double 17 square meters) which can be hard to find in Tokyo. Had read some reviews about the breakfast not being good but we found it being totally OK. We paid half of the price here compared to the 2-stars MyStays Asakusa so the value for money is really great. Can overall recommend, for a more quite room request one not facing the street.

1. Reservation ProcessWe booked through Hotels.com. I found choosing a room quite confusing but this was not the hotels fault, I wish I had booked with them directly as their website was clear and had the best rates. 2. ArrivalI had put in a request for early check-in because I knew we would be arriving at the hotel at around 10am as we flew all night. When we arrived unfortunately my request couldn't be accommodated. We were however upgraded which was a nice touch. The reception staff spoke great english (maybe not as great as other countries but you'll soon learn that barely anyone in Japan speaks english so they do a great job). In terms of finding the hotel, we had no trouble! We took the east exit and followed the sign to Kabukicho and then looked for the Mister Donut and there it was. About a 5minute walk and as our weeks stay went on we found more and more shortcuts to get there quicker. 3. The roomExtremely small! We stayed in a 'Double Room'. We had low expectations however because I chose the hotel based on Trip Advisor reviews we knew how small the room was going to be. In saying this however the room had everything we needed - a comfy bed, good shower and toilet. We also had quite a nice view over Tokyo too! I found the room to be quite well set out for the space there is to work with. My only complaints would be firstly, that we couldn't get our air conditioner to work and the room got quite stuffy but the directions were in Japanese so we just left it - if we had really wanted I'm sure if we called staff they would have helped but it didn't phase us too much, and secondly, that the pillows were HORRIBLE. I ended up sleeping on my clothes some of the time because my neck got so incredibly sore. Shower water pressure was great. I must also comment that the rooms were EXTREMELY clean which I think is a determinative factor in my overall impression of accommodation. 4. BreakfastOk so this I would say would be the major downfall of the hotel. We only had breakfast at the hotel 3 times as we just couldn't stand it. If you are happy with REALLY basic food it's fine, but we got over potato wedges and onion rings. There were barely any fresh fruit options either. We tried 'Bills' in Harajuku one day - amazzzzzing! You must try the hotcakes - see seperate review! 5. LocationThis was the best part of the hotel. It was close to everything! We weren't concerned with spending our holiday in the hotel room, we just wanted a good base, and it didn't disappoint. With Lawsons downstairs, Shinjuku shopping just minutes away and the JR station only 5 minutes walk, it was PERFECT! If I have any tips for you if it's your first time to Tokyo - bring your walking shoes! We left the hotel room in the morning and by the time we returned in the arvo we had walked about 13km each day. In terms of being in the red light district - I am quite young and I never had any trouble. Some of the nigerians approached my partner one night however we just kept walking and they didn't bother us again. Definitely nothing to worry about at all and I am very safety conscious. 6. One extra pointOne night we were woken by a fire alarm at 3am. It was actually quite stressful as the alarm was only in Japanese so we didn't know what it meant. It was only another couple who could translate across the hall who alerted us to the fire. We walked down the 12 levels only to find no staff at the bottom of the building at 3am. We went back to reception to find lots of other guests standing around not knowing what to do. The reception staff were quite casual about the situation, saying it was a mistake and we could go back to bed. I'm not sure whether anyone actually checked that it was a mistake as it seemed no one really knew what was going on. Lucky for us there was no fire but I would be worried in the future should the same thing happen as not all guests knew what to do and half of the people didn't even evacuate. We received a letter of apology the next day but that was it - I found this quite strange!OVERALL:I would stay here again. It was basic, but it was also much cheaper than other options in Tokyo, and I wouldn't waste my money staying somewhere which I considered just to be a base for exploring. Yes there are things that could be improved but it was fine for me.

It's cozy. It's near a lot of restaurants and activities. It's near the train station. The rooms are quite big for Tokyo standard haha!The breakfast is also nice and adequate. There's also a convenient store below the hotel.

5min walk to Shinjuku, not far from subway station, shops and restaurants. Off busy road, convenient for a shopping fun which you can always put your shoping bags back to the hotel and keep on going. Loved Lumine est! Breakfast ok, staff were ok.

I stayed here for five nights late October. The hotel is located very close to JR Shinjuku and Shinjuku subway stations from where you can travel almost anywhere in Tokyo and directly to Narita Airport which was ideal. The staff were very friendly and helpful. One lady kindly offered to rearrange a mount fuji tour pick up point to make it more convenient for me. The breakfast was sufficient but could have included a few more fresh fruit options. I had to queue to enter the breakfast room on two mornings because there weren't enough tables. My bedroom was compact but comfortable and the bathroom was well appointed. As with other Japanese hotels, the only English language tv channel was cnn which became repetitive after a while. The surrounding area is very busy and hectic 24/7. It is a nightlife area but not overly seedy - it's comparable to Soho in London. The hustle and bustle was fun but after five nights I was getting tired and ready to move on. I think the hotel is better suited to short breaks of 3 or 4 nights. You get good value for money in a convenient location with friendly service.

Stayed here for 5 nights (Oct 13-17). A bit of trouble initially finding the hotel, but it was at night, raining and we had been traveling for 24 hours. During the day we easily got oriented and appreciated that it was only 10 minutes from the Shinjuku station. The front desk staff was very helpful - they had 2 pieces of mail for us when we arrived and helped confirm a tour for us. The hotel was clean and quiet. This is Tokyo, a lot of people in a small space, so rooms are smaller than US standards. But this is normal and adequate. The breakfast buffet had a great selection of Western and Eastern foods (much better than other hotels we later visited). The udon noodle restaurant on the 2nd floor of the building is also excellent. And the 7-11 right down the street is incredibly convenient. We loved the neighborhood. Never felt unsafe. It was lively and fun. The Golden Gai area is directly behind the hotel, a really interesting place to wander both during the day and night. I highly recommend this hotel and would stay again.

I booked a cell up the road for only 19 dollars a night, and in the morning I would eat at this Best Western. I have got to say that it is the best deal around. If you are not staying at the hotel the price is about 15 US dollars, which is nothing in Tokyo. You can have some really nice salmon, and all the fresh fruit you want! Cereal was great, coffee awesome, and the croissants and butter and all the other items were really perfect. Japanese foods along with Western dishes made this awesome. If you eat at a local place for breakfast it will cost you half this, but you will not be full, AND you get all the coffee you want here.
user_name:
worldexplorer130
New York City, New York

review_body: This was our second stay at the Best Western since our last trip to Tokyo last year. We love it here! Fantastic hotel, comfortable room and we are much more familiar with the area now. It feels like they have improved and taken in some of our suggestions from last year as well.In terms of location, we have always known that the hotel is in Kabukicho and a quick look on Google shows that this is the red light district. In reality, the hotel is really more on the fringe of the red light district, so we never felt that was of any issue. If anything, it just adds a bit of colour to the areas around the hotel! It can be a bit of a long walk from Shinjuku station but if you walk through the Subnade, it is an easy and leisurely walk. The Lawson's (convenience store) in the same building (on ground level) is as convenient as ever. We were there picking up little snacks to pack in our bags as we headed out for our big days in Tokyo. Highly recommended hotel!

Located in sort of a red light district, definitely not appropriate for ladies to stay. Was being touched at the arm n touted almost every night. Room was freaking small, washing machine and dryer are two separate machines and of cause it's not free. Asked for an extra bottle of mineral water because i'm having a bad cough and we ran out of water, the staff told us to pay and still ask us our room dont have? Why would i ask for a bottle if our room has it. Well definitely I wont be back to this hotel. Quite a walk from JR Shinjuku

Great hotel and staff. Fantastic hot and cold breakfast included. Hint: don't have a daily room cleaning and you get a 500 yen gift card per non-cleaning day - we bought a Sake set with ours. Great value and very nice staff.

This hotel is very clean and the service from the staff is very high. I think both myself and my partner were pleasantly surprised. I would not recommend this hotel for families travelling to Tokyo as the surrounding area morphs from a time square vibe during the day to what it is part of the red light district.

Excellent property for a sightseeing and relaxing holiday in Tokyo.Situated in the happening area of Shinjuku.Shopping,dining, nightlife----you name it.Within walking distance of Shinjuku Railway station from where you have train access for anywhere in Japan.Hotel staff effecient,courteous and ever helpful.Excellent housekeeping and room service.Good breakfast with a variety of choice,only a few more choice of fresh fruit would have made it excellent.

Great little place in Shinjuku - although the rooms were a little small, they were very comfortable and clean. The concierge were very helpful and provided us with very helpful maps/instructions and so on. Breakfast was provided as part of our stay which was very convenient. A very comfortable and convenient located hotel with very reasonable prices - would recommend.

Good location in Shinjuku district, close to the Shinjuku main station. Lots of restaurants around. Hotel provided free internet. Staff is friendly. Rooms are a bit small size, but good location and good price makes up for it.

Shinjuku is such an exciting area of Tokyo and this hotel gives you the opportunity to stay right in the middle of it. The reception on the first floor is welcoming and the staff speak good english. The rooms are good for Central Tokyo with extensive toiletries and the usual yukata and slippers. Breakfast is good with lots of choice, both western and Japanese.

The hotel is pretty close to the Shinjuku train station (this metro station is a confusing maze). Leave out the East Gate and it is about 10 mins northwest (look for the Mister Donut). The area immediately around the hotel is a little seedy, even though the city government offices are nearly across the street. Just walk a block south and the area improves a lot. It is completely safe, however, and there are lots of tourists and other people around, so nothing to fear. The hotel itself is good, starting on the 3rd floor of the building and going up to the 14th floor. The top 2 floors are "executive" floors, and the next 2 down are designated for "business". I don't know if the rooms are any different, but you do need a card key to access these floors and not the others. My room faced the rear of the building and was quiet. I never heard my neighbors, although I think I might have just been lucky. The breakfast buffet is the standard fare with hot and cold offerings (was included with my rate). The biggest find: two washing machines and two dryers on the 7th floor. 300 yen to wash, 200 to dry (laundry detergent automatically added to the wash). This was a really nice feature of the hotel. The internet access is barely acceptable. Wi-Fi signal strength is high, but the bandwidth is very limited. My SlingBox was brought to it's knees, and downloading email attachments was slow. The TV has no English channels, so lack of good internet access makes watching internet TV impossible. The hotel needs to do something about this. The staff was very friendly and accommodating. As for Shinjuku area, there is a really cool area of small alleyways with little bars tucked in due East of Shinjuku station, but overall I didn't love it. I'm not an expert on Tokyo, but I found Shibuyu and Harajuku a little nicer.

There isn't much to say in favour of this hotel ....oh apart from being close to Shinjuku station!The hotel is like the gateway, or side fence to the red light district! At night you get hassled, pulled, grabbed and followed by spruikers! The spruikers were aggressive big men who shook your hands then wouldn't let you go. If you got away they follow you to the edge of the boundaries calling to you until the next spruikers gets you! There is NO security at the hotel to stop them following you up to the evelevator.The hotel staff were uninterested, unhelpful and inattentive....nor did we get one smile from them.The Executive Lounge was a laugh! A table, some chairs and a drink vending machine for coffee.The rooms were small; as were the beds. My bed had a definite lean to it so I felt like I was sleeping up a slight hill on my tiny pillows. The shower was in the top 5 best showers.With the rooms facing onto the "red light" district be aware that the blinds do NOT keep put the lights.... we were on the 13th floor and it was like daylight! The noise itself wasn't bad though.Not a place for woman, young kids or people who don't like getting hassled constantly.We asked for a later check out as we were on a 9pm flight. They wanted to charge us based on % of the room rate....per hour....... e.g ours was approx USD75phr

The rooms are cute and cozy and gave me that happy feeling I enjoyed in my first studio apt. As the hotel itself is only a few short blocks from Shinjuku Station, it is perfect for anyone one who wants to spend their days exploring Tokyo's neighborhoods and taking daytrips utlizing the rail system. You can then spend your evenings at your liesure exploring Shinjuku's nightlife and the Golden Gai on foot. There is no need for a taxi, you are right there. The post office is also right up the street a few buildings down and there is even another post office (a short taxi ride away) that stays open 24/7 for last minute packages. The included breakfast has a wide variety of Western and Japonese choices and your breakfast coupon can also be exchanged for a restaurant credit at Stella or for credit at the Lawson's convience store downstairs which has everything you need to eat if you slept in late (ready-made salads and sushi, hum boas, boiled food, juices, snacks and a variety of meat skewers). The staff is awesome and ready to help 24/7. The rooms and the bathrooms are clean, comfortable & well equipped. There are also laundry facilities on site which I didn't personally use but appreciated non-the-less. Overall the hotel is really a great value and perfect for solo travelers or couples. The week I stayed, the couple next door to me shared their room with their young daughter who was able to comfortably sleep on the chaise lounge next to them. Any more than that probably wouldn't be possible.

Lovely clean hotel. so glad we chose to stay here. it was our honeymoon so they upgraded our room to the 11th floor, the room was small, but everything in Japan is small. the room was very clean, fridge, wifi, had a seperate shower and the deepest bath ive ever been in! The area is the red light district but we never got hassled or anything. it was about 5 minutes from Shinjuku station so very local. the staff were very helpful, spoke very good english. We chose to have the breakfast and it was very nice, could have done with a bit of varity though as i was a bit sick of eating white bread by the end of the holiday! didnt fancy fish or fried chicken for breakfast, Could have done with some brown or fruit toast. Overall it was such a good stay. Tokyo is an amazing place!

Such a great location! this hotel is right in the hub of Shinjuku and is walking distance to local restaurants and bars. The rooms are modern and clean, and the staff are very attentive and helpful. Would stay here again!

We stayed one night on our way back from DisneyTokyo before we left Japan. Room was clean, well appointed, decent size. Staff were attentive and spoke great English! Breakfast was included, which was appreciated. The breakfast buffet was generous and had a good variety. Our room was clean and the entire hotel is modern and well decorated. The location was actually good, just a few minutes from the JR Shinjuku station and about a block from the subway line. My ONLY complaint was the neighborhood; our room looked over the Golden Gai ("that looks interesting" my husband quipped) and there were a lot of men touting their nightclubs on the street. Practically pulled my boyfriend and I into one at night! I probably wouldn't stay at this hotel if I were on my own, but it was okay with my husband.

Extremely tiny rooms. I dislike the location of this hotel, which is in the Kabukichō neighborhood. I couldn't walk on the street of the hotel without being hassled by touts. I would not stay in the neighborhood if I were to visit Tokyo again.

Very convenient hotel. Good quality price with attentive staff. Good breakfast buffet selection, bit busy for the size of restaurant. Take your breakfast before 10am. The rooms are clean and quite spacious for Tokyo, nice amenities salection.

This is a great budget hotel for the days when you're out exploring Tokyo. It's only 7-10 of minutes from the JR Shinjuku station and a couple of minutes from the subway line. There is a convenience store next door. The rooms themselves are very small, not much more than a bed but very clean with attentive staff. FYI on location, it is on the border or Shinjuku's "red light district" so the walk from the station / prefecture center to hotel is fine but just a few yards further you can see the promoters trying to get people into clubs. Didn't bother us but something to note.
user_name:
Jose L
Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

review_body: This hotel was perfectly adequate for our needs when visiting Tokyo. It was a bit of a walk from the station but once you get your bearings it is fine and there is an entrance to the subway just 2 minutes from the hotel. Staff were friendly and professional, rooms were comfortable and of average size. Breakfast was provided daily which was a great way to start the day. Convenience store downstairs and lots of nightlife. However I found the east side of Shinjuku much too busy and I think I will book a hotel somewhere else next time. Overall a good stay and a decent base for exploring Tokyo.

We took ages trying to figure out the best place to stay for our first trip to Tokyo. We had booked another hotel in the district, but I wasn't happy with it, so we got out of that with a small cancellation fee and after further research booked the Best Western for 5 days. We were really happy with our choice. The location is perfect (right in the action, but quiet and peaceful up on the high floor where we were). Bed, very spacious and comfortable and a great bathroom. All spotless. Also easy walk to the Shinjuku Station. We were a few minutes from the Golden Gai district where there are many tiny, quirky bars in small laneways. We went for the executive room with breakfast and we'd recommend that as much more space and we had a great view. Staff were really pleasant and helpful (lent us umbrellas for the rain) etc. Breakfast was very nice, lots of choice and staff provided maps of the area, subway maps etc with their recommendations for local restaurants and outings (e.g. cat cafe) etc. All in all very good indeed. We would stay here again as it's great to have a base that offers so much in location, price and quality.

As usual, rooms are not so big (but are quite good for the Tokyo standards), but are really clean and nice. The location is ideal, only 10min from Shinjuku main station. The neighbourhood may seem special for some guests, but also comprises several points of interest. Even if the area is vibrant, noise level is low inside the rooms. We were really pleased with the overall quality of service. A great choice in Tokyo eastern area.

I was unexpectedly in Tokyo overnight because of a typhoon and followed some fellow Americans into Tokyo to this hotel. What a gem! The room was very small but very, very clean and the hotel was so quiet you could hear a pin drop. Loved the surrounding area! Would definintely come back and recommend to others. Breakfast was also really good with a fun assortment of items. Hotel is located just a few blocks from the Shinjuku station, which is one of the stops for the Narita Express train.

Booked this hotel because of all the good reviews and was not disappointed. About 10 mins walk from Shinjuku station East exit. Had a semi double room which was big enough for both the bed and the room size. Bottle of Water, new sleepers, clean bedding every day. Breakfast buffet was good and with fair choice of European and Asian food. Staffs were excellent and helpful. The location is a great with easy access to shops, bars and shopping. Would definitely recommend Astina Best Western hotel.

It was a pleasure to stay at Best Western Shinjuku Astina. We stayed here for 5 nights during our honeymoon in Japan. Location is great! Nearby to JR Shinjuku Station and lots of restaurants and shops and shopping malls around this hotel.We arrived a little early before check-in time, and our room was ready. Definitely a plus point.We reserved our room with breakfast. Breakfast was superb, a great selections of food from Japanese to Western.We were given some chocolates and a welcome letter from the staffs congratulating us on our wedding (we mentioned in our reservation that we are on honeymoon)Another great thing about this hotel is that, they are promoting "Go Green" environmental solutions, so if we do not asked for our rooms to be cleaned for a day, we are given a 500 yen vouchers which can be used in the hotel... so yeah, it is a great thing to play a part to save the environment.Definitely will return to this hotel on our next trip to Tokyo.

great breakfast best ever. very good value. great location. best deal in Tokyo. will return in future. easy to use local trains to get anywhere in town. safe to walk the streets excellent excellent excellent can not say enough good about hotel..

This hotel in Shinjuku is great location. It also has very nice rooms. The room was bit bigger than I expected. There is a cuboard to hang clothes if you prefer, but there was enough space to push chair & table over and put suitcase on ground. The bathroom was really spacey and nicely renovated.Breakfast was nice with mix of Japanese and western food. I stuck to cereal & fruit. Worst Cappacino I've ever had though! Instant coffee with froth on top! Lucky there was a Nice coffee shop within walking distance. Train station was only 10 mins walk. Plenty of restaurants and bars all around. Behind the hotel is a Gia Corner which has streets of little bars which fit about 10 people. It's so interesting walking around. Many bars are up narrow stairs. Really intriguing.Nice hotel, I recommend.

Loved the hotel. Trust me when i say that as a first timer to tokyo, i deeply regreted not taking a taxi from the shinjuki station to the hotel. We took the airport limousine shuttle from narita and it dropped us off at the station's west exit and it took us over an hour to find the hotel. I think the only reason we found it is because a nice lady at an electronic store let us use the computer to get specific directions. Well, maybe we could've prepared better and gotten the wifi portable device that everyone else had. A pre printed map is pointless since u are gonna get lost on tokyo, no matter what. Check in was smooth and we got a nice economy double room overlooking the street. It was small, as expected, but offered great amenities. Front desk was more than helpful with directions. If we ever come back to tokyo, will definetely stay here again.

Compared to the mediocre Best Western brand name in the US, the locations I stayed at in Sydney and now Tokyo were very nice, with design and finishing a little better than other options in the same price range. My room was a standard single and expectedly on the small side, although it still had a full-size bed and even a couch, desk, etc...The price included breakfast, which had a few Western/Japanese items and was good enough to start the day. I have mixed feelings about the location. Shinjuku felt like the busiest part of Tokyo, and it was a short walk to the station (a major hub for JR lines), but most of the time it was challenging getting through the crowds. On the other hand, seeing hyper-urban Tokyo was cool, though I would probably prefer to stay in a more peaceful area like Ueno next time. A couple of notes - the famous "Golden Gai" bar area is right behind the hotel, and if you are a man, actively avoid the African men outside of the hotel - they will aggressively push you, even grab you, to go the bars they are promoting. Considering the area, it would be hard to find another hotel of the same price/quality.

Me and my boyfriend spent 4 nights here while visiting Tokyo and were very impressed! Perfect location for anyone wanting to explore the area and the station is a 5 minute walk away from the hotel. The rooms are lovely and clean and the staff were very helpful (especially with letting us leave our bags here before check in time). Also the added bonus of free wifi for guests!

I was very satisfied with my stay at the Best Western Shinjuku. The hotel is well situated near public transportation and amenities the staff was very accommodating. I had to send my luggage to Kyoto as I was doing a side trip to Nara, and they easily arranged it for me. The breakfast buffet had adequate choice and the food was good.

We stayed as a couple at this hotel Sept 23-25 in a double room on the 11th floor. It was reasonably priced, has a great location and is generally a good deal if you book a few weeks ahead. The nearest metro station Shinjuku-sanchome, is only a few minutes walk away. However, like most large metro stations around the world, the walk between the entrance/exit and the actual train can be quite far. Just make sure you choose the right exit to minimise your walk.Isetan and other stores are just 5-10 minutes away on foot. Of course, the main Shinjuku station with connections to just about everywhere, is not far away either - about 10-15 minutes walk at the most.The hotel itself has very clean rooms that are reasonably roomy. All necessary toiletries were provided. The reception staff are friendly and speak good English. There was free wifi which was very fast as seems to be typical in Tokyo. One drawback is that the sound proofing is not the best as we were able to hear voices from the next room and footsteps from above. The noise wasn't too bad but can be a problem if you're a light sleeper.

Although the hotel is very close to Shinjuku Station, it can be quite difficult to locate. Once you become familiar with the area, it is a very convenient hotel in the Shinjuku district for exploring Tokyo and the surrounding areas.We found the staff to be very helpful and polite at all times, and spoke very good English. I would recommend this hotel as a base to explore Tokyo.

We had a 3 beds for the 4 of us for 4 nights and although the room was a tight sqeeze it was great. Currently we are staying in the same area in are far more expensive hotel with more room but the location is no where near as handy to shops and the main station. We felt perfectly safe in the area.

Nice hotel close (<10min by walking) to the next train station. You'll find in the close proximity shops, shopping malls, cafe, restaurants, bars and the red light district. The room was very clean, quiet and the furnishings are on a modern level. Friendly staffs are serving in Japanese and English language and supporting your stay as good as possible!

This is the place to stay if you want to be in the thick of everything Tokyo has to offer. You're right on the door step of all the bars, shops, restaurants and general hustle and bustle. The rooms are small but nicely fitted. The buffet breakfast is average but I think it's included in the room price for all guests. The coin laundry is a bonus. Staff were friendly and accommodating. I would stay here again for sure. As a side note don't bother with the udon restaurant underneath the hotel- it's overpriced and average food.

The Best Western is a great hotel chain world wide.So, when I saw they Had one in Shinjuku I had to stay!It is backs up to the Golden-Gai bar district and around the corner to the red light district and entertainment district and a couple blocks away from Don Quixote buildings.From the Shinjuku train East exit it small 7 US dollar taxi ride to the hotel. They have a map of the area and surrounding areas and metro map for you to have at the lobby area.I really recommend this hotel for this area!The room was great, bathroom was even better with hot hot water and all the bathroom amenities one needs.They also have a shoe shine polishing mitten and shoe horn for free as well. I wanted to dress up nicer while in Japan so these came in handy!The hotel breakfast very good and a wide variety of food was available at the free breakfast.The downstairs lawsons mini mart was great to get some pre-gaming Suntory whisky and beer.

The Best Western is a great hotel chain world wide. So, when I saw they Had one in Shinjuku I had to stay! It is backs up to the Golden-Gai bar district and around the corner to the red light district and entertainment district and a couple blocks away from Don Quixote buildings. From the Shinjuku train East exit it small 7 US dollar taxi ride to the hotel. They have a map of the area and surrounding areas and metro map for you to have at the lobby area. I really recommend this hotel for this area! The room was great, bathroom was even better with hot hot water and all the bathroom amenities one needs. They also have a shoe shine polishing mitten and shoe horn for free as well. I wanted to dress up nicer while in Japan so these came in handy! The hotel breakfast very good and a wide variety of food was available at the free breakfast. The downstairs lawsons mini mart was great to get some pre-gaming Suntory whisky and beer.

A hotel right in the heart of the shinjuku nightlife ! an amazing location for a hotel and i love how everything ( and i do mean everything!) is within 2 minutes walk! there are bars, malls, trains and even a small temple nearby. Try walking the back road of the hotel and you will encounter some quaint pubs that is not visited by many. Room is small as per japanese standard but everything else is top notch. Oh yeah, as i mentioned this hotel is in the heart of the shinjuku night scene so you can expect to hear the lively buzz in your room. if you want someplace quiet, this is not for you

What a superb hotel for Tokyo...very clean, modern, close to Shinjuku Station and a very good breakfast for an excellent rate overall. I could not be more pleased. 2 minor items: the rooms are on the small side, but not unusually small for Tokyo. The wireless internet in the room was slow, but functional. Overall, probably one of the best hotel values I've found in Tokyo.
really convenient to stay here. The service is quite good and the price is nice. It's just a bit pity that their beds and pillows are too hard for me.

Booked a smoking room which was the only option through the website, arrived and asked for a non-smoking room which they gave us, as well as upgrading us to a bigger room which was great!Rooms were decent enough, small compared to other countries but relatively sizable by Japanese standards. Standard amenities included - kettle, toiletries, an above average powerful hairdryer. Bottles of water were only complimentary on the first day. Free wifi in rooms which could at times be slow.Complimentary breakfast was a somewhat eclectic mix of Japanese and Western. Not a great lot of choice, but nevertheless did the job.Staff were friendly enough, English was local but able to communicate. Don't expect staff to help you with luggage etc.Locationwise - a few minutes walk from JR Shinjuku Station which was great (East Exit is closest to the hotel) with lots of bars, restaurants, shops close by, and a convenience store right underneath the hotel. However.. the street parallel is the red light district which is pretty obvious at night - a lot of touts inviting you into sex clubs etc. That being said, didn't really feel any aspect of danger, even at 3am. Do expect a level of noise if your room faces the street, even from 12F can still hear the hustle and bustle at night.It was a decent enough hotel (especially as we were out all day and only spent time there sleeping) but I would choose a different one if I were to return to Tokyo.

Great service, the room good size for Tokyo, interior of hotel is well kept. Quick 5 minute walk to the JR line East entrance, subway even closer. Kabukicho is active 24/7, but safe and sane. Great room for the price. Pillows were HARD as rocks!
user_name:
Dexter T
San Bernardino, United States

review_body: A comfortable, but compact, hotel pretty much in the heart of Tokyo. Nice decor and layout in the rooms, although (with a lot of rooms in Tokyo anyway) very small - much smaller than what I was expecting! The bathroom was clean and well set-out (actually bigger than the bedroom section!), with electronic toilets! What I was impressed about was the bathroom dispensers for shampoo, shower gel etc. They come in large containers, rather than the small, one-off containers that you would normally get elsewhere. This method saves both resources, and doesn't pressurise you into using small amounts unnecessarily.The staff also provided a miniature toiletry set for my son which I thought was both novel and considerate.In terms of location the hotel is a bit difficult to find, although it is no more than 10 minutes from Shinjuku Metro station or the bus terminals that link Tokyo to other parts of the country.We travelled directly here after landing at Haneda Airport, and it took ages by bus due to the traffic!The area is Tokyo's version of a red-light district though judging by the number of seedy looking establishments and love hotels, so be wary - especially if you're travelling with family. However, there are a couple of decent supermarkets if you need to stock up on supplies, and several nice restaurants to go to in the evenings that are reasonably priced.Breakfast buffet is a bit limited in choice and variety as well.There is no ATM on-site either which can be inconvenient. I also think that the rooms should be fitted with "blackout curtains" as there is a lot of light pollution in this part of Tokyo, although noise was not an issue.Overall I'd say this was a good choice, but slightly on the pricey side.

This place was really easy to find and was in the heart of Shinjuku's Night Life. The rooms were comfortable and the views from the rooms were spectacular. I'd for sure stay here again next time I'm in Tokyo.

Best Western Astina ShinjukuA nice, good hotel with small, clean rooms in a great location.It has a business hotel feel, but had a lot of tourist guests and is a great value hotel.I would definitely return.Pros: This hotel is all about location, location, location.It's within walking distance to the train station hub that is Shinjuku, a ton of shopping/department stores, restaurants and bars/nightlife. If you are looking to get out and see Shinjuku/Tokyo this a great hotel.The rooms are clean, updated and well stocked (toiletries, tea/coffee, etc.) There is free wifi throughout the hotel.The restaurant has a good breakfast buffet, and the staff was very pleasant and very helpful.Cons: The standard rooms are small, although probably par for the course in Tokyo. (There were bigger rooms available, but they were way more expensive and not worth it for us.)The hotel itself does not have a lot of amenities, like a bar, gym, pool, etc. The breakfast buffet was good, but kind of redundant with almost the exact same thing every morning.If you are looking for a more plush hotel, perhaps look elsewhere.**Please note that Shinjuku can be a difficult area to navigate, and this hotel (and a lot of others) can be VERY hard to find. You will probably get lost, and while parts of this area are considered the "red light" district, we felt fairly safe. Note also that the street maps do not all face North.

We stayed 3 nights here and could not fault it. The staff are so polite, breakfast was delicious and plentiful although a plea to future guests.... please don't go down to breakfast in the hotel provided pyjamas. It is not the same as wearing a yakata in a spa resort - they are pyjamas and by the looks on the Japanese guests' faces, it's not just me that thought this chap was taking it a bit far!! It took us until the second night to cotton on to the fact that the hotel's at the top of the street where the red light district is concentrated. As a couple we weren't at all bothered and I felt safe -it's all very discreet. Have a great time staying here!

Close to everything, literally ( train/subway station, tons of amazing restaurants, shopping areas etc ) - in the heart of a vivid Tokyo! Great breakfast choice, clean rooms, pretty small as you can expect. The whole area around the hotel is safe, despite the noise or the so called red district - nothing to worry about! It's a little pricey but well worth it! I'd stay here again and only here!

The rooms were very clean and the beds were extremely comfortable. The previous hotel I stopped in had incredibly hard beds so it was such a relief to get a good nights sleep.Our main reason for choosing this area of Tokyo was due to it's location with the Aikikai Hombu Dojo. If you have come to Tokyo to do Aikido then this hotel is just a 15 minute walk away. As this is a very large city you need to get transport if you are going to travel around it so location in relation to other things seemed irrelavent and Tokyo has a good train network that is very easy to use if you're an english speaker. There is a good selection of shops, bars and restaurants in the local vacinity of the hotel if you are just looking for a quick venture out or for food on an evening. There is also a 7/11 right below it. I've also been advised that this area of the city is the "red light district" of Tokyo and having experienced various areas of Tokyo I would say this seems accurate. If you are coming here with children then don't worry as there aren't prostitutes hanging around on street corners. It is likely that you may get approached by a gentleman offering his ladies services however they aren't pushy and you don't feel harassed, so I wouldn't let this put you off.The staff in the hotel seemed very friendly and the hotel even provided us with umbrellas when it was raining. When we were here in October 2013 Tokyo got clipped by a typhoon. The staff were very caring and tried to warn us about going out. When we ventured out we were pretty much the only ones on the streets. Needless to say our umbrellas all got returned to the staff destroyed by the high winds and they thoroughly understood whereas most hotels might be less forgiving.Overall, I can't fault this hotel. It is a good place to stay in Tokyo, especially if you practice Aikido.

This is our 3rd stay at Astina. Each stay was approximately 5nights. We loved the convenience of the location eg. 24hrs Family mart downstairs, eateries round the corner, 6mins to shinjuku JR station etc. room size was small but extremely cozy.Breakfast spread was good for a 3star establishment. Pricing of the rooms were very reasonable during peak season too.If you are bringing children, you may have to consider getting a premier or bigger suite room as the deluxe room is just cozy enough for 2 adults with not too many luggages. We usually catch the early morning flight back to SG n getting a cab to the airport limousine express at shinjuku pick up was easy n cost less then ¥2000. I would definitely come back here again!!!

We selected the Best Western Shinjuku Astina as part of our Tokyo itinerary based on prior reviews, and being rated #4 for the area on Trip Advisor. We arrived from Kawaguchiko/Mt. Fuji and we were tired from climbing the mountain and still wearing our hiking clothes. I had read earlier that starting from the east entrance of Shinjuku JR Station was the easiest way to orient yourself towards the hotel, and also studied Google Earth street view. The hotel proved easy to find and looking for landmarks like Mister Donut was helpful. The check-in process was efficient and friendly. I wished our double-standard room had been a little larger given that we had hiking gear to sort through but this is Japan and smaller rooms are to be expected. Muji, Isetan, Uniqlo,Takashimaya/Tokyu Hands, etc, all within walking distance, as well as a wide range of restaurants. We even found our way to the popular and delicious Ichiran Ramen which is on the way to Shinjuku Station. The breakfast buffet included Japanese and Western options and was good. Recommend eating between 7-9:30 am, otherwise there can be a wait with other guests trying to get breakfast before they have to check out by 11am. I was also aware from prior reviews that the hotel is near the red light/club area and like clockwork, the Nigerian touts appeared on the street at sundown. Being aware if this in advance was helpful. We never felt threatened or bothered. The would ask my husband " can I show you something?" and quickly backed off when they realized we were together. If traveling with children, simply head out toward the main street to avoid this. There's a machine in the lobby that changes USD$ to ¥en and it was broken when we needed it. We simply went to a Seven Eleven ATM which are plentiful. The machine appeared to be promptly repaired later that day. The Lawson's convenience store at the street level is OK.......frankly we thought it was kind of sketchy for Japanese standards. Adequate for basic snack items but would not want to rely on it for a proper breakfast. Better to dine at the buffet. Overall, we were pleased with our stay, the room was clean albeit small and a little stuffy but it was mostly a crash pad for our purposes. Compared to Best Western locations in the U.S. the premises felt a little more modern and upscale. For Tokyo peak season the rate was reasonable and would stay here again.

Stayed here for ten nights in August, and it was a delight!The rooms are slightly small, but it is Japan. The room was equipt with a comfortable bed, desk and TV, side table with safe, chair, and an area in the hallway with shelving, storage and (best of all! An empty fridge). Bathroom had a deep plunge bath with overhead shower.Service was fine, all needs and questions catered to swiftly and with ease.Location is excellent. Right off Golden Gai and 8 mins from Shinjuku JR. As it is so busy and BIG, we tended to use the smaller Shinjuku sanchome station for local trips. The red light district does.surround it, but it is safe, and you can pretty much avoid it if you take the back way to the hotel, with a lovely paved and well-lit winding path.WiFi was free but could be spotty. Certainly not unusable.A Lawson convenience shop is right below the hotel, perfect for drinks and breakfasts.A lovely, clean, modern hotel in a really solid location. Makes a perfect base for exploring Tokyo. Would return.

Chose this because of the Best Western name and reasonable rate. As with most hotels in Tokyo, the rooms are small but very clean and comfortable. Bathroom has an automated Japanese toilet with heated seat. Great location, with a 24-hour Lawson convenience store right beside and mere steps to shops, cafes, restaurants and metro/train stations. The breakfast buffet that comes with the room is ample, with miso soup and select Japanese dishes provided as well as a full Western spread of the usual eggs, sausage, breads, cereal and yogurt. Pay attention to breakfast hours, which vary from weekend to weekday. My first day was on a Sunday so breakfast was served till 10:30 AM. I assumed it was the same the next day and arrived a little past 10 to find the restaurant closed - breakfast is only until 10 AM on weekdays! Had to find a cafe outside to eat - bummer. Overall this no-frills hotel is not a place to hang out in but use as a base to explore Shinjuku and the rest of Tokyo.

We have just come back from a wonderful stay at this hotel. Being nervous about visiting Japan this hotel made our experience wonderful. From the clean and large room with 3 king single beds, to the supplies in the bathroom,and the Buffet breakfast this hotel ticked all the boxes. The location was also wonderful as Shijuku has everything that is needed to have a great holiday. The station is a few minutes away and with the train you can go to any part of Tokyo as well as other areas of Japan . The people that worked at the hotel were lovely and although they did not speak a lot of English they tried to understand our requests. Thank you Best Western what a brilliant hotel you have.

We stayed here for a couple nights during our japan trip. The location was great with lots of bars and places to eat . Not too far of a walk from JR station . It's by a mister donut like others have said so look for it when you are looking for the hotel . The rooms are ok . They are clean , bathrooms are small but nice but the bedrooms may need some updating . We were on a business class floor .Breakfast was also ok , decent options of western and asian options , if you can't use your breakfast vouchers you can use it at the Lawson's store downstairs .There is also a English pub close to the hotel that had great food .Overall a good hotel but nothing fancy just good value for what you pay and a great location .

This is a competently run hotel and is not a bad option provided you aren't planning to spend much time in it, as a crash-pad it is adequate. That's just what I used it as on a recent trip to Tokyo, and it sufficed, but don't expect anything special here. I will say that the staff on reception were all very nice.

room was clean and modern. Bathroom was the best part. But the room was small, even for a Tokyo hotel room. The double bed was smaller than a normal double bed and there was a small sofa, which took up the rest of the room. Nice view of Shinjuku, though. The free breakfast was very good, bacon and eggs and fresh breads. It's not exactly far from Shinjuku Station, but it's a good hike. Between the station and the hotel you will encounter lots of African men who promise you beautiful Japanese women for the evening, or even just to take you to a nice bar. Do not go with them. Look it up online. Shinjuku is famous for a dangerous scam where these guys take you to a bar, drug you, and you wake up with your credit cards maxed out, no cash, and sick as a dog. That said, they are not very pushy and if you wave them off and keep walking you will be fine. We had no problems with them. It did not make us like the hotel or area less. I took off one star only because the room was so small for the price. Next time we will probably look for a hotel in Shubuya because the shopping and dining are better there.

This was my second stay at BW Shinjuku Astina hotel. Ever since I first visited Tokyo 2012 I've dreamt of coming back and since I was very pleased last time with this hotel I chose it again. This time we had an executive room located on the 13th floor. It was 27m2 and had twinbeds each 120cm x 200cm. The executive floor/ rooms have some extras not included in standard floor/rooms such as morning newspapers ( hanging on the doorknob every morning) and plush bathrobes. Also special shampoo set ( from Algotherm, and smelling lovely) , new toothbrushes daily, razors, combs, facial creams and cleaners etc. There are an executive lounge , but don't expect to much. It's more of a meeting room but there's a drinkmachine and you can get hot and cold drinks( coffee,sodas) for free. I'll include a picture so you can see.Free wifi and it works well.Nice helpfull staff. Do use the restrooms at the reception and be amazed :) The bathroom in the room is great too.The breakfast was included in our booking. The coffee is great and the breakfast is fresh but it's nothing to write home about. You can choose to exchange your breakfast coupon for a 500 yen voucher that you can use at the Lawson downstairs. they have loads of foods and drinks.The location of this hotel is amazing. You have bars, restaurants, shops, metro, trains and entertainment on your doorstep. Yes it's in the red light district but never once were we approched or bothered of anyone. You feel totaly safe at all times!Don't miss the Golden Gai bar area behind the hotel. It's a lot of fun and a chance to connect to the locals and other tourists. They take a covercharge of about 500 yen to sit down, you get some snacks or a bowl of food for that price and the drinks/beer is about 500 yen each. Best bartime ever!Last time we avoided taking taxis since we heard it was so expensive but it's not, at least not compaired to swedish prices! They start at 750 yen and you can go far for that before it starts ticking up. For exampel the hotel to Hilton ,total cost 750 yen! The hotel to Harajuku 1500 yen and we were a party of 4 splitting the fee.We also took a taxi to the airport. The NEX and Limousine buss was about 3500 yen pp. Total cost of taxi for 4 with a LOT of luggage 21000 yen, with less luggage it would have been 18000. Only about 1000 yen more pp for not having to drag siutcases to the station ,down stairs and onboard the train. (When we arrived to Narita we took the NEX , they have a promotion for arriving visitors only 1500 yen pp )I hope to come back to Tokyo soon, I LOVE this city and I'll stay at the BW Shinjuku Astina next time for sure!

Me and my husband chose this hotel based on the good reviews it had, mostly about staff and location and we were not disappointed!.Other reviews mention the great location in the heart of the Shinjuku area, where we spent two days walking around, visiting stores, restaurants and bars.Yes the hotel is close to the red light district, and you get to see a lot of advertisement around you but to be honest, i never felt scared or overwhelmed by it, even in the late evening hours. I am not sure if because we were a couple or because we were foreigners, but never in our 4-day stay in Tokyo (or our 2 weeks in Japan), were we approached by any of these girls or men offering any kind of services. So it was an interesting place to be, located close to many restaurants and bars with a lot of nightlife options - and still noise was not a problem for sleeping.There is something i really have to highlight about this hotel- THE STAFF!!!Every single one of them in the front desk went beyond their way to help us at every moment. During our stay in Tokyo they attended all our requests, answered all our questions, provided us with advise, maps, and all sorts of helpful tips to move around the area and even go to the airport. We asked them to store our luggage for the entire day after checking out, and to reserve a taxi to take us to the train station at 5:20p.m. We arrived at 5:15 and they helped us with our luggage and the taxi was already downstairs waiting for us - all that, even when we were no longer guests at the hotel!!!. Furthermore, they had already explained the taxi driver where exactly we were going so there were no communication issues between us.If this wasn't enough, i contacted the hotel about 1 month before our arrival, asking for advise for visiting and climbing Mount Fuji. I recall writing about 10 emails during this time and every single one of them was responded promptly. Long story short, we requested advise for booking the bus that would take us to the 5th station and most importantly, a reservation in the mountain huts, because they do not have much information online and do not speak English at all! (in the hut itself they do but not in the phone number provided to make the reservations).The staff at the Best Western took the time to call the Mt. Fuji hotels, advice us on prices, room sizes and make all the necessary arrangements for us to get there. I am beyond grateful with them because without speaking Japanese, this was impossible for us. If my review is not clear enough, i am beyond grateful with the hotel staff and very happy we booked this hotel. Even when it was not the prettiest hotel we stayed at in Japan, this was without a doubt, the hotel that exceeded our expectations and the one that provided us with the most rewarding memories.I will strongly recommend for anyone to stay here and i would definitely come back here if i have the opportunity.

I really liked this hotel. While the lowest priced rooms are small by western standards, there are some really nice qualities that puts it a notch above other hotels in Japan:- Our non-smoking room did not smell of tobacco - Bathroom is good size with a tub and shower stall- Air conditioning is quiet and effective even in a hot August day- Quiet, even in a 5th floor room- Beds are NOT rock hard like in some priced Japanese hotels- 24 hour convenience store with ready to eat food - Refrigerator in room to keep food- Breakfast with good choices (even curry!) for about $10/personGoogle map shows the hotel on a pedestrian alley but the hotel's main sign next to the Lawson convenience store is on the other side of the building. You can enter the hotel from the other side but it is a bit harder to find the hotel from that side. I will post a picture that shows some stone cubes on the pedestrian alley where you enter the building. The hotel's front desk is on the 3rd floor that you can reach by an elevator or the escalator.You can get to about 100m of the hotel underground by going through the "Subnade" underground shopping arcade that is connected to the connection between the Shinjuku Metro Station for the Marunouchi line and Shinjuku 3-chime Metro Station (Isetan department store). Go straight through the arcade to stairway 13 that puts you close to the side street that that the hotel is on.

This is a great hotel. A short 10 minuet walk from Shinjuku JR station, Take the East Exit and follow the direction in my map attached to this review. Also if your coming from Shinjuku Sanchome subway station I would recommend exit B9, I have also highlighted this on the map.The staff here are really friendly. When I first arrived, I had a problem getting into my suitcase as the padlock had reset the combination to something random. I took my suitcase down to reception to see if they had anything to break the padlock. Within minuets the receptionist located some bolt cutters and opened it up for me. If you are reading this, Thank you!Breakfast was a buffet style layout with everything you could want from Japanese to Western style. The room was bigger that I was expecting from reading reviews. I stayed in a standard single for 7 nights and had all the space I could need. There was enough room for my now opened suitcase allowing me space to walk around the room unhindered. There was also a safe and a small fridge located in the room. The bathroom was nice and contained a modern shower/bath, toilet and sink. My room was located on the 8th floor facing the street, it was really quiet and the only noise I heard was from passing fire engines. The room was cleaned and sheets and towels changed daily. Cleaning staff were also very friendly and polite.I would recommend this hotel to anyone.

The rooms were of typical Japanese standard, not huge, but big enough. We just fit our two suitcases in. The bathroom was clean and had a a glassed off shower room. Considering the noise outside, the hotel itself was very quiet.Depending on what you are after, the hotel is in a good spot. It's close to Shinjuku station with lots of shopping, restaurants and bars nearby.Breakfast was included, and for a hotel it wasn't bad. They had your typical Japanese type meal as well as Western options.It is close to the red light district, and it does feel quite seedy at night, but we never felt afraid or like it was that much of an issue. It's also right behind Golden Gai, and we had a lot of fun in this area trying out small bars.The staff were quite helpful when we asked them for recommendations and assistance and they could all speak English very well. There is also free wifi throughout the hotel.There is a Lawsons convenience store open 24 hours next to the hotel which is very handy.The one issue I had was that we decided to forgo our room clean and instead claim a voucher. However, they would only issue the voucher after we checked out which didn't make much sense as we could only use it in their restaurant on the lobby floor or they had small display of some tourist type gifts for sale. We ended up not using the voucher at all. So I do not recommend taking up this offer.For the location and the price, this hotel wasn't bad at all.

the hotel is clean and the service is great the personnel speaks a very good english and they are very efficient and kind the rooms are spacious and clean i was traveling with my family therefore the area sounded like "strange" ( but absolutely safe) in that contest, but it is very convenient because a block away you can find a lot of restaurants bar mall and so on i would recommend also for the cheap price on respect of the value of the hotel

We stayed in this hotel for 4 nights on our trip to Tokyo. In my experience, this was a comfortable and clean hotel in a good, yet bad location.
