I can't really comment on the service because I had exactly 2 interactions with them- about 2 minutes while checking in and 15 seconds checking out. They were efficient, and spoke English well enough. I'll write what I thought was good about the hotel first, then give a couple negatives, and finally write some tips. The good: The hotel was spacious and reasonably priced. We paid a total of about 62,000yen for the four nights we stayed here. We had a twin room with two beds that were about 150cm wide each.The room had enough space for myself, my wife, and my two small children (4 & 6 y.o.) to stay comfortably. I spent a lot of time searching the internet for hotels before our stay, and this one seemed to be the the best value I could find in that we could all fit in the one room. The room was very clean, and it had most amenities that you would want, and a few that were unexpected but nice such as shaving razors and combs in the toiletries. The wifi worked pretty well and was fast. The beds were comfortable, though not extremely so due to the poor quality pillows. The A/C was cool, but not as cold as I would have liked during the 34C (94F) weather we had during our stay. The room was quiet, even though it's right above the street. The only street noise I heard was from an ambulance that went by. The location is good in that it's a 5 minute walk to the subway, and a 10 minute walk to Shinjuku station. There are lots of restaurants and shopping nearby, so it was very convenient. It's also right next to Golden Gai, which has a number of narrow streets with tiny little bars stacked up on top of each other. Our room didn't include breakfast, and we didn't eat at the hotel.The bad: The location was also bad in that it's just on the edge of the Kabukicho red light district. That gives the hotel's immediate neighborhood a little bit of a seedy feel, with lots of touts trying to get me to go into their bars when I walked around by myself in the evening. A red light district is obviously not a place for kids, so when we were outside with the kids we didn't linger near the hotel. Instead, we walked across the big street about 200m north towards the subway when we wanted to find food and it was just a normal commercial district.Tips: - There is a Lawson's convenience store on the street in front of the hotel. I went in there and got some bread and bento boxes for breakfast. That cost about 900 yen per day for the 4 of us, which is very inexpensive compared to the hotel restaurant. Lawson's was also a good way to have an affordable beer- a 500ml Asahi can costs about 220 yen in Lawsons, but it's 370 yen in the hotel vending machines. - Take the Narita Express from the airport to Shinjuku station. If you have a foreign passport it's discounted 50% and it is fast and convenient. Shinjuku station is about a 10 minute walk to the hotel. - If you're a white male, like me, you will be approached by many Nigerian and some Japanese touts asking you to go to their strip clubs if you walk around by yourself. They were actually friendly, and I never felt threatened or unsafe, even when I got tired of them and was rude to them. I found it was effective to just say that I wasn't interested in their club, and they didn't bother me after that. Overall, I liked the hotel and I would stay there again.

This Hotel is great value for money, its clean, comfortable and has free wifi, although be aware that it is in the middle of a red light district, we were constantly hassled by Nigerian hawkers trying to sell us massages and entry to strip clubs, This area is not for families, i wouldn't say its dangerous its just a pain getting constantly hassled every time you step outside and come home, But this review is about the Hotel not the area

1、The room is clean and neat, and what I love the most is the air fresheners they offer in the room. The air freshener smell great, and become pretty handy when you have a big Japanese feast like sukiyaki, tepanyaki, tempura or yakiniku.2、Bathtub is great which fits for 2 people, and when you have a long day walking shopping, it is always good to have a bath, you can even get some nuyokusai(like bath salt) from the stores near by like donkihote(which i absoluttely recommand).3、breakfast：quite good, there are western breakfast for you, and also gyudon or japanese curry for breafast, and the restaurent is bright and clean.4、location：(1) It is in the red light district of tokyo(not the hottest zone), but the staffs won't bother you too much unless you have really an eye contact with them. if you are still worry about it, i suggest you walk by the park on the other side of the street which you can easily find.On the other hand, you can find a lot of restaurent opened in late night, and it is great when you have a long day shopping walking and feel like some late night snack like Ichiran Ramen or Kanza Ramen(both recommanded)(2)about5~10 minutes walk to shinjuku station, reasonable length

Many have already sung praise of this motels cleanliness, compactness (fine for me) great bathroom shower hand held separate deep tub, wonderful staff (more then proficient English) and excellent location from which to base exploration of Tokyo. First night I got lost but lovely locals walked 20 mins with me to find & from there easy 5 mins to station (google maps mislead me), heaps of shops, eateries, a shrine at the era with a Sunday market, very tame red light area and cheap lawsons store below. Breakfast is ample and some changes over the 6 days I was there & this veggo didnt starve was very busy after 9am, never lunched there. All room facilities fine including toiletries, with a cheap efficient laundry on floor 7. Gardens close as is massive train station and the gay area a 9 minute mince away. Only gripes the pillows were hellish made rice it seemed and the sun could be detected in room at 445am despite curtains so maybe a stronger cloth? Or eye mask. And given this is a lively area I did hear sirens 24/7 but not to my sleep detriment and at times heard neighbours even on 12th floor. Would stay again here as highly affordable with great included wifi clean & staff wonderful.

the Best Western Shinjuku Astina hotel is 2 blocks from Shinjuku JR station this makes it a perfect base for your travels while in Tokyo, the hotel is super clean and not to small like other Japaneses hotels.A large array of restaurants and bars are in close proximity to the hotel making the search for food or drinks after a long day sight seeing easy, if your not a smoker i highly recommend to ask for a non smoking room when you book or you might be disappointed with what you are given.

The hotel is located in a very busy area, small street two blocks from the Shinjuku station. The rooms were not big but not too small, loved the bathroom. You don't need to bring a converter the outlets worked for my chargers. Breakfast was great, a lot to choose from.

Within walking distance to metro station and main shopping places like Isetan, Takashimaya, Muji, Uniqlo etc...There is a machine located in lobby to exchange USD notes to Japanese yen. You can use your breakfast voucher to exchange voucher to use in the convenient store next to the hotel, or you can choose not to clean the room to exchange the voucher for the convenient store as well. This is something unique.The receptionist is well verse in English.

Great value and location. There are three subway stations within walking distance, depending on which subway line you are taking that day, you may want to start at one of the smaller stations, as the Shinjuku station is a bit of a zoo and very confusing. A taxi from the Shinjuku station to the hotel is about $10 so save yourself the hassle of trying to find the hotel on foot with suitcases. The Lawson convenience store downstairs has everything a traveler might need, including sushi that is boxed fresh daily and some nice desserts. You are also right in the center of the nightlife district (no worries, the windows are thick, you won't hear a thing), blocks away from the Golden Gai, and have tons of dining options nearby. Try the Tsukiji Sushiko restaurant a few blocks away on Yasukuni Dori, the avenue featured in the "Tokyo Drift" speed race. Or stop at the Isetan department store depachika to pick up a bento box or some artisan pastries. As for the hotel, it is clean and has a boutique feel to it, not like you'd picture a Best Western hotel. The bathrooms are very modern, the room comes with some nice amenities including a massage chair. Hotel staff is very friendly and speaks English. The breakfast buffet has a selection of Western items, like omelet, toast, jams and hash browns, as well as Japanese staples like mackerel and steamed rice. Several juices, cereals and fruit salads, as well as very good coffee. The one thing I was missing was some whole grain toast, all they had was white bread and croissants. If you get there early you might snag some French Toast before they run out.

We stayed on the executive floor what gave us more space. Rooms were big and very clean. Location was very good a first time visitors (in the middle of the action). Breakfast could better, above all hardly any fresh fruits. Service was good but not everybody spoke decent English

Our family stayed at this hotel in two rooms (for 4 people) over 6 nights. Finding the hotel was easier than I anticipated by following other reviewers directions from the east exit. The Mister Donuts on the corner is the landmark to look for or find Isetans and go from there. The service at hotel was good and while the room sizes are small it was quiet and had access to Lawsons downstairs and vending machines on every floor - breakfast was included and was good value if limited in variety. The location was great with easy access to all subways and JR. The area was also really safe despite being quite near the red light area. The little bars out the back were fun and worth a visit (without kids!). We would stay at this hotel and in this area again.

After reading many reviews and considering the cost of other hotels, we booked and stayed at the Best Western Astina for the 2nd part of our honeymoon and we were more than pleased with the hotel and its location during our 7 night stay. Getting from the airport to shinjuku was very easy using the express train, and then only 5-10 mins walk from the station to the hotel. If you didn't want to go outside from the station to the hotel, you can walk 90% of the distance by going into the subnade shopping mall underground. We found this useful at busy times and when it was Raining or very hot. The shopping mall also had some really nice places to eat closer to the station end. We used the suica travel card to get around Tokyo which made it very easy as you didn't need to buy a ticket for each journey and it worked out very cheap compared to day travel cards. Shinjuku and the smaller stations around the hotel couldn't have felt more convenient and central for getting around Tokyo. The hotel is located next door to the golden gai which is loads of miniature bars, its worth taking a look and is one of Tokyo's top places to see, it is also located in the red light district ( Do not let this put you off, the red light district is extremely safe, its not like European red light districts). We arrived earlier than our check in time and had to pay a small fee to check in early, we were happy to pay this after a 13+ hour journey and were pleased it was offered. The hotel has a 2 lift system, the first takes you only to reception and the next takes you to the floors with the rooms on, we suspect this is for security but thought it was a good idea. The room was very clean and although smaller than most hotel rooms was plenty of space for what we needed, the room was cleaned daily and there was a small fridge in the room which was useful. We also phoned reception for an iron and ironing board which was left in our room for the week. The bed seemed to be changed everyday and it may have been the long days but was exceptionally comfortable. The air conditioning in the room came in handy as the room got quite warm without it. For breakfast we were given a token for each day of our stay when we checked in, I didn't realise it until the end of our stay but if you didn't use them in the morning you could use them towards lunch in the restaurant. The breakfast had a fair choice and varied selection, it set us up for the day and great value to be included in the cost of the hotel and room! Their are more than plenty of choice when it comes to evening dinner, I would recommend the restaurant floors at the tekashimaya shopping centre or the restaurant floors above the Shinjuku station. There were over 100 hundred restaurants which all looked great, the restaurant udon below the hotel was very fresh, good value and tasted great to. I think I have probably sufficiently bored whoever has read to this point of my review, but I can assure you that you won't be dissapointed with this hotel in Tokyo if you need a clean, comfortable, good value and well located place to stay!

I recently stayed at Best Western for two nights recently and was pleased with the stay. I stayed in a Standard Single, which was plenty of space for a solo traveller.Location: Hotel is located on the third level of a building on the main street of the Red light District in Shinjuku. Please don’t let that turn you off this place. I’m a young female- safety was priority. The district is timid by most standards. Plenty of people and lights. I was never approached or made to feel unsafe. There is a sake bar, a Lawson’s convenience store and a tempura restaurant beneath the hotel. It’s an easy 5-10min walk to Shinjuku station. There are also plenty of eating, drinking and entertainment options in the surrounding area. The room- clean and spacious. It’s not a very big room, but there was a desk, couch, double bed and still plenty of room to spare. The bed was very comfortable. Bathroom was spotless and featured toilet, ‘glass wet room' with separate shower & bath. The room also had a safe (big enough for an 18inch mac), air con, free daily bottled water and free Wi-Fi. Food- I enjoyed breakfast both mornings of my stay. The range was great and very fresh. You can watch the chefs prepare and replenish the buffet regularly. I was particular impressed by the western elements of the breakfast- fresh toasts, a range of fresh fruit, as well as delicious Japanese items. It was the best breakfast I’ve had in Japan. Staff- was very helpful. I have an allergy to an ingredient in the shower amenities, and the staff quickly provided alternate products to use with no fuss caused. They were very pleasant, and most spoke English or were happy to try. A great place to stay.

Excellent hotel, stayed 2x at this fine establishment in 9 months. Central location, very clean. Professional and helpful staff. A pleasure to stay here. Very large room for Japan. No noise from the street whatsoever.

I had no complaints. All was in order. It was clean and no problems at all. They even provide umbrellas for free when it's raining. I did not try breakfast. The location is great. The staff was great too. Kudos to the staff, especially the staff that worked nights on June 26th. Stay here. It is a very good choice.

Hotel about 2-5 min walk to Shinjuku Station.Close to restaurants.Staff friendly and able to communicate in English.Our room was small for family of 4 but we're out most of the day.I didn't like the strong cigarette smoke when you go to the elevator by our room.The breakfast buffet was redundant that if you stay longer you get so tired of it.

The location is absolutely ideal for people who like to go out, the hotel itself is very clean and modern, reception staff/check in is very efficient (no lines), bathrooms are luxurious, with many welcome perks inside. I had a great view of Shinjuku Breakfast is delicious and diverse.The only minuses I had were: - rooms were a bit small, but that's Tokyo- you need your card to take the elevator to the floors... I know it is officially for safety reasons but means you have to go down pick up your guests at the reception.- Internet connection dropped from time to time (both Wireless and Ethernet) when I was there. These were really minor things. I moved somewhere else in Japan with a different hotel and can see even more how high-quality this one was by contrast!

A friend and I stayed here for 4 nights in Tokyo. It is an awesome location: so close to Shinjuku station, food and shopping. Great for adults/couples/solo travellers. (the area has a lots of clubs/night life). The entrance was a little hard to find (lift next to a convenience store) if you are walking to find it for the first time. Rooms are nice and clean, okay size for two people.

This hotel is very customer focused. Everyone was very helpful and polite. I stayed at this hotel for 10 nights and would gladly stay another 10 if I didn't have to go home. The hotel is an easy 10 minute walk to the Shinjuku train station. There are plenty of restaurants, shopping and entertainment in the area to keep you occupied. It is in the red light district which meant that I was approached by people touting "services" and what not. Just ignore them and continue to walk and they will leave you alone. I learned to develope a stoic look when I'm the area so after a few days, they left me alone. Other than that the area didn't have a seedy vibe and I didn't feel unsafe. The room is on the small side, as mentioned in other reviews but very comfortable. Service was excellent. What was really great was that If I missed my breakfast buffet which was included in my room rate, I could use the breakfast voucher for a credit of 1000 yen towards the lunch buffet which was 1600 yen. So, essentially, lunch would only be 600 yen, a real bargain. Also, if you're the type that keep your room clean, you may opt out of having your room cleaned for two consecutive days and you will be given 500 yen gift card to be used at the hotel for each day that your room isn't cleaned. Your room must be cleaned by the third day. In all my travels, I have never experienced this kind of service and what a great way to go green. I requested to be on a higher floor to be away from the noise and my request was honored. Although, I don't think the noise level was too drastic that you would have a problem if you were on a lower floor. Overall I would definitely stay here again when I return to Tokyo.

This hotel is great! The rooms are, as you would expect in Japan, quite small but very clean and modern. The staff and the breakfast is good although it's not a big variety of choices and it doesn't change at all during your stay.Located in Shinjuku, one of the most busiest parts of Tokyo, you can easily move from part to part by train, taxi or even by foot. It's not that difficult to walk from here to Harajyuku or even Shibuya, actually I would recommend you to do it! You will se a lot of interesting things on the way and at the same time save some bucks (if your that kind of person maybe Tokyo is the wrong place to be, but anyway).

I would definitely stay here again on our next visit to Tokyo. The hotel is really clean and much nicer than I expected. The rooms are standard (i.e. small) but completely functional and clean. The staff were exceptional! They really went above and beyond in helping to answer any questions we had about attractions, restaurants, how to get to places, and made bookings for us. We had breakfast included with our booking, and the spread was very good - a mix of Western and Japanese items. The location was perfect. It's in Kabukichou so plenty of bars around. It's about a 5 minute walk to Shinjuku station (east exit) and close to the metro as well. Lots of shopping in the area as well as some really great restaurants.

It is accessible . Room is clean .It was a complicated area for children . Quite number of clubs are nearby . Parents may want to access to the hotel from the back trail even its a longer path to reach to the hotel .

Partner and I stayed here for 3 nights over New Years' after a couple of days skiing in Hakuba. Had some reservations booking here as it is located in the 'red light district', but it really is very tame and I felt safe at all times - even when walking back to the hotel by myself after a fun night shopping at Lumine department store. The hotel itself is only about a 7min walk (including stopping for pedestrian/traffic crossings) from Shinjuku Station, which will take you to just about anywhere you want to go in Tokyo and beyond. With friendly and welcoming staff, a particularly well presented for what I would have expected a Best Western hotel to be and a comfortable room made for a very pleasant stay.I can't recommend this hotel enough, especially for first time visitors to Tokyo for the convenience and proximity to Shinjuku's amazing array of shops, restaurants and nightlife.

We stayed at this hotel for 2 nights, the hotel was very good. Quite spacious rooms for Japanese standards, the hotel provided us free of charge with a baby cot for our 5month old, which was great as not all hotels in japan offer this service. We had buffet breakfast included in our rate which was good too. The hotel is in a great location in shinjuku, very close walk to the JR station, and numerous food options as well. We had not been to Tokyo previously so was unsure on which district to stay in, we chose shinjuku based on other traveller reviews. However next time we travel to Tokyo we will stay in either harajuku or Tokyo. We loved harajuku it had a great feel, great food and shopping. We stayed in Tokyo near Tokyo station at the end of our trip and we found this was a much more convenient location to travel around than shinjuku. If you were to stay in shinjuku I would definitely recommend this hotel, as well a trip to the shinjuku gyoen which was our favorite place in shinjuku, just beautiful.

we had a room facing the street and man we couldn't sleep till 4AM.make sure You get a room facing the back if You want to get a good night sleep.also i was surprised the hotel didn't have a swimming pool.

Stayed in Best Western Astina Shinjuku for 5 day 4 nights on 21 June 2014.Hotel is about 10-15 mins walk from the limobus station in Shinjuku or 10 mins from the Tokyo Metro Shinjuku. The double room (17.5sqm) seems small but the room is up to date. There is no English channel on the tv set since all channels are in Japanese.There is a convenience store 'Lawson" at the ground floor. Food for breakfast is average but adequate.Near to Korean town which is down the road and easy access to Takashimaya and Isetan for shopping.Overall a nice experience.

I traveled with my friend to Tokyo at the beginning of June, 2014. This was our first visit to Tokyo, so we were a bit unsure where in the city we should stay. We went with a safe bet and chose a hotel centrally located. We were very happy with the location and the condition of the hotel. The hotel is modern and very clean. For people who regularly travel to large, expensive cities, you know it can be challenging to find a nice hotel at a reasonable price. I was impressed with the value of the hotel for what we paid. We opted to pay a little bit more and stay on the executive floor. This includes WIFI and breakfast. The room was spacious and the bathroom very nice. I did not see any of the regular floor rooms, but I would recommend paying the extra money for the executive floor. The breakfast in the morning was delicious. There was a good variety of western and Japanese breakfast items. The hotel is very close to Shinjuku station. Warning - Shinkuku station is a main station and always packed full of people. Unless you are familiar with the station, plan on adding an extra 20 minutes to your schedule just to get through the station. We were late to dinner one night because of the time it took just to get through the station. This is to expected since it is a main station - we just didn't think about it at the time. Many train lines stop at this station, so it is convenient to travel to many destinations throughout the city. The staff at the hotel were extremely kind and helpful. We spoke no Japanese, and the staff all seemed very well equipped to communicate in English. Despite the hotel being located in a very busy area, the hotel was quiet and we were never disturbed from street noise during the night. Next to the hotel is a convenience store - very nice for grabbing waters and a snack on the way up to the room. I would definitely stay at this hotel again.

Hotel is 5-10 minute walk from Shinjuku train and bus station. It is a little hard to find the first time but easy after you realize where its located. Once I exited the station I called the front desk and they gave me great walking directions. Some reviews complain of the room size but for Tokyo and for the price the room is actually large. I have been to Tokyo and all over Japan many times and I have had much smaller rooms for the same price. To get a room that is Western size you will pay at least twice if not three times as much. Location is very convenient.Property and rooms were clean and modern. Staff were courteous and helpful. Breakfast buffet was decent mix of western and Japanese. Our flight did not depart from Haneda until 2300. They stored our bags until we picked them up at 2000.Overall nice value. I would stay here again.

This is an attractive and modern hotel about 10 minutes walk from the east exit of the Shinjuku JR train station. It is on a busy street in Shinjuku but the rooms were quiet. A buffet breakfast with a variety of Japanese and western items is included and served in an attractive room with an entire wall of windows. The hotel lobby is one floor above street level. We saw many fellow Americans at this hotel. Relative to American hotels, the rooms are a bit smaller, the beds firmer and the pillows harder.

In Tokyo, most hotel rooms are small. This hotel is not an exception. However, I would not hesitate to give it a five star rating because it provides good balance between price and quality. This hotel has a great location. It is right next to the Kabukichō 新宿歌舞伎町. It is the perfect place to enjoy nightlife in Tokyo. The breakfast is pretty good. The room is clean. Even though the air-conditioner is not cold at first. Give it some time. it will cool the room to a comfortable level.
user_name:
Tewei
Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam

review_body: My husband and I stayed at the Best Western Astina not expecting anything too special, but we were pleasantly surprised. The staff were extremely attentive, friendly and helpful. Our room was nice, spacious and clean, and the bed was comfortable. They provided robes and lovely bathroom goodies. The location was central and the free internet and breakfast included was a bonus. The only down side was that there was no gym or pool. I got very very lost one day on a morning run! But we would definitely recommend this hotel to friends and family!

We have stayed here last Nov and decided to book again when planning this trip in early spring. The staff provided easy directions to various places, helpful in make meal reservations on our behalf. They spoke quite fluent english and smiled a lot. The hotel's location is fine. The food in Stella is also fine.If the rooms can be a bit larger, that would be perfect! The first time's room area is 17.5 sq m & this time we tried the 21 sq m executive room. Perhaps next time we should try 24/27 sq m size if the price is okay!

My partner and I enjoyed our stay at this hotel. It was clean and the staff were very accommodating. It isn't located in the best neighborhood but it is close to the train station. Would stay here again if I ever find myself back in shinjuku.

Best Western Astina Sinjuku has a excellente location, in middle of Shinjuku, close to action and restaurants, and a 10 minutes walking to station.Rooms are a bit small, bus is Tokyo and enough confortable.Helpful staff.Breakfast has japonese and western food, and was OK, but I had better in other hotels in Japan countryside.The best was value for money,when consider hotel is in Tokyo.It´´s not a five stars, a excellent hotel, but a good option for Tokyo and value for money is the main reason.

Location is great and staff was courteous and helpful. Staff was multi lingual and did try to help out. AC however is another story ... not cold .. cool but definitely not cold. Rooms are very small and not expecting this as BW has always had western sized rooms... Note to self not to comfortable as far as personal space.

We stayed on the executive floor for 5 nights.Great full Western and Japanese buffet breakfast with long accessible hours.FYI, when arriving by subway (Shinjuku station), follow yellow exit signs overhead for exit #B-9, at street level turn left and walk slightly downhill about two blocks, you'll quickly see the Best Western logo/sign if you look to the rooflines. Executive room was large and had comfortable beds, full tub and independent standing shower in a separate room off bathroom, very nice. Refrigerator and safe in room. Very nice hotel, would stay here again.

Breakfast full buffet, central location, but at first it was hard for us to find this hotel. Customer service was outstanding from front desk. A very good location for people who enjoy partying. This hotel is at a reasonable price.

All staff in the hotel are excellent I'am very happy hosted in this hotel, excellent and meets all requirements.of the guestThe location is perfect, the breckfast is very testy, large rooms andcomfortable, the service of the staff is very friendly and courteousI will recommend the hotel

Stayed four nights in this hotel and I must say that it's a very good hotel in a special neighbourhood. The staff was very helpfull and friendly, actually we booked this hotel for three nights but we found out the train the airport was not going anymore so we got stuck, but the staff at the hotel changed an one person bedroom into a two persoon bedroom and so we were able to stay one more night here. (Only the price of the this last night changed a bit and there was no breakfast included anymore, but we were already glad we had a place to sleep one more night.) The hotel is nearby the shopping area and located is what we called here the red light disctrict, but I never had the feeling I was not safe. The breakfast is really good but can be a bit crowdy and sometimes there are not enough seats for everyone. All together I can recomomend this hotel to everyone who likes shopping and going out at night. We are happy we stayed here.

My partner and I have now stayed at the Astina many times over the last few years. The rooms are plush- comfy beds, free high speed internet and wonderful bathrooms. The A rooms are quite small but still comfortable.Service is wonderful. It's worth paying the additional for the breakfast- it's convenient and there's a wide choice. If you book on the Hotel website and join the Astina Club, you can get additional discounts, making this Hotel very economical for a Tokyo hotel.You can't get a better location- Shinjuku is a fabulous area for shopping and people watching and there are hundreds of different restaurants within walking distance. It's easily reached on foot from the East exit of Shinuku station.

Good base for exploring Tokyo. In red-light district and can be annoying if you are pestered by touts (like I was). Otherwise, hotel staff great - helpful, friendly, professional. Hotel rooms a bit on the small side, but this is Tokyo.

loved this place, everything nearby aside the train stations west entrance.east entrance not so bad. so walking with my suitcase and backpack was a bummer since I took the airport bus which uses the west entrance. on return to bus station I took a taxi and that was just 1030 yen. it was raining both ways so that was my option. walking to the hotel I got soaked. normal sunny day about 15 minutes. I used the TA map to find it easy on my phone. get that data card at the airport it helps. room was super small but so was the price and only me. deep tub safe and a bed. TV only Japanese and maybe I saw German. you can rent a movie and you can see all movies till midnight for 1000 yen. I signed in for 3 days of movies and was only charged 2 days. new releases, classics and Hollywood Hits.  area very fun, Capcom Bar directly across the street, close to Robot Restaurant and many irritating naughty bars. lala if I had more money I would probably check them out, anyway dozens of people on the street trying to shake ur hand and get you to go in. just ignore them. behind the hotel is Golden Gai. its a night life area where your sure to find good fun drinking buddies in many of the small bars. no monkey business just a fun place with so many bars that hold about 8 people only in each. breakfast buffet came with and nothing to boast about but average with western and Japanese selections. I'm into nato and they have that every morn and pickles and interesting enough for me to go downstairs early. staff very helpful and u can use their computer for printing no charge. the English wasn't to good but they accommodated my taxi and wake up call on time when I wasn't sure. so I would say they understand but don't speak the best. hmmm lastly there's a mini mart here 24/7 which helped me with beer and an umbrella.

Best Western offers modern, clean accomodation a few minutes walk from Shinjuku Station. I had concerns about finding the hotel as Shinjuku Station is huge but did lots of online research and leaving the station at the East Exit (for Kabukicho) I was able to spot landmarks on the hotel website map and find the hotel from their. Staff were excellent - a friend was even able to leave a package for me at the hotel. We paid a little more for a larger room and it was a good size for Tokyo - biggest room size I had experienced during my visits to Tokyo. The room was spotless and modern. Hotel caters to international clientele. Breakfast was a terrific bonus and a good selection of asain and western choices. Although in the red light district this was never an issue for us.
user_name:
Matt B
Bristol, England, United Kingdom

review_body: We stayed here for two nights and it was okay, nothing amazing and nothing horrendous!The location is great for the nightlife but quite far from Shinjuku train station. We stayed a Friday and Saturday night and all we could hear both nights were sirens coming through our bedroom window. The hotel room was quite big for Japan's standards and clean but nothing special. The bed was exremelly hard, uncomfortable and a very small double! However the bathroom was very modern and nice to use.The breakfast was standard and was okay.Overall I would recommend this hotel to young people who want to enjoy the nightlife and not families. The hotel is situated in the red light district with strip clubs and massage parlours either side and all down the high street. There is a 24 hour Lawson under the hotel which is convenient!

at the city center the hotel offers great in room amenities and comfort for business travelers, good breakfast and value for money... the room size is 17 sq mtr which is small as compared but that the way japan is ! good stay!

We stayed here for 5 nights and had a pretty good experience.Hotel staff was friendly; rooms were very clean and modern (loved the robes and slippers they give you) but a little on the small side; breakfast in the restaurant was quite good (shout-out to the super friendly women working here). I think the thing I liked most about this hotel was its location -- in the heart of Shinjuku (see review). The hotel is within walking distance to the train station, all the restaurants and bars and just general craziness of Shinjuku. It's a street down from the Red Light district, but you're not so close that it's annoying -- albeit you do get some guys asking you if you want to partake.I would stay here again just to be in the neighbourhood ;)

Booked a room in May for a holidayChose one of the bigger rooms with a tub which had a view of Tokyo skyline (14 floor)Room was big for Japan's standards, very quiet and the floor even had its own vending and ice machine. Free coffee and tea also available a floor below us (11-14 were exec suites and needed our room passes to access these floors)7th floor had a laundry room (coin operated) and at the 1st floor was Lawsons, 24 hour food/drinks and experience of a konbiniIn terms of location, smack dab in the middle of Kaubukicho, interesting characters all abound but safe and they will not hassle you if you are in a pair or group so no worries. Very safe, made me feel like an idiot after a while for trying to protect my wallet at all times. Had to do a bit of walking to reach Shinjuku Station but it was all in the experience as you get to pass shops of all manners. You will most likely get lost the first time you attempt to reach back the hotel like we did, but you manage after a while. Just remember the street where Mr.Donut is and you're golden.Overall good service, a big room and wonderful food all around,Speaking of food, morning buffet is somewhat disappointing and tables are cramp if you're used to normal dining, you're better off buying stuff from Lawsons like we did, or getting some toast and sausages just for fueling up for the long day of shopping and walking (Scrambled eggs were gooey)

Stayed there for 4 nights. The hotel is located within well known shinjuku area, thus can be quite messy at night. During the weekends, you can hear police cars having their sirens on and patrolling around. But as we all know that hotels in japan are expensive, what you pay is what you get.

5 min walk from the train station albeit it the middle of the red light district (which in itself a novelty for about 5 min until you quickly get an absolute gutfull of the Nigerian guys harassing you to buy 'services'). Room was of excellent quality (cozy not small) and no problems with noise. Buffet breakfast was decent. CNN is the only English channel.

The hotel is nearby JR Shinjuku and department store that make us very convenient. The room is small but functional. There is a shop below the hotel which mean you can find a food or drink even an umbrella. A location of this hotel is a strong point and recommend to everyone that come to Tokyo that this hotel is a good choice and good valuable.

As for us, it was the best deal we could have made: Top Hotel, everything very new and clean, good standard and nice furniture, big room and bath (for Tokyo standards) - and not expensive at all! Staff is very friendly and helped us with anything we approached them for. Breakfast is ok, more suitable for Asians, but we could get along. Location is very central, Shinjuku or Shinjuku Sanchome metro station - yet rooms very quiet. Nice bar streets behind the hotel... We were happy with This hotel

Although the rooms in this hotel are quite small, they are very luxe for the price you pay. The breakfast is very satisfying and the location is perfect. Right in the middle of Shinjuku and only minutes walk to the main JR Shinjuku train station, it really was our favourite hotel! It's also great for travellers as theres a 7-11 next door which is one of the only places that have an atm that accepts foreign cards.The only thing I will say about this hotel is that its hard to find at 9pm at night when you've just gotten off a 9 hour flight!

Everything is very close which is great as you can just walk to go shopping. The trains are near by too. The hotel has all the essentials, even a shoe horn hooray. The only thing was we left our brand new travel pillows in our hotel before we left and when we contacted them they said they didn't find anything. When we checked out the service consultant just took our pass and said yes tats fine, he should of had someone check the room before we left. Other than that the hotel was great.

We stayed there for 4 nights during our first visit to Tokyo. As expected the room was quite crammed but still have some good storage spaces for your clothing items. We loved the location as it's close to shopping, drinking, eating attractions and also Shinjuku JR station. Vending and ice machines on each floor were also a great idea. The free breakfast (buffet style) was more than adequate. The only minor issue we had during our stay was that the cleaning lady did not remove our garbage bags we placed next to the already full garbage bin after housekeeping. Overall, this is a great value hotel. They went for an extra mile to make your money worth it, for example, if you skip to have the free breakfast, you can exchange the coupon and use it as a 1000 yen credit towards your lunch at the hotel restaurant, and if you do not want your room to be made up the next day (provided that you stay more than a night), you will get 500 yen voucher in return and you can spend it at their souvenir shop, it is a very good incentive to save on the resources (unnecessary refill on the amenities, and washing of towels and sheets). The red light district did not botehr us at all, people (touting guys) were still polite if you say no to them.

Hotel located in the central of shinjuku, around 10 mins walking distances to from station, and only 5 mins walking distance from metro station. Also they do provide a lot personal caring product, like cleaning foam, facial lotion, etc. The room is big enough to put large suitcases together.It was really a great stay, certainly will stay again when I travel to Tokyo.

We stayed at the hotel with our 2 year old toddler. On making the booking, I requested for a higher level room to avoid road noise and this request was met by the hotel. They even offered to remove the couch in the room to fit a baby cot for us - free of charge!The room itself and bathroom was very modern and clean. Daily house keeping staff does a great job replenishing all the amenities and tidying the room. There is a Lawson convenience store on level 1 of the building which was great!The location of the hotel is not as close to the JR station as we first expected but it's still less than 10 minutes walk. Plenty of shopping and food places within minutes. Be aware though the hotel is located on a busy street on the edge of the red light district - so it has a lot of bars and clubs. Day time and most nights the area is fine but on Friday nights it can get very rowdy. Music is louder and you have "interesting" people dressed up outside girl clubs. From our room it was very quiet though.We would definitely stay at this hotel again!

I'm happy with the service and room quality of hotel. Staff was very helpful and courteous. Rooms were clean and had the appropriate amenities, including a toilet seat warmer! Breakfast was a very decent and simple buffet of breads, jams, cereals, hot food, salads. Hotel per se deserves a good rating! Location wise, the hotel seemed to be ideally located near restaurants and groceries and train stops, making dining and transport very easy. However, it was located in Kabukichon, the heart of adult night entertainment in Shinjuku, so laden with bars with adult-rated posters and big burly staff members at their entrance gates and the streets around, trying to entice adult men and women to come inside. I was with my young teen sons who are tall enough not to be immediately perceived as young teens until up close so I would note staff members trying to come near us then backing off once they see that my 3 sons were young teens. In fairness, they were respectful enough to keep their distance and not give us trouble but each time we would walk outside at night, I always had some fear. And because of this, I didn't allow my young teens to go out to explore by themselves specially at night. So, if you're just adults traveling on business, this hotel is a good place to stay at. But if with children, on a family vacation, best to stay elsewhere.

Loved the hotel; stayed for a few days. The neighborhood is fun and is incredibly close to stores like Don Quixote, Komehyo, Isetan, and a ton of different restaurants. There is a 24-hour Lawsons downstairs selling food and drinks. The hotel staff are professional, young, and helpful. A very sunny and clean breakfast area frequented by a good range of travelers from Japan, Thailand, Korea, Hong Kong, and the USA. It's a smaller hotel so you won't find hordes of noisy group tours! That is a big plus. You have a coffee maker, fridge, in-room safe, and free WiFi. It has a great breeze since you can open the windows. There's also a nice bathtub and one of those Japanese toilets with a heated seat. It is a 10-minute walk from Shinjuku station. Now the downside: the rooms are incredibly small!! That's okay if you are expecting that, otherwise see if you can afford a larger Executive Level room. The free breakfast gets tiresome as it's almost all fried. Shinjuku Station is so hard to understand so if you come off the Narita Express; just follow the yellow signs to the Southeast Exit - then head outside and left and along the narrow streets north toward the hotel (study maps before you arrive). Theoretically, one could also walk underground all the way from the station to about a block from the hotel if you could find your way around...then go up some steps near the corner with Dunkin Donuts. They also have this fun program where if you tell them no room cleaning; then they'll give you a 500 yen voucher to get a souvenir on your way out from their display case.

My rating is based on the hotel. Extremely helpful staff, clean rooms, reasonably big rooms for Japan, good service, good value, and I sure do appreciate chowing down on western food (and lots of it) before tackling Tokyo. Near just about any kind of transit you require. I would stay at this hotel again in a heartbeat.I wasn't expecting Shinjuku to be quite so tout and hustle filled, and, although they didn't bother or harass us (as a couple we probably weren't quite their market for bars and clubs), it didn't make for pleasant walking and gawking on our part.

The hotel is nice enough. OK Buffett breakfast, big. Beds in a twin room. Good, responsive staff. I inadvertently left a small box and a folder filled with travel folders in the room and was not contacted. I was in transit. The neighborhood is dodged with many touts and other "interesting people. Was not comfortable.

Perfect for our needs, central and clean with all the basic necessities. Communication might be challenging at times as several employees do not speak English. However I will have to shine extra light on one special front desk clerk, Igarashi. She is super friendly, speaks English and is extra attentive to our every concern. The dining room is quite adequate, breakfast and lunch selections vary by day but for the most part it served it's purpose by fueling us for the daily jaunts around Tokyo. Servers are also nice and friendly.For the price, this place is a great deal. For our next trip back we would definitely consider staying here again.

The hotel is near the Shinjuku JR station and the Shinjuku Sanchome subway station. It took me about 15 to 20 mins to find the hotel when I first arrived (it normally takes about 10 mins to walk from the hotel to the JR station). The hotel lobby was on the 3rd floor, so you need to take a lift first from the ground floor to get to the hotel lobby. The hotel was within walking distance from major shopping malls in that area (like Isetan, Takashimaya and Lumine) but the hotel was also next to the Kabuki-cho red light district. Good or bad for latter? it all depends on your purpose there (LOL!). Restaurant choices near the hotel were also good. From budget to high-end. From Japanese to Indian to Thai. The hotel staff were friendly, helpful and speak good English. The room was clean and of comfortable size. What I like is their bathroom. Unlike some other hotels which I had stayed previously in Japan, this one I didn't have to stand in the bathtub for a shower as there was a small space next to the bathtub to get one (yes, I have this dislike of standing in the bathtub for a shower). The choice of TV channels was also limited. CNN is the only English channel available.The spread of the breakfast was ok but with little variation. Every other day, I had the same choices for breakfast. Also, the breakfast only starts from 7am, which I think is a bit late. The other issue I had with the breakfast was that the choice of fresh fruits was limited. Of the five days I stayed there, I had banana for four days. The only other day, they served oranges. Overall, I had a pleasant stay at this hotel and would consider going back to this hotel for future stay.

We stayed three nights (one night on arrival, two nights after back from Tateyama) in this hotel in May, 2014. I sent email to the hotel informing that we will have late check in on our arrival date, their quick response to our email is much appreciated. As I spent my birthday during my stay in Japan, they gave me a small gifts with greeting card (two packs of chocolates) in the first night.For the room, it is clean and spacious than expected. The front desk staff with fluent in English and is very helpful. For the breakfast, it offers Japanese and Western styles. Even not many choices but enough. It includes boiled eggs, hams, photos chips, salmon fish (Japanese style) rice, miso soup, salad, 4 choices of juices, coffee or tea, bread, croissants, etc.For the location, it locates in Kabukicho( 歌舞伎町), just opposite to the City Government Office. Many 24-hours restaurants nearby. One convenience store (Lawson) situates at the 1st floor of the hotel. Only 15 minutes walk from the hotel to Shinjuku Station West Exit. For the price, it is reasonable as compared with other similar hotels in Shinjuku area.

We stayed here for 5 nights in April and couldn't have been happier with the location. It was right in with the main streets of Shinjuku making it our favourite place to explore each night as we could walk around easily and make our way back yet we couldn't hear any street noise from our room. It was also a short walk from Shinjuku station making it very easy to get around Tokyo. The hotel intself was lovely and clean with very helpful staff that spoke English well enough to assist english speaking travellers like us. The room was a little small but we expected that in Japan and we still managed to find room for our two suitcases to sit open. We had everything we needed for a trip where we weren't going to spend too much time in the room including a nice clean bathroom. We used the laundry as well which was easy to use. We also decided to have the buffet breakfast one morning which was quite nice (buffets are not normally my favourite style but this one was quite good.) I will definitley be staying here again when I return to Japan.

We spent 4 nights at the Best Western and were immensely impressed. Whilst facilities were minimal, rooms are ample sized, value was frankly amazing, staff excellent at every turn (restaurant recommendations were top notch every time but one!) and location perfect. We were lucky to be upgraded to a dlx room so not sure how much smaller the original superior rooms would have been

This is a surprisingly nice hotel for what is kind of a scuzzy area of town. The breakfast buffet is pretty decent and the staff is nice, with OK English ability. The rooms are pretty small, but that's to be expected for Japan and the price point.

Our family has traveled all over Asia and have experienced a vast array of accommodations. For the price, I was expecting a very small room and average service....I was totally wrong! Our room was on the top floor (14th I think) and it was extremely spacious with 2 queen beds and a large bath. The view was wonderful! The desk personnel were very friendly and helpful when we asked for tourist information. They all spoke excellent English! We had breakfast each morning (4 days stay) and it plentiful with a wide variety of cuisines. The breakfast area is small but it seemed to accomodate everyone just fine. For us, the location of the hotel couldn't have been more perfect. It's just a few steps away from the subway station entrance. I have to admit that I never exited the station and ended up at the right place (by our hotel) during our stay...just confusion for the 1st time Tokyo travelor.  There are lots of restaurants and things to see within walking distance. In fact, one of Tokyo's cool areas is just behind the hotel. There are hundreds of tiny bars that hold 6-12 people all along a walking path. Don't worry though, it seemed to be a place where foreigners pop in and experience a small pub atmosphere for a little while and then try another small 'pub'. Our son was with us so we didn't experience the nightlife but it certainly seemed like a place to visit! Don't hesitate to stay here, it was by far one of the largest and nicest rooms we've stayed at in Asia. Conveient, clean and spacious with outstanding service! We would definately return to the BW Astina.

We stayed in this hotel for three nights. The hotel is in a central location close to Shinjuku station. From the station, once managed to get out on the right side, you can walk (10 min) or take a taxi with a cheap minimun fare (730 JPY). The lobby is upstair from the road and an elevator is available. The dimensions of the room were a bit small as usual in Japan; the width of the bed was a little smaller than we are accustomed and with one side along to the wall resulting a bit uncomfortable due the possibility of beating against the wall. The window looked at Golden Gai but no noise was heard coming from outside.The bathroom was well equipped with the super-technology wc. Both the room and bathroom were well cleaned during all the stay. The breakfast was quite good with a plentiful buffet although most Asian food.The staff was always very friendly and helpful with a good level of English to understand and assisted us for a reservation. The proximity to the station allows this hotel a good starting base for traveling around the city or the country.Overall a good hotel that I would recommend.

Went to Japan for the first time and stayed in this hotel for 6 nights. Reception was located on the 3rd floor, staff were extremely helpful and could speak excellent English. Ours was a standard twin room on the 5th floor. Bed was comfortable and bathroom was well equipped, free WiFi was available, there were vending machines on each floor for laundry (coin operated). Location was perfect, only 5-6 minutes’ walk from Shinjuku station. Take the east exit at Shinjuku train station and walk down through the stairs, look for Subnade shopping mall entrance and take exit 15 to go up the stairs, once out, you will see a Mister Donut on the corner, turn left and after a little walk you will be in front of the hotel. Since the location is Shinjuku it is easy to reach any attraction from there e.g. Asakusa, Disney Land, Odaiba, Harajuku, Shibuya and even Hakone. Another good thing about the hotel is that the breakfast was included in the rate, not many hotels in Tokyo would offer free breakfast. They also give you coupons so if you miss the breakfast, you can use the vouchers at the departmental store downstairs (store name is ‘‘Lawsons’’ and is 24/7).I would recommend you to check the hotel website for seasonal deals, we booked 45 days in advance and saved 40% which was really good. Over all, we loved the hotel and will definitely come back the next time we visit Tokyo.

Good location in Shinjuku, with a karaoke bar just across the street. Good breakfast. Good service, the staff helped us book reservations at restaurants. The rooms were larger than expected. NIce and clean.

Stayed here 9th - 12th April 2014. Nice sized room. Helpful staff that speak English well. Short walk to Shinjuku station. Very close to Golden Gai and Shinjuku's Red Light District, which is good and bad. If you go out at night, expect to be harassed by Nigerian guys out the front. 24 hour store on the bottom floor. Breakfast was OK.

Stayed at the Shinjuku Best Western April 15-23rd, 2014 as part of my first ever visit to Japan. I have to say that this is one of the best hotels I ever stayed in.Location. Perfect! Very lively area, yet very safe and easily connected via subway/train which take you to other areas of the city or country. Shinjuku station of one of the city's major hubs. Lots of restaurants and shops (including major dept stores) are just steps from the hotel. 5 mins from Shinjuku station and other smaller subway stops.Room: I had a single "business floor" room (no longer offered). While slightly on the small side, it was the same size as typical European hotels 3* hotel. Very good layout. Great bed and furniture. Lots of lights and outlets. VERY QUIET, however I wish I could have opened the window for fresh air. Amazing bathroom/shower/toilet (oh do I miss those toilets!!)Service: Always greeted with a smile and handled all my requests very efficiently. One day, upon returning to the hotel, I stopped by the front desk to ask for an Iron. I was told one would be sent up to my room. I barely had time to enter my room and take off my shoes that someone knocked on the door to deliver it. Now, that's fast.Food: Had breakfast included in my room so ate there almost every day. It's got a nice combination of western and Asian type foods with items not typically found for breakfast such as breaded chicken and shrimps, onion rings... Lots of tables and on busy days, they ensured the tables got cleaned up quickly to avoid lengthy waits. If you don't use the Buffet and have a voucher, reception can stamp it for 500 yen credit at Lawsons downstairs. Or you can keep it for Lunch and just pay the difference. Same if you choose to forfeit room cleaning one day, they will give you a 500Y "gift certificate" for the hotel (not valid for Lawsons)Other: Internet is free and worked fine. TV could use more English channels (just CNN), but I later found that some channels (such as NHK-1 and DLife) often have shows or sporting events in their original language. Simply hit "Bilingual" on the remote to switch between languages. Laundry machines on 7th floor is a great benefit, but dryer takes a bit of time (had to leave my in for 90 mins)Only minor drawback was the lack of drawer space for clothing. Things like sucks cannot be hung or placed in the shelf above the clothing rack. Also wish window could open, as I stated earlier.If.. uh.. I mean WHEN I return to Japan, I will certainly return to this hotel. They do everything right.

great located hotel, small economy rooms (with almost no view if you are located in the lower floors, we were on the 5th), very clean, recommended if you are in tokyo to explore the city and drop in bed in the evening. in this area there are lost aof 24h convinient stores, restauranst and bars. lawson located in same building, shinjuku train station just minutes walk from here, also big department stores such as isetan, barneys, OIOI...

This hotel was really clean, rooms are cosy but not cramped. Shower is amazing, excellent range of toiletries supplied.Bed was really comfy, wifi is free and good signal strength. Breakfast was included and was ok, bit strange to have chips onion rings etc at breakfast but all the nor,ail things like toast, croissants cereal, fruit were also available.5 minute walk from shinjuku jr station, use the east exit, cross the road and walk straight up next to the train line until you reach the next street which is quite a large street, cross over, turn right and keep walking past I think 2 streets until you get to the street with a donut shop on the corner and go left up that street, the hotel is halfway up on the right next to Lawson.I would definitely recommend and was really pleased with my choice.

The rooms were clean and the toilet were big based on Tokyo's size. However, I was very disappointed with the overall stay, the housekeeping did not clean the room thoroughly. I could still coffee stains and toilet stains after the housekeeping. In addition, I stayed here for 6 nights, the first night I only check in on mid night, however on my last night stay I requested for a late check out around 1.30pm check out but was declined and was requested to check out latest by 12 pm or else I will incur charges. I had stayed there for 6 nights and I don't think it was too much to request for a late check out at 1.30pm as my partner was sick and needed more rest. Overall, the stay was bad. I had never stayed in a hotel that has such rude staff and unhelpful staff. i would definitely not stay here again unless you like to hang out near the red light district area.

The Hotel is ideally situated only a short walk from Shinjuku Station. Although it is in an area with plenty of clubs and bars there was no problem with noise at night. The staff were friendly and helpful and some spoke good English. The breakfast buffet catered for both Asian and European tastes, We had a very pleasant stay and would certainly use this hotel again

I stayed in Tokyo's Best Western Shinjuku Astina for seven nights in March 2014. I had done some research on Tripadvisor prior to booking and looked at staying in many different Tokyo hotels. All of the hotels in my price range had tiny rooms and most looked a little dated or basic. Then I found the Best Western. It looked very modern, great location, free Wi-Fi, free breakfast and pretty cheap. Too good to be true?I was extremely happy with my stay here. The location is great, very central and close by to Shinjuku train station, which means you can get to pretty much anywhere in Tokyo very easily. It is quite close by to the red light district, but I didn't see too much of the seediness associated with that. Being a white westerner, I was asked most evenings if I'd like to go clubbing or have a massage by hawkers on the street. Be firm with them and they'll leave you alone though. Finding my way to the hotel at 11.30pm after exiting the insanely busy and massive Shinjuku station was a little daunting. There are so many different exits, which means leaving by the wrong one can bring you out to street level nowhere near where you need to be. This is what I did; luckily though I found some English tourists who helped my orientate myself using their iPhone. Eventually having found the hotel, I checked in easily and was greeted by a larger than expected room with a really comfortable double bed and a nice view of the skyscrapers of Shinjuku.The room had everything I needed; alarm, TV, slippers, safe, toiletries, trouser press, air freshener (!), mini-fridge, phone, everything you'd expect and a little more. It was very clean and very comfortable. The Wi-Fi was pretty quick and reliable and there was a LAN cable too if you wanted a wired connection. Just down the hall was a vending machine (common in Japan) with a selection of alcohol and soft drinks as well as snacks. There was also an ice machine. I don't think the hotel had room service (I might be wrong) but there was free breakfast included in my room price. On the ground floor opposite the hotel was a Lawson 24/7 convenience store where you could buy snacks, drink and other things you might need. Very handy and the staff were super polite.Nearby to the hotel worth visiting, there is the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden with beautiful landscaped gardens (great for cherry blossom spotting), Kabukicho district is also close by with its noisy Pachinko slot machine stores, Yasukuni Dori is a neon-lit street with hundreds of shops and restaurants and a little further down the road you have Yoyogi park and the Harajuku district. To sum up, I would definitely recommend the Best Western Shinjuku Astina to anyone visiting Tokyo. Don't be put off by the red light district being nearby; it is there but not particularly in your face. The area is filled with great restaurants and things to see and do. Thank you to the staff at the hotel for being so friendly and polite and making my stay as comfortable as it could possibly have been. I'll be coming back one day!

We had a group of 5 and stayed for 3 nights. Unfortunately we checked in late in the evening and it was very annoying getting through the hordes of people with all our luggage as we walked all the way from the train station. Its a very busy area at night and this was noticeable in the noise in the rooms. Rooms had little room to walk around the bed when you have two suitcases on the floor but otherwise the amenities in the room were good. Breakfast was not the best very small range of hot food but ok if only staying for a short time. Golden gai area is right behind the hotel if your interested in that. If I go to Tokyo again I would stay in a different area like Shibuya as I did not like the red light district for going out at night time as a foreigner you can't get into any of the bars which was annoying.

Stayed 3 nights at end of trip. Shinjuku was favourite part of tokyo and hotel is located right in the middle of it. Area is actually a red light district but wife and I barely noticed it. Its there but if you dont go looking for it it wont go looking for you.5-10 min walk from shinjuku station. Lawsons downstairs and 7/11 nearby. Lots of restaurants, bars, shopping and food choices nearby.Rooms were small but actually the biggest we stayed in during out trip. At least we could store luggage without having to jump over bed. Bathroom also decent size.Rooms are modern and clean. Can get a bit bright at night if you face the main street and are on a lower level.Staff were attentive and helpful.Overall recommend as a great modern clean and comfortable no frills style hotel in tokyo.

As mentioned by other travelers, this hotel has great location, great service, the room is consider spacious in Tokyo and it is clean. We stayed on the 4 floor and unfortunately there was an incident at like 3 or 4am, so we were awake by the police siren. Never found out what had happened. Although it is located in Kabukicho, I never felt unsafe. Yes you will sometimes see drunk people at night and in early morning, but that doesn't bother me at all. The location is just excellent, it is within 10 min walk from the Shinjuku East station, many restaurants and shops near the hotel, a convenience store is located right by the hotel.

This hotel was perfect for us! In Tokyo you are barely in the room, so the room, although a bit small, suited. Location was great, really close to restaurants and shops! The Shinjuku Golden Gai is also right behind the hotel which is really cool to check out at night. Breakfast was good the first few days, but after a week there we were a bit bored with the options. Overall though, I would stay there again.

Booked this place for a night as it wasn't too expensive and I wasn't disappointed.The room was clean and functional. The location was fine, walking distance to shinjuku station and the area itself was fairly lively, so ideal for a walk around.

We started our two week tour in Japan In Tokyo. The room as expected was small however the toilet was pretty spacious considering the size of the room. The amenities provided were helpful. There are many restaurants around the hotel. Once you cross the main road many izakayas (local restaurants) Food is not cheap and one must remember there is a table charge per person. Which can amount to a cost of the dish.Breakfast served was pretty standard. However very centrally located as the hotel is close to the shinjuku station.

Hotel in excellent if lively location. Very close to public transport, restaurants, bars and department store. Room very compact but functional and clean. Reception staff very friendly and helpful. Good breakfast. Hotel also has a washing machine/dryer for guest which is a godsend for an extended stay.

We stayed in a triple room for 6 days in April 2014 and loved the hotel. It was very clean and the staff were friendly. The bedroom was a great size for the 3 of us , especially for a Japanese hotel. It's close to some great shopping and train stations so we would stay there again.

This hotel was an excellent choice for us. Great location in busy Shinjuku, an easy walk from the JR train station, subway station, countless good and reasonably priced restaurants, parks, department stores, convenience stores, etc. Good breakfast included. The staff was able to answer any question. Wi-Fi worked great.

A very comfortable stay with good quality fittings in the room. Breakfast spread is also reasonably good and the service at the Front Desk and Cafe is excellent. If one does not mind the lively karaoke and bar area in which the hotel is located, it is perfect for a traveller who wants a comfortable but not terribly expensive stay in Shinjuku.Tip : As the street signs are not clear in Japan, especially coming in from Narita or Haneda airport via limousine bus, we find that the easier way is to go underground. Walk towards Keio Plaza and you will see the Tokyo subway entrance at Shinjuku Station. Follow directions for the Marunouchi Line and get out at exit B9. Once on ground level, turn left, walk towards main street. you will see Mister Donut across the road. The hotel is just 50m past Mister Donut down the road. If you are craving for a bowl of authentic and delicious soba (hot and cold available), walk towards Uniqlo department store near the hotel. The soba stall is tucked into a narrow lane behind Uniqlo. For 400 yen, you can have a hot steaming bowl of soba with tempura bits and an onsen egg. You can't miss the store as there is a always a queue forming, but it moves pretty fast.

Great hotel in a excellent location in the heart of the action in Shinjuku. Stayed 3 nights here at the end of our trip, and while the room was very compact, it just fitted our 2 large suitcases and souveniours. Bathroom was exceptional for space compared to all other hotels. Breakfast included was fantastic. Staff were very helpful regarding directions, and holding luggage after checkout. Location was good, although confusing... the closest train station is within a major shopping centre... we never once found the same exit back to the hotel... this was made more fun by the shops shutting at 11pm forcing us up onto the street in a new exit every time! Thank goodness for Google maps on our mobile phone :) Not quite close enough to walk with lots of luggage to and from the hotel from the train, but close enough to get around each day. Be sure to eat at the restaurant on the floor below the hotel... we unfortunately only discovered this on our last night... with a free drink for hotel guests, amazing food, and awesome sake, it was one of the best restaurants we ate at on our trip. Much fun to be had in the hotel street alone with Karaoke offering nomihodai (all-you-can-drink) just 4 doors or so up, and a late-night cocktail/dessert bar directly across the road ( the honey bread was sensational). We would recommend this hotel. (if you ever get lost staying there... just look for the Mister Donut shop on the corner - it'll get you home!)

This hotel is in a great location and we would stay here again for that reason alone. The hotel is well run with helpful and friendly staff at the front desk and excellent free wifi. But having read many reviews on the hotel we think we may have drawn the short straw in terms of the hotel room. We were allocated a room on the 6th floor which is a designated non smoking floor. We are non smokers but are not overly sensitive to smoke, however the oder of stale smoke was always present in the room. We were expecting a small room but were surprised to find that one side of the double bed was right up against the bathroom wall, making it an effort to climb out of bed from that side. Also, the bathroom door was opaque glass with a 6 inch gap under and above it. This meant that the bathroom couldn't be used with the light on in the middle of the night without lighting up the bedroom. We got a very good price for the room, so perhaps we were allocated one of their worse rooms, so we will give it the benefit of the doubt.

I stayed for 5 nights and confirm all the positive reviews on Tripadvisor for this hotel.I would certainly recommend it for its position, comfortable and clean rooms, firendly staff and good value for money.

Very nice hotel in a very well located place in Shinjuku. I will recommend it for visiting Tokyo. The only but could be the breakfast because it doesn't have a lot of variety but is quite good. 5 minutes walking to Shinjuku Sanchome Metro Station and 8 minutes to Shinjuku Jr Station. A lot of restaurants close to it of every kind of Japanese food.

Stayed with my family for a week. Love the location, safe and alive!! It is at the heart of Shinjuku and convenient to train stations , both the subway and JR lines. Close to shops, restos. Good wifi. The room is quite small but since you are out most of the times, you wouldn't mind it. Reasonably priced, clean. The only thing is the buffet breakfast with not much variety after staying for a week and having the same breaky, you tend not to enjoy it. But we'll and good rather than nothing. I love the staff, very helpful esp those staff at night shift! Gorgeous even ;)

Fantastic location, easy access to Shinjuku station and shopping and nightlife, very friendly and helpful staff, clean and we'll maintained and reasonably priced. Excellent start to our 2 weeks in Japan

The hotel is pretty much spot on! Its located 5 minutes walk from Shinjuku JR station East side exit North or Central gates which are well signposted from the Narita Express platform. The staff are pleasant and helpful and speak English. The rooms are a bit small but are well equipt and a decent hair dryer was a bonns for the wife. The breakfast included was nice and a good way to start the day, some interesting choices on offer :). I would recommend this hotel to all types of traveller and would use again. Some fab little bars just in the ittle alley if you turn right from hotel elevator and not sure where some people stayed did not see any shady touts at all.

There arent many breakfast spots out there so the option not needing to think of where to head for breakfast is great. Standard food fare, but refreshing to have a mix of Japanese and Western spread. Stayed for 4 nights and it was great. Room and toilet are clean, location is great, just a stone throw away from golden gai (dont believe the reviews when they say they dont accept tourists and you can only walk by to sight see. We had so much fun there we was there for 2 nights) and a 5-10mins walk to the Shinjuku main station. Room is a tad too small though. but good enough since we dont spend much time in the room anyway. reception is friendly and helpful, they will always try to assist with any questions you may have on the area and how to get there. I would return again definitely!

I was very satisfied with my stay at this hotel. The room was confortable and the staff really helpful. You can notice they thought of the key things that a person traveling would need, like access to a washing machine, that was excelent for me, I was very happy about being able to wash my clothes. The room was relatively small, yes, but as everybody says, that´s the norm in Tokyo, so I was expecting that. However, it had all the things I needed (like hairdryer, shampoo, rinse, toothbrush, comb, face soap, etc), it was clean and it had wi-fi. Perhaps they could also include some body cream, that´s the only thing missing. The breakfast was OK, I would only suggest to add some fresh fruit instead of canned, but perhaps they don´t do it because fruit is expensive in Japan (not asking for watermelon, but some apples?). The location is good, but some people would proably prefer a quiter area. It was very convenient to have a shop and quiet restaurant/bar just next to the hotel. Overall, I would recomend this hotel to friends.

Hotel is about 15minutes walk from JR Shinjuku East Exit. You may pass through Subnade and use Exit 15. Check In/Out is a breeze. Breakfast has limited choices but filling enough to start your day in Tokyo. Room is really small but since I stayed with my two small kids, It's not that much of an issue. Bed is comfortable but the pillows are so small they look like throw pillows. Bathroom is clean though the drain on the sink is clogged, it takes a while for the water to go down.The hotel is within the Kabukicho area but I never felt unsafe. Hotel is near Takashimaya, Isetan and Lumine for those who are into shopping.Hotel is good and worth the price but nothing exceptional.

We stayed at this hotel for 3 nights and were on the overall very impressed with the hotel and level of service we received. This is probably close to a 4.5 stars hotel in Australian standards. We booked the Executive Double B room on the 13th floor and had great views of the city. Staff were extremely friendly and helpful, and they spoke basic English. Breakfast buffet was included with our room and consist of Japanese and Western style options, and it was delicious. The bed was comfortable and room was cleaned to a high standard. I was impressed with the size of the bathroom given the size of the room and there were heaps of space to put my toiletry bags at the sink. I love the complimentary Evelyn & Crabtree toiletry provided. My only complain would be the lack of towel rails and places to hang our clothes. This is however a minor detail. We would definitely choose to stay here again if we return to Tokyo.

Have just returned from a staying at this hotel for 3 nights, and the room was clean and cozy, albeit a little small. We stayed in the double room and the bed was slightly smaller than a single bed, but again....soft and comfy. The hotel staff were friendly enough, but not overly bubbly or warm. The breakfast was a big disappointment, as I often look forward to a big spread at hotels of this caliber. However, the western selection was very limited with some orange/yellow gloop available that they claimed was scrambled eggs. There was no bacon anywhere to be seen, and one small toaster oven with a timer for all the guests to share if one wanted toast. The hotel is close to one of the Shinjuku train station entrances if you exit the hotel and go left, with a short walk up the street to loads of restaurants and shopping. However, for god's sake...down go right out of the hotel as the street in front and nearby is filled with African/shady Japanese touts offering to shake your hand and introduce you to "sexy girls."

Pros:We booked 3 rooms for 5 nights at the best western. The rooms were clean and tidy (beds were a bit on the smaller size), staff were very friendly and helpful, and breakfast was included and offered a good range. The hotel provides service laundry facilities. Cons:The hotel is not in a good location if travelling with children - African pimps harass you at night. Tips:There is a lawson convenience store on the bottom floor of the hotel for snacks/drinks. There is also a close metro station.
