this rating is only because the location is in tokyo, elsewhere i would have given a lower rating. this hotel has very good location and quite easy to find if you follow the hotel map (print from the hotel website). the walk to the shinjuku main train station is an easy walk. but if you hv a lot of lugages, then a diff story because we hv to climb many stairs in the train station. from shinjuku JR station exit walk towards ABC store across then follow the map isntruction. nearby there are BIC uniqlo store, yodabashi etc. also walkable to takashimaya. we stayed here for 4 nights. 2 nights upon arriving and another 2 nights before leaving japan. we stored our big lugages in the hotel for 5 days in between our stays for free. the breakfast is average but almost same menu every day. our room is very small compared to other same class hotel outside japan and the double bed is small for 2 smaller than a queen sized bed. esp if you are a 180cm man. everything else is great very clean, room amenities are complete with a warming toilet. but the best thing is the location hence i would say this is a good value hotel. although the area is in kabukicho i dont feel the location is unsafe. no such feeling at all. we would definitely return and would recommend this to our friends n family. oya the hotel staff has quite a good english also.

Booked online and stayed for two nights with my wife. Never expected the room to be so compact (considering that I just check out from a spacious hotel suburb of Tokyo) but sufficient for two person with two huge luggage bags. Strategic location, around 5-10 minutes walk from train station and plenty of place for food, shopping, site seeing and clubbing (if you're interested). A convenient store is located just below the hotel, great place to grab some beer and snacks. Clean room and toilet (which is very important to me). Wifi is superbly slow but if you're patience enough, you are good to go. A/C could be better, takes awhile to cool the room. Perhaps will come again but if with my baby will definitely request for a bigger room. Staffs are very friendly and helpful with our queries.

I stayed here for 2 nights, and it totally surpassed my expectations. Sure the location is right on the edge of Kabukicho, but it is Japan and I have never felt safer. The staff was very friendly and helpful. Check in and out was a breeze. The room and bathroom was super clean. A bit small yes, but it is Japan. I loved staying at this hotel. Close to Shinjuku station and the metro line. Great value for money!

Our children very like this hotel ! Becouse this hotel room is very clean and bathroom is very comfortible ! This hotel's location is good. have many line can take likely JR line,京王 line , 都營新宿line and 丸之內line! If you go to tokyo , choice here is a very good idea i think!

My partner and I loved this hotel, the staff were very welcoming, the room was lovely & spotless. The breakfast buffet was good & very fresh. They even lent us umbrellas when it was pouring! Couldn't fault a thing, would definitely recommend!

Friendly staff. Room was smaller than expected (one side of double bed beside wall) but was off a good standard.Great breakfast buffet with something for everyone. Easy enough walk back to train station. Good location.

I spent 16 nights in this great buy of a hotel.I booked my stay through wotif.com and got a AU$5 a night better deal than the Best Western 40% rate.Location can't be beaten. Not only is Shinjuku a hive of restaurants, night life and culture, the hotel is located 10 minute slow walk to the JR line and there are entries to the subway no more than 50 metres away. I was trying to find a way out of the snow storm and found the rabbit warren of cafes, cute shops, restaurants all on the short walk to the subway line.This area is not as sleazy as past reviews have mentioned, I think the most interesting site was a transgender geisha handing out flyers for a massage place. I walked confidently after dark and always felt safe. Lawsons convenience shop is on the 1st floor which have great prices and hot food though the staff at the 7-11 10 metres down the road are MUCH friendlier and the 7-11's atm accepts foreign bank cards. The breakfast offered here was great and if you can;t find your usual breakfast fare, i'm not quite sure what you are eating. I did have lunch one day and wasn't too wowed but certainly couldn't complain with the cheap price.Two of us shared a standard double room which after 16 nights certainly tested it for size and comfort. We never felt cagey. We ended up putting our bags at the end of the lounge. The bed was spacious for us, 6ft6 husband and a chubby wife. The pillows weren't to my liking. One was too soft and the other felt like a bag of rice. The bathroom was surprisingly big. Modern and clean. Cosmetics and toiletries were replaced daily and were of good quality. I really miss the bidet. First time user and now addict. (I miss you Janis).All staff were lovely and helpful. Couldn't fault them. One tip is to write down questions or requests in case you have a thick English accent, makes it easier all round.Vending machines are on every floor except on level 7 where there are washers and dryers. You can also buy movie cards which have English movies. The only English channel is CNN. Already recommended this hotel and they will be seeing us again all too soon.

The hotel room is clean and tidy. Staffs are helpful and the most important is value for money. It takes only 10 mins walk from shinjuku JR station to the hotel. There is a convenient store at the group floor of the hotel， so you can buy necessity， food and drinks in a very convenient way. The buffet breakfast is also fine.

This hotel is the perfect one for city addicted visitors.- PERFECT location meters away from the Golden Gaï, in the heart of Shinjuku, across the street from Kabushicho. 3mn walk from the JR Station (direct rom the airport).- GREAT service, we were able to confirm our Jiro Sushi reservation, they can also arrange tours.- (good) breakfast and internet included- rooms are bigger than most rooms in Tokyo, you can actually move around even with two suitcases.- the hotel is quite new and very clean.At this price, it's the best value we find and we keep coming back - even after trying several others in this neighborhood and others. (they tend to be quickly fully booked)

We stayed at the BW Shinjuku for almost a week in October 2013. This was the perfect place for us. The hotel is relatively recent, the design is modern and stylish, and the hotel is very clean.Location is great, very close to Shinjuku station (east) and at the edge of Kabukicho and Golden Gai. Regular rooms are a bit small, but not unusual for Tokyo. We upgraded to a room on the executive floor, which gave us a room twice as large as a regular room for a small fee. Bathroom was large and clean. Included breakfast is average but offers the basics (hot and cold): eggs, fruits, yogurt, etc as well as Japanese breakfast.Overall, we loved this hotel and will definitively go back at our next trip to Tokyo. We had previously stayed at the Washington Hotel, in Shinjuku West, but the BW is a lot better (more recent, cleaner, more stylish and better located).

The Best Western was a great value for the cost. The location was excellent for activities and restaurants and shopping. With good access to Metro and airport limo. The neighborhood was an interesting one with a few unsavory businesses nearby. However, we always felt perfectly safe. The breakfast was decent, although the same every day. The staff was very friendly and helpful. The room was very nice with lots of amenities. The bed was comfortable however the pillows were hard.All in all a great value for the money.

Very good hotel, right by golden gai bar district, try Aruka bar, very welcoming!Getting to and from Skinjuku station is very easy and other reviewers have described it in detail.I took train from shinjuku to Narita, very easy ans recommended.Hotel rooms are small but well equipped. Good breakfast.

Stayed here for four nights with my family during our January holidays. The location of this hotel is perfect as it is a 5-10 mins walk to the Shinjuku JR station. Lots of eateries nearby and very near major shopping malls such as Isetan and Takashimaya.. Right below the hotel is Lawson's convenience store, which we visited everyday to get snacks, milk, etc.We stayed on the business floor, and there was a vending machine that you could go to get cups of hot coffee, tea, hot chocolate, etc. It was a hit with my kids! Rooms are quite spacious for Japanese standards and we had 2 double beds that accommodated the four of us (2 kids) comfortably. There is also coin operated laundry facility on the 8th floor which we found very useful. Breakfast buffet was included in our rate. The buffet included a mix of traditional Western breakfast items and Japanese breakfast items (mackerel, miso, salad, rice, beef curry) and a rotating mix of other items (onion rings, shrimp tempura, chicken karaage).Overall, you couldn't fault this hotel.

It took us more than an hour to locate the hotel from the shinjuku airport shuttle bus stop.Was surprised at how small the room was for me, my wife and 2 li'l kids of 2 and 6 and immediately opted for a bigger room. Staff at the hotel was friendly to accommodate our request and helps me with directions.A friendly smile will welcome you every morning for breakfast.The only big problem is the location as it is located in the heart of red light district in shinjuku.I was approached by hordes of locals and even foreign people for (illegal services) every time I walk around the area and it is quiet annoying to be honest.BTW having a free WIFI helps!

People looking for gentle and kind Japanese culture, will frown at vulgarity and racketiness of this area of deep Shinjuku. But for the traveller willing to enjoy a night in Shin-juku, this is the best location.The rooms are on 3rd floor above, so guests are separated from the noise of street. The room I stayed was clean and quiet, I was relaxed on a cozy couch. The size of room and bath room was sufficient to one night stay, big enough compared to standard hotel in Tokyo.The front staff in night shift was so kind to tell me FREE Wi-fi password in midnight. Great thanks!

After reading various reviews on which area to stay, decided on Shinjuku for its proximity to a lot and ease of getting on the metro/JR line. The hotel had decent reviews. I booked the Female Only Executive floor room. It is small but cosy. The bathroom is a big winner though with great shower and lots of amenities. The massage chair is nice after lots of walking around. Bed is pretty comfy and like the ability to control my room temperature. Would like a better curtain to darken the room at 5am but it is ok. Good wifi/internet connection. Breakfast is so-so but comes included so won't complain. The main thing to be aware of is that this street is the "seedier" side of Shinjuku because it has a lot of girlie bars on it. No one bothers me aside from a few guys saying hello, but for men they apparently get some harassment. Otherwise not unsafe and constantly bustling with people. The Lawsons convenience store at the bottom of the hotel is handy too.

Be warned, it can be a little hard to locate this hotel, street signage is not very obvious and the entry is on the 2nd floor so easy to miss, and no one on the street seemed to even know it was there, look for the Lawson convenience store and there is a elevator opposite the side entry to the store. Side note, Lawson is great, cheap beer and food ( sushi, cakes, steam buns etc ) As we arrived in the middle of a snowstorm it is worth noting that you can almost walk the whole way underground from the train station, you follow the signs to the East Exit of Shinjuku station and then continue to the Subnade shopping arcades and walk until you locate exit no 15 ( there are maps ), this brings you up on the main road where you continue in the same direction to Mr Donut on the corner, turn left and Lawson / Best Western is not far down the block on the same side.We stayed at this hotel twice in the space of a month, for a total of 7 nights, staying in a double room on the Executive floors. Yes the rooms are small but it would seem to be similar at all but the largest 5 star hotels in Tokyo. However the bathrooms are huge, almost equivalent in size to the bedroom, with excellent and large showers as well as the ubiquitous electronic Japanese toilet. The beds are double size and placed in the corner which is not ideal for 2 western size people, however for a little more you can get a twin room and avoid this. There is free Wifi ( ask for password on check in) and the staff were very helpful with my multiple requests for additional bedding, bag minding, change for the washing machine etc. We didnt have breakfast included in our rate but decided to eat in the hotel every morning as it was excellent value @ approx AUD$10 pp for the buffet, it is worth noting that many cafes and restaurants dont open before 10am anyway, as it doesnt appear the Japan has the cafe breakfast / brunch type culture as you may be used to if from a western country. The best part of the hotel is its location, go out the back exit and turn right, you will be in the Golden Gai area of small cheap bars. Or go back to the main road and cross it you find the more upmarket area of Shinjuku with the high end shops ( the multiple shops selling 2nd hand designer goods are worth checking out if you're in the market for a Louis Vuitton bag or Rolex watch, they are as good as new ) and great bars / restaurants.

As many people would expect japan is quite a tricky place to get used too in many ways, but once we found the hotel which was a little tricky we realised it is in a very very good location meters from the main shinjuku train station and a lot of bars and restaurants and shops. the rooms are very small but still nice and clean obviously as it is japan. japan is a little expensive for most things so the accom was expensive for the size but you don't really have much choice as most hotels are very similar unless you can afford to spend $500 + a night. free wifi was available in the lobby.

This hotel is in a great location once you eventually find it! We walked the wrong way from the train station first so had to back up on ourselves. My tips for finding the hotel;From Shinjuku train station walk straight ahead to the main road and turn right. You will need to cross over to the other side and keep walking until you see Mister Donut. You turn left down this street and you will see the hotel signposted on the right hand side of the street with the signs for the hotel reception on the 3rd floor which you can get in the lift (next to Lawson).I had read many reviews that the hotel was very small but I'm not sure if it was just our room (we were on floor 13) but we had plenty of space and did not find Japanese rooms small at all, not large either but average, particularly for a budget chain hotel. Hotel was very clean, and whilst it is in the area of kabukicho we didn't think this was a bad thing, it just meant there were plent y of bars, restauarants etc to go to on your doorstep and we had no bother. We found a street of extremely tiny bars (fit max 10 people in) nearby which was a great find and spent many hours here!

This hotel is in a great location only a few stones throws from the Shinjuku action & the Shinjuku metro & JR stations, yet quiet enough to enjoy a blissful nights rest. Yes the room was small & required a little judicial placement of luggage, but hey, we only occupied it in the evening & in the morning.The hotel backs onto the Golden Gai area, thus it is only a short walk after enjoying a night cap beverage.Front desk staff were very helpful. Would definetely stay again...

I read many reviews about hotels in japan before going and they all said the same - hotel rooms are small! And yes, that's exactly true for his hotel. The bed was a double bed for both me and my husband leaving barely any room for our two large suitcases. Apart from the room size everything was great. The staff were very helpful, the hotel was very clean and modern. the location is just near the red light district in shinjuku but please don't let this stray you. We never felt unsafe, uneasy or saw anything creepy. It was the perfect location to find hidden restaurants and quirky cafés. We never used taxis staying here, we would take the subway everywhere. Great hotel overall!!

Perfect for our stay, nice small and cosy room, and somehow very quiet considering its a busy area of Tokyo. Wifi was free and fast also. walking distance to a few train stations which was also very convenient.

Stayed here for four nights with my partner and a group of friends including another couple from 7th March to 11th March 2014.The location is perfect for visiting Tokyo, as it's a 5-10 minute walk from Shinjuku station and in the heart of Shinjuku's somewhat seedy (yet quite safe) nightlife!Rooms were well equipped and comfortable and the staff went out of their way to make our stay as pleasant as possible. Our rate included a breakfast buffet which was quite reasonable and a recommended option.

Very nice hotel, it was clean and comfortable. The staff was top notch! Booking and checkin was a breeze and even helped us with some changes. Breakfast was wonderful. The neighborhood is well located but in a seedier part of Shinjuku but we never had any problems with that. My only gripe was that the lobby smelled heavily of a fragrance or cologne which I disliked. Rooms were ok, TVs at least had CNN. Wifi was spotty but useable.Great hotel, would recommend

This property is located very close to the red light district, but it does not bother us at all! This location is very close to the subway, shopping malls, small shops as well as food places! Many parts of Tokyo actually sleeps at around 10 pm, only busy places have shops close at 11 or 12... and this is the part of town that does not sleep! At 12 am.. the streets are still filled with people!For around 130 USD a night, with clean, comfortable, decent sized room, (bathroom's shower is very comfortable and the heated toilet seat...amazing) and FREE wifi as well as FREE breakfast.. you can't ask for much more. The staffs are extremely friendly and some random things you can ask for at the front desk are.. weights for your luggage (to ensure you don't go over the 23 kg limit at the airport), umbrella if needed when raining.. and they also have a promotion right now for buy one get one free voucher for the robot restaurant, you can ask the staffs to help you book if needed!Not sure when I will be back, but would recommend this hotel to friends traveling around this part of Tokyo.

We have stayed one week here and it has been an absolute pleasure The staff are extremely helpful and courteous as is the rest of the population here in Tokyo. The room is quite large for a Japanese hotel room, everything is super clean and comfortable. I would definitely stay here again on next trip

Great price (paid ~ $130 AUD per night inc breakfast). Location is very central and although its meant to be bordering on red light district, did not feel unsafe at all. Rooms are small however very modern and the shower is amazing. We stayed on the business floor (level 11 and above are business levels) so I'm not sure if this is in a standard room but we got a proper shower (located next to a bathtub) instead of a bathtub shower. Wi-Fi kept dropping out which wasn't a huge issue. You just had to keep reconnecting with the password. Lawsons downstairs if you needed snacks. Would definitely stay again.

I've stayed here twice now, Jan 2010 and Feb 2014. Both stays were great and I really liked the hotel in 2010, I must say that in my opinion the hotel has improved and is even better now. Staff are lovely, rooms spotlessly clean and still in great condition. The quality and variety if the food in the breakfast buffet is also much improved and enjoyable. We love the location right in the heart of Shinjuku and easily walk from the east exit of Shinjuku station.

Quick and hassle free checkin / checkout. Room was twin, with two nice bed. Size of room is compact, as expected in Tokyo, with a nice bathroom. Stayed on 14th Floor executive rooms.Short walk to and from Shinjuku station, and is very close to the Golden Gai area.

This is a great place to stay close to Shinjuku Sta. When leaving the station, remember to take the Kabukicho exit, in the east side (Shinjuku is huge, it is easy to get lost there). The rooms are small, but you are in Tokyo! Breakfast is nice for westerns too. Don't forget to take a coffee watching people in Shibuya, just two metro stations ahead.

I came to Tokyo for the Tokyo Marathon and sought a hotel close to the race start. I also wanted a modern, Western style bathroom. While small, this was an extremely nice, newly updated hotel bathroom with a seriously great toilet. The heated seat was much appreciated after sightseeing in wintry February. Breakfast buffet was included with our stay which defrayed meal costs and made our day more efficient. The buffet included a mix of traditional Western breakfast items (toast, cereal, OJ, fruit) and Japanese breakfast items (mackerel, miso, salad, rice, beef curry) and a rotating mix of other items (onion rings, shrimp tempura, sweet and sour pork, boiled ham). The scrambled eggs were not like Western scrambled eggs, much soupier but they got the job done. Coffee and tea and a variety of juices were available. The location is superb, a quick walk to Shinjuku Station where you can get on virtually any train line in Tokyo, and nearby Takashiyama Times Square which has a great restaurant selection if you are too tired to sort out the numerous Shinjuku offerings. The front desk staff was extremely helpful in facilitating and explaining transportation to the airport, posting mail for us, and helping with a faulty LAN line in our room. I have traveled widely and would stay again at this hotel.

Conveniently located in Shinjuku. Direct Narita express toashinjuku station. Get out from East entrance. Print out map from hotel website. Directions are super clear for you to locate the place. About 5 to 8 minutes walk from station. Lobby on third floor with elevator. Look out for the Lawson convenient store downstairs to locate the hotel. Room is small as expected for Tokyo. No luggage spaces hence need to put on the couch. But bathroom is more than suffice with bathtub and bidet. Hotel staff are friendly.Lots of eateries nearby. Robot restaurant is just at the next alley. Situated in nearby red light district but relatively safe. On the Main Street nearer to Burger King, you can go to Calico cat cafe situated on 6th floor if you are a cats lover. Reservations required though. Very near major shopping malls such as Isetan and Takashimaya. And near many train lines that take you to all over Tokyo. There are shoppings underground too.

I stayed here for 4 nights in February 2014. This was my first visit to Tokyo, and I wanted to be within walking distance to the Shinjuku Station. With a little advance planning I didn't have any trouble finding the hotel by walking from Shinjuku Station (about a 7min walk). The location is relatively quiet (for Tokyo) but just steps from the heart of the Shinjuku entertainment district with a plethora of dining, drinking, and entertainment options. The front desk staff were polite and spoke fluent English. My room was a decent size...I was expecting something unmanageably small for the price I paid in such a central location, but I was pleasantly surprised. It was actually a bit larger than single hotel rooms I've stayed at in Paris. The room was quiet, had a nice view, and the bathroom was a decent size and very modern. The housekeepers did a great job everyday and the room was always spotless when I returned from sightseeing. Most importantly, this location is excellent for transit options to explore Tokyo, and it is also a one-seat ride from Narita Airport to Shinjuku Station on the Narita Express train (about 75/80mins).The only negatives I can think of were the free breakfast (limited options and some rather strange dishes for breakfast time) and that you have to take an escalator or lift from street level up to the 3rd floor, then take a different lift to the guest rooms. Overall, this is a great choice for travelers who looking for a clean, modern, mid-range hotel without paying the crazy prices of the Park Hyatt, etc.
user_name:
RobbieNYC
New York City, New York

review_body: The hotel is in Shinjuku and as other reviewers have commented, Shinjuku is not a family place. The hotel itself is ok, but the rooms are small (even for Tokyo). Breakfast was nice and the hotel staff were very friendly and helpful.

Location: The Best Western was a short walk from the JR Shinjuku Train Station. The hotel was easy to locate using google maps navigation. Close to 24/7 store, several restaurants and international ATM facilities.Hotel: Very boutique in style, the Best Western is located on the second floor, with a lift facility. Staff spoke limited English, but we're very helpful with any request. Room: Average room size. Modern bathroom facilities. Fairly hard bed and pillows. Wifi and safe included. View: No balcony with not much of a view.Summary: This was the first hotel we stayed at upon arriving in Japan. Would book again. Couple in 20 - 30 age bracket. Stayed in a double non - smoking room.

As it was our first trip to Japan, and we weren't quite sure what to expect, we chose to book into a chain as we thought the English language of the staff etc. would be better. Finding the hotel from the station was a bit of a challenge, especially as we had arrived rather jet lagged, in the dark and bitter cold, but by sheer luck we managed to get there. It would be easy to walk past as the sign is at first floor height, but once we were in, we were very pleased. Yes the room was small, but we had anticipated that based on the fact that when we booked one of the pieces of information about the room was its square feet! Having researched we knew that the hotel was in the red light district, but to be honest, from what we saw it was no different from being in somewhere like Soho, and we experienced no problems. Location is good, it's on all the main train lines. Would stay here again.

Myself, wife and 12 year old son stayed at the Best Western Astina in January 12th for 5 nights.We did a fair research on where to stay in Tokyo as we have never been to the city before. We chose this hotel because it had good reviews, the location and importantly it's ability to accommodate my son in a twin room.This is what I liked about the hotel.The beds. The single beds are what I would call king singles. They can easily sleep two.The room. Clean with a table and chairs and a good size.The Location. Brilliant. Everything in Shinjuku was at your doorstep. The place had a buzz to it. The red light district was very tame and completely safe.The Staff. Kind, courteous and efficient.The breakfast. Included in the price was quite ok without being anything special.The price. We booked directly 3 months ahead and got a good discount on the room. Excellent value compared to other places we stayed.In summary. We couldn't fault this hotel and would certainly go there again.

Hotel can be a little challenging to locate if you are not familiar with the Shinjuku area. It is about an 8-10 mins walk to the Shinjuku station. But once you figure your way, it's actually okay.The hotel rooms are small which is typical of hotels in Japan. It is very clean and bathroom is of a decent size. They provide slippers, robes and a deodorizer which I found to be a thoughtful touch. We love usingthe deodorizer to rid of food smell from our outer coats/jackets as well as shoes and carpet.Rates at this hotel are affordable and I would consider returning on my next trip to Tokyo.

I noted most of the review here vote the location down -- but if you're in Shinjuku and are shocked and appalled by the Red Light District and ample supply of adult stores, you clearly haven't done your research. The hotel was very comfortable, and was very reasonably priced for our stay. There is a convience store located below the lobby, which made it easy to load up on essentials. You've got more than enough choice when it come to food and drink in the area, just be careful who you follow down a dark alley. I must say, it was slightly annoying to be walking home after a reasonably large night out, only to be pestered by persistent Nigerian men, spruiking their girly bars. Be careful for this, lads. Other than that, a little bit of a walk from the nearest train station, but very central to the nightlife area. Would recommend for friends travelling to experience the raw Shinjuku.
user_name:
Robert B
Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: Had a nice 3 night stay in february 2014. It was a little hard to find at first, walking from Shinjuku station as the the signing was limited and the hotel lobby was situated on the 3rd floor above a small convenience store. The staff were welcoming and helped with directions and bookings, but something was lacking. Comming back from day trips they would rarely take their eyes off the computer screens to welcome their guests. This was something very different from staying at a traditional japanese ryokan as we had done previously that week. The rooms were clean and modern but very small. With two large bags, we had very little space left on the floor. The rooms were well sound proofed from the busy streets but you could clearly here every single person that walked through the aisle. When it comes to location, it is good for the price but beware, it is bordering the red light district. When walking through this area we were constantly asked if we were interested in "tittybars" and so on. Later in the evening there were often african men following us up to the hotel elevator, trying to get us to follow them for "a fun night". This was a little uncomfortable. I do however recommend going to the "Golden Gai" district, behind the hotel. This is a series of very small streets with hundreds of very small bars (3-12ppl). We had a great night out, meeting local japanese people and singing karaoke into the early hours of the morning. This is the perfect hotel for you who wants to experience the hustle and bustle of one of tokyos bussiest districts,and doesnt want to stay inside at the hotel all day. (no other sitting areas than the small lobby. no gym etc.)

First stayed in February 2013 and was very impressed. Location simply outstanding with the rail station only 5-10 minutes easy walk away. Dining options galore, at every turn there's a great place to eat...too many to name. All the mod cons expected, well appointed rooms, staff helpful and breakfast great. We were aware that this was bordering on the "Red light" district of Kobuchiko, however it wasn't that apparent.2014 very very different indeed. The "Red light" aspect of the area has greatly encrouched on the Hotel and is very very visible in the streets surrounding the Hotel of a night. There are men standing outside these establishments up and down the streets trying to coax people in...rather intimidating looking men.As we returned this time with my Husband and 14 year old son the feeling we had was rather unimpressive of the surrounds and I feel that the area is rapidly declining due to this presence. Would we return to this Hotel based on this last experience.....I would say No!Absolutely nothing wrong with the Hotel and if you weren't planning on venturing out at night then perhaps I may consider but not likely.

In January I stayed at the hotel for one week, All was well until the last night.. I tripped over loose carpet in my room. The hotel went to denial mode. I broke teeth and my glasses. I photographed the carpet and emailed these to management who replied in poor English there was no problem with the room. They refuse to pay for the cost of damages, They will no longer answer my emails.If god forbid there was a fire or earth quake you would not want to be here, they could not cope with a simple incident..

Clean, quiet, in excellent location right on the edge of Kabuki cho (red light district) and 8 min walk from Shinjuku station. Staff is great, helpful, speaking good English. Nice breakfast. Affordable price. If I'll decide to stay in Shinjuku again, I would choose this hotel. However, I think it would be good to stay at other areas of this amazing city. Metro and train network is so intuitive and easy to navigate, and making Tokyo very easy to get around, being so huge. I enjoyed Shinjuku, very unique and safe, despite being a "red light district".

We looked at various reviews on how to get to the hotel after arriving at Haneda airport and though most guests seem to have used to train system to get to the hotel the airport limousine buses are reasonable, efficient and there is no lugging baggage around. The airport limousine bus costs 1200y (~$12) per person, then when we arrived a taxi to the hotel was only another 700y. We arrived late a night and would definitely recommend this as an easy way to arrive.The rooms are small - it's Tokyo space is at a premium, but we were pleasantly surprised with the well utilised space.The hotel is going Eco friendly so if you are happy to pass on room servicing for a couple of days then you get 500y voucher per day, which we used toward the breakfast buffet.The breakfast buffet is OK, fine but nothing to rave about.Wifi was reliable.Location was great, right in the middle of everything in Shinjuku (kabuchiko), 5 minutes walk to Shinjuku or Shinjuku sanchome stations, Golden Gai small bar streets behind the hotel. The area is considered to be the red light district but it felt very safe to walk around into the early hours, we even had touts helping us to find our way around.Couldn't have asked for more, great value, great location, great hotel. For a 3 star hotel you can't expect much more.

We loved our stay at this hotel. The staff were super helpful and the rooms (whilst reasonably small) were spotless and well appointed. The hotel is in the main night club area however its very safe and amongst a hive of activity. Convenience store is right across the road as well as downstairs. The subway is less than a five minute walk so the hotel is ideally suited. Theres wifi in the rooms and the speed is fine.

The hotel is in a great location. It's a 5 minute walk to Shinjuku station. There are heaps of places to eat within the area. The reception staff were excellent. They spoke good English and often helped me out with making phone calls and writing down directions in Japanese. The hotel was very clean throughout and they had a convenience store located on their doorstep. I am glad that I stayed in Shinjuku over Shibuya. I would most definitely stay again.

This hotel has a great location, right in the heart of Shinjuku, with the train station, shopping, restaurants etc all around. We were expecting the room to be small as that is the standard for Tokyo, so in terms of the room quality and expectation, we were happy - very modern and clean and great bathroom. Our only issue was that the room was VERY warm which made sleeping a bit difficult especially on our first night (it seemed to be cooler the next two nights). There is a heating/cooling system but you cannot get the cooling system to go below 20 degrees - the Japanese do love a warm room! Our solution was to open the curtains which worked quite well & even though it was a Saturday night and it was super busy outside, the was little noise in the room. One other random thing that happened was that we were woken at 1am on our last night by what sounded like an alarm. I got up to check things out and there was a red light flashing on top of this little box near our wardrobe. The alarm eventually stopped going but the red light kept flashing. I was about to call reception to see if we should be worried, when someone knocked at our door. My partner answered it and it was a women looking for another room - so the 'alarm' noise was her pressing the door bell outside our room, not super awesome in the middle of the night but If you at least know what the noise is that helps. The breakfast was great, lots of choice. I would stay here again, despite the warm rooms, you just can't beat this location for the price.

I recently stayed at the Best Western Shinjuku Astina Hotel. I loved my stay here very much. The hotel is new, modern, and quiet. I really enjoyed the buffet breakfast, very unique. The location of this hotel is excellent and I wouldn't be concerned about the "red light district" nonsense. You likely won't even notice. The extra charge to check out at 2pm instead of 12pm seemed abit excessive. Overall very good place to stay.

Having everything at your doorstep is great. There are tons of fabulous restaurants around, the Shinjuku train station is a mere walk away and shopping is right there too. The regular rooms are rather small: good for one person but really tiny for two. The executive floor rooms are nice and quite spacious. Like in all Japanese hotels the bathroom provides shampoos and so on. In the morning they serve a fabulous breakfast buffet (mostly included) that gets you off to a good start. I stayed there twice at the beginning and the end of my trip and would go back again. From Shinjuku station you have direct access to Narita Airport and to most city attractions.

Best Western overseas are unlike US, they are modern and clean. The hotel is located in Shinjuku and is minutes away from main station East exit. Plenty of shopping, restaurants, etc around. Airport Limo bus 50 mins from Haneda or 85mins from Narita. There is a Lawson store on the ground level. Take the elevator to the hotel front desk on the third floor.

This hotel is sandwiched between the red light area of Shinjuku and the Golden Gai bar area. The hotel is very convenient and well maintained. The rooms are reasonably sized, compared to other hotels in Tokyo. The lady at the reception was not welcoming at all when we checked in. But other staff were polite and respectful. The hotel has a Lawsons below it and has ample of stores and restaurants around. If you're there for work and want some action at night, this hotel is the place to stay. *But beware of the African American guys outside the hotel who are trying to earn a quick buck to get you down to their girl bars, some of which do not even have any girls!*

The Best Western Shinjuku Astina is in the heart of Shinjuku a short walk to Tokyo's largest train station and a significant office, retail and entertainment precinct. The location really has it all in terms of Tokyo and if you like being in the heart of at the activity this area is certainly for you.The Hotel itself is modern, renovated and surprisingly quiet. Staff at the front desk speak English and are helpful. The rooms are modern, comfortable yet compact. The beds are comfortable and the shower excellent. I enjoyed the excellent head-room (floor to ceiling over 2.1 metres) in the shower, a bit more space than most Japanese bathrooms!We did not have breakfast at the hotel, but there are plenty of convenient options to choose from in the area.

We booked a standard twin room. It was the tiniest room we have ever experienced but it was very clean and had all the expected amenities like fridge, tea/coffee with kettle, a small table with 2 chairs, good number of power points, slippers, lots of toiletries, powerful shower, hair dryer, etc. there was even a security safe nicely stored within a bedside drawer. Beds were very comfortable. Heating thermostat was in Japanese but the reception has an English translation printed on paper should you require one to know how to adjust the temperature in your room. Free wifi and speed was good. We stayed 2 nights and felt it was just right. Any long stays would become quite uncomfortable as the room is very tiny with just enough space to walk round the beds. Staff were all excellent and spoke good English. The location was extremely convenient with the main station Shinjuku being only 5 mins walk away and the largest ISETAN dept store just down the road. There is an element of weirdos hanging around in the evening (men dressing as women looking for punters?) but they didn't bother us at all. We found it quite amusing (although sad in some ways) to see the odd one here and there outside the hotel. So, for very short term stay, this hotel does the job well! Would definitely recommend it.

This hotel was great for location, just 5 minutes away from Shinjuku station, and nestled amongst shopping, food and entertainment. The hotel itself isn't glam or plush, but what can you expect when the price is so reasonable. It was clean, modern and the staff were friendly! I would have liked more variety at breakfast, but again, I can't want too much with such a great price!

This is a very run-of-the-mill place, don't expect to be wowed here, I wasn't and wasn't. I don't know what made be book a Best Western in the first place, I guess it was the lowish price, but I'm sure there must be other more interesting places in the same price bracket

Stayed for 4 nights in a Premium twin room on the 14th floor. Very spacious for Japanese standards. Big bathroom with twin sinks, great shower. The only problem was that someone had been smoking on that floor before we arrived, even though the floor was nonsmoking. Not the hotels fault however. Seems a lot of smokers in Japan. The area is great. Very central to Shinjuku easy to get around. The black guys that tout outside the hotel can be a little annoying , but just ignore them. Again not the hotels fault. I would highly recommend the hotel. The Food Mart on the ground floor is great for snacks and surprisingly good quick and cheap meals. I thought breakfast was good, I mean really....don't expect a full English breakfast in Japan. That's just stupid ., and for about $5more you can have lunch instead, which is great because we usually slept in. I did see a few of the standard rooms on my way to do laundry and they did look tight... But again it's Japan .. If you need a bigger room pay extra...

This little hotel is perfect. It is only a few blocks away from the Shinjuku train station (the busiest train station in the world) and surrounded by restaurants, shopping and entertainment. We were able to walk a few blocks to join our pre-arranged tours. It was truly like staying in Times Square in New York. Lots of lights and partying at night (I was traveling with my teen and not participating in this type of activity and there was no problem) with dirty streets and a few drunk stragglers in the morning. However, we were never bothered. The hotel room was *tiny* but provided all of our needs. The bed was comfortable as were the pillows. We had a choice of pillow types. The front door staff was *very* helpful and kind. The buffet breakfast in the morning included both western food and traditional Japanese food. It was the same both days we attended. There is a hot pot in the room with instant coffee available. Right next door is a convenience shop. There are ATM machines inside this shop. I would gladly return to this hotel.

Best Western Shinjuku Astina Hotel is a great place to stay. Our room was large and well maintained. Our room (on the 13th floor) also had an amazing view of Tokyo. The hotel's location is great (only a short walk to the metro). The staff were very professional and helpful. Overall great value for money. We'd happily stay here again.

We stayed at Shinjuku for a week. The staff could not do enough for us - even helping us with our subway & toursit questions & giving us loads of tips. The room was clean & the size was good. The buffet breakfast was great & being able to upgrade to lunch was handy. The lady on reception was fantastic - so polite & helpful with excellent english.We miss it all ready & would love to go back! THANK YOU!

We stayed 6 nights prior to skiing at Hakuba. Great location, friendly staff and lovely breakfast every morning. We had one of the larger rooms so it was very comfortable. Special thanks to one of the front desk staff who assisted us in booking a special restaurant in Ginza for dinner.

I spent a weekend in Japan to collect valuable musical instrument I purchased. Whilst there I rushed around Tokyo in a weekend. In that time I had mail delivered to the hotel which the staff took care of to notify me, they helped with storage of items and luggage whilst It was too early for me to check in too. When I asked questions a lot of information was given. The attention to detail and service here in Japan and Best Western I found exemplary. If y need anything always ask the staff. They are fantastic. The rooms are great too. I didn't do much sleeping however.

Located within 10 min walk from Shinjuku east entrance, Astina is a relatively new hotel in Kibucho entertainment area. Initially we were concerned that the location may not be safe for the family, but our fears were founded. We understand that the presence of the hotel had in fact uplifted the immediate neighborhood.Restaurants, convenience stores, department stores (Isetan is the closest) and other shops are easily accessible. there is a walkway behind the hotel that leads to the main road. Quiet and safe!The room is reasonably sized for Japan standards, and a self laundry service is available .Staff are polite, friendly and helpful. Special commendation for the waitress serving breakfast at the hotel restaurant. Always ready to serve with a warm smile!We really enjoyed our stay here, and highly recommend this hotel.

Nice room. Excellent bathroom. Close to everything. Would stay here again. Staff are very friendly and will assist you with whatever you ask for. The breakfast here is good, not great, but sufficient to make the inclusion worth while.

This is the 2nd hotel that we have stayed in Tokyo (after staying in a hotel in Shiodome). The atmosphere is completely different as Shiodome is more business-like and fairly quiet at night while Shinjuku is full of neon lights and life goes on even after 3am. As I have done a fair amount of research on the website, I knew very well the way leading from the Shinjuku Sanchome station to the hotel. The location is quite good and is close to the shopping area and there are many restaurants closed by. The hotel looks fairly new and the room is nice and just big enough to fit my family of 4. Bathroom is considered big (Japanese standard) as it includes a bathtub and shower area. The service at the front desk is ok but I would not consider it to be very friendly or too welcoming - I stayed from 21 Dec to 24 Dec and left for a 1-night trip to Hakone before checking into the hotel again on the 25th. The staff that served me the first time are professional but they are not very friendly. The male staff that served me the 2nd time speaks perfect english but he seems a bit cold (and he only gave me 1 access card as oppose to 3 cards given to me at the first check-in). In fact, it was not mentioned that I could utilize the breakfast voucher at the convenience store on the ground floor (at a value of JPY500) if I chose not to have breakfast. The best part of the stay has to be the breakfast as my boys enjoyed the meal every morning (even though food doesn't change much) and I must mention the welcoming waitresses at the cafe. Their bright smiles really brighten our day! I am not sure if I will stay in the hotel again considering that there are other good hotels in the area - sunroute shinjuku, century southern tower, Keio plaza hotel. The rates of these hotels could be attractive at times.

Comfortable stay. Good location- plenty of food outlets and main Shinjuku shopping area.Convenient store just at entrance to hotel.Friendly service and helpful front desk staff. Breakfast choices and spread is good.Negatives: small room, even for the "executive rooms"..

I was really impressed by this hotel! Great location in Shinjuku, just one minute walk from the main shopping street and 5 minutes from the subway station.Hotel is brand new and looks very modern. Rooms are the biggest I've ever found (at a decent price) in central Tokyo area!! ... Which means a decent size of about 10 square meters.Very comfortable and modern!!

My family decided to go to Tokyo for 8 days and stayed at this hotel based on reviews. Here's the scoop:PROS:- Very close to central Shinjuku Subway station* allowing you to inexpensively explore all of Tokyo and the surrounding areas where Mt.Fuji, Hakone, etc are located.- Very Clean, average Tokyo sized rooms w/the usual North American amenities.- Located slightly off the central area, but close enough that there are a bunch of English speaking restaurants and North American franchise chains such as: Subway, Burgerking, a couple of McDonalds, KFC, Shakey's Pizza, Baskin Robbins, etc.- Very friendly staff and complimentary breakfast buffet.CONS:- Very close to central Shinjuku Subway station* which is also a con because even though its not far (5 minute walk) it can get pretty confusing to get from the station to the hotel.- In the heart of the Shinjuku nightclub district, which can be sometimes loud at night.TIP #1 At the Airport, get the "Suica & N'EX" combo deal: the train takes you right to Shinjuku station quickly, gives you a starter train pass for exploring & is excellent value. Once you are at Shinjuku station, You could find your way to the hotel on foot (its only 5 mins away), but there's a lot going on and can get confusing. In hindsight, we should have taken a taxi as its only $3 -$5 US and takes the driver 2 minutes.TIP #2: Avoid taking the subway during rush hour! I've been on Subways from New York to Paris and nothing was more uncomfortable than this. Sardines have more space in a tin than I did!TIP#3: If you know Japanese, Great! if not, most restaurants in this area have English or picture menus to point at. Just be polite.All and all, we really liked the hotel. It was close to everything and made it very easy to eat, sleep and see all the tourist attractions. I'd absolutely stay there again!

i like its location: very close to shinjuku station. we took the taxi to the limosine bus stop and it cost us the base charge only!i like its modern style: you don't have to pay too much and still get the quality. the convenience store downstair is a plus!i like its breakfast. both japanese and western style! nice environment, too!i like its price. the early bird promotion is very attractive!i'd like to check this hotel first if i am going to tokyo again!

This hotel is 5-10mins away from JR Shinjuku station if you know how to orientate yourself. The staff were all very welcoming even a trainee staff at their reception desk was impressive enough with his professionalism. Room was a wee bit small but we still managed to fit 3 big luggages inside. The breakfast was decent and the smiles from the breakfast crew was very welcoming!

Location is very good with convenience stores right next downstairs of the hotel. Restaurants and bars are available until 4-5am in the morning but only open 11am. Red light district is opposite the street but is child safe if you walk towards the train station.It is 7 minutes walk from the jr station and subway station.Rooms are small as expected but worth for the location. It is 4 minutes walk to the shopping area of shinjuku with lots of restaurant too.The hotel is more like a business hotel but is family friendly too.Breakfast is not bad and I would stay here again for my next trip.

I was a bit unimpressed, I have to say, that despite the attempts of the super-friendly staff to make the guest welcome, the hotel never really pulls it off and does nto really deliver the wow factor. I had a reasonable stay though, so I ain't really complaining.

Nice hotel in Shinjuku. Really convenient, about 5 mins walk to Shinjuku Station. Hotel surrounded by eateries, have not problem filling your tum tum with cheap and delicious food namly yakitori, ramen, sushi, curry rice, cold soba and etc. Hotel is very close by to well known district called Kabuki Cho, an eye opener to night clubs in Japan. Nevertheless its still very safe for us to roam around at night. Will revisit this hotel again.

I stayed at this hotel for 2 nights during a recent business trip to Japan. The room was clean, the staff was friendly, and the buffet breakfast was delicious. I will definitely stay at this hotel the next time I'm in Tokyo.

Very happy with overall service. Great location. Very helpful staff and very friendly. Room a bit small but very clean. Would love to go back n stay here again. Seriously recommended.We stayed here for 2 weeks and we really enjoyed it.

My boyfriend and I stayed at this hotel in November 2013, after reading the reviews on Trip Advisor. We arrived earlier than the check in time but the receptionist made it possible for us to have the room an hour before check in, which was most appreciated after a long flight. The staff were very friendly and it certainly helped they all spoke very good English as our Japanese was very limited!We expected the room to be small but the layout was more than adequate and the bathroom was great. The room was spotless. My only advise on the room would be to add some drawers as there's little room for your clothing but then I don't travel light! Oh and the wifi was pretty good too and free!Breakfast was ample with plenty of choice for both their Western and Eastern guests. The location couldn't have been better for us as we used the Tube to get around the whole of Tokyo. Shinjuku Station is a bit daunting at first but you soon get use to the exits and it's so easy to use. All in all our trip to Tokyo exceeded our expectations and we would most definitely stay at this hotel again.

We found this Hotel to be excellent for our needs. We had a business room on the 14th floor which was lovely with panoramic views over Tokyo and lovely fittings in both the room and bathroom. We could recommend this Hotel to everyone, as it's central position to the train station(Shinjuku) and all facilities makes it a must. ^ ^

This hotel took me by surprise, I was expecting much lower standard but this hotel was clean and fresh and the layout in the room meant that they didn't feel too small. For the cheap price you can't ask for more. Last year we stayed at Sunroute plaza and were a bit disappointed how worn out and small the rooms were. There is free wifi in the rooms which is always a bonus. We had a room with a good view too. We tried the breakfast once and it was ok but nothing to write home about. Location is smack bang in the middle of the buzzing Shinjuku but somehow the hotel is very quiet. I would highly recommend this hotel for anyone with high standards on a budget.

No, this place is not easy to find, but as we stood at the station looking lost a helpful woman pointed us in the right direction. Outside the East exit of Shinjuku rail an equally helpful young man lead us to the hotel. Once you know the route, it's dead easy. The hotel was very comfortable - spacious (for Tokyo) rooms, every convenience supplied, and the staff went out of their way to assist (even brought soft pillows to my most particular niece). Great restaurant on the second floor, but make sure you're hungry if you go there because the portions are huge. Big recommendation from me.

Check in was prompt and efficient. Don't expect someone to walk you to your room or bell hop service. I do lower my expectations when I occasionally check in non 5 stars hotels. The staff serving breakfast are really nice and friendly. Front desk can do a little more in the morning. They looked so dead every morning. Greet your guests when you see them at the lobby instead of staring in space! They tend to suck up to westerners.by trying to be nicer. Pathetic!Room was pretty good for this class of hotel and size reasonable by tokyo standard.Only issue I have is with standard of housekeeping. Basic standards are not even there. Complimentary bottles of water not replenished after day 1. On 9 dec, the table was not even cleared. I returned to my room after a long day out at mt fuji only to be greeted with a dirty table left uncleaned. Cups were not washed and bowls of noodles uncleared. I was already quite pissed off but thought maybe this is the low standard expected of a best western property. After this is my first stay at best western and with good reviews from this forum. I then went on to placed the dirty bowls in bag, tied it and placed them next to the bin in the toilet. They can't fit in the small bin. On 10 dec, I returned to my room to see the trash is still there. I am really annoyed by the sub-standard housekeeping this hotel provides. Where am I expected to throw my rubbish? Along the corridor? Bring them to the front desk? Throw them at the manager? This is not what I expect. This hotel cannot even provide basic needs for their guests. I am not going to stay I another best western property after this experience. This will be my last visit to this hotel. Think again if you want to stay here. You might be better off elsewhere which is better located away from the sleaze around here and the filth both in and out of the room.

The hotel and rooms are clean and well-maintained.. Located just next to Kabukicho, the accessibility is fantastic with JR and subway lines, shops and restaurants nearby. There is also a convenience store just below the hotel which is great for last minute needs. We stayed at this hotel on two separate occasions during our trip and the staff allowed us to put our luggage in their care between our stays and after our check-out. The hotel also has a green plan where you can receive a 500-yen voucher if you opt out to have your room cleaned for the day. Breakfast is decent with a variety of items but during our stay, they did not change much. If you missed breakfast, you can use it for lunch with an additional 500-yen but I wouldn't recommend it as the taste and variety is below average. Overall, a good hotel for its location and price.

I'm an owner and former GM of a Best Western Hotel in the USA and I was so amazed when I entered this hotel. The quality of service, decor, and overall furnishings in this hotel was beyond that of most other Best Westerns. In the USA this could definitely be a high class or premium hotel. The guest service was excellent and I was able to make my reservation quite easily with Aya over email. Room quality was excellent. Well thought out use of space, modern decorations and room furnishings and all the fixtures were working perfectly.The location is absolutely first class for travelers. You will be in the heart of Tokyo and very close to transportation.Aya is the person who helped me reserve over email and she was very response and helpful. She was very understanding when I had a cancellation due to a missed flight. My only comment is that she can include the hotel address in her signature of her e-mail since I printed out her email but didn't know the address to the hotel. Luckily a nice man helped me look up the hotel with his smartphone.Bravo!!

We took my parents, who are in their 70s, to Japan for the first time and we loved it. The hotel location is conveniently located near the Shinjuku shopping area as well as the train stations. The rooms are clean and the staff are very helpful. The buffet breakfast was also good. We booked the room through their website since it was cheaper than Agoda. It is not a 5-star hotel, but for what we pay and the location, it was definitely worth the price.

We stayed here for 5 nights. For the price and location, this place is a steal. Word of advice though, book in advance to enjoy their discounts. And book through their website, it's cheaper than agoda or other online hotel booking websites. The rooms are small, as many have commented but I found myself staying in the room only when I sleep. Tokyo is all about heading out there and chill. The front desk staffs were very helpful. I had trouble finding a pub that airs the Premier League live, (Chelsea v Southampton - local time 1am)...they happily searched online and found us the place. Hub Pub by the way...if you ever wanna catch rugby or football live. One minute walk from the hotel.While many may not like the location at the Kabuki-cho district; I find it very lively and safe. It's good that it is near the hotel, so you can stroll about without worrying if it ever gets too late. If you are travelling as a couple or family they wont bother you, bother means asking you if you were interested to see some stuffs (peep show, dance, drinks etc)..not harassing and following you. You will never get hungry too, as there are many 24 hour eateries and a convenient store (Lawson) just below the hotel. And oh..don't forget the charming Golden Gai at the back of the hotel...walk home drunk! cause you don't need to holler a cab. The subways are also very nearby..5 minutes to Marunochi line and about 7 to the main Shinjuku Station. Shinjuku has the most train lines connected, so convenient wise; simply the best if you want a central location for your vacation in Tokyo (for the price).The daily breakfast could be improved...almost the same everyday. I think it is pork free too. Perhaps an egg station. Some pancakes, tamagoyaki or some smoked fish or sushi too perhaps.

Many good things have been written about this hotel, including its central location, the amenities, the breakfast, but what stands out the most is the people who work there. Everyone goes out of their way to make your journey an experience to remember. We had a specific problem with the booking of a tour and the front desk did an awesome job in fixing it. Our thanks go especially to Kaneko who did everything she could to resolve the matter and even followed up with written documentation. The service was beyond our expectations. We recommend this three-star hotel without any hesitation whatsoever.

Location: Near Shinjuku station East exit.Breakfast: Breakfast selection is reasonable. You can have bread, rice, salad or beef curry. Room: The room size is bigger than hotels in Kyoto or Osaka(at same price).

We booked for twin room for 4 days and Best Western Shinjuku Astina upgrades us to the Exec suite. The location is great with close proximity to food and shopping (yes shopping with great bargain). Easy access to Shinjuku station which is a central location for travelling on train to visit various places. Very convenient and upbeat. We have a wonderfui stay and the staffs were very friendly and helpful. Highly recommended. Will stay here again if visiting Tokyo next time.

My friend and I thought the food type of breakfast is not enough.And the eating space is kinda small. ex: when we try to toast the bread or toast, there is no space can stand few people.Overall, I love your room, bed, bathroom :)

Impressed by the bed, it was really excellent. My last day I pulled off the sheets and found: Simmons. Well, I liked it better than the Simmons in my home.Location: convenient but drove the taxi driver from Shinjuku station crazy finding it (at 710Y for a fraction of a mile). Essentially starts at the third floor of a building.Not fancy. No bellhop or concierge.Join the Astina Club and the price falls from standard Best Western AAA rate. Large (for Japan) room, executive twin, at under $200, including decent breakfast.Quirks.... maid service means the linens get changed, so that happens every day unless you opt out (and get a little reward). Udon restaurant on second floor will give you any of their drinks free (one drink of course) with meal and proof of being at the hotel.5 or so minute walk to Shinjuku station. A crazy complicated station, we kept finding new parts by accident. Finding the correct exit to get to the hotel is not so easy even after managing to do that a couple of times.

Location: Near to Shinjuku train station. Shinjuku is a hub with easy subway and rail access. Only downside is hotel is near to red light district so u may see some shady characters near the hotel. They don't disturbed tourists though.Breakfast: Breakfast selection is reasonable. You have bread, cereal, salad, hot Japanese dishes to cater different taste buds. As we have to check out by 7am on the last day and are unable to utilize our breakfast voucher. The hotel allows us to exchange the voucher with 500 yen of items from Lawson at ground floor. Room: Rooms are of a reasonable size. We stay in a small double Room so the beds are slightly small for 2 adults. Otherwise all's good. Wi-Fi: Available in the room. However, the last room at the corner has zero or very little Wi-Fi connection. Tip: Get out at Exit B9 from Shinjuku station. After exiting from B9, turn left and walk till u reach the main road. Mister donut will be diagonally across to your right. Walk along the pavement of Mister Donut. After 5 minutes walk, you should see Lawson. Hotel lobby is on level 3.

Stayed in Oct 2013 for first Tokyo trip and was overall very satisfied.Room was very clean, modern looking, with tv, desk, and free wifi (which unfortunately was a bit weak and sometimes dropped out).Size was adequate and bigger than expected - whilst much smaller compared to a US hotel, it was bigger than what we anticipated based off things we heard regarding Japanese rooms. Whilst it made one corner a bit tight, we managed to keep 2 normal-sized suitcases laying flat.Fridge and safe is included, which are free to use, and no over-priced drinks inside to tempt you. There is a vending machine near the ice machine though, as reasonable prices.Bathroom was very clean and a good size, with a spacious shower area that also kept the water from going everywhere. Toilet was modern and clean, with typical Japanese functions like heated seat and bidet.Breakfast buffet was included in our deal and pretty good. Selection of meats (such as fried chicken, mackerel, beef), types of egg, miso soup, fruits, cereals, coffee, juice, etc.Location was pretty easy to find, considering our first time in Japan. Probably roughly 7 min walk from East Exit of Shinjuku, but factor in more time to walk/find your platform as the station is quite big.It is also within the red light district (Kabukicho), however we didn't really notice (my wife didn't know until I said) and it doesn't feel seedy. Walking from the station to hotel at night time feels very safe and it's pretty busy for the whole journey.There is also a 24-hr convenience store directly under the hotel, which sells anything you would need at good prices.Had minimal contact with reception other than check-in and check-out but they spoke very good English.Overall a very good experience and would definitely consider again or recommend.

This was our first trip to Japan, and for the last part of our trip we stayed at the Best Western in Tokyo. We received instructions to walk about 5 - 8 mins. from the train station to the hotel. The map was very confusing to read, as Japanese is not in our vocabulary. We had to stop several times to ask for directions (which is challenging, as not very many people speak English). After about 30 mins, we found the hotel. It was on the 2nd level of a building, and did not have huge signage, like we are used to here. Hotel rooms were quite tiny, but beds were comfy. Breakfast buffet was overall pretty good, but had ice cold boiled eggs. Location of hotel was good, as it was walking distance to several amenities, but watch out when you go out at night. It is located boarder line of Japan's "Red district". We encountered transvestites, and there are several "Massage" places. Hence, my 15 year old son commented it was "Sketchy". Overall stay was welcoming. The hotel staff were very friendly, as was everyone else in Japan.

Tokyo is wonderful and our stay in this hotel surely made our vacation an even better experience. Room and bathroom is big, modern and very clean. Breakfast buffet is great and on days where we had to leave the hotel before the buffet opened we can use the breakfast vouchers to buy food at the convenience store at the ground floor. How awesome is that! The location is great as well - a short walk from the Shinjuku-Sanchome train station and short walk to the major shopping district and restaurants! The vicinity is well lit i never felt scared walking late at night or early in the morning. Last but not least - they have an awesome staff that provided excellent and the most warm and friendly service. All this for a very reasonable price. Oh by the way, we booked our stay some 5 months in advance with no deposit or anything!

Thank you very much for the memorable experience!! I love this hotel very much..the room design is very modern/contemporary with huge bathroom. Thanks to best western for the free upgrade - they even give crabtree&evelyn toiletries!! One of your staffs which i met at shinjuku station help me to go to the hotel. She is very helpful with good spoken english but i forgot to ask her name. Thanks a lot!!

I stayed at the Best Western Shinjuku for 3 nights at the beginning of October. The room was very clean and of adequate size for one person. I appreciated that it was also quiet. The front desk was very helpful and assisted me in booking a tour to Mt. Fuji. Location is good, although finding the hotel at first is a bit confusing. The only criticism I have, which admittedly is a personal bias, is that the room windows do not open, and I was unable to get fresh air. Air conditioning was good, though I had to change rooms, as the AC in the first room was weak. Even though the hotel is on the border of the red light district, it is safe.

We stayed at this hotel on the business floor for six nights, and were quite happy with it. The room was not big, but it was sufficient. With the discount, it cost us $148 Can/night, including breakfast. Buffet breakfast was good. They served it in western and Japanese styles. If you do not want your room be cleaned every day, they will give Best Western money (500 yen per night). There are two subway stations and a train station about 500 m away. If you are arriving by train the very first time, it is wise to take a taxi for just 710 yen. Do not be afraid of this hotel being close to the Red Light district, it will not bother you, and it is not dangerous at all.

I have read other reviews before booking the Best Western. I have stayed at other Best Western in Canada before, however, this Best Western is quite different comparing to the ones I stayed at before. First let me talk about the location. Shinjuku is the best town to stay if you are looking for a lot of 24 hour shops, a lot of people on the street even it is 3am. This hotel is only 7 minutes to the shinjuku train station where you can hop on the train to Mount Fuji or downtown Tokyo or even Osaka. There is a metro, underground subway, that's operate a different route than the JR train line that is a minute away from the hotel. I guess not a lot of people know this, but there is actually an entrance directly across from Mister Donut. Beside the convenience location, the breakfast that they served is prefect for both Asian or westerners. For the nine days I was there, they have some varieties and some main dishes are different everyday. The room size is really no complain in Japan. The room is 188 sq ft and it's big a nought for one adult. For toe adults or more I would definitely get a bigger room. The only downside I would say about this hotel is that is too near the red light district area where people on the street always hang out coupons flyers to try to get you in the clubs. But if you say no and refuse their offer, they won't drag you in. The area around the hotel is still a safe area and the hotel is well lite and protected I found. Also, the wifi is slow when you are trying to watch videos. For browsing the net, you shouldn't have any problems. Tips, the convenience store downstairs is very handy and have a great varieties of food and drinks. Also, if you refuse room cleaning for a night, the hotel will give you a 500¥ coupon to use in the hotel. I used it to buy water and used it toward lunch instead of the free breakfast.

Best Western Shinjuku Astina Hotel Tokyo was our base hotel for 15 days while we traveled to Okinawa, Kyoto, Hakone, Nikko and other parts of the greater Tokyo area. Reasonable room rate came with daily breakfast buffet which had both American and Japanese-style breakfast -- a good way to start off your day. As with all hotel rooms in Japan, it was small for 2 people; but very clean. Location was ideal -- only 8 minutes to Shinjuku train station by foot; and in the heart of all the popular department stores (Takashimaya, Isetan, Marui, etc.) and surrounded by more restaurants then you can count. It was also on the edge of the red light district that provided a lively feel to the area and yet you are still quite safe. Most of the hotel staff spoke fairly good English and were extremely helpful when we needed directions, restaurant and taxi reservations and umbrellas. And we received discounts from the taxi's that were reserved by the hotel. We would definitely stay here again!

I stayed there twice in the same week. Booked for one night on the 20 and then went to Kawaguchiko one night and head back for the last three nights in BW. The first night I was lucky to book a non-smoking room. It was great! Very clean and all cozy with everything I needed. The space in the room was acceptable and I was very satisfied. The last three night I wasn't that fortunate and had to book my three nights with a smoking room since the non-smoking rooms were full. In my opinion, if you are a non smoker... stick to the non-smoking room. Though they tried to take away the smell in the smoking rooms, but once you reach the smoking room floors, you smell "the smell" very heavy and all your belongings will catch the smell after staying there for three nights. If you don't bother with it, then it is ok. But for my next visit, I will definitely go with the non-smoking rooms. Overall, the staffs was very friendly and I would still stay here on my next visit.

Everything is in the title of my review...for your next own pleasure. Enjoy !Your first breakfast will enjoy your first day !You will have a genuine rest with your first night...It is a very quiet place which is very closed to the very exciting district of Shinjuky and not so far away from the Shinjuku station... from where you can go almost everywhere !Sebastien

The room we had was booked through wotif for approx $120 AUD per night. The staff were friendly and available and the rooms were clean and modern. A buffet breakfast was included in the cost however this was average. The highlight of this hotel was it's location amongst bright lights, bars, entertainment venues, karaoke rooms and restaurants. We felt safe and had a fantastic time using the Best Western as a base for exploring Tokyo.

Stayed a couple of night in Shinjuku Tokyo on a holiday. Came in from Haneda airport and used the subway to SHinjuku station. Big mistake - it has 200 exits and I am not kidding. Took me forever to find the right Northeast exit ( I used B9 but there are some closer if you can find your way through the maze). Better to exit any of the other shinjuku subway stations if you can. The hotel is near or on the red light district but dont worry - its very harmless.The streets around are the best tokyo shopping streets in my mind ( muji store across the street) and it was also easy to jump on any of the subway lines aroung the city. The receptions was very friendly and helpful with lots of pamplets, information sheets and maps. Rooms are smaller than average, more than half the size of any EU or US hotel but very modern , compact , very clean and with your own electric chair - the toilet seat had heating.You also get 2 bottles of water on arrival but no refill during your stay which is a shame. Breakfast was good but limited .There is a conviniency store 'Lawsons' on the street level if you need anything.

The hotel is centrally located in the busy Shinjuku district. It's about 30 mins in a taxi from Haneda Airport which will set you back approx ¥6500. The check in was smooth and staff were very pleasant and welcoming. The room is not the biggest compared to European hotels but more than adequate for our stay. Free wifi in the room was good. Room had a fridge and flat screen tv within. A drinks vending and ice machine could be found at the end of our corridor (12th floor) not sure if these were on every floor. 7th floor had 2 washers and 2 tumble dryers which were really cheap. Hotel has it's own laundry facility but you'll pay big!! Breakfast isn't the best to be honest, I like my food but not onion rings, curry, cod fritters or chips when I've just woken up. There is bread, fruit and cereals though so you won't starve. We didn't try lunch or dinner in the hotel so can't comment on the choices there. Location is great, the hotel lies just behind the Golden Gai and is about a 10 min walk to the train station. There's loads of places to eat around the hotel and of course, a 7 - eleven or family mart for the room supplies. Overall, a great place to stay and if you've booked here you won't regret it. Enjoy!!

This hotel is centrally located in Shinjuku, just a 10 minute walk from the station. It was perfect for us to explore Tokyo in the 5 days we spent there. The staff were friendly and efficient and the room was (small) but perfect for us and very comfortable.Breakfast was not to my taste, I'm not one for eating beef curry at 8am. However the cereal/bread/fruit was adequate and plentiful.All in all a great choice and if i were to return to Japan I'd stay here again.

We stayed 4 nights during our Japan holiday. Location was almost perfect only 5-6 minutes walk from Shinjuku station. Also you can reach the hotel from underground. Just take the east exit at Shinjuku train station and walk down through the stairs. Then turn right and walk about 70-80meters to Subnade shopping mall entrance on the left. Go down from the stairs and walk through the end. Then turn right and exit 15 will be on your left. Take exit 15B to go up with stairs and after 50meters walk through the street; you will be in front of the hotel. Reception was located on the 3rd floor and checkin process was easily completed & wifi password provided during the checkin. Our room was a double room and size of the room was OK and almost same as with European standarts. Bed was also comfortable and bathroom was well equiped. Shaving set, toothbrush type amenities were provided along with slippers. There was only CNN as an English channel. Breakfast was also included during our stay and there were plenty of everything; both Japanese and international type. I recommend you to take the breakfast. Location was just in the heart of Shinjuku and walking distance to everywhere in Shinjuku. Shinjuku rail station was the main transfer point for trains. If you had a JR Pass - which you can buy at your country before arriving to Japan - you can also use JR Yamanote line instead of Tokyo subway with JR pass. It will take little longer, but you can reach almost whole main stations such as Ueno, Tokyo, Shinagawa and Shibuya.
