Also if you are planning to travel to Osaka or Kyoto via Shinkansen bullet train, I also suggest you to transfer at Shinagawa station instead of Tokyo Station. So that you cn avoid the Tokyo station crowd. For the airport; we took Narita express (NEX) train and in around 80-90 minutes; you will be at Shinjuku station. Overall; it was a nice hotel with reasonable price & location and I can recommend it.

We spent one night here during our trip to Tokyo May 2012. Hotel is modern and not very pricey. Breakfast was good. Service is hospitable and they help you with your queries as much as they can. There was an earthquake during our stay and we slightly panicked. Hotel staff made us to feel relaxed again by asking "Was there an earthquake? I didn't notice" :)Rooms are small but that the case in every hotel in Tokyo.

I stayed in the Best Western Shinjuku Astina hotel for several days during a conference in Tokyo. It has the usual Best Western standards: comfortable, modern, clean, elegant rooms, particularly for the norms of Tokyo (tiny rooms). Everyday cleaning of the room, huge variety of amenities and bathroom toiletries (with daily renewal!), large buffet (although choices are not that many if you are not particularly fond of fish), with soups, fruit, vegetables, fish, fish and fish...Location? Right in the centre: just 2 blocks from 3 different metro lines (among which Shinjuku line and railway station) and also in the heart of youth nightlife, near Kabukicho. The hotel's price was not among its pros, however, how easy is it to find and decent, large-roomed and relatively cheap hotel at the same time?The stuff was really helpful and willing to help me out with a broken wheel of my suitcase, however their communication skills in English were not always adequate; but this is a common aspect for most Japanese, isn't it? Well, this is counterbalanced with their extraordinary courtesy and helpfulness...Overall: i highly recommend this hotel...

Stayed here for 6 nights and thought for the price we paid (USD150 per night), it was a steal. The service from the reception is immaculate, and most importantly most of them speak fluent English which is not common outside of 4 and 5* hotels. Talking about the service, they are hospitable and always did whatever they can to accede to your request. I had trouble looking for a good yakitori restaurant around Shinjuku and they actually went online and researched about it, open the Google maps and directed me the way to the restaurant. I certainly didn't expect such service coming from Best Western frankly. I had the business room (which isn't much more expensive than the normal ones), and the interior is more spacious than neighbouring hotels such as Prince Shinjuku and Ibis. The bed linens, coffee table and bathroom are all clean as well. In all, I really enjoyed my stay here. If I have to give a criticism for this hotel, it would have to be that the Wifi is not very fast and sometimes it can be a bit frustrating when you are downloading Youtube videos. But I think this is not a crucial issue. I will definitely come here again without even considering any other hotels.

We had a fantastic stay at the Best Western Shinjuku. We took the train from Narita airport to Shinjuku station. Please read the other reviews regarding directions from the station to the hotel - you are going to need it as Shinjuku Train Station is HUGE and very easy to get lost in! From Shinjuku station it will probably take 10mins to walk to the hotel. The hotel room was clean, modern and a great size with a comfortable bed. The bathroom was very clean too, and the shower had great pressure. Check in was quick and simple and the receptionists were very helpful and spoke English. We stayed for 3 nights and they were able to suggest great restaurants located close by.When we come back to Tokyo we will definitely book the Best Western Shinjuku again!

The area where the hotel is located is unique in itself. Lots of bars and especially close to Golden Gai. Interior of the hotel was modern and nice. For the price, I can overlook the smaller end size of the room. Who stays in their room anyway?! this is japan!!! Love the amenities in these japanese hotels..they supply you with everything..hairbands, toothbrush, hair brush, scrubbing cloth, razors, shower cap, and etc. Overall, very clean and staff spoke very good english. Also, we used the subnade mall a lot to get around and there is an entrance close by to the hotel. Super convenient location.

Mistakenly delayed booking this hotel and missed out on a discount rate. The room was very, very small for the price however was very clean, modern, and comfortable. The free breakfast was appreciated, however the restaurant was very small, and not many items on the breakfast buffet (food quality was excellent however). The restaurant does not open for dinner service. Access to the hotel is a bit difficult, with a two escalators that change direction depending upon the time, and three elevators that must be taken to exit the hotel. English speaking staff was extremely friendly and helpful. I will stay again, but will definitely book much earlier to get a more economical rate!

It has all what you need. For its pricetag, the location is great, 7 minutes easy walk from the shinjuku station. There are many rrestaurants nearby a long with a 24 hours supermarket just below. All you need for a pleasant stay

Amazing room. Plenty of room and no noise. Very clean and large bathroom. Would love to stay here again. Very close walk to Shinjuku station which was handy for us as we had the JR rail pass. We got lost every time we exited the station but there are many exits. Lots of great food nearby. Really yummy and cheap chinese restaurant on the same street. Breakfast was great at hotel. Gets a bit boring everyday but that's to be expected as it's not a 5 star hotel buffet. It's included in the room rate so there is really nothing to complain about as there are many other breakfast options outside if you're fussy but I would save my money for dinner as good restaurants are quite expensive in Tokyo. Also if you don't want the breakfast you trade your breakfast voucher for credit at the convenience store downstairs which we used on our last day. We organised a car to the airport on our departure without any hassles. Staff are very friendly.

I've been twice in this hotel and I think it's a very good choice and a great value for money. The hotel is quite new, clean, easy to find. Rooms are big enought for the japanese standard. Breakfast is very good, with choice of japanese and western food.

A wonderful, modern hotel in the heart of crazy Kabukucho in Shinjuku. For those who do not know, you should be aware that this is the red light district. However, it's not crazy filthy, just a little chaotic. It's the only major hotel in this area (that I saw), and is really an amazing location, just blocks from Shinjuku station and the center of the area's shopping district, as well as a short walk from Nicho, the gay area. Best of all, if you exit the back you are in the tiny fabled Golden Gai district, with the hotel's Eastern windows overlooking it directly. The hotel was pretty sleek for a Best Western. The room was the nicest of the three very nice hotels experienced during our vacation, complete with chic features like a basin sink in the bathroom. For price, location, and comfort, I doubt the Best Western can be beat in the area.

I spent 2 nights in Tokyo on my way to Korea. First time in Tokyo. Easy access (10 min walk) to Shinjuku central station which connected me to all attractions in Tokyo. staff was very friendly. very good breakfast buffet.

Stayed here 5 nights. Location is very convenient at Shinjuku. Breakfast is wonderful - western & eastern mix every morning - good variety & selections and also very tasty - really worth it. Bed very comfortable and not too small at all. Room size also bigger than I expected. Very clean overall, wonderful front desk service, no "smokiness" at all on our non-smoking floor. Bathroom also adequate size with tub-next to shower combo (typical Japanese set-up). Amenities all there and more! (tea, coffee, kettle, fridge, safe, etc.) Shinjuku station is confusing (east side only connects to west side via 3 routes! Which is not enough for its size!) Hotel easy to find, though. Use the "east/Kabukicho" exit and only 5-10 min. walk. Definitely look for "Mr.Donut" as marker to make your turn into the right street. Kabukicho is toleraable, and you can always avoid walking thru it. TONS of shopping in the area. I've also stayed in Tokyo Station area, and I prefer that for myself. But, the hotel itself is a great value and in great condition!!

Stayed at this hotel for 6 nights in September 2013 and had a pleasant stay. With the amount of luggage we had, we decided to take a taxi to the hotel from Shinjuku station (cost us about 750 yen). Staff at the hotel are extremely friendly and more than happy to help with holding luggage prior to/after checking in and out.We requested a 'business double' room from their website. Cost us about AUS $150/night (81,000 yen for 6 nights) which included a great buffet breakfast which included Japanese and Western foods - hotel usually charges 1000 yen for breakfast. The room was on the 12th floor...rooms above the 12th floor require you to swipe your room card for added security.Hotel is in the Kabukicho area of Shinjuku, about a 8-10 minute walk from Shinjuku station. Need to ensure you choose the right exit from the station otherwise you may find yourself walking for longer than required.I found the room itself quite small and difficult to store 2 large luggage bags, however was still manageable (room is average for Japanese standards so not a big issue). The bathroom was great and modern. There's also free wifi.Pros:- Good location in Shinjuku, near to Kabukicho/Golden Gai for bars, plenty of food options around, Lawson just outside the hotel- Buffet breakfast with lots of variety- Room is modern and bathroom is largeCons:- After a long day of walking, Shinjuku station can be quite far away (about 8-10 minute walk)Overall, we had a great stay at this hotel. I'd stay here again for the price, comfortable stay and location in Shinjuku.
user_name:
JadeF896
Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: A very nice hotel in the middle of it all in Down Town Shinjuku. Right next to the Kabuchi-ko and the night life area. The Tokyo JR and Metro stations are only 5 minutes walk. The rooms are tiny but the lovely full sized bath in the bathroom makes up for the small room size. The toiletries in the room are very well stocked and replenished daily. The breakfast buffet downstairs near the lobby has a nice selection of Western and Japanese foods, the staff are also very friendly.Heaps of shopping malls around, don't forget to look underneath the roads as well as they have shopping malls there as well - "Subnade".We would definitely stay here again next time we are in Tokyo

We booked a double room for 5 nights, it was so small there was nowhere to put the cases. Upgrade to a twin room and you get twice the space for another 1000y. Worth the small extra.There is a laundry (300y) and dryers (200y). Very quiet rooms, pleasant staff. Free internet. Breakfast OK Western and Asian choices. It is difficult to negotiate your way out of the station to the hotel, suggest you get a good map before trying, if all else fails ask a policeman.

Excellent location, and overall good value for money.Art deco / modern design. The rooms are well appointed, i recommend you to use the one above the 1th floors.Cannot try the breakfast, since left the hotel too early.The hotel is surrounded bu a lot of nice bars and restaurant.10 mn from the train stationGood choice, i recommend

A 10 minute walk from Shinjuku station, the Best Western Astina hotel is well situated in the heart of Tokyo. If you arrive by train from Narita (like we did), take the east exit out of Shinjuku station. You can walk to the hotel in about 10 minutes from the station. My tip is if you have a smart phone with GPS, that's way better than using a map to find the hotel. Shinjuku is a major train hub, very big, busy and confusing. Easy to get lost.The hotel is located just off a major street with mister donut at the head of the street. There is a Lawson's convenience store beside the hotel. The main entrance to the hotel is on the 3rd floor. Look up to see the Best Western logo on the building.The hotel itself is beautiful and very modern. The staff were very friendly and efficient, getting us to our room quickly. The room was an okay size, average by Japanese standards. Meaning small. Although the layout is good and the room is very modern and neat, it's still tight for 2 people by North American standards. Nevertheless the bed was great, quiet room and great shower. This hotel doesn't seem to offer suites if you buy on line, but after a day you get used to it. After all you are in the centre if Tokyo! We got breakfast included in our rate. Great breakfast, a little for everyone. Beef curry, rice, miso soup, breads, cereal, salad, eggs and fried chicken to round out your choices. Beautiful restaurant and very attentive and friendly staff.In the heart Of Shinjuku, great stay and I would stay here again, but with less luggage.

We stayed in BW Shinjuky for 2 nights and the stay in general was comfortable. The room rate are not high (compared to other hotels in Tokyo) hence we did not expect much so that was a good thing.The location is really good although as said in other comments it is hard to navigate from the train station and the map on the website is not very clear, make sure you know which exit you are taking.The rooms are extremely small and we could barely move around with our 2 big bags in the room as well. The staff at the reception is not super friendly and they don't know much about giving recommendations. Last but not least, the breakfast buffet is horrendous.... It is not hard to make that a little nicer by adding some fresh fruit and maybe a little bit more variety intje western buffet.

Stay in this hotel many time and each time it never fail to give me a wonderful and friendly feeling.the bed is comfortable , bathroom is clean. The only thing I hope is ,if they have a bigger wardrobe then everything is perfect .

I would echo what most people have said. The price was very fair for what you get. The staff are kind and gracious. If you want Tokyo energy -- Shinjuku is the place to be.I haven't see others comment on it but my internet connect came and went. Sometimes it was fine. Sometimes it was painful.Also, if you are a first time visitor to Tokyo and you are coming into Shinjuku station, look at a map before you come. Try to find the East exit at the station and spend some time with a map before you try to find the hotel. It is close to the station but Shinjuku is not trivial to navigate.

The Best Western hotel in Shinjuku is an attractive modern hotel in a fabulous location. It is easy to get to and has great access to the metro to get to other parts of the city. We found it very comfortable and quite spacious for the two of us. Bathroom is great, breakfast fine, typical hotel fare and staff very polite. The Golden Gai is literally at the back door and is a really interesting area to wander about in. Very good choice and great value for money for first timers to Tokyo .

I didnt expect the location to be so great, I didnt expect the room & to be SO HUGE, and I didnt expect the great breakfast!! My husband (who is built like a football linebacker) and I really liked this hotel and all the space it offered for the price. (granted we got it on sale)The breakfast tickets they give you can be used downstairs at lawsons as well if you miss breakfast or prefer some of those tasty treats instead. Wish we had know this on day one because Lawsons (7-11 type place) is our fav Japan spot. lol. So many Japanese style treats and fresh food plates!

I wonder how it is possible to sell a double that hardly accommodate 1 person and however without a suitcase.Why employee at reception keep temperature at 18 C., only because they wear jacket and socks? what about the poor tourist that is coming from an outside temperature of 38/40?Who care the customer....

Stayed here for two nights and we were very happy we chose this hotel. The value was great for the price, especially considering the location, free breakfast, and wifi. We had problems finding it - it was our first night arriving in Tokyo, so getting through the busiest train station (Shinjuku) with all our luggage and then trying to navigate the streets to find the hotel was stressful, but once we found it we realized it's in a great location near to the train station and shopping/sights of Shinjuku. I'd just recommend making sure you know exactly where you're going to get from the station to the hotel - we had just printed off the map from the hotel website and it wasn't too helpful (use Google streetview so you can recognize landmarks to help you find it). We were upgraded to an 'executive room' so I'm not sure how different it is from a regular room but we were very happy with it - plenty of space for a Tokyo hotel, the bathroom was lovely, and lots of free amenities (face lotions and cleansers, razor, toothbrush, water bottles on the first night, etc.) so if you forget anything you're covered. The staff at the front desk were all so friendly and welcoming. Breakfast is fine if you're not picky - I didn't like a lot of things but there was enough to fill me up. Wifi works in the rooms but you'll just have to keep logging in with an email address.Streets right outside the hotel are busy with nightlife and people trying to get you to come into their clubs, so if you want a quieter location this might not be a good choice, but we liked the excitement.Overall we'd stay here again!

This hotel was located in a prime location in Shinjuku. It may be a little challenging finding it if you are not familiar with the area as it is a couple minutes walk from the underground station. The hotel is modern & clean, the room is adequately sized (despite the complaints about it being small), and the space is well utilized and even comes with a mini fridge, coffee machine, blow dryer, and welcome bottles of water for your first night. The semi double beds were very comfortable for 2 smaller sized adults, so no complaints there. The breakfast buffet, which was included in our reservation, had a great variety of Japanese & Western items, including miso soup, natto (yum!), sweet potato salad (my favorite!), seaweed salad, yogurts (asian yogurts are very watery), cereals, juices, etc. Considering how expensive the cost of living in Tokyo is, this hotel proves to be great value! Don't forget to visit the nearby Kabuki-cho to observe some interesting characters walking around at night...

Stayed there for 8 nights this month.Overall a good hotel, with clean rooms and professional, helpful staff. The hotel is conveniently located in Shinjuku, but at night the area livens up and there are too many recruiters for strip or gentlemen clubs roaming around, the hotel street. I wish the hotel were situated on a quieter street still in Shinjuku.I found the breakfast buffet to be of low quality especially the almost soup like scrambled eggs, so don't waste your time there.

This is a good hotel in a great location in Shinjuku. The room is small (as it seems to be the rule in Tokyo), but it is very comfortable and clean. It is next to the biggest train and subway station in great Tokyo. So, it is pretty convenient. Just be careful to take the right exit. The station is HUGE, so taking the wrong exit might make the walk to the hotel pretty long. They have a self-service laundry, which is a must for long term travelers. The breakfast is not a big deal, so if you find a good rate without breakfast, go for it. There are lots of shops, groceries and restaurants around the hotel, opened from very early until late at night. Shinjuku is a good location for a first time visitor. It is a busy commercial area with everything you might need for your convenience. As the city is immense, it takes about 40 to 60 min by train or subway to the main tourist sites.

By far, the best thing about this hotel is its location. It is located right near Shinjuku station in Kabukicho, and it is on the more 'exciting' side of Shinjuku. As in, there are lots of shops, restaurants, bars, etc that is open all hours, as opposed to the more 'business' side of Shinjuku. My husband and I stayed in their semi-double room on one of the 'business floors' - it just means there is extra privacy - you need to swipe your room key at the elevator to get to our floor. We were there for 8 nights. My main concern when booking hotel rooms in Japan is the size of the room - my husband is over 6ft, so I didn't want him to feel too squished. The semi-double room is - as most Japan hotel rooms are - on the small side but was a comfortable size for the hubby. Room is clean, beds are very comfy, bathroom is also nice and to me, these are the main important points, alongside location. There is a Lawson's convenience store downstairs in the building, and there are vending machines on each floor so it's very handy. We also opted to get a room with breakfast included. Breakfast buffet is pretty good - and great for fuelling up for a full-day ahead.Walking to Shinjuku is easy once you get your bearings a bit, as Shinjuku station is huge and there are so many entrances. On the first day, lugging our bags around was a bit tricky looking for the hotel. We followed the advice to go to the East exit of Shinjuku station but ended up walking the streets looking for the hotel. My advice is to head towards the East exit at Shinjuku, go towards Shinjuku 3 Chome metro station, and exit when you see the Subnade shopping area (underpass). Head to exit 13 or 15, and once you're up the stairs, you will see a Mister Donut on the corner. Turn left down that street and before you know it, you will be at the Best Western Astina. My only criticism of the hotel: perhaps the staff should know the area and give better instructions for tourist services. In particular, we found out there was a bus to Tokyo Disneyland and Disney Sea from Shinjuku. Long story short, we had gone to Disney Sea by train (which I don't really recommend), but then took the bus back. Bus stop at Shinjuku is at the 'New South entrance,' which is a bit of a random place compared to the rest of the station if you haven't had a chance to really walk around Shinjuku yet. As it was late and we ended up walking along the platform back to the main part of Shinjuku station, we needed a more direct way to walk to the bus station the next day from the hotel. Asked the hotel for guidance, and guess what - they gave us the wrong directions to a completely different bus terminal - did a huge loop around Shinjuku station (whilst walking outdoors on a hot Summers day). The only few reasons we were able to find the bus terminal in the end, is that thankfully, we had been there the night before so remembered buildings around it, we had to re-read the map a few times and from having some conversational Japanese skills. On the way back, we walked a different way back to the hotel and it took less than 10 minutes - pretty much straight up the road on the other side of the station (and not the loop the front desk had directed us towards that morning). The most helpful thing we had was in fact, a map to the bus station that they had printed off for us! Despite that little hiccup (I just wanted to share for any others who plan to visit Disney), we definitely won't hesitate to stay there again the next time we're in Tokyo. We really loved the Shinjuku location and it was so easy to start so many great journeys/ adventures from Shinjuku station (Hakone via Romancecar, Studio Ghibli tour, Harajuku is a couple of stops away, metro to Asakusa and Tokyo Sky Tree, etc)

Stayed for 4 nights while on vacation with my wife and child. Location is perfect, max 5 minute walk from Shinjuku station, in a very lively area. Rooms are very nice and extremely clean and full of amenities (pj's, slippers, razors, toothbrush, safe,...) but obviously on the small side (normal for Tokyo). WiFi was provided in thr room but the signal can be improved. Breakfast is average, nothing special but they do provide good coffee. Staff is nice and very polite. I would add at least one tv channel in English for news. Air con worked fine and it was much needed as heat/humidity outside were umbearable. Would definitely go back if in Tokyo again.

We had a comfortable 5 night stay at BW Shinjuku, and found the room/hotel to be a pleasant surprise after the cramped room we had at BW Fino Osaka. BW Shinjuju is conveniently located near Shinjuku station and the night life is on it's door step. Overall we were very happy with the hotel, amenities and staff.

We had a pleasant stay at BW Shinjuku, the room was nice and finally we had enough space to live comfortably for 4 nights. At the beginning we had a hard to to find it since the name of the hotel is not really on display. Once arrived we appreciated the comfort of the room and the silence even if the hotel was fully booked.What we did not like was finding stained bed sheets, called the reception around 11pm and they almost could not understand what the problem was. Then came a service guy who did not have a clue on how to change the bed sheet, he finally managed to move the bed away from the wall but this showed how much dust was on the floor under the bed. The bathroom had some issues also, while the floor and bathroom fixture were clean the walls and ceiling had some hairs sticking which were not removed with the daily cleaning.I even applied for the no cleaning day but un-applied immediately when I found out that not only they do not clean, but they don't even make up the bed, so it's more a no service at all!Breakfast was good and had a decent variety of options to choose even for continental breakfast.Location is good, just 10 min walk from Shinjuku station.In the end I do not quite understand why this hotel is a 4*, facilities are not any different from a good 3* and the service is not so outstanding even if I still think it is a very good hotel and would probably go back.

Ok, the rooms are small...but this is TYO. Service was consistently attentive, friendly and helpful - no request too much trouble. Buffet breakfast is a great way to start - good selection, that had some variation each day. Bathroom and shower were a highlight. Shower was just excellent after a hard day sightseeing/shopping/touring - great pressure and 'soft' water that allowed the good quality amenities to lather nicely!Enjoyed the thoughtfulness of having simple cotton kimonos available in the room - comfortable.Room very clean - could not fault it.My only suggestion for an even better offering would be an additional English TV channel. As useful as CNN is - it is sooooo repetitive. We did watch some Japanese TV (many, many stations - over analogue, digital and satellite offerings)...but perhaps BBC or even ABC Asia?Great area - short walk to Shinjuku; many great restaurants (including a great sushi restaurant recommended by someone at the Front Desk) and great shopping.

After a long weekend of music and and running up and down a mountain at Fuji Rock Fest, I just needed a place that let me sleep. And Best Western was perfect for that. Now don't get me wrong, this is not some cheap hotel in Shinjuku, It is a beautifully laid out hotel which has all the amenities that one needs in a compact and comfortable layout. The room is super clean and the running water is strong and plentiful. One of the worst things to have is low water pressure in a shower. This place doesn't disappoint.As I only spent one night here, I wasn't able to use the facilities to the fullest, but the buffet breakfast was more than adequate and I have zero complaints regarding the rest of the place. Other than a constant need to sign up for wifi every two hours, this place gets my vote for convenience, comfort and most likely my imminent return. Food around the area is good but you do have to do a bit of digging (not everyone around the area speaks English). Also there surrounding the hotel is a sorta red light district. But it will not get in your way. The rooms are superquiet and also dark, so if sleeping in is your thing, you'll definitely wake up not knowing what time it is or where you are. All-in-all, an excellent place and an excellent hotel. Staff are friendly and more than adequately represents the Best Western name.

The hotel is very clean, comfort. The staffs are very kind. Location of this hotel was great, center of Shinjuku. If you like nightlife n 24Hr entertainment n foods, this hotel is really suitable for you!If i visit to Tokyo again, i would stay here again.

We had a great stay in this hotel . We were traveling with a toddler and wanted a hotel which would be near to most of the attractions and this turned out to be perfect for usPros : 1. This hotel is like 5 min from the subway station (no. 13 and 15 ) 2. Rooms are very clean and has a good ambience.3. Not many hotels in Japan have a breakfast inclusion . Thankfully this one does and has many western varieties to choose from, which was a big plus point ,considering we would have to search for a restaurant early in the morning with a toddler by our side.4. Since the location is Shinjuku it is easy to reach any attraction from there without many change in lines5. Staff can speak excellent english .Cons: 1. I m not sure if it was a problem with our room or usual Japanese trend, but the air cons are usually kept at a minimal temp,making it difficult to know if its even working !!!!! and this was everywhere we went !!!!2. It is very near to the red light area, so good for those who want to enjoy the night life, but for family with young kids it can be a little creepy.

We really enjoyed our stay in this hotel, We had a room with a separate lounge room , fairly big for Tokyo. Staff was very nice , Location was great, you walk out the front and turn right and you`re in the so called red light district ( very tame ), but very colourful., you turn left and you walk up to some great shopping and restaurants. It`s very close to all transport. Would stay here again if back in Tokyo. I should also mention ,there is a coin operated washing machine and dryer in the hotel

Great hotel in a great location. The rooms are clean and comfortable. The rooms had free wi-fi and a safe inside.Close to the Shinjuku subway and JR station so it's convenient for getting around. Definitely a good hotel for couples or young travelers. The breakfast in the morning is decent with a good mix of Japanese and western food. Would definitely stay here again.

Very friendly helpful staff. I booked a "ladies room" which came with a massage chair and extra toiletries. The cleaning was of a good standard with an eco-friendly choice of only having it done every second day. By booking in advance I got an excellent discount so it was great value. Location was convenient. The only drawback was the breakfast, I ended up having scrambled eggs and French toast or brioche for 12 days because they were the only things on the menu that I liked. But if you like coco pops, hot chips or curry for breakfast then you'll be fine. Would definitely stay here again!

My wife and kids are traveling to Tokyo for vacation and we found this hotel to be on the central location to everywhere they want to go. I booked the hotel online and then needed to make changes to the reservation so I called them. The lady who answered the phone speaks fluent English and was very professional. Room was nice and clean, the staff were friendly and very helpful. The included breakfast served both Japanese and US style, very yummy! We stayed there for 3 nights and then decided to come back right before flying out of Japan and they upgraded us to a larger room free of charge. Over all, we love the hotel and will definitely come back the next time we visit Tokyo.

This now being my third time in Tokyo you can definitely tell the difference of the amount of people on the streets during different times of the year. As my previous visits have been during February & March, this time visiting in June the streets in Shinjuku and Tokyo in general are definitely busier/crowded. As a side note, as I had travelled around Western Kyushu prior to arriving in Tokyo you can definitely tell the difference in how flamboyantly individual the people of Tokyo are in their appearance which is neat to notice. Stayed at the Best Western Shinjuku Astina again during this trip, a pleasant stay, I would recommend booking through their direct site http://www.bw-shinjuku.com/ rather than the international Best Western site as you have more options in the types of rooms that are offered & various packages that can be booked. I booked the Executive room ladies package that included additional bath amenities, higher floor & ladies amenities inside the room such as an air purifier, massage chair & facial makeup steamer. Again smallish room, but comfortable for one person & a view this time. My only issue was that in booking an executive package/room you would think that this would include breakfast, but my package apparently did not which didn't make sense. I did end up paying for breakfast on my last day as I knew I had a long day ahead of me which cost me 1000 Yen. Not particularly please with that. Overall good consistent experience, good location, good room amenities, Lawson's on main floor next to escalator/elevator, close to Shinjuku station & fare in price. I will most likely stay again.

I have stayed at Best Western Shinjuku for the 3rd time now, and in the meantime it is definitely my favorite hotel for short leisure and/or business trips to Tokyo. It has superb value for money if you book a 5+ nights plan (45% off), excellent soundproofing, modern and spacious rooms, and best of all (and that's different from the Nishi-Shinjuku topclass hotels like Park Hyatt or Keio Plaza which I've also stayed at) you're right in the middle of the nightlife action - some of the most awesome Kabukicho clubs are just across the street (though conversational Japanese is much recommended to get in there). Directly at ground floor you have a 24/7 Lawson's, 20m to the right a Seven-Eleven with an ATM that takes foreign cards, and 30m to the left the Shinjuku city ward office with a complete post office. All in all - superb. Will be coming here again and again for sure.Shinjuku station also not far off

Pros:1. Convenience place access from/to Haneda/Narita Airport (5-8mins walk from Shijuku JR Line*with luggage)2. Accessing to business lounge when stay above 11th floor (various options free drink)3. Room rate including breakfast (small restaurant with comfy space)4. Reception speaks good English (and super warm service when you request needed help!!!)5. The best room capacity I ever stay in Tokyo. (Hotels room are normally small in Tokyo)6. Convenience store (Lawson) at hotel 1F (famimart and 7-11 also near by)7. Public space and aisle smells nice (lol)Cons:1. Located near red light area in Shinjuku, kinda scary walking alone on street after 112. Electrisical outlet are too few, only 4 in total in my room I remember 3. Complimentary water on first day arrival only.Tip:1. Book room above 11th floor needs to access security guard, this makes guest feel more safe2. Request the room face to Shinjuku tall building area, when you wake up in the morning, it feels great to see the view of ShinjukuStayed June 2013, traveled on vacation

Good convenient location for exploring Tokyo and doing some business on the side. Very clean and also spacious. The people were very friendly and were able to assist me with all my needs. I would definitely go here again!

Stayed here for 4 nights in June, about 10 mins walk from Shinjuku west exit.Staff were really polite and helpful with great local knowledge.The room was pretty small TBH, but that is the norm for Asian hotels. But the bed was a proper double sized bed which was the main thing.Had free wifi, however you have to register for it. Normal mod cons, air con, shower etc.The room was clean.There is a Lawson which is 24 hour that is located right underneath the hotel, which was handy as the breakfast that is offered at the hotel was not nice at all IMO. Was a very strange offering, you had fish alongside scrambled egg lol very strange. None of the food looked nice to me and this was confirmed when I attempted to eat some egg.This is a good hotel with a great location and base to check out Tokyo, you have Golden Gai and the Shrine behind the hotel. Times Square about 10 mins away.

The hotel is light on facilities with laundry and a restaurant for breakfast and lunch the main two features, but the rooms are comfortable and very well serviced. The customer service is typically Japanese, almost flawless, which made the stay very pleasant. It is very well priced for a hotel in Tokyo, and its location is excellent very close to the JR line and subway at Shinjuku station making travel across the city very easy. It is placed in the heart of Shinjuku Tokyo's "2nd city centre" but a word for families it is placed within Kubukicho a very large red light district within which many "adult clubs" are situated.The hotel is in my opinion a fantastic choice for adult groups and student groups and for business trips. Pros: Wonderful staff, generous buffet breakfast, 24hr shop downstairs, excellent central location, very well priced. Highly recommend this place. Cons: Immediate proximity to red light district something to consider if you have young children, laundry room is tiny (2 washers and 2 dryers) and often full, just the basics (no gym, swimming pool, entertainment area etc)

Please consider to prepare a form with two columns and mark X / Y.1/ Do you want to change your bed sheet. 2/ Do you want to change your towel!If the customer want to change bed sheet, they will mark on the Yes box in colum one, and paste on the back side of the front door.

We stayed here for three nights and found it to be very convenient. There are lots of bars and restaurants close by and the hotel is very close to the subway lines to explore other areas of the city. Our room was small but since we were only there to sleep it did not matter. There is not much space for storing or hanging clothes but this is a minor complaint. The staff is very friendly and breakfast buffet was fine. There is a choice of Japanese or Western breakfast. The beds were very comfortable.

As commented by many others, this hotel is at the heart of Shinjuku with easy reach to numerous restaurants, shopping malls and night clubs. It is much safer than you may think if this is your first time to Shinjuku. No one bothers you if you hold hands with your lover. Room for Improvement: (1) Better make it clear during checking-in that complementary bottles of mineral water are provided only for the first day. This puzzled me for the first few nights during my stay. (2) Be more lenient when being asked for late check-out. I asked if I could check out at 12noon. I was asked to pay 30% of the regular room charge and I would be allowed to stay until 2pm. it's perfectly alright to have a charge but the way how the front-desk staff puts it can be better trained - should not make guests feel money is what matters most.

Great location in Kabukicho.We booked a room on high floor, with town view.Rooms are spacious. Wifi in rooms and hotel.Bathroom very clean.Staff gentle and very good service.Good breakfast (western and Japanese food).

The first task in finding a hotel in Tokyo, is to determine what area you want to stay in. Having been to Tokyo before, I knew I wanted to stay in the Shinjuku area. There are many hotels in this area as it is one of the entertainment zones in Tokyo. We chose the Best Western Shinjuku Astina for its convenience, price and location. The rooms are small, but that is common in Tokyo, clean, and modern. For myself the room was ample, with desk, and love seat. My two friend's room, same size as mine was snug but acceptable. They offer free breakfast and free wifi, just what I was looking for. The hotel is located in the Kabukicho area of Shinjuku and is on the second floor. Easy escalator or elevator will bring you to the lobby. A Lawsons convenience store is on the first floor. The Kabukicho area is an entertainment zone with many bars, restaurants and girly bars, but I found the area completely safe and not intimidating at all. The hotel is a short walk from the JR Shinjuku train station. Come out the East exit and walk along the Shinjuku dori, cross over to the Yasukuni dori and left onto Kabukicho (Shinjuku ward office street). there is a Mr. Donut on the corner. Maybe 10 minute walk. There are very little amenities, no pool, fitness room, but computers in the lobby and a restaurant and laundry room. Plenty free maps and brochures in the lobby. Morning staff good English, afternoon staff, not as good, but understandable. The hotel was always well maintained and clean. Breakfast was heavy on Asian items, but eggs, some meat (sausage or bacon) and cereals and breads always offered. Large selections of teas, coffee and juices. It is certainly enough to get you started, just do not look for a banquet.

We were booked into a hotel in Ginza, but at the last minute decided to change as we felt the Best Western Astina was a better location, we made the right choice!We loved the liveliness of Shinjuku, the bright neon lights, the busy streets and the great choices for eating out.The hotel is located right near the Golden Gai,, although we did not go to a bar there, we ventured through for a wander and it was quite entertaining.The hotel itself is really clean and comfortable, although I can't say I loved the Japanese pillows, but you get this at any hotel.The breakfast buffet is a bit odd, but it saved us from going hungry.The hotel is within walking distance of Shinjuku station and this makes it's perfect for getting around all of Tokyo.If I were to return to Tokyo, I would definitely consider staying here again and I recommend it to fellow travellers who enjoy being in the middle of the action!

Convenient, clean and well appointed. I've stayed at this hotel many times over the past five years and my partner and I highly recommend it to all Gaijin. Even took out loyalty membership based on my experiences.

Very good, and will refer this hotel to my friends--the room is very clean, and hotel gives guest a choice to clean the room once every two days, the 500 yen credit can be used in the hotel.Free wifi, breakfast is good.
user_name:
Rex M
Auckland Central, New Zealand

review_body: Small room which is normal by Tokyo standard but very clean. 5-10minute walk from Shinjuku station. Although in midst of the very busy kabukicho, room is sufficiently sound proofed for a good night sleep. Breakfast nothing to shout about.

very nice hotel not only that but i feel i was in cairo - Egypt- my home very polite stuff hep at any time indeed reserve here not go away eveything in your hands high standard service . dr. wael hewidi

Can not recommend this hotel highly enough and will certainly stay on any return visits. We arrived about 8.00am after an overnight flight and we were able to change and freshen up and have our luggage held until check in time. Our twin room was on the 13th floor next to the Excetutive Lounge which was strange but a nice open spot with free vending machine drinks. The room was modern and quite spacious. Our son had a double on a lower floor which would have been a bit uncomfortably small for a couple. Again it was well appointed with good quality bathroom products. We enjoyed the big range of breakfast foods. I think some reviewers forget all foreign visitors have to be catered for not just Westerners! Shinjuku is a big busy station but the beauty is you can get everywhere very quickly and it is on the Narita Express. The hotel is reasonably easy to find the first time if you take the Eastern train exit and no 15 exit in the Sunade. Other reviewers have given very careful clear directions.The hotel looked after our luggage while we walked the wonderful Kumano Kodo and we returned to our luggage taken to two up graded rooms. The 14th floor was a wonderful experience!We found the area around the hotel vibrant but not at all threatening and were not hassled by touts. We entered via the back alley along the Golden Gai rather than Kabukicho. Although in a busy area we experienced no street noise except cheering the night Japan played Australia in the Soccer and everyone was watching on TV.Memory Lane and all the big department stores are nearby. I had to replace long distant glasses and got a great price and selection at a nearby Alook, all done with lenses fitted in 30 minutes.Thank you to the great staff for a wonderful stay!

This hotel is very convenient for the subway & train in Shinjuku. The room was somewhat small but otherwise very nice. The breakfast buffet was good. The interesting Golden Gai area is literally just outside the hotel. There are many, many restaurant options in the area.

Other than the cigarette scent left over by the previous occupants of our non-smoking room, everything was perfect. Notwithstanding, the hotel staff was quick (and extremely polite) to transfer us to another room. We were equally pleased with the breakfast spread. The hotel also took care of guests who are unable to have breakfast, by allowing them to exchange the breakfast vouchers with items of equivalent value at the convenient store downstairs. We had to catch a wee-hour flight so got food from the store, on the go - free.

My family and I stayed at this Best Western for a week (May 13-19) we had the double bed rooms and also single bed rooms. Although the rooms are small you have to remember you are in Japan and the hotel rooms tend to be smaller unless you’re paying a greater price (you get what you pay for). Upon my arrival I was arriving after my family by myself and didn’t have any directions to the hotel so I called the Front Desk at the hotel and I had a male member talk me through from the train station all the way to the entrance of the hotel itself. I really appreciated his patience for me (sadly I forgot his name). We also ate at their breakfast buffet which had a very good selection of food to choose from. In our last days of our stay I wanted to surprise my mother and get her hair done in Japan so I asked *Higarashi* at the Front Desk to help me find a salon she was very helpful and sweet. On our day of departure she (Higarashi) also came out behind the desk to say goodbye to us. This gesture really made us feel special as guest of the hotel.

We stayed there for 10 nights. A great location for exploring tokyo, only a five minute walk to the station. Very close to the attractions of western tokyo (Shibuya/Harajuku) and right next to Golden Gai. The beuffet breaksfast was quite good, could do with some more western style food though. The rooms are small by western standards, but spacious compared to other rooms I have stayed at in Tokyo. The people at the service desk were always ready to help, their english was more than adequate. The only issue was being pestered by touts when returning to the hotel at night. Would stay here again.

I love this little hotel. I arrived quite late after transiting from Singapore (just after midnight), and the English-speaking front desk clerks were efficient and friendly in getting me checked in (and lending me an adapter). The room wasn't huge--I don't think anything in Tokyo is--but it wasn't tiny either, and it was extremely clean, comfortable and pleasingly put together. It's quite modern (including one of those fun Japanese toilets that shoots out spray to help you, er...clean). The bed makes for a good night's sleep.The breakfast buffet is solid--it was very easy to put together a substantial, healthy meal regardless of your tastes, and the dining room itself is lovely and relaxing. Service is excellent there and throughout the hotel. it's convenient to have a convenience store located at the first floor (the lobby is on the third, FYI). I was also pleased to discover that there's a laundry facility within the hotel on the 7th floor, so all of my worry about having to haul my laundry somewhere vanished instantly. Dryers could be a little more efficient, but it's a minor quibble.On top of all that, the room prices are extremely reasonable. Shinjuku is very well located, and despite the bustle on the adjacent streets (it's a very happening area with lots of shopping and dining), I found that my room (and the hotel in general) was quite quiet. Bottom line, I'd come back here in a heartbeat. So happy with this place.

Stayed for 3 nights in June and thought it was a great base, small rooms but as expected for Japan. Breakfast was included and quiet good. Brilliant little bar area just behind the hotel. Red light district is close but easy to avoid.

This hotels location close to the Tokyo Metro makes it a perfect choice to explore all of Tokyo's prefectures. We stayed at the hotel 8 nights. We had a standard room which is rather small, but for the price it is very good. Breakfast at the restaurant is plentiful and accommodates all nationalities. Front desk very helpful and can give advice on local area and how to get around. All in all we were very satisfied with our stay at the Best Western Shinjuku and will return on our next stay.

I was surprised to find out how affordable this hotel was while offering all the basic necessities with such high quality. Although the room was small it was very clean throughout, and it was a nice treat to see two clean pajamas on the bed everyday. The toilet is also equiped with the high-tech, auto spray feature, which can really spoil you. The free breakfast is my favorite part of the day. The food is great and the staff super friendly. Don't miss the French toast which was so delicious we requested it again the next day and the chef made it for us.Not only is their staff friendly they're also very honest. On the instruction sheet for using the safe, there's a disclaimer that the service people won't take anything from the room and that it is the guests' responsibility for the contents of the safe. I found out what that meant the next day, when I placed a tip on the table and it was still there when I returned at night (In any other hotels the $ would be taken by the room service person - I did place the tip there again when I checked out).I have only good things to say about this hotel.

good impression by last stay so take second stay but room was located lower floor makes some fan noise all the night. should ask to stay higher room when check-in even you are not booking for security floor.

Have to admit that we initially facing some problem to get there as that is our first time landed in Japan and hard to communicate with local. Once we reach there, everything smooth. Hotel prepared really nice baby-cot for my daughter which she enjoyed so much. New and nice hotel with all the small things make you feel warm.

Superb value for money, nice location, nice room, nice service...baby cot prepared before we arrived...nice staff, nice breakfast!!! just superb!! Nice location which near to the shinjuku station, very convenient...a convenient store just downstair...

Good location for shopping in Shijuku, all the big stores are in walking distance. Hotel Room is nice & Clean, Our kids like the Breakfest very much, The Twin Room is big enough for our family with 2 little kids.

This hotel is located right in the heart of Shinjuku. The service was pretty good with an English-speaking front desk. The breakfast was yummy and just the thing you need to start your day. Overall, it was a good deal considering the location and the fact breakfast was included into the rate. There was nothing special about the room itself, it was small and pretty standard. But nobody really comes to Tokyo to stay in the room - so all in all, a good bang for your buck. Will stay again.

From the moment we arrived and until I checked out, the service was outstanding. Any question I had was answered. The entire staff was very friendly and informative. I would definitely recommend this hotel and would look forward to staying here again for my next visit.

The hotel is located very close to Shinjuku Station & a good base to explore Tokyo. The rooms are very small by western standards - the double bed is against the wall - but was comfortable. Breakfast was a large spread including western & Japanese options. Staff were very friendly and helpful throughout our stay.

Liked staying at this BW. We were glad that we took the rooms on the business floors, above the bustle of the street. The room was small (as they are everywhere, except 5-star hotels many times the price of this BW, in Tokyo) but the bathroom was big and clean. We had breakfast included and it was fine for a 3-star place. The location is good for getting around town and for the livelyness Tokyo has to offer. The hotel is on the edge of the red light district of Tokyo and there are some shady buildings around it, but you should not feel unsafe.

Clean convenient central. Good value and stylish with an interesting and delicious breakfast. Good bathrooms and comfortable beds. Unfortunately area just outside hotel has loads of Africans trying to sell strip clubs. Tokyo government should do something about these people.

We usually stay at Sunroute Plaza, but wanted to be at the other side of the tracks this time, just to be in a different environment when you step out the door.This hotel was great! It's in the Kabuki-cho area of Shinjuku, at a 10-15 minute walk from Shinjuku Station, right near all the big shops and the underground shopping arcade (Subnade).We booked a twin room on the executive floor, which included breakfast. There was wired internet in the room, which wasn't a problem cause we alway take an Apple Airport Express and make our own wifi network. The room itself was perfect, on a high floor with views of Shinjuku. Perfect beds, enough room space. Fridge and safe. Breakfast was OK to start your day. They have two selections they switch each day. Fish, rice, some bread, scrambled egges, juice, some fuits, etc.We had dinner in Subnade a few times. Just go down at the streetlevel (exit 15 I think). There's a great Tonkatsu restaurant and a Okonomiyaki one. Both have an English menu with pictures in them and displays outside.

Big rooms compering to other places in tokyo. Nice breakfast and English friendly staff. Great room service. Goldan gai is just outside the hotel and worth a visit especially at night. Shinjuku station in just 7 min walk from the hotel.

THis hotel was good. We even got an upgrade to a better room, which was nice. The breakfast was good, the staff friendly and well located to golden gai (bar street). The restaurant on the 2nd floor was also really good. The only downside to this hotel is the distance from shinjuku station, it takes about 10-15 mins walk which can be annoying depending on how much luggage you have.

Rooms are small but not a big deal. I have a double for my partner and I and its fine.Free wifi is really good although has stopped working a couple of times which is annoying.Everything is clean and the included breakfast option I got is good.In a good location, easy to get to metro trains to explore, good nightlife here.Will come back here again

The hotel is good situated in the amusement quarter of Akihabara , Shinjuku. It is just a place to overnight and has nothing more to offer. What they call executive lounge is just an open room with some vending machines for free coffee drinks, not what one normally means with an executive lounge.

The FREE SPOT wi-fi service that we were told to use in order to access free wi-fi never worked for us - despite the fact that we tried on numerous instances to sign up for the service and apply the passwords that were supplied by the "service".Front desk personnel were quite disinterested in providing assistance.

My partner and I recently travelled to Asia on a two week holiday. Our first stop from April 17th-April 18th was inTokyo and we decided to stay at this hotel because it would not break the bank. We were hesitant to stay at this hotel at first but the location, amenities, class and service of this hotel although not quite a four-star, it truly deserves a four star rating from reviewers. I say this because comparison to other Asian hotels that we've stayed at in the past, the Shinjuki Astina to other hotels in Asia it has some great things about it and some items to work on. The Pros:* Location: The hotel is located in the Shinjuku district, which during the day is nothing out of the ordinary but at night time this district becomes alive. Tons of shopping located just steps away from hotel. The JR Yamanote line is about a 5-10 minute walk, which for Tokyo standards that's a plus.* Price: We booked a hotel for two days and for Tokyo standards we paid a lot less than let's say the Hyatt Shinjuku. * Breakfast: A breakfast buffet was included with our hotel reservation, which was really good. The food portions in Japan are tiny, so when you get a buffet breakfast we were quite pleased. * Shower: For Japanese standards, our room had an actual shower that was accomodating for tall people, we're 6'2" and 6'6" -- so it truly helped. The Cons:* Front Desk: While all of the staff on the front desk was quite friendly, their English skills were not very good (granted we're in Japan, so we should speak Japanese) but this is an American brand, so I just expected a little more help -- not a major turn off but since I'm a Tripadvisor Contributor, I really want to be specific. * Room Size: Very small bedrooms, which barely gave room to possibly walk around. But in a way the nice bathroom size with good quality amenities almost offset the lack of space in the bedroom. * No Gym/Pool: While we're on vacation we like to have little workout session but this hotel did not have a gym or pool. This was a bummer, which I should have checked but again it was not a big deal for only two day staying here. Overall we had a great stay at the Shinjuku Astina, so if we're in town next year on holiday, we will be back. Hopefully the prices will stay similar to what we paid, this really made me choose this hotel over others that were just slightly above the rate.

As a first time visitor to Tokyo, I found the Shinjuku location of this hotel to be fantastic. Plenty of shopping, restaurants and bars nearby and open at all hours, and easy to get everywhere else of interest in Tokyo. The Golden Gai bars directly behind the hotel were also a treat and felt like something that not every tourist gets to experience.As is typical for many Tokyo hotels, our room was absolutely tiny, but otherwise clean and with decent views/light. The breakfast buffet was pretty average but a good enough start to the day.

This is a lovely hotel in the middle of the red light district. It backs on to the Golden Gai, which we love. The directions we had from the station weren't great so we initially took a Y610 taxi. Once we walked back to the station, it was a pretty easy 5-6min walk. Being in the red light district was fine, none of us were bothered by the touts. Everything is in walking distance, food, shops, karaoke. It's a great location. The rooms are nice. Very clean and the space is good for Tokyo. Great bath. Love the vending machines/ice on each floor. There is also a Watsons on ground level which was handy. The buffet breakfast was fine. We were on the 10th floor but I could still hear people talking on the corner at ground level so I would try to stay on the higher floors if possible. Reception were helpful and held our bags after check out as we had a late flight.I would recommend this hotel. It was great value.

This nice and modern property is walking distance to Shinjuku station and the complimentary buffet breakfast is excellent - we tried everything Japanese we could find and it was all delicious. We took advantage of a five-year anniversary special and booked a two-room suite that was very comfortable and well appointed, including a heated toilet seat that added warmth to the memories... We highly recommend it and would definitely stay there again.

I was pleasantly surprised when I arrived at best western hotel. The hotel was easily accessible from through public transportation as we took the narita express train to get from narita airport directly to the shinjuku train station. From there, it was a 5 minute walk (depending on whether you know where you are going). Anyways, the hotel is on the second floor above a convenience store similar to a 7 eleven. It's pretty nice compared to other best westerns I've stayed at in the United States. The room is small but then again, we are in the heart of Tokyo here in their version of Times Square. One of the best things about the hotel is its proximity to shops and restaurants and bars. It's literally smack in the middle of the action. It's also a block seat from the golden gai alley, which is a small cluster of 6 alleys crammed with these small themes bars. Very old school Tokyo. Highly recommend. (Albatross bar rocks - great drinks and tourist friendly). I'd definitely recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Tokyo that doesn't want to spend an arm and a leg for just a place to rest and sleep.

I was really impressed with the 4 nights I spent in this hotel. The room was quite spacious for a Tokyo hotel, and both the room and bathroom were nicely decorated and furnished. The location was fantastic - just minutes walk from Shinjuku Station - and right in the middle of countless shops and restaurants. The area is always buzzing and lively, but very safe and a lot of fun. Very good value for the size of the room and the location - you could walk all over Shinjuku and easily access the rest of Tokyo. The breakfast was sufficient, and staff were friendly. I would stay here again as you just can't beat the location and the price.

The Best Western Astina is in the heart of Kabuki-cho (neighborhood) in the Shinjuku area of Tokyo. Within a few minutes walk in any direction, there are more restaurants and shops than you can count. There are both eastern and western restaurants, so satisfying your palate won't be a problem.The hotel is about a 10-15 minute walk from the Shinjuku train/Metro station, and just under 10 minutes from the Shin-sanchome Metro station.The hotel lobby is on the third floor of the building. The lower floors are stores/convenient store. There is an elevator and escalators that take you up from the outside street. The lobby is very modern and nice. The staff speaks very good English and is extremely friendly. The elevators are very fast. The room is small, which is typical for Japan, however there was enough room for my wife, toddler, and myself. There is a myriad of lighting options in the room, but some of the overhead lights are directly above the bed and can be too bright. The bed is very comfortable and the pillows are plush. There is a small couch and desk as well.The bathroom was very nice. The toilet is electronic with a constantly heated seat. The shower has great pressure and a very ingenious shower know system. The mirror is heated, so it will not fog up during a shower. The only downside to the bathroom is the door. It is glass, so at night, the light and sound may bother those in the room.The internet is wired, but free. It is also very fast!A free breakfast buffet is included in the lobby restaurant. The service is very friendly and a variety of food is offered, from cereal, yoghurt, and bread to traditional Japanese cuisine.Behind the hotel is a quiet flower/tree-lined path that connects one main street to another.There are two self-service laundry machines on the 7th floor. The washers dispense detergent automatically, so no need for your own. The dryer is not very efficient, so extra time for drying should be expected. Expect to spend 500-700 Yen depending on your load size.I would definitely stay at this hotel and recommend it to others.

I chose this hotel last minute and reserved an economy double room on the 9th floor. Although moving around in Tokyo can be daunting, finding this hotel was super easy, as it's just in the corner of the main road connecting Shinjuku on the east gate (8 min walk). Near the hotel you have metro, convenience stores, restaurants, department stores and all entertainment you can ask for. The hotel itself is really new; rooms are tastefully decorated and very confortable. There's wireless in the room to compensate for the japanese channels only TV. Breakfast is really nice as well, buffet style.I was really well impressed with service - I had trouble setting up the wi-fi and the lady at the reception arranged it for me. I also had to ask for help in adjusting the temperature in the room and it was promptly resolved. I loved this hotel...I think that you don't need to spend a fortune at the Hilton when you have everything you need here!!!

We stayed 4 nights at Best Western and enjoyed our stay. Room is small, but we've gotten smaller rooms in Japan. We found the bed comfortable, bathroom very clean and appreciated to have coffee and tea available in our room, as well as free wifi. The best thing about this hotel is it's closeness to the restaurants, shopping and the train station and the price was reasonable. You are in the entertainment district, but like other reviewers, we found it tamed and didn't bother us at all. The front desk was helpful and you have a convenience store below the hotel. We tried breakfast for our first morning...it was nothing special. We preferred to grab different foods at a bakery, cafe or department store food basements. Having stayed at the west side of shinjuku station at the end of our trip, we preferred Best Western and liveliness of East Shinjuku better. I would stay here again and recommend this hotel.

I stayed here for 3 nights in a business room on the 11th floor. The room was not huge but certainly big enough for a single traveler, had a desk, a fridge and a small couch. Very comfortable bed, nice bathroom, but no closet. It was quiet with no noise from adjacent rooms though occasionally you could hear a door slam from the corridor. Pretty nice view of the Shinjuku skyline. The location is good, close to lots of shopping and less than a 10-minute walk to Shinjuku JR station, nearly all of it underground, which is welcome on a rainy day. By the way, the exit closest to the hotel is 15B from Subnade (http://www.subnade.co.jp/english/e-floormap2.pdf) but good luck finding that on initial arrival. The area is an entertainment district, but seemed pretty tame. Two not so good points: the English proficiency of the front desk staff varies a lot, and the breakfast was sad unless you're partial to Japanese or Chinese breakfast. I don't think I'd book breakfast again, not a lot of choices for Western food. But overall, it was a pleasant stay and good value at $110/night.

I just want to share that my gilfriend and I are very grateful and impressed by the help and initiative of the hotel's front desk staff. His name is Wang Rui, and he made our entire stay in Best Western Shinjuku Astina memorable.We woke up on our last day, not realising we missed the flight back home and he was quick and sincere to offer his help and suggestion of an alternate and more affordable airline while we were on the phone with the airline we were suppose to fly back on.If not for his help, we would have spent more than double of what we would have paid our original airline for the rescheduled flight home. We will definitely stay at Best Western again when possible.

I stayed here for 6 nights and it was a great hotel. The location is brilliant it is 5-10mins walk from Shunjuku station so easy to get to from the airport on the Narita Express which comes into Shinjuku. The room was small but had everything you need including a fridge and the bathroom was modern and clean with lots of complimentary cosmetics and a washlet toilet! The rooms were relatively quiet but its not the most soundproof hotel. Fortunately most guests were not noisy.I never could be bothered to get up and sample the complimentary breakfast but the hotel is so convienent as it is above a Lawson 24hr store which has all kinds of hot and cold foods, drinks, alcohol, a photocopier etc. The hotel also has vending machines for drinks and snacks on each floor and a laundry on floor 7.The location is great and is right on the edge of the red light district and the Golden Gai bars . One thing to watch out for as a single male traveller is very aggressive (for Japan) foreign pimps who try to get you in to see their girls. To avoid them walk down the back road by Golden Gai not on the main road opposite the Shinjuku ward office.The price I paid was pretty good at around 9500Y per night but the early check in charge for checking in 3 hrs before 14:00 was a bit steep at 5700Y however after a long flight I just wanted a shower.Anyway great location, good value, really convienent and exceptionally clean and modern so it was a great hotel.

I stayed in a triple sharing room with larger than expected beds. My sleep was super comfy. With very modern interiors. At the same time, the breakfast at Stella was better than expected considering the reasonable price. Special thanks to Ai Omura who worked in the Stella restaurant.Her service was personal and impeccable.She even remembered my check out date and made an effort to come see us at the restaurant. With her level of good English and hospitality, she should be at the front desk! Soon hopefully. I will definitely recommend this hotel.

For this time of staying experience, i quite satified of this hotel . It is located at the heart of Shinjuku, but quite a distance from JR station. if next time come back, i will consider to live here again.
user_name:
Kai Yap Y
Johor Bahru, Malaysia

review_body: This was the second hotel we stayed in Tokyo, and is was great!Great location in Shinjuku, one of the greatests spots in Tokyo. 5-10 minutes walking distance from Shinjuku Station. The price is really good comparing to others Tokyo's Hotels.Comfortable and really clean rooms. Not big, just the necessary to have a great night sleep.The breakfast was good, costs like 10 dollars. I'm from Brazil, so was a little weird to have food for breakfast (like rice, chicken, salad..). But they have olther options like cereals, bread and egg.If we come back to Tokyo we would stay there again for sure.

This is a reasonably priced hotel in one of the busiest areas of Tokyo. Great access from the hotel to the subway and JR station. The rooms are clean and relatively quiet (you'll never be able to completely avoid the noise in Shinjuku). The rooms are small but that is to be expected in Japan. The hotel location borders the sketchy area of Shinjuku so it's probably not the best hotel for families but fine for couples and young travelers. The breakfast buffet has a nice mix of western and Japanese food. I would definitely stay here again.

Tokyo is known as an expensive city, and Best Western Hotel is an option to manage your budget. First impression with front desk is the language barrier. Crime and prostitution is close to this hotel. Front desk employee explained that by night is better to go to the right because to the left "there are bad people". Location is OK because is close to Shinjuku subway station (8 blocks), and to be picked up by a touristic bus you need to walk for 20 minutes to a designed hotel. Room size are better for locals. They are extremely small, but clean. However, in the front desk area rugs and sofas are dirty. Breakfast is average. Touring Tokyo and other japanese cities is just amazing for their life quality. Is impressive to watch 5,000 people crossing a street without a noise, and without seeing a paper on the floor.

Kinda average hotel, but sited walking distance from Shinjuku JR and Marunouchi Stn. The hotel itself was comfortable, clean and safe. The counter staff spoke English and provided good service. Except for the one occasion when the wifi service was failed. I could not get them to fix it until many hours later and many complaints. The wifi is free in all rooms and public areas. Breakfast is adequate though boring. There is a convenience store at street level, and many restaurants/food establishments within easy walking distance.

Just came back from Tokyo and had a great stay at the Best Western Shinjuku. Arrved at the hotel at 2pm and my husband and i were immediately greeted by the friendly reception staff and not only were we given the room immediately, we were also upgraded to a higher floor (12th floor). I have heard that rooms in Tokyo were very small but i was still suprised at the size of the double room. Once you put the suitcases down there is hardly any room to move around. Other than the matchbox size rooms, the rooms were very clean and comfortable with tea and coffee making facilities, complimentary water for the 1st day, Hair dryer, toiletries etc.. I did find the shower postioned in a strange manner (outside the bath tub) so that you had to hold it one hand to take a shower! The pillows were not very comfortable, a little flat and hard. The best part about this hotel is the location. Just up the road you find loads of shops, eating places, bars etc.. when i read reviews of this hotel, i was a little concerned about people saying that it is located in the red light district and that there were dodgy characters hanging around outside the hotel but this turned out to be a false alarm as we were not bothered by these people at all. The touts come out only after 10.30pm and they are just trying to get people into their club, i heard that this is the same in Roppangi where there is alot of nightlife around! The shinjuku station is just a 5 minutes walk away but be careful as this station is huge and very busy and you can easily get lost! take note of the exit's and entrances that you come and go from! The breakfast at the hotel was not bad. The choice was limitted but there was a little of everything to satisfy everybody. The breakfast choice was usualy 3 kinds of cereal, sausages, eggs (scrambeled and boiled), fish, ham, french fries, japanese rice and curry, miso soup, salads, fried fish and chicken, bread basket and fruits with 3 kinds of juice.The restaurant staff are always pleaseant and greet you with a wonderful smile! Wifi in the room was excellent. getting WIFI initially was a bit of mess as you have to enter an email address to get the password and the password gets emailed to you. you have an option of choosing wifi for 2 hours or 6 months so we choose the later option or else we would have to keep getting passwords everytime we needed to use the internet! There is no cable tv at the hotel so there are only Japanese tv programs available. Not too sure if this hotel is suitable for families purely beacuse the rooms are so small! Overall had a great stay with no issues!

Hotel is really close to a hub train station so in addition to being easy to find its brilliant for getting around the city. Lots to see in the area, I felt safe around the area too. Stayed on the exec floor so pretty nice sized room with good cityscape views. I was a bit bemused by the "executive lounge" which is listed as a feature but is really just a big room with a large boardoom style table, its not like any exec lounge I've ever seen! There is wifi in your room but I was only able to access via a phone/tablet with an email account which has an app rather than going to a webpage e.g. hotmail. You have to renew access every 2hrs, not a huge deal but worth saying

Reached hotel 10.30 am, walked from Shinjuku East Exit around 10 mins, easy to find with Google map which i checked before leaving to Tokyo, room charge for early check in or else drop luggage and come back at 2 pm. Front counter speak good English, nice staffs as well as breakfast cafe.Wifi not stable in room but lobby no problem, clean but small room for even 2 big suitcases, bathroom size just nice and water pressure good, bed comfortable but a bit too small for 2 persons, TV all Japanese channels, breakfast good food but almost same for 5 days, at the end i just took fruits and eggs. Good location for shopping, dining and night life and easy access by train and subway. Lobby have PC and printer easy for online check in but charged.To avoid the African and Japanese try to offer u massage and girl at night, u can walk the back lane which is safe to the hotel from main road (the other side of Mr Donut)

Location was great, near the train station and downstairs from the hotel there is a Lawson - 24 hr supermaket! Hotel rooms were reasonable size for Japan, not too big, but main thing is that it is clean!Breakfast was pretty average with the typical hot and cold dishes.

This is a very standard hotel in a lively area of Tokyo and provide all the basics, but do not expect anything exclusive. My room was OK though. The best was the filter coffee provided for your own cup when you need it! Breakfast is fine with a decent selection of both Western and Asian cuisine. The entrance to the building is awful, as there is only a single lift on the the ground floor amongst other entrances to take you to the 3rd floor lobby and foyer. Not a very welcoming and stylish entrance!

I stayed at the BW Shinjinku in mars for 2 nights and it was just a good value for money.Not too far from the station, well located with a 24h supermarket on the ground floor (very convenient when hungry in the middle of the night or lost to find something you may have forgotten for your trip).The room was clean and had everyhting needed (wifi - don't expect to download a movie to watch, TV etc...). The room is small but did not spend much time in it. Bathroom is small too but ok !Buffet breakfast was great, a lot of choice and a mix between asian and european food.Well I would recommend it !

We stayed here one night at the end of a cruise and wish we could have stayed longer. The hotel is in the Kabukicho area of Shinjuku, within walking distance of the Shinjuku train station. To walk, make sure you take the EAST exit, then orient yourself and look for an ABC Mart (should be diagonally to your right as you stand at the exit), walk towards it, cross the road diagonally, and continue along the street that's on the side of the ABC Mart. At the next big street, turn right and walk until you see a Baskin Robbins, then cross the street and look for a Mister Donut and walk on that small street that's next to the Mister Donut (keep on the side of the Mister Donut). After a bit more of walking, the escalator entrance to the hotel should be on your right.The hotel staff was very helpful with directions and restaurant recommendations. The rooms were just right for our overnight stay. It may be a bit tight with two suitcases though, but it's clean and comfortable. A good breakfast is served across the third-floor lobby.

We stayed in Best Western Shinjuku for 4 nights on the business floor. The hotel is located in Kabukicho, which is one of the red light districts in Tokyo.
