Although it is in this area, it is still a safe area, with a lot of restaurants, bars and cafes to go to. The size of the room is quite big for Tokyo standards. The reception staff speaks good English so communication was not a problem. There is a restaurant on the 2nd floor, Udon Dining, which is open until morning so dining at all hours is quite convenient. We had late night dinner there the evening we arrived in Tokyo, at around 11pm, and the food is quite good, although a bit pricey. Beside the hotel is also a great Yakiniku restaurant wherein anyone who comes to Japan must feast on their Wagyu. The hotel is a short walk from Shinjuku station and all the major shopping brands are within walking distance. There is also a Lawson convenience store on the ground floor and other various 24-hour groceries 1 minute away.All in all, I would recommend staying at this hotel. Good value for money.

I could not imagine a better location for our 3 night stay in Tokyo thanthe Best Western Astina located in Shinjuku. The hotel is at most a 10 minute walk from the Shinjuku JR station and issurrounded by fun places to eat and fun places to drink. The rooms were a bit small, but I think you have to expect that in Japan. The bed was nice and soft, the bathroom was great, the showers are 'tall people friendly' and I love that the toilet has a built in bidet. One small thing that I was impressed by was the quality of toiletries, the soap, shampoo, and conditioner that the hotel provides was outstanding. You have to have a drink at the Golden Gai which is behind the hotel, know that you have to pay a "service" or "table" fee which can be anywhere from 1500 to 2500 yen just for sitting at the bar, but it usually comes with some snacks. The places are cramp but the atmosphere is great. Another awesome bar behind the hotel is called 'Champion Bar', and it is PHENOMENAL! At Champion Bar there is no service or table fee, and it is considered a '1 coin' bar, because you can purchase many drinks for 500 yen, which is, you guessed it, 1 coin. The bar is standing only and if you are brave enough, you can give the bartender 100 yen to sing a song from a handheld karoake-remote-searcher-machine. I had a blast at this bar drinking with hard working Japanese salarymen who wanted to unwind after work with a lot of cheap drinks and loud singing. As for the food, you really can't miss with all that there is to eat around you. The hotel provides breakfast which is ok. I take that back, the sesame salad dressing was pretty awesome. I really can't speak for the service because I was really low maintenance and didn't need any assistance aside form checking-in and checking-out, both of which were super fast and easy. Another great convenience is that there is a convenience store next to the hotel where you can purchase snacks, drinks, etc.. I would definitely stay here again the next time I come back to Japan.

Usually when I think of Best Western I think motel. This Best Western was REALLY nice. Out of all the hotels that I stayed at I liked this one the best. When we got there it was actually hard to find, but once we figured out what exit to get out from Shinjuku station it was a breeze. I believe the easiest way is to get out of Exit A9? I forget but it is a clothing store and you just make a left and go down the alley. You'll hit Mr. Donut and just go down the street and it'll be on the right. The three prongs adaptor has a deposit of 1000 yen and the staff was super friendly. The size of the room was pretty good as well and I got a heck of a deal at $115 a night at this place. Center location to things to do in Shinjuku and Shibuya is not too far away. I highly recommend staying here. I would highly recommend buying a travel router since they only have wired internet. (Free)

We were there for 1 night in Tokyo as a couple. Love the location, may be a bit of a turn off to some but we love how lively it is as they are so much to see! We also checked out Golden Gai, literally at the back of the hotel and had a wonderful time in a tiny bar with 6 others and a bartender that spoke little English. Also close to Isetan, which has one of the most amazing food halls ever and Shinjuku Gyoen. As our luck has it our 1 day in Tokyo coincided with the Sakura season!We love to feel the more exciting part of the city, smell the street and feel the heartbeat so this hotel was perfect for its location yet offers a great modern room and comfortable bed and shower. And no, as close as we are to the entertainment area, we do not hear any street or outdoor noise in our bedroom.

A colleague and I stayed in this hotel after a few days of business in a different part of the city. The location is excellent, and I found the hotel easy enough to find from the Shinjuku station. If you’re coming from that station, you need to research what exit to come out of though.The reception staff are very nice and friendly, and the hotel is clean. Breakfast is quite good too, there’s a huge selection. While I went for a European breakfast most mornings, my colleague went for the Asian options, so there should be something for everyone’s taste.The rooms are pretty good, bearing in mind that this is central Tokyo, they are an ok size. My single room had a big enough bed and the bathroom was a good size too with all the amenities that I needed. My room looked out to the Golden Gai area of Tokyo, which is just a few minutes walk away and good fun for a night out. My colleague and I did quite a pub crawl here!The rooms are a bit dark though as the windows are small and covered in some sort of tinted film. There was a small earthquake one evening while I was in my room, but I can’t blame that on the hotel! Maybe a call to the rooms of non-Japanese guests, who are not used to them might have been nice, just for reassurance.This hotel really feels like you’re in downtown Tokyo, but at least it’s on a slightly quieter side street. The area is very safe and there are plenty of 7elevens, restaurants, fast food places, bars, atms, shops, taxis, and department stores close by. If I was in Tokyo for leisure, I would probably stay here again.

This business hotel is fuss free, affordable and situated in a very good location in shinjuku. It is very near to the subway and shopping malls like isetan. Front desk staff are helpful and friendly. Rooms are very basic, fuss free but clean and comfortable. Room size and bathroom size is considered good for a tokyo hotel. Wifi is free. Breakfast could get monotonous after a few days. Hope they could consider a fitness center in the near future.

Good point is from JR station shinjuku east side to hotel walk around 5 mins, convenience store downstairs in the hotel, but the wifi in room received signal so poor and receptionist is not a good attitude. Next time I will not choose stay here!

First of all, great location. The hotel is less than 10 mins walk from Shinjuku JR station and less than that to the M09 metro station. Before I went there, I studied a map and the hotel looked quite far away from the JR station. But when I arrived, it was an easy path. You simply exit the JR station from the east exit and walk around 300 meters eastward, you will find a big 6-lane road. Turn right and walk along the road for around 400 meters you will find an intersection with traffic lights. There is a Mister Donut on the opposite side of the road at a corner. The hotel is just 200 meters away in the smaller road on the same side of Mister Donut. If you have big luggage, a taxi would cost less than 1000 Yen.The room is not very big and comfortable enough for the price. Mine was very clean. A small fridge, coffee, tea, and a flat screen TV are provided. The bathroom is a standard Japanese one, not very big but not too small. The air conditioner and the internet in my room initially required some set ups, the staff helped promptly. The internet in my room sometimes was not very reliable, my be because of high traffic. The breakfast was very good. I stayed for 5 days and the menu are the same. Since the quality was very good, I have no complaints on this issue. The hotel lobby is on the 3rd floor and a restaurant on the 2nd floor. I did not try this one but ate outside or bought food from a nearby supermarket. A convenient store is on the ground floor. Food are available here as well. All in all, a decent hotel in a big city. I will stay here again next time I visit Tokyo.

Stayed here at the end of February and found it to be a great place for a short stay. It's very close to the station. We had a little trouble finding it but a tip read here helped. We came out of Shinjuku Station - after heading to the easterly entrance. It gets a little confusing there but if you head downhill then you cross a major road where you can see the doughnut place - easy walk downhill again to the Hotel. Although the rooms seem small - they are most comfortable- bathroom was plenty big enough. Wifi took a bit of sorting but the people at the desk were most helpful. We organised a tour for the day in Tokyo as it was a bit daunting at first. To join the tour we had to go to another nearby hotel but it all worked like clockwork. I can recommend the Grand Tokyo tour - although a long day gave us a great oversight of Tokyo. Shinjuku was a great place to stay - close to many department stores and good links to all transport.

I stayed here over a period of 11 nights in March 2013. I have stayed in many hotels in Japan and must say this is the best! Great location , NOT seedy as suggested by others but colourful and educational also VERY SAFE for the solo traveller with Golden Gai on doorstep, Omoide Yokocho nearby and a million eateries not to mention amazing shopping. Quick and easy access to all train lines. 5minute walk to shinjuku stnI booked online economy double room, well worth the extra $3 night upgrade from a single room, also included breakfast. This room is the largest I've experienced in Tokyo, well designed, functional and decorative. (designer bathroom) did i mention HUGE room? I had a room at the rear and did NOT hear any noise from the lively area. Very friendly and extremely helpful staff.A big Arigatou goes out to the hotel management, staff and especially MR Wang Rui who assisted me during a time of illness. The staff contacted paramedics and friends to let them know of my condition, brought food to my room, plenty of bottled water and 2-hourly observation checks.This is the type of service money just cant buy and I will certainly recommend this hotel to family and friends for all the above reasons. See you on my next visit.

I stayed here March 4-8 with my 7-year-old daughter. I lived in Japan several times, but this was her first visit. The BW Astina worked well for us: very good rate (45,000Y for 4 nights for one adult and one child), clean, small but well-organized room (would have been uncomfortable with a 3rd person), reasonbly priced breakfast with many Japanese and Western choices, and convenient enough to Shinjuku station. It's not a luxury hotel, but we were comfortable. The area was lively at night, but the room was always quiet and, being safe Japan, even the edge of entertainment district Kabukicho was not bothersome. There is even a lovely back park path the last block to the hotel. We also enjoyed the udon restaurant attached to the hotel on the 2nd floor.
user_name:
C8276AHmatts
Upper West Side, New York

review_body: Excellent location, near to Shinjuku station making it easy for day trips around Tokyo.Large variety of restaurants in the hotel area.Very friendly and helpful staff. Excellent hotel choice for Tokyo usually pricey standards.

I stayed here for a week in feb 2013 as recommended by a friend. We booked special rates via rates to go as it was cheaper then booking it directly with the hotel.First time we have stayed at the best western chain and I am very impressed. We had room 405 which was just the standard room. Small but enough to fit a big luggage on the floor and another one on the stool (although walking space was restricted). All the amenities were perfect and you could always ask for more from the front desk.We were able to redeemed 4 nights of no housekeeping as it was not necessary to make our bed and change our towels everyday for credits which we put toward a sake giftset from the hotel. I think this is a wonderful system.A bit of a pain to change lifts to get to your room but i got over it. The lawson below the hotel was very convenient for midnight snacks and drinks. The Udon Dining restaurant on the 2nd level is a must!!! a bit pricey but they served a variety of fusion udons that made it all worth it. We only decided to attempt this restaurant on the last day in tokyo.. what a shame..The staff was great help however a few more smiles and eye contact would make the experience abit more enjoyable.If you have heavy luggages when you leave for the N'ex enter via entrance/exit 13 across the road wher family mart is with the lift to Basement2, it is easier this way to wheel your luggage across to the station underground then lugging it above ground with all the busy crowds.The area was abit seedy but as long as you have someone with you, its all cool.

The hotel is within walking distance from the train station. Perfect location in Shinjuku with lots of restaurants and shops. Tons to do even at 10pm. I enjoyed my stay there. The room (Executive Twin Room) was clean and reasonable size. The staffs were friendly. I learned the red-light district is nearby. I did see some "special human being" on the street and was bothered by a few.Overall, it's a great hotel in great location and I would stay there again

My boyfriend and I stayed here for 4 days just gone in Feb, after staying at a different hotel in Shinjuku I think this place is great, largish rooms for Japan, big bathroom breakfast is included in the price. Was a few different things on the brekkie menu like mackerel but we stuck to cereal and toast. Which was plenty. I will be staying here again and recommend it :)

Location : I find it to be quite far away from Shinjuku station although I took the East Exit. Maybe my husband and I were not used to the cold weather as this is our first winter trip and find the 10-15 min walk dragging our luggage quite a torture since we are used to the hot & humid weather in Singapore. There is a convenience store right below the hotel which is a plus point. At night, the streets gets quite busy/rowdy though since its near the red light district but we did not have much problem with that maybe cause we were a couple.Staffs : Polite, friendly & helpful. They speak fluent English and is ready to provide you with directions by marking the maps.Room : The size is OK as we were able to fit in 1 huge luggage and 1 medium sized luggage comfortably. Beds & pillows are comfortable & clean. Toilet is great like all the toilets in Japan which comes with all the bidet and seat warmer stuffs with many buttons and all. Daily room amenities are adequate. All the channels are in Japanese and to watch the movies you need to pay 1000 yen so we rarely switch on the TV since we can't understand Japanese. Maybe they should include 1 free HBO channel or something since they accept international guests.Breakfast : Choice was little. The croissant & mackerel were delicious though. Everyday the spread is the same. Maybe 1 or 2 different dishes different but it gets a little boring as we stayed for 8 days.Overall the hotel is value for money and our stay was pleasant. It is not as expensive as the other hotels around but you get a clean and decent room. This is our first and only hotel in Japan so can't really make a comparison with other hotels.

Stayed for one night at the end of our Japan trip and encountered a few problems which was disappointing for my first stay at a Best Western. Booked via their website and found the site very clunky and tricky to use. Arrived at the hotel - which is in a great location by golden gai in Shinjuku - at around 6pm and asked for a room on a high floor but was told there were none available as the hotel was fully booked. There was no option on the website to request a room on a high floor. We then went to our room on the fourth floor, just above reception and also the kitchen, and opened the door to be greeted by a strong fish smell. We used the air freshener spray and that helped cleared up the odour. The double room was very comfortable and of a good size (by Japanese standards) and the bathroom was nice with a decent size tub in a wet room. Free WiFi and cable TV also great. The room was quiet despite the loud streets. Unfortunately the food smell returned as the chefs started making breakfast and we awoke stinking of bacon and burgers. There was no room they could have changed us to so I thought a suitable resolution would have been to offer a deduction to the room rate but the manager, who took an age to say sorry despite this obviously being a routine issue that anyone staying in or near room 410 would experience, said that was 'not possible'. Opted to reject his offer of a late check out (and being located to another room) as it was our last day in Tokyo we wanted to get out and explore some more. This is obviously a daily issue for the hotel and I felt cheated - surely they should be attempting to fix this issue rather than playing dumb about the problem and hoping that guests don't complain? If i stayed again I wouldn't order the breakfast as it was quite average for the high price and their are so many cafe options within walking distance. Could have been great but it was our worst accommodation experience over 10 days in Japan and also one of the most expensive.

Knowing I wanted to stay in the Shinjuku adedkrea of Tokyo, I did lots of research and read countless reviews on hotels before choosing BW Astina. The location could not have been better. It is a straight shot from Shinjuku station ...about 5 blocks..with a handy Mr. Donut on the way. The staff at the hotel for the most part spoke good English. The breakfast buffet which was included in my room booking was a real plus and totally a factor in choosing this location. Hint if you are taking a cab from hotel to some location I suggest that you get someone at the front desk write it in Japanese to show the driver as many of them did not speak or understand English. Also carry one of the hotel cards with you to give a cabbie to get you back. I feel obligated to mention that... yes the rooms are small... but I was in one of the most exciting cities in the world so I didn't spend a lot of time in it. I would stay here again in a heartbeat.

Only four stars because the bed was against the wall and the room was small- but that is quite common in Japan. Breakfast was excellent, staff were good and everything was clean. Easy to find when you leave Shinjuku station from the East exit. I would return.

Heard that this is one of the best Best Western Hotel located in Tokyo. So being a loyal traveller of Best Western, we decided to try out this hotel during our recent trip to Tokyo.Located in only 10 minutes walk to the Shinjuku Station, this hotel is located within the busy Shinjuku area. This is very convenience as there are many restaurant located within the area.The rooms are small in comparison to most other hotels that we have stayed before, however, the room are very modern. The accessibility to the self operated washing machine and dryer within the hotel was a bonus to us as we were travelling around Japan over the last several weeks without being able to get any laundry done.Staff were very helpful despite their limitation to the english language. Breakfast were simple yet a good combination of japanese and western breakfast items.

Only a 5-10 minute walk to Shinjuku station (best to take the north east exit), value for money, clean and the room size was small but not bad considering it's in the middle of Tokyo and you really should only be there to sleep! Staff were helpful, included breakfast was a good mix of simple western and Japanese food. Definitely recommend this value-for-money hotel for a convenient location close to shops, bars, restaurants and the beautiful Shinjuku Garden.

The hotel is located about a 5-7 minute walk from Shinjuku station. I can't remember which exit you need to take out of Shinjuku station but I would highly advise you figure that out before arriving in Tokyo. Shinjuku station is huge with tons of exits so make sure you get out of the right one. The area around the hotel is the entertainment district so there are plenty of restaurants and shops. There is a convenience store on the ground floor of the hotel so you can pick up drinks etc... there easily.The hotel seems like it was fairly new. It was in spotless condition with very modern looking rooms. Be warned that the rooms are tiny. You really don't have much room inside to move around. It's normal for Tokyo but think of it as smaller than New York city type of rooms. The rooms had free wi-fi and a safe inside. Breakfast was included and had a very simple Japanese/Western selection but enough to get you going.

This hotel is good value, very clean and ran efficiently.PROS:-very close to JR line stations, no probs getting around-beer vending machines in the hotel hallways-breakfast is great and delicious-behind the hotel is all these amazing little locally owned miniature bars that are so cool-walking distance to shinjuku gardens-convenience store directly under hotel for stocking up-shinjuku is buzzing at night, and you're in the heart of it allCONS:-the wifi is dodgy and cuts out a lot, (they need more seats in the lobby!)-the sex pests that hassle you to go into the brothels next-door-don't as the hotel for ideas of where to eat as they'll send you to expensive restaurants!Worth staying here to save some coin.

Best Western is quite nice. As is typical of Japanese hotels, the rooms are small. I had a business double for myself and it was still small. The double bed, for example, had one side against the wall; so, if somebody wants to get up while somebody else is sleeping, it means going over the foot of the bed. Inconvenient in the middle of the night. The hotel is modern, clean, well-kept and has an efficient, English-competent staff. Fast broadband connection and good wifi. A good value. Although it is hard to find (even my cab driver had trouble) the location is good, with lots of things nearby. It's on the edge of Kabuki-cho, however, a red light district. In the daytime, it's not a problem. At night, a group of aggressive Nigerian pimps and touts gather on the sidewalk up and down from the hotel and pester you all the way to its entrance, trying to persuade you to "just come and take a look." I hated somebody tugging at my sleeve for 90 feet. That's not the hotel's fault, of course, but it is something you have to contend with.  I was there in January 2013 and my choice of January to see Tokyo was a mistake. It was bitterly cold and they closed the airport twice while I was there, even though there was at most an inch on the first occasion and less on the second. I met somebody who landed at 8 PM on the night of the heavier snow. The roads out of the airport were closed and she---along with many others---was given a sleeping bag to sleep in on the floor in the airport. When I went to take the airport limousine bus on January 28th, they told me there were no buses running: the roads to the airport were closed. I finally got there by a train but it wasn't easy and I just made it. Fortunately, the airport was still open.
user_name:
Lawrence N
New York City, New York

review_body: It's about 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku Station, it is kind of difficult to find so study the map prior your arrival, hotel room is clean, bathroom size is good too & like the shower head with strong water pressure, buffet breakfast consists both western & asian dishes, enjoyed the stay, would use this hotel again.

For the price you pay - this hotel is very good value. We didn't have any issues checking in or out and actually found the breakfast to be very decent compared to others we had experienced in Japan. The location is great - close to shops, restaurants and the JR/Metro station. We were on the 7th floor and heard a little noise at night, but nothing to keep you awake. Room was an ok size - clean, modern and with everything we needed. I would stay here again.

Whenever I go back to Tokyo, I like staying "in the thick of it." So this time, I chose the BW Astina purely for its location. It's in the middle of Shinjuku Kabukicho, the number one entertainment district in all Japan. It's chaotically crazy and fun. This hotel is a bit of a walk (5-6 min) from Shinjuku Station but walking through busy Shinjuku streets is entertaining to say the least. I paid less than 9,000yen for a business plan single room on the executive floor. I knew it's not a luxury hotel so I wasn't expecting much but I was pleasantly surprised. My room was clean, cozy and very comfortable. The front desk personnel were friendly, helpful and spoke excellent English. The housekeepers did a great job each day. Overall, this hotel is a great value and a fun place to stay!

This hotel has a convenient location as it was close to Shinjuku Station and many restaurants/shops. Although the room was on the smaller side, it was clean, modern and had all necessary amenities (e.g wifi in rooms). The staff were very helpful and spoke good English. I will be staying here again when I return to Tokyo! Good value for money.

The location is great; eating, drinking and shopping on the door step, close to the ‘Shinjuku’ train station for site seeing (one of the main stations, it has an ‘English’ info counter). The Hotel it self was a great surprise; the room was very stylish, clean, comfortable and a good size for two ppl; we had plenty of room for a big suitcase and a backpack. The Breakfast was good offering a buffet of cereal and fruit as well as Japanese style breakfast of meat, fish, noodles & rice dishes. We ate lunch here once too and it was also delish. The staff where extremely helpful with advise and went out of their way to get information for us on the Emperors NYs speech and getting to the Palace. The Hotel backs on to the Golden Gai which offers a great night out and karaoke, As a female traveller I have never felt as safe as much as I did here in Tokyo. Across the road is an area that is classified as ‘red light’ but do not let this put you off, it is not as you might imagine, we didn’t see any street walkers and while nightclubs have reps (smartly dressed in fashionable suits) standing outside they don’t hassle passers by and showed no interests in us at all, I felt perfectly save drinking and walking around this area at night. On Friday night the place is packed with office workers unwinding with a few drinks and of course karaoke. I will definitely stay here again and recommend to friends and family.

My husband and I stayed here for two nights during a brief visit to Tokyo, and found it perfect for our needs. As others have stated, the rooms are small by U.S. standards, but as we were only staying two nights, we felt we had enough space. If it had been a longer trip with more clothes and larger luggage (as opposed to the single duffle bag we brought), perhaps things would have seemed more cramped. The room was clean and comfortable. Yes, the pillows are quite firm, but that did not prevent us from sleeping well. The bathroom was great. High-tech toilet, plenty of hot water, good water pressure in the shower, and a nice deep tub.The location of this hotel is fantastic. There are restaurants, bars, karaoke, and convenience stores all within a couple of blocks. It's just a quick walk to and from the Shinjuku train station, which is huge and can get you anywhere. Make sure you take the East exit out of the station for your walk back to the hotel. There is a review farther down the page that gives explicit walking directions from Shinjuku station to the hotel--I highly recommend seeking out and writing down those directions. They are dead-on, and made our arrival into Tokyo so much easier. After getting to the hotel the first time, we were able to make our way back and forth to/from the station with ease. The Golden Gai area is literally right behind the hotel; I definitely recommend chilling in a tiny bar that seats only a handful of people as a neat Tokyo experience. With regard to safety, we felt totally safe walking around the area, even at 3 a.m. Obviously keep your wits about you and don't be an idiot, but as far as big cities go, I'd have to assume this is one of the safest.People seem kind of divided on the breakfast. Personally, I loved it. I'm a picky eater and stick with Western tastes, and I managed to stuff myself both mornings with rice with curry sauce, fried potatoes, lettuce salad, mandarin oranges, and cocoa krispies. Some may be thrown off by the unbreakfasty nature of many of the offerings (onion rings, salad, fried chicken chunks, etc.) but to me, that was actually a plus. I'll take that stuff over a crappy dried out pastry or prepackaged muffin any morning. Plus with the time change, my body thought it was 5 p.m. at breakfast anyway.If we ever take another trip to Tokyo, I will definitely want to stay here.

My husband and I returned to the Best Western Astina after visiting a few years ago. The hotel was just as fantastic as we remembered - clean and modern rooms, friendly service, and an excellent location in the heart of the Shinjuku action and right above the Golden Gai area. During our last stay, we were in a semi-double, which was incredibly small. But this time, we got an upgrade due to our status, and our room was the perfect size with a sitting area and a large bathroom. We were on the business/executive floor, with "lounge access". The hotel lounges I have used in the past had drinks, food, etc., so I expected the same. But here, the lounge was just a large meeting room. So, I wouldn't advise paying extra for a room on this floor unless you plan on using the conference room (?).The breakfast was strange, as it was during our last stay. One man I spoke to in the breakfast room summed it up well, I think: "I mean, I like fried chicken and chips, but for breakfast? Umm, okay."Overall, we loved this hotel again, and will absolutely return.

If you are travelling to Tokyo and choose Shinjuku as the area you wish to stay in you won't be disappointed with this hotel. It's within walking distance of the subway and rail station and has an abundance of shops and restaurants all around so ideally located. The hotel itself is western, so if you are looking for a more traditional hotel this may not be for you. Rooms are very small but thats the norm for Japan, they were however well planned out. They were very clean, beds were comfortable and the bedding was crisp white. After a day's sightseeing, a much appreciated fact. Breakfast is ok, plenty of choice with a few unexpected things thrown in, but hey embrace it, you are in Japan! Shinjuku is a great place to stay whilst in Tokyo with a real hustle and bustle vibe. Would I stay here again, you bet!

Stayed from 28th to 2nd Jan with my family. The staff at reception was very good especially Ayya (spelling?) We requested rooms facing the main street and she was prompt in arranging that for us and was also helpful in arranging a taxi to the Haneda airport (made sense to get a cab since it was 4 of us). The complimentary water was only available for the first day perhaps that could be extended to all days but other than that a great experience.

The service is great, also the location is wonderful. I think Best Western Shinjuku ASTINA will be the only one choice when I go to Tokyo.I think the soft pillow filled with feathers will be a great choice. I love Best Western Shinjuku ASTINA, but the pillow is not good enough for sleep quality.

My tokyo vacation was totally great ! The hotel is clean, big room for japan standard and very convenient...nearby, there are good shopping places; 100 yen store, daikokuya and many food places too...But, the wi-fi signal is not that good...

Just two block away from Shinjuku metro with 10 mins walk, easily found with dunkin donut right at the corner, plenty shops and mall at surrounding area. Cozy room clean and tidy, pillow is quite hard as others comment hereNice breakfastStrongly recommend.

Very good location in Tokyo. The size of the Standard Twin is acceptable. The only disappointed is not helpful by the reception staffs. As we're not good in japanese and we ask the staff to call the rental company and tell them we'll return the car a little late after we check in Best Western, but the staff tell us we can call the car rental in our room by ourselves until a senior come to the reception. in fact, we're quite often asking help in such matter in japan, and never got refuse.

Very good location as close to everything and walking distance from JR. Reasonable room size that can support opening luggage on floor. Overall a good experience but suggest to improve the pillow quality and tea bag choice

I stayed 3 nights at Astina during May. Room was very clean and functional. Breakfast decent and location was OK. I would definitely consider staying again, especially if rate was OK. Nothing negative to add. Even though it is in 'red light' district - I had no problems. I walked around at 2-4 AM and would have done so with my wife as well if she was with. Nothing like other red light districts in the world. As with everything in Japan, even this district is clean and safe.

stayed in december for 8 nights in the astina best western , for the fifa team world championship, won by corinthians, from sao paulo brazil.booked a double non smoking room, but discoverd that double was only one bed, so i requested an extra bed before arriving, and had to pay a little extra.room was a bit small for 2 people, but beds were nice, and bathroom was very good (good shower and the fantastic japanese eletric toilet seat,wich for me is an atraction by itselfwi fi in the room was a bit complicated to get started, but once i got it, worked fine for all other daysbreakfast was included in my rate, and was pretty good, with juices, some hot food, croissants, cereal, ( no fruits and cheese ). you can use the breakfast voucher for lunch, if you pay 500 yens extrafront desk staff was super, always ready to help with directions, and other issueshotel well located, 5 minute walk from east side of shinjuku station ( but if you are arriving from the airport, and dont know your way out of the station, could be a little tricky to find if you walk from the station, so study the map before), at night, the red light locations nearby for me are more amusing then anything, not a problem of safety AT ALL, after all you are in japanoverall....very good

The hotel was fine, clean and well equipped, modern and a good size for Japan. Greta location ver close to Shinjuku station. Being in the middle of the red light district may or may not be a problem. I was approached twice in the evening by a pimp outside the hotel which was not great and once a bit threatening. The area is livley and interesting but if you want something quiet look elsewhere.

We enjoyed our stay here, staff were lovely, very helpful and spoke english. Rooms were typical Japan size but very clean and really quiet. Breakfast could have done with more western options. Comfortably located within 1km to Shinjuku station, it's a nice walk to the station with lots of shops. We didn't have issues with it supposedly being located in the red light district as you could even tell. There is also some really great restaurants around, especially a Korean BBQ restaurant just up from the hotel.

Great hotel and great location...but a little pricy...although Tokyo hotels are usually expensive. Great service, interesting location (not only Shinjuku but Kabukicho), but actually really cool for night-time walks...just don't go crazy into alleyways, but enjoy the specific night vibe!
user_location: New York City, New York, USA
user_name:
DayTrip415265
New York City, New York, USA

review_body: Spent about 3 days here. Very central location and easy transportation options. Rooms are small, but good sized for Tokyo. Not crazy expensive, and great food and entertainment options all around. If you have to get around Tokyo or to other parts of Japan. This is a good base point for a few days. Clean and efficient.

Love the Hotel, We were looking for a nice hotel with free breakfast and very near the Shinjuku Train Station, Dept. Stores and restaturants and we were very glad we booked this hotel. All the places we wanted to see was just a walk away and if ever we come back to Tokyo, we will still stay in this budget friendly, clean and nice staff hotel.

We stayed at this hotel for 6 nights in total on our honeymoon. It is an interesting building built from 3rd floor and there is a convenience store on 1st floor. This hotel is well located near Shinjuku station (about 5 mins walk), which is one of the biggest stations in Tokyo. Our room was very tiny, but I believe it's a standard size in Japan. Everything was working and our bed was comfortable. Although we were concerned about noise, we did not hear at all because of the double glass windows I guess. This hotel should be new and if you like to stay at new hotels, this is good. Breakfast was included in our rate since we booked online in Canada. There were so many varieties and quite tasty. Very freshly baked breads are available which was our favorite part. Front desk agents can be more friendly. Some of them were helpful, but some were not. I don't know how great their English is, but there are so many foreigners were staying at this hotel. We will come back again next time in Japan:)

Impressed. Good value. Location much more vibrant (if a little sleazy, some of us don’t mind that) than most places you’ll find in Tokyo. Super helpful staff. Having said that, finding it isn’t easy. Make sure you check out the back pedestrian alleyway behind the hotel – feels like a little piece of early 20th century Tokyo in the middle of the city. Be adventurous and try some of the tiny bars, restaurants and yakitori joints around – even if there’s no English on the menu, you will be welcomed and have a great time.

This was a great find at a very affordable price for Tokyo. My cousin and I arrived into Japan and had to stay one evening in Tokyo before heading to Kyoto. We chose to stay in Shinjuku because it's a train hub. The Best Western was two or three short blocks from the station (a little hard to find because the sign was parallel to the sidewalk), but very clean and hospitable, with pajamas and slippers in the room and the nicest soaking tub and shower I've seen in a hotel. Beds were very comfortable and the room was quiet despite the central location. Breakfast was included and was fresh and yummy (Japanese and Western options). Never thought I'd rave about a Best Western, but the chain's international locations are really nice.

The location is great, but the rooms are very small, even by Japanese standards. The Citadines brand (there is one in Shinjuku) offers substantially larger rooms for a similar price. The service upon arrival was not overly friendly either. We would probably never stay there again.
user_name:
Anthony I
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: We always stay at the Best Western Astina when we travel to Tokyo. We take the Narita Express to Shinjuku and it is a very convenient short walk from Shinjuku station. Lots of restaurants and shopping nearby. There is a Lawson's convenience store on the first floor. We love the sushi restaurant down the street from the hotel (they are a branch of a shop in Tsukiji!). Right behind the hotel is a beautiful tree-lined walkway and there is a Shinto shrine within a block. The hotel itself is clean and modern. The breakfast is a typical Japanese hotel buffet breakfast with a pretty good selection of western and japanese food. The staff members are all extremely gracious and helpful. They all speak English beautifully. We will definitely continue to use this hotel in the future.

We just stayed here for six nights, Oct 29-Nov 3, 2012. The room is clean and big for Japanese standard, much bigger than the rooms in Shinagawa Prince Hotel where we stayed the last time we went to Tokyo. Hotel staff are helpful and although its buffet breakfast does not have that much choices, its choices are ok. Hotel location in Kabukicho area is also very convenient. There is a Lawson convenient store right at the ground floor and an ice and vending machine at the end of each floor of the hotel. Many restos are nearby the hotel and the Shinjuku train station is just a few minutes walk away. There are only two drawbacks of this hotel: 1. Their internet service is so slow that i could not believe it took more than five minutes just to log out of my yahoo account. Waiting for downloads feels like centuries. They certainly need to UPGRADE their internet service. 2. We could hear car horns and other street noise (from the 8th floor or room 814 to be exact), to think that our room windows are facing just a side street, not a major street. They need to improve their room acoustics.

My Husband and I stayed 4 nights at this hotel and loved the location and service. The rooms were very clean when we arrived, and although small, we never felt uncomfortable. We opted to skip daily service and the hotel provided a voucher to use on gifts or food at the hotel. The breakfast was not your typical buffet spread, and there was no fresh fruit, however it was good and it helped to have access to it early, as you will wake up early from jetlag! I ate the japanese curry and miso soup daily, and it was warm and satisfying. What I loved most about the hotel was it's location. Less than a 10 minute walk from Shinkuju station, less than 5 minutes from another location to catch the Maronuchi subway line, and 5 minutes from Isetan department store and other places to shop. The Lawsons at the ground level of the hotel was perfect as well. It is open 24 hours and has food, drinks, and snacks. The fact that this hotel was in the red light district just made it all the more entertaining as well. We didn't hear any street noise, and found it fun to walk the streets at night when the jetlag kept us awake. It felt safe and made for some great people watching! Directions by foot:To first get there, if you are flying in to Narita, the easiest thing we found was to just take the Narita Express all the way to Shinjuku station. Once at the station walk and follow the signs to the East Exit. Go up the stairs and walk forward to the street. Looking right and diagonal to the street, there is an ABC mart that you need to walk towards. Take a left at the side street where ABC mart is and you will notice the street has lots of trees. Take that side street towards the next major intersection. This will be Yasukuni-Dori. Turn right and you will see down a couple of blocks a Baskin Robbins. Turn left and cross Yasukuni-Dori on the street where Baskin Robbins and across the street is a Mister Donut on Kabukicho. The hotel is on the same side of the street as Mister Donut and just keep walking straight until you see the escalator entrance of the Best Western and the Lawsons convenience store. I took the walking view on Google Earth to see a visual of the buildings and we found the hotel within 8 minutes. My Husband and I had 1 large suitcase, and 2 carry-on bags in wheels and had no problem walking with them. Definitely worth staying here if you want easy access from the train, and easy access to the surrounding neighborhoods. Will definitely return if I make it back to Tokyo!

From hotel point of view, this is an excellent choice, room are nice (but small as usual in Japan), well equipped and with a good internet connection. Room was quiet and bed excellent. Breakfast is also good with nice choice (Local and international)From environment point of view I was in this hotel the week end before Halloween, and animation in the street was excellent but also very very special. (Hot area !) From Western mentality, some people could dislike it, but the most important is that it is very safe and I was not in trouble.So I will really recommend this hotel and for sure I will come back, but people has to be aware of Shinjuku place and be open mind ! ! so enjoy

Stayed 4 nights here in mid september! rooms are small but clean and comfortable.Location is decent. With train station maybe bout 10-15mins slow walk. Lots of clubs nearby if you plan some night life.

I was a little apprehensive about staying in a Best Western since the chain doesn't have the best reputation in North America and Europe, but booked this hotel based on the reviews in TripAdvisor. I stayed for 8 nights in October, and was very pleased with the hotel. Yes, the room wasn't large, but it's Japan and this is to be expected. The hotel was VERY clean and I rarely heard anything from outside. My only complaint is that the pillows in the room were rock hard (personally, I like a soft pillow), but that's the only minor problem I had with the room. The hotel is located a short walk to the subway and Shinjuku train station, and there are lots of food options close by. It's in a bit of a sketchy neighbourhood, but I had no trouble being approached by men when walking home at night. The breakfast buffet was a mix of Japanese and western food, although some of the western food was a little odd to be having for breakfast (french fries, onion rings). I would certainly stay here again.

This is a great hotel. the staff, especially the cleaners, were excellent. We where on the 7th floor facing the street and had no trouble with noise. I wish we had had a balcony, I could have sat and people watched all day (and night ) The room was not massive but I was pleasantly suprised by how big it was. The breakfast was fine. Reception staff very helpful on the few times we needed help. We stayed 12 nights and never found a fault. The location was perfect, right in the middle of all the action. Never felt safer in a major city

Had a great experience at Best Western Shinjuku Astina Hotel in Tokyo. Great Service! The entire staff were very welcoming and accommodating to our every need. Would not mind staying at this hotel again.

Stayed here for 3 nights, sept 30th to Oct 3rd, at the beginning of our 21 day Asia trip!!! Great hotel!!! Location was convenient for the metro and airport bus limo and it was bustling all the time but rooms were small and quiet. As mentioned before, area is a bit shady and we were uncomfortable sometimes with the people hanging out at bars on the same street trying to get us to go into their establishment. Would definitely stay here again.

Thank you for invited me to share my feeling for this hotel.As we are the first time to visit Tokoy, your staff ,specifically Yuko,are very kind and polite. Yuko introduced the transportation methods with website and suggestion to us before we arrived Tokyo. She makes my plan more easily.Besides, the room, toilet(3/F) and restaurant (3/F) are very cleanliness and tiny.Thank you for make us have a confortable resting place.

The Best Western Shinjuku Astina in Kabukicho-1 wins the most points for its location, roughly 8 minutes' walk from the central transit hub of Tokyo. Although the neighborhood is a combination of London's Soho and Victoria areas, in Tokyo this brings all of the good and none of the bad.The hotel is adequate if no-frills. The "Executive Lounge" is one long meeting table with 8 chairs and a free coffee maker; there is no business center, gym, pool, or spa. The television has one channel in English (CNN), and an unnecessarily complicated pay-TV system. Make no mistake: the hotel is squarely a Best Western (not Plus or Premier, either!), but it is perfectly 3-star.The worst part of our stay experience was the hotel restaurant, Stella. We had both daily breakfast buffet (included in the room rate) and lunch buffet there, and they were borderline-disgusting. I had to force myself to find something nutritious each day, and was grateful that previous visits to Japan had given me a taste for miso soup and rice in the morning! I would have preferred to have the money for breakfast back in my pocket and purchase from the 24-hour convenience store on the ground floor -- which is exactly what we did. The hotel has a convoluted system (designed to keep the cash in its account) whereby unused breakfast tokens can be used for JPY1000 off the lunch buffet (JPY1500, also not worth eating) or JPY1000 towards a purchase from the souvenir curio cabinet or JPY500 in the downstairs store. Skipping a day's maid service also gives you a JPY500 Best Western voucher that can only be used in the Shinjuku Astina towards lunch or tchotchkes, as above. Given that major Western chains (including other Best Western properties) compensate guests with cash off the bill or loyalty program points, this voucher system is unacceptable.As expected in Japan, the staff are friendly and capable; collectively, their English-language skills are good (although individual variation is huge). They were essential to making the stay run smoothly.For another stay in Tokyo at this price point, I wouldn't hesitate to book the Best Western Shinjuku Astina.

I've visited Shinjuku a number of times, but this was the first time I stayed at this hotel, which opened just a few years ago. The price was better than most similar hotels in this area, so I chose it based on its high rating on Tripadvisor. I was very pleased. The staff are friendly and helpful, the rooms are clean, the bathroom has everything you need, and the bed is very comfortable. The rooms are small by western standards, but this is Tokyo after all! The included breakfast had both Japanese and Western items, and was nothing fancy, but perfectly fine. And best of all, the hotel is located just a short walk from Shinjuku station, making it easy to get to/from Narita airport on the Narita Express train. And it is even closer to the nearest Metro station. As some other reviewers noted, the hotel is located in Kabukicho, which is the "entertainment" district. So you will occasionally get offered "services" as you walk on the street. But this is a minor inconvenience, and should not dissuade anyone from choosing this hotel. (There's a lovely path along the back side of the hotel, which takes you directly to Yasukini-dori, if you want to avoid the commercial scene.) I would higly recommend this hotel if you want a great value for a central Tokyo location.

The hotel itself is fairly generic and the service was fine but not especially outstanding. Still, it's a new and good looking hotel, and the double room is a good size by Tokyo standards. The bed was comfier than average and the bathroom and toiletries were all very good. Coupled with the amazing location in the Kabukicho area of Shinjuku, we felt this hotel was excellent value for money. Yes, there are a few "characters" hanging around outside but for us Kabukicho was fun, lively and exciting and we felt safe wandering around at all hours of the night/morning. Right next door to the Golden Gai, one of the most awesome and unique nightlife areas in the world - absolutely unbeatable! Would stay here again for sure.

Tiny rooms, but very well equipped. Comfortable bed, free internet (bring your own router if you want wifi), tea and coffee making facilities, decent breakfast included, Lawson convenience store on the ground floor, close to shops an restaurants. Recommended.
user_name:
NPUk
Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom

review_body: Hubby and I really enjoyed our stay at Best Western Shinjuku. The room was small, but hey, you get that with Japanese hotels - the one we stayed at in Kyoto was waaaayy cramped. Even though Best Western was small, I didn't feel cramped at all. The room was very clean and the bed was soft. The TV was a good size. The staff were great, their english wasnt too shabby and a lot of them have a great sense of humour! We asked for alsorts of stuff like, where is the nearest and best Karaoke places, we went to the golden cat one.. Had a hoot of a time.. Just book more than 1.5 hours - time flies when you're belting out 70's hits! I had one little hiccup and I have to say, it was the only incident we had on the two week trip in Japan. Please let me stress, this is NOTHING to do with the staff or the hotel. In fact, the staff were very considerate and fell over themselves to help me after the event as I was quite shaken. I encountered a very drunk sexually aggressive African (I think he was african, there are a lot of africans loitering outside the fronts of stores near the hotel) at the Lawsons convenience store underneath the hotel. He was trying to get me to have sex with him!! In no way was I dressed provocatively (demure dress and tights to keep the sun off me) or tried to interact with him. Like mostly everyone else there, I was purchasing a few small sundries. Needless to say, if I was in my country I would have 'decked' (hit) him, he was disgusting and gross. This was at 10.30 AM on a weekday. If you want to avoid these types of people, you can access the hotel around the back lane which is the lane way between the hotel and the Golden Gai (awesome fun place). As I mentioned, the staff at Best Western Shinjuku were very helpful towards me, concerned for my wellbeing after that event. I was concerned that individual was going to follow me upstairs and harass other hotel patrons. Breakfast is very good. They have a very satisfactory selection of Japanese and western breakfast things. Hubby and I tucked into Miso soup every morning as well as our usual eggs and toast. The staff at breakfast and very professional - the lady that greeted us upon arrival for brekkie was very sweet! She is a lovely lovely Malay lady who spoke fantastic Japanese (of course) and she has a beautiful smile and has a very warm engaging personality. I enjoyed my brief interactions with her.We chose the hotel due to its location and price as well as from other reviews here on Trip Advisor! The Reservations department was very efficient as Hubby dealt directly with the Hotel. The price was very reasonable for a 8 day stay. Location wise, we were close to a lot of things. The hotel is extremely close to Subnade exit B15, which leads to the rest of Shinjuku station.

Location was great, a couple block walk from one of the main drags Yasukuni Dori & Shinjuku station. I had read reviews/google search's that the hotel was located in the red light district. I did see a few people in animated outfits, anyhow I couldn't even tell the difference or notice anything. Checking in was efficient, breakfast an okay variety, though it seems to be included with most rates makes up for the super small rooms. Enough for 1 person with a comfortable bed & modern, I didn't mind. Also there is a Lawson's which was pretty handy at ground level next to the escalator/elevator. Overall a good stay, I would stay here again.

Our family of 3 stayed at this hotel for 3 nights. We stayed on one of the executive floors, twin type A room.What we liked:The hotel is in a central and convenient location, about 5 minutes walk to subway entrance -to reach the Shinjuku station took about 10 min. A convenient store is located downstairs.Breakfast was included, a fairly good selection of Japanese and western food are available.Our room was nice and clean, bathroom was of a decent size with a tub.Nice toiletries provided daily(Crabtree and Evelyn)Friendly staffLots of places to eat around the hotelWhat we didn't like: -not so much about the hotel but about its surroundingSurrounding of the hotel after 10pm - the red light district becomes alive. Although we were not disturbed, it's still not great for kids.We saw some VERY drunk girls in the morning around 9am...

Great location in shinjuku, a little hard to find in unfamiliar with the area. Street is busy 24/7, but couldn't hear the street from the room. Reception staff very good English and welcoming. Room was a little small but quite normal for Tokyo. Relatively basic breakfast but enough variety.

In walking distance of Shinjuku station this is a great hotel from which to explore Tokyo. Shinjuku is sometimes described as the red light district but you will get minimal hassle from hawkers when walking the streets. The area feels very safe. The other area I would consider staying in is Shibuya which is fantastic.We stayed 4 nights in a business room which wasn't much more expensive and we were on a higher floor to enjoy the Shinjuku skyline. The room was very clean, bed comfortable, very quiet air conditioner, buffet breakfast good but not extensive. We were woken a couple of nights by police cars, who put there alarms on no matter what time it is. The convenience store below the hotel is very handy.We had a JR pass and used the luggage forwarding service throughout Japan. About £12 for one medium sized suitcase to be sent to your next hotel, makes traveling easy.

This hotel is in the perfect location for sightseeing and nightlife in Tokyo. As everyone said, it is so simple to get to Shinjuku station - which offers direct transfer to the airport. It's also a major hub for the light rail and metro lines of the city. There is no way that I would have been happier in any other area! It was so interesting and lively. We loved it!

Stayed here for my first four nights of a month long trip to Japan. Great place to acclimatise.I won't repeat previous comments too much but the location is excellent. Only a 5 minute walk from the east exit of shinjuku station and fairly easy to find. Rooms are functional, very clean, up to date and compact as you expect in Tokyo. Reception very good with excellent English - my Japanese is not great. Breakfast is ok, although I ate breakfast out of the hotel after the second day as the choice is not great. A pity there is no wifi in the rooms although there are LAN cables, not great if you only have an iPad with you. So I bought a one month b-mobile data only sim card for a month for about 3400¥ from bic camera near shinjuku station. Best option to avoid extortionate roaming charges, but make sure your phone/iPad is unlocked. Back to the hotel and vicinity. There's a lawsons convenience store right underneath open 24/7. Handy. There's lots around in shinjuku which is a cool place to stay. Geared more towards Japanese socializing unlike rappongi which is a bit more western and sordid (but fun nonetheless, although not to my taste).Despite location, which is busy 24 hours a day, rooms are very quiet. Beds are good. Linen changed every day and great functional bathroom.Overall I'd stay here again. Excellent value for money, great service and super location.

And I mean it, not only the best location in Harajuku and Shinjuku, but as it is minutes away from the Shinjuku station and in the heart of Tokyo's night life, it is maybe the best location of all Tokyo.Rooms size is average for Tokyo and rooms are well organized. Do not expect view or anything fancy, but if you can get a nigh for less than 150$, this is a geat value.

Not too far from Shinjuku station. Very clean and compact. Good value for money. Only difficulty is finding the front door initially as was not aware the reception is on third level.Convenience store on street level very handy. Close to all food places and easy walk to train and shopping.

My partner and I stayed for five nights here back in February 2012 and managed to secure a reasonable room rate with buffet breakfast included each morning. The breakfast vouchers can also be exchanged at the Lawson convenience store on the ground floor but ONLY ON THE DAY THAT THE VOUCHER IS DATED FOR! In addition, you can only redeem each voucher for 500 JPY at Lawson, but this is always an option if you don't feel like the hotel breakfast. Whilst the hotel is located in the slightly seedier part of town, it was close to food, shopping and transport and had convenient in-house facilities such as a coin laundry which made things so much easier. The standard room was well-appointed with surprisingly large bathrooms (when considering the size of the bedroom itself). Most of the reception staff were proficient in English and all were courteous, though perhaps not what western travellers would consider 'warm' or 'friendly' (a common theme in chain hotels). However I had been corresponding with Yuko and Aya in reservations prior to my stay who were extremely helpful and friendly especially as I had an important package delivered to the hotel in time for arrival. I was also pleasantly surprised that all my optional room requests had been granted. I would gladly stay again.

My daughter and I stayed at this hotel for 2 nights. Upon arrival my room with 2 double beds, which I had requested in advance was not available. The hotel insisted that I pay an additional 2000 yen per night. What is one to do when they have booked the room through a booking service? The room we were finally given was actually very nice. The hotel is in a rather "sleezy" area of Tokyo and we found the staff to be a little bit on the cold side. The internet in your room in not easily accessed. It is only free if you go down to the lobby. It is quite a hassle to get it in your room, as you have to have an email authorization using Free Spot to your cell phone. We did not have such a phone with us, so it was impossible to use the internet in our room and had to go to the lobby each time we wanted to access the internet. Quite an inconvenience and not as advertised. Upon departure, the only offer of a settlement was for the additional 2000 yen I had paid. Nothing for the full amount of the room stay. All in all, I probably would not stay here again, as there are other hotels in better areas of Tokyo.

We stayed 5 nights in Tokyo at Astina Hotel. This is a very good base for visiting the city. The hotel itself is nice. Room are quite small (this is Tokyo) and the bathroom is adequately sized. The service at the hotel is quite unpersonnal (large hotel).We booked at room at the business level to get access to the lounge. Actually, this is not a lounge but a meeting room (one large table and 8 seats). Nothing fun to relax. The business level is not a good deal but for the quietness.

Stayed here for 6 nights in August. Stayed in a standard room with my partner - room was fairly small (which wasn't surprising given it's Tokyo!). Even though the room was small (ish), it was very well decked out with bed, desk, small sofa and a really nice bathroom. Everything was immaculately clean and modern. Very impressive. The bed was so comfy, slept so well! The buffet breakfast was good (mix of western and eastern foods). The hotel is in Shinjuku so yes there a number of seedy places nearby and guys coming up to you to see if you want to go to one of the stripper bars, but just give them a firm but polite 'NOT INTERESTED' and you'll be fine. Would definitely recommend this hotel.

Stayed here 7 nights end of July. Rooms are spotless. Hotel is in an ok position, not too far from the subnade which we took each day to get to the train station, easy to get lost under there, and sometimes you just come out the other side of the station, but not to worry, its air conditioned. Breakfast wasn't too bad, staff are lovely. Beds are harder than any bed i've slept in before, and I like a firm bed.

Almost everything said - Several japanese adult entertainment options around the corner - and when you are planning to leave the place in the early morning you might find some leftovers sleeping in front of the door.Nevertheless I enjoyed the place - the breakfast was ok, the location is very good and the rooms were small but clean.Windows can be opened - and I would come back!

Yes, it's on the edge of Kabukicho, which becomes a bit of a cesspool at night. As a 27 year old female I was never once bothered or made to feel unsafe. If walking with me, my boyfriend was never bothered either - they were quite respectful in fact.The hotel is clean, modern and the rooms while not huge, are relatively spacious for Tokyo, and are especially good considering the price (we paid about $130 AUD a night for the economy double). The air conditioner was a lifesaver in the hot August weather.Breakfast was included, but it's not great - unless deep fried chicken and onion rings is your thing. I stuck to the yoghurt and fruit.The best thing about this place is the location - within 10-15 minutes of Shinjuku station and other local stations that can get you all around Tokyo. I recommend buying a Pasmo card which you can top up with credit so you can just tag in and out wherever you go.Just behind the hotel is Golden Gai - a group of tightly packed alleyways filled with tiny bars. It can be expensive - keep your eye out for cover charges and drink prices displayed on the doors, but it really is a unique experience.

Booked 8 nights beeing a bit worried that the 140 cm bed would be to small for my daughter ( 19 year) and me. But it worked just fine! Nice clean room ( bigger than I expected after reading the rewiews here, and we mostly used it for sleeping, beeing away all day) and a lovely bathroom. Lots of toiletries and we got new every day! Wifi in the lobby and restaurant.We had a room on business floor with daily newspaper and coffee/tea making facilities on 13th floor. The location was very good and made it easy to get around in Tokyo since Shinjuku station was at a walkingdistance, it took less than 10 minutes to get there.The Metro stations where even closer.Breakfast was included and perhaps not the best I've had but the food was fresh and it's nice to have it included. Very unusual that breakfast is included in Tokyo hotels! Even though it beeing in the Kabukicho area we always felt safe and was never bothered by anyone. I don't think I ever felt as safe as in Tokyo , what a wonderful city. And that it should be so expensive! No.....it was not! At least not when you are used to swedish/danish prices.But be aware of the seating charges some ( but not all) restaurants take, "giving" you a little dish as a starter. I can truly recommend Best Western Shinjuku! The staff was helpfull and nice. By the way,try some of the little bars in Golden Gai, just behind the hotel( and here are seating charges , but worth every penny) a fun experience and a chance to talk to the locals, well it proberly helped that my daughter speaks japanese :)

We stayed at the Best Western Shinjuku in early July. We stayed here for 2 nights before going off to Kyoto. We had a little trouble finding the hotel. We just happened to look up and saw the hotel name. We ended up flying into Narita instead of Haneda (last minute flight change) and the drop off point was a bit different at the Shinjuku station, so that didn't help matters. Though once we got our bearings it is a pretty quick and easy walk to Shinjuku Station.Checking in was pretty quick and easy. We got up to the room and it was about what I expected. Not the biggest room, but about enough space for us and the luggage. The beds were comfortable and all the necessary amenities were in the bathroom. The buffet breakfast was pretty good. A little bit of change up in what was available every morning. Enough of a variety between eastern and western breakfast. A good start to the day.The surrounding neighborhood was pretty interesting. Lots of bars and such. We did see one guy who looked like he was on the losing end of a fight on morning. If you get a chance go to the Studio Ghibli museum if you like animation. Pretty interesting. Just remember, no tickets are sold at the museum.

The room and bed were a bit small. Generally the hotel is at a good location (on the Narita Express line) but not so easy to find the first time on a dark rainy night for a first timer to Japan. The room and bathroom were clean and well maintained. The staff will help when able.

The hotel is nice and central though its rooms ie the beds are not spacious (we were aware of that and it's not a complain - I am just pointing it out) so if you need space when sleeping be sure to book a "big" room otherwise you'll be really uncomfortable. Apart from that the cleanliness was impeccable and its location made it a sensible choice - even though the red light district is nearby the area is not seedy and it's safe and nice 24 hours. Breakfast huge and good, Internet fast and reliable. Nice staff.

We stayed here for 3 nights in early June. Directions to hotel given to by other TA is correct. The corner MisterDonut & Lawson downstairs is a good landmark and for replenishments of snacks and water. A good 7-10 min walk to the JR Shinjuku station. As expected, the standard double is really small/cramped, this is Tokyo after all. Can't compare. The hotel surrounding is not suitable for family with kids as the suspicious characters and drunks becomes 'alive' as the night grows.Buffet breakfast menu was okay, menu doesn't change much from day to day. Combination of Japanese and Western style breakfast.It depends on how you use your room though, if it is just a crash pad then it is fine. We were out in the morning and back late in the evening. Wireless internet only at the reception area and quite weak.For the price we paid, we are okay with the limitations.

We enjoyed a recent two night stay in Shinjuku at this well appointed and easy to reach hotel. Shinjuku is on the Narita airport train line and so after the 80 odd minutes on the comfortable and timely train, and some friendly and helpful advice to orientate us once we reached the station, we were warmly welcomed to the hotel and given some advice on a local place to eat. There were lots of options within a stone's throw of the hotel right in the heart of the vibrant Shinjuku region, and at all times we felt safe. My husband is a photographer and had a ball! The hotel was clean and well staffed. The breakfast in the morning was excellent, with a range of Japanese and Western foods, and a great place to plan the day ahead. The staff were polite and the service fantastic. We spent a morning walking around Shinjuku, visiting local temples and the older neighbourhoods, and then took a train a few stops to join a bike ride with Toyko Bicycle Tours we'd organised on the net before we left Australia. Getting to Tokyo station on our final day to catch the Shinkansen to Kyoto was easy after a quick stop off at the well positioned and signed information booth and the ticket office at the Shinjuku station. The only down side with the hotel was the internet connection, which was not very fast and only available in the lobby, however in all other respects we were really pleased and would recommend this hotel and the Shinjuku region highly.
The hotel was very clean, staff was friendly and breakfast great. Conveniently located near shinjuku station.

This was a very nice hotel in a great location. It was a bit expensive (what isn't in Tokyo) but still a very good value. The included breakfast was very good. The only problem was that the internet in the lobby did not work very well which was a problem considering that we really needed it for our smart phones (no data plan in Japan).

Love this hotel and the location. The price was very good and included a lot of amenities, including LAN cable, toiletries and excellent breakfast buffet, which included both Japanese and Western style breakfast. Love the location, near nightlife but very safe and so close to the station. The staff was very helpful with directions and questions and spoke English very well. The room was smaller but efficient and comfortable and it was so convenient to stores, restaurants and 7-11's, which was essential to staying in Tokyo. I have no hesitation in saying that my fiance and I will be staying there again, which will hopefully be in a few months! Plus, that hotel room was where he proposed, so I'm probably very biased :)

When we first read about Best Western Astina while we were looking for accommodation in Shinjuku, we were apprehensive of the hotel's location in the famed Kabukicho's entertainment area. Having stayed there, we were pleasantly surprised that the location was quite civil despite the entertainment outlets nearby and their predominantly African promoters milling at the outlets' entrances every night.We stayed in a Business Double room on a high floor which provides a panoramic view of Shinjuku's CBD in the distance.The room was good sized, comfortable, clean and well maintained. A dining table with 2 armchairs served us well for meals as well as working on our laptops. Inside the spacious bathroom, the bathtub and adjoining shower area were enclosed behind glass panels and a glass door. Water pressure was good. A fully automated WC and wash basin complete the bathroom features.As we stayed on the club floor, we enjoyed complimentary access to the executive lounge where we can use the expresso machine and a selection of coffee, tea or chocolate pods.Buffet breakfast was not extensive but adequate with the usual Western offering of ham, sausages, potatoes, etc; Asian offering of noddles, fried rice, etc; Japanese breakfast offering; and desserts. An egg station served the guest's choice of egg preparation.Two noteworthy facilities/services are the in-house coin operated laundry/drying service and the incentive voucher to opt out of a daily change of guestroom linen. The voucher is redeemable for gifts and souvenirs at the reception.A 24-hour minimart on the ground floor provided us with a daily supply of fresh fruits, drinks and snacks throughout our stay.Hotel staff were simply great, very pleasant, service-oriented and best of all, English conversant. They assisted us with our first use of expresso machine and coin operated laundry service. When we accidentally locked our padlock key inside our luggage, the front office came to our help immediately.Hotel is located within walking distance from Shinjuku Station, world renowned as the busiest train station in the world handling over 2 million people daily. Shopping? The nearby Yasukuni-dori and Shinjuku-dori with their large shopping malls, roadside shops and restaurants will keep any hardcore shopper and gourmet diner busy.We fully recommend BW Astina.

The Best Western Shinjuku is a good, clean and efficient hotel in Shinjuku. As you will read in other reviews, you will be accosted by Africans on your way to the hotel unless you access it by the very safe lane way behind the hotel. So do not walk down the street on which the hotel is located. Rather at the streets intersection with Yasakuni Dori, find the laneway and walk there. Access to the hotel is great, it is serviced by the world's busiest train station, Shinjuku! Staff are great, check-in was efficient and all information was provided. Below the hotel is a 24hour mini mart. The hotel rooms are small, but windows can be opened allowing fresh air. The bathrooms are equipped with bath, great shower and plenty of toiletries. The breakfast was not too bad, a mix of continental and Japanese fare. Coffee was filtered and good strength. No espresso coffee though.

It is my first time in Shinjuku and I knew the rooms are usually very small. I got no surprise by the room size. We are pleased as it is clean. We got normal treatment with two bottle of water. All complimentary tolietary are there which is generous in Tokyo. Breakfast is included which has reasonable range of choice, though not surprisely delicious. One shortcoming is the hotel only provide wifi, which is free, in the lobby, there is no wifi in room.Location is probably the main advantage, which is convenient. There is a charming bar district at the back of the hotel which worth a visit. also a Lawson convenient store downstairs is a plus to our stay,

We stayed here just the 1 night coming back from the countryside, but before flying out of Japan.The location was absolutely perfect - obviously there is so much going on in Shinjuku in terms of entertainment & places to eat & neon to be hypnotised by & shops to explore. Being a central hub, it was fairly easy to get anywhere else we wanted to go, including Narita airport (we took the bus rather than the train, simply because timings worked out better).But the best thing about the hotel is that it is right by Golden Gai. It's a tiny area of little alleyways, filled with ramshackle bars. It's something of a time-warp, back to maybe 1950. Many of the bars only hold 3-4 people & are a fantastic place to develop a sake hangover. Note - pick your bar carefully. While some are very welcoming & friendly, some were quite obviously keen to cater to regulars only.A couple practicalities:1 - We got lost coming from Shinjuku station, due to a slightly incorrect map (from Booking.com I think). Lots of narrow lanes & Japanese addresses aren't always the easiest to decipher. Make sure your map is correct.2 - Room size. We paid the little extra for a 'Business Floor' room. It was still very compact, but sufficient for 2 average adults who pack neatly. It had a nice view over Tokyo buildings.3 - Red Light District. It's seriously low key and aside from some illuminations, basically hidden. It's nothing like parts of South East Asia. Unless you're travelling with children & you don't want to explain some things to them - then it probably won't even register that it's there.4 - Go to Golden Gai.

Very close to the Shinjuku train line so you can easily get around on the JR lines. By day the business side of the neighbourhood is bustling with Tokyo's trendiest and come 6pm a lot of people appear from seemingly nowhere, quite cool to see. The night time brings out a seedier side with the red light district coming to life but don't discount the area because of this fact as safety never seemed an issue. The hotel has free wifi in the lobby, which drops out a lot but comes in handy when it isn't running at dial up speeds. The rooms are great but expectedly small for this part of the world. Not too shabby if elbow room isn't an issue. If they offer bigger rooms which we were never privy to seeing I'd say not a bad stay

Stayed here for a week. The relation between price and what you get is really good. Good location close to Shinjuku station, placed in the busy red light district but still quiet during night. I stayed with my family and we didnt notice or got offended by the character of the district. Behind the hotel is a very charming area with bars that only takes 3-5 guests per bar. Room is modern and clean. Great value for the buck.

Stayed there for 15 days ! The location is perfect, Very clean rooms, not too big but excellent for me and my husband ! The staff was really nice and friendly and kind enough to explain directions when needed. Toiletries available every day such as shampoo,conditioner,shower gel, razor toothbrush etc. I will visit again !

Stayed here for two nights. Hotel is located in a lively area of Tokyo with plenty of restaurants and coffee shops in general area. Rooms were fair sized (large by Japanese standards I think) and quite comfortable. Morning buffet was nice but get there early as seating can be a challenge if you sleep in. Hotel is a short walk from the Shinjuku train station.

Stayed here for 1 night an booked because of trip advisor reports.The location is ok although 2 taxi drivers outside the shinjuku station had no idea where it was. One eventually phoned the hotel for directions.
