Taxi was approx 5 pounds so worth it if you have luggage.The room was decent enough and there were plenty of toiletries available if you had forgot toothbrush, razor etc.Plenty of choice for breakfast so no real complaints there. I asked about the hotel bar but was told that it has been closed since the tsunami to save electricity. Found that strange but noticed hat half he light bulbs had been removed in the breakfast area so they are taking it seriously.Didn't particularly like the surrounding streets as I was constantly being pestered by the pimps. Tip, go out by the road on he back to avoid this. If you then turn right there is quite a lively but very small karaoke bar about 100 yards on the left.Probably would return if when I am next back in Tokyo.

We chose this hotel due to its good reviews and good prices and we have to say that we were pretty satisfied..although part of the reason for being satisfied is that we upgraded from the small double room which was more like a small big single but then 2 people can sleep on it to a much bigger twin room on the business floor for an extra 6000yen a nightThe bad...The bed.. i visited with a friend and it was terrible since the bed was so small we could barely sleep.. the breakfast was nothing special but was better than nothing.. you can though use your coupons at the lawson store below and buy your own breakfast on that day for 500yens worththe good...the location.. now im not saying the red light area is good but the bar scene behind the hotel.. or the golden gai was amazing.. we hit up more than 30 of these tiny bars and met people from all around the world had great times .. great drinks. great laughs. a walking distance from the subway but still in a great location for shopping eating and generally enjoyingnice bathrooms... very good quality fixtures and amenities

We had a very pleasant stay at the Astina. By looking in various websites we managed to get a good rate. The hotel is very well located just a 5 or 10 minute walk to shinjuku station which seemed to have a direct link to everywhere we wanted to go. The room was very clean and modern although small as you would expect in Tokyo. We found it perfectly adequate for what we needed a place to sleep and shower. If you were staying longer than a few days you might consider upgrading. The breakfast was good,they covered all the basics and had a few extra choice which we enjoyed. You can actually use your breakfast coupon towards there lunch buffet if you get up late which we also enjoyed. The convience mart downstairs was also great for cheap snacks and drinks.

I only stayed one night, but I was pleased with this hotel This is a clean, modern budget hotel with basic amenities. The room was compact but comfortable and efficiently furnished. There was a small TV with CNN, a small refrigerator, a room safe and a well-equipped bathroom. The breakfast buffet was ample, with Western and Asian choices, though not particularly memorable. There was wired Internet only (no wifi) in the room, but wifi was available in the lobby. As mentioned in other reviews, the area around the hotel is somewhat seedy but not offensive. In daytime, it is perfectly calm. In the evening, there are various undesirable elements around, but I never felt threatened or uncomfortable . On the plus side, this hotel is very convenient to the Shinjuku rail station and many shops, restaurants, etc. As a basic no-frills hotel for bed and breakfast, this is a good value and fine for a short stay. If I was going to stay for a longer period, I might consider something a bit more upscale.
user_name:
Carl K
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: 4 of us stayed at this hotel for 7 nights in the economy double room May 2012. From previous reviews we were not sure what to expect as had read things such as lack luster breakfast, red light district, small rooms, rude front desk etc etc etc. Let me assure you any reviewer who has said this is WRONG, obviously has too high expectations, and for the extremely affordable price I'm not sure what they expected. This hotel is PERFECT for any stay in Tokyo. Highlights:- 5 min or less walk to Shinjuku main station (which gives access to Narita Airport Express train, JR and Metro lines) and also 5 min or less walk to Shinjuku 3-Chome (Sanchome) Station. On the corner of the block our hotel is on there are stairs leading underground that say SUBNADE, you can go under here and walk through shops to get to the station - a good way to stay out of the rain-Area has several awesome shops, bars, restaurants that have good prices - don't be scared to try somewhere even if it's all in Japanese. Standing on street outside hotel if you look towards Shinjuku station on right side 2 doors down from Mister Donut there is a 270yen restaurant and bar where all meals and drinks (even cocktails) are 270yen plus tax and the food is delicious and beer always good. Awesome value for young travellers such as ourselves-Anyone who said breakfast isn't good...how often do you have 4 types of juices, 3 types of cereals, the best miso soup ever, several hot dishes including stir fried vegetables, curries, chicken, onion rings, eggs, delicious mackerel, several types of fruit, 10 different types of teas to choose from? My guess is never - the breakfast is awesome and a perfect start to the day - and what's best is hardly any hotels in Tokyo include it-Yes rooms are small...but in a city that has to accommodation 14 million+ people...most houses, apartments and hotel rooms are small. The rooms are modern, very clean, comfy bed and pillows, contain a desk and a small couch, and have air-conditioning (and this is the cheapest kind). The bathrooms are small but the shower is AWESOME good pressure unlike most hotels, clean, new, radical high tech toilet with heated seat, all amenities such as hair brush and dryer, tooth brush, exfoliating towel, shampoo, conditioner, body wash provided. We had NO problem in the room. The rooms do not have WiFi but the lobby does and if you're on holiday you shouldn't be on WiFi anyway you should be out exploring the amazing city that Tokyo is. There is also a computer for guests to use in the lobby free of charge, or if you have a laptop the room has LAN cable access. You can also hire a laptop for 1000 yen a day (Roughly $12 AUD). If you stay in rooms 405 or 406 WiFi will work, but signal very weak. Restaurant also has WiFi so you can eat your delicious feast breakfast and get your days facebooking in all at once.-Hotel is on the cusp of the red light district, Kabukicho. And by cusp I mean walk out of the hotel at night and there will be africans standing around touting. But why previous reviewers have let this bother them we have no idea. The touters came NO WHERE near us, once they see you are not a man who is alone, they leave you alone. So if you're staying here as a male alone, yes you will be approached at night, but it's nothing to cry about in a review you just say you're not interested and keep walking- they will follow you but if you keep saying no they will go away - no big deal. It's probably the safest red light district in the world. As an extremely paranoid young girl, I walked around at night alone and NEVER felt unsafe - the presence of Japanese people is high, and although there are japanese touters, they are super friendly and helpful if you approach them lost, just because they work for a strip bar does not make them shady people. If you're in a family or groups of mixed sex they will literally not even look at you and they only extend about 10 meters each way outside of hotel, the further you go towards Shinjuku station they disappear. You also NEVER see these people during day light hours.None of us could understand why other reviewers even mentioned it.-Front desk staff are AMAZING!!! They are so helpful, cute and polite. I don't know why other reviewers said they were rude...I think a lot of westerners confuse Japan's shyness/low english skills for rudeness. Of course they're not going to strike up a conversation in English if they're not confident, but if you ask them for help they are more than willing. I asked them to help me set up my tamagotchi (RADICAL Japanese toy) and all 3 of the desk staff helped...they always smiled when we entered the lobby and we cannot thank them enough - specially Yuko, who had email contact with us before our trip to book restaurants for us.-The whole 500 yen voucher if you don't get your room cleaned needs to be organised with reception before hand, you can't just put a do not disturb sign up (like we did) and expect a voucher. Bit disappointing but who cares.-Rooms are very sound proof, you can't hear neighbours or any noise from outside. You can only hear room next door if the occupants are screaming or singing REALLY loudly (as we often were after a few drinks) and even then sound is extremely muffled and can't make it out-There is a Lawson convenience store at the bottom of the hotel which is AMAZING, sells delicious snacks, salads, sushi etc for really cheap and ALCOHOL IS SO CHEAP!!!! 500ml beers are like $3!! 9% vodka drinks 120 yen!! AMAZING!IMPORTANT: from Shinjuku station the best exit to take is the CENTRAL EAST EXIT for Kabukicho. We walked, with our luggage, to the hotel, it was fine. Take a cab if you want - but it was totally fine to walk. Sidewalks are smooth.Japan, in my opinion, is one of the greatest, most interesting countries to visit on earth. The people are so kind, cute and helpful, and although many do not speak English they always do their best to help you. We went down to Kyoto and stayed in a hotel which left us yearning to get back to Tokyo, and The Best Western. The Best Western Astina Shinjuku is the perfect hotel to stay in: it's affordable, modern, new looking, clean, easily accessible and in a great area no matter what your point of travel is, business, holiday, partying, family visit. Surrounded by heaps of cheap, yum, awesome restaurants and bars, totally awesome clothing and other shops...Don't read any further reviews, book this hotel, you will not be disappointed.

We planned to stay in this hotel 7 nights, but ended switching hotels after only 2 nights.The rooms are really small. We stayed in a standard double and with 2 big suitcases and hardly had any room to move around. The bed is also small, not queen size. The TV only has one English channel, CNN and the pillows and the mattress are a little hard.The neighborhood is ok during the day, but not nice by night. The street is full of bars and stripclubs. You can even meet a couple of drag queens in the store downstairs. It is 10 minutes from Shinjuku station, but we had a hard time adjusting to the area.The staff is friendly and helpful and the breakfast is not bad.Resuming, if you are in a somewhat tight budget, don't mind sleeping near the stripclubs and don't have too much luggage, this hotel could suit you. If not, there are other options. We will not be staying here again.

So far my favourite place to stay in Shinjuku. Near shinjuku train station but at kabukicho area. So guys, please be prepared to be accosted by people when you walk back to to the hotel. I manage to find out that we can walk the dimly litted backlane where no one would ask you if you want a lady or not. Room is small but most hotels are small in Shinjuku. Even though the room is tiny, every single thing you need to make you comfortable can be found in the room. Loved the bathroom. Everything is so well organised. Breakfast is very good. Free wifi only works in the lobby area/ breakfast area & it's pretty weak. I would recommend this hotel for its location and amenities.

We stayed at the 14th floor (business floor). Room was small but comfortable.. only the pillows were a little "hard" for our standard... Location was superb, shinjuku station was just about 5-10mins walk away. We loved the breakfast buffet even though the menu seemed to be the same for the whole week we were there. Staffs were courteous and never ceased to assist us despite the communication barrier. The hotel provides free coffee/tea making facilities for those staying at business floor.

I stayed in this hotel with my husband and two other couples who travelled to Japan for the first time earlier this year. We decided to book after reading the reviews on TripAdvisor. We did find the hotel hard to locate at first from the train station, but it didn't take us too long to master the Japanese rail network and had no problems getting to and from the hotel after that initial confusion. The rooms were small but this really didn't bother us as they were very clean and well maintained. The hotel staff were very friendly and helped us on a number of occasions with any other queries we may of had. The convenience store downstairs is also very handy and great for picking up snacks. They also had some fruit and light meals which were good for a quick & easy breakfast. Shinjuku is a great location in Tokyo and there was lots to see and do right near the hotel. As we were a group of three couples there wasn't too much harassment from the strip club staff trying to get our husbands in the door. All in all at good place to stay at a reasonable price.

I was in Japan for a vacation and decided to venture up to Osaka for a few days. The Best Western provided the best rates for what I was looking for and I decided to go with it, normally I stay with Marriott, but the choices between a Courtyard and a Ritz Carlton, both of which were at least double what I spent at the Best Western made this a great choice. It was clean, though the lobby was very worn looking in places, and the amenities provided were beyond adequate. It was easy enough to get to the train station on foot and finding my way around wasn't that difficult when I had a decent map. I would absolutely consider staying in this Tokyo hotel again.

This is always my first choice when going to Tokyo. My next stay will probably be the 7th time. It’s certainly a level above most other Japanese business hotels in the same price range. Pros:- Excellent location in busy Shinjuku.- Clean and modern rooms – not the biggest ones, but perfectly fine.- Nice bathrooms (not like the cramped boxes in ordinary Japanese business hotels).- Quick and efficient check in and check out.- 24h Lawson convenience store by the entrance.Cons:- The Kabukocho-area can seem a bit shady at first, but it’s perfectly safe.- Rooms facing the main street can be noisy.The hotel can be a bit tricky to find the first time, and the streets of Shinjuku are often packed with people. However, the Subnade underpass gives access directly from the station to an exit about one block from the hotel. Don’t remember which exit no, but the hotel staff will surely be able to tell you.The service is excellent – they even let us store our large luggage during a 1 week trip to Kansai, since we stayed with them a last night before going back home.

Shinjuku Astina Hotel is solid and very good as always.I stayed at this property at least 5 times and I will come back of course.Just 5min from Shinjuku station its location is great. One might not like that it is at the beginning of the red light district and the number of foreign club hosts who try to drag you into one of their shady establishments is increasing but besides that there is not another location at this quality at this price.Rooms are clean and cosy, shower is efficient and doesnt look like the standard "box shower".Bed is comfortable. As for me price/quality is the best I have found in Tokyo in the mid-price segment.Service from Front Desk could be better and more friendly but keep in mind that this is not a luxury 5 stars resort.I prefer a rate without the breakfast buffet, save the JPY1'000 and invest it otherwise, the buffet at Stella although the variety is huge, it is just crap.

We had asked for a twin room but got a double so the bedroom area space was very tight.The bathroom, however, was great but it took up 1/3 of the room space! The shower was a delightful walk-in....lots of space!Breakfast, included in the room price for us, was wonderful. Lots of choice for both Western or Japanese style or a combination of both.The east side of Shinjuku is quite....interesting. Yes, after about 7:00pm all kinds of nightlife appears on the street but we were in no way encumbered by the activity. Hotel is a short 10-15 minute walk from Japan's national garden, which, during our stay had a wonderful display of cherry trees in blossom. The whole garden is worth a visit.

We stayed at the Best Western Shinjuku Astina for 7 nights. It was a really nice modern room. Size was small but expected for Japan. The room was very clean and the bathroom had a tub inside the shower room. There was also a mini fridge inside the room for us to use. We had broadband internet available in the room free of charge. Our breakfast was included in our room fees but they only changed the menu every other day and it just alternated the same menu. There is a convenience store right outside the hotel by the elevator and the walk to Shinjuku station was only about 8-10min walk away. All in all, a very comfortable and clean room.
